HEADLINE: The Pop Life

BYLINE: By Neil Strauss 

 BODY:

 
 
Mickey Hart's New Life
 "There really is life after the Grateful Dead," said Mickey Hart, who played percussion with the Dead from 1967 until its breakup last year after the death of Jerry Garcia. 
 "I've been in the Grateful Dead my whole life," he continued. "It's had its ups and downs, and it has taken almost all of my time. Now that the Grateful Dead isn't there, it opens up a whole other set of possibilities."
But the projects Mr. Hart is now involved with seem Deadlike. This afternoon at Liberty State Park in Jersey City, his group, Mickey Hart's Mystery Box, is to appear at the Furthur Festival, which includes Ratdog (led by another former Dead member, Bob Weir), Bruce Hornsby, Los Lobos and Hot Tuna. For an encore, members of these bands plan to indulge in a jam session; past shows have featured renditions of such Dead staples as "Truckin' " and "Fire on the Mountain."
"This festival is gaining its own consciousness," the 46-year-old Mr. Hart said during a telephone interview from a tour stop in Indiana. "The musicians are meeting in buses and working stuff out and trying to make the show better. In the Grateful Dead world, we were kept from interacting like this on tour because of the pressures of being the Grateful Dead. This is very refreshing to me and Bob. It's easier. My only gripe is that we don't play long enough."
The music of Mr. Hart's new band is quite different from the American-roots musical journeys of the Grateful Dead. The product of four years of precision work (he spent two and a half weeks just preparing a piano with small percussive objects for the album's tribute to John Cage), "Mickey Hart's Mystery Box" (Rykodisc) offers a mix of world percussion and soulful pop vocals. Nonetheless, Mystery Box also retains strong connections with Mr. Hart's past, mainly because the former Dead lyricist Robert Hunter wrote the words.
The emotional centerpiece of the album is "Down the Road," in which Mr. Hart, who has rarely recorded his voice, gently speaks, over the soulful cooing of the Mint Juleps, about a strange sound he hears coming from the sky. "It sounded like Garcia, but I couldn't see the face," he intones. "Just the beard and the glasses and a smile in empty space."
Though Mr. Hart seems happy for the opportunity to move into the next phase of his life, he says that not a day goes by when he doesn't think of Jerry Garcia. "This morning I was looking at NBC," he said. "My eyes are not like they used to be, and the sunny weather symbol over Florida, it had glasses on and it looked just like him. I said, 'There's Jerry over Florida.' "
Next week, Mr. Hart's music is to be performed at a place where Deadheads will be a minority: he will be in Atlanta for the opening ceremonies of the Olympic Games, for which he composed the call to nations. "Much of the percussion of the world I tried to put out there on that field," he said. "But I refrained from using the military: I don't want the world to march. I want the world to dance."
 
Days of Music
 The second annual testament to the madness and ambition of New York club owners begins next week: from Sunday to Saturday (July 14 to 20), 450 bands have been booked in 17 clubs in Manhattan and one in Hoboken, N.J. Unlike its predecessor, the New Music Seminar, this Macintosh New York Music Festival is not just for the music industry. It is also offering $50 passes -- 3,000 of them -- that allow bearers access to all these concerts as well as to a three-day symposium on the Internet and its applications to music.
There will also be related concerts at more than a dozen clubs around the world, most of which will be broadcast live on the Internet. At 7 on Wednesday morning, for example, anyone with a good alarm clock and enough computer power can watch the Dynamite Masters of Blues Quartet, a noisy Japanese guitar band that has never performed in the United States, perform at the Club Milk in Tokyo. "I can foresee a day when other countries start thinking of the festival as a showcase to the world," said Michael Dorf, the owner of the Knitting Factory, who organized the festival with Andrew Rasiej, an owner of Irving Plaza.
Despite Mr. Dorf's global ambitions, one of the most important events taking place at the festival is strictly a local one. On Monday at 4 P.M. at the Bottom Line, club owners, clubgoers, politicians, law enforcers and community board members are getting together for a public Quality of Nightlife Forum to discuss the future of clubs and bars in Manhattan.
David Hershkovits, the publisher of Paper magazine, who organized the conference along with several club owners, said that between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's quality of life campaign, the increasing power of community boards over the approval of liquor and cabaret licenses and stepped-up scrutiny by law-enforcement officials, it is more difficult than ever to open a club or bar safely and keep it open profitably. In addition, Peter Gatien's recent indictment for conspiracy to sell the drug Ecstasy at two of the clubs he owns, Limelight and Tunnel, has saddled clubs with the worst reputation they have had in years.
The conference has set goals: to form an alliance of clubs and bars; to convince the city and community boards that clubs are an economic and cultural boon; to teach clubgoers the importance of behaving responsibly and respectfully, especially outside these places, and to ask the city to cooperate by making public kiosks available for promotional posters. (Most flyers posted on lampposts and buildings are illegal.)
Mr. Gatien is to appear at the forum along with Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan borough president; members of every community board below 57th Street; representatives of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, and employees and owners of the Spy Bar, Don Hill's, Wetlands, Irving Plaza, Sound Factory and more than a dozen other nighttime haunts.
 
Soundlab's PartyUnder a Bridge
 For those who have found the floating art, technology and experimental dance music party called Soundlab too crowded or too hard to find, it is holding a blowout with four sound systems and some of Manhattan's most innovative disk jockeys (Spooky, Olive, the Bedouin and Soulslinger) on Friday night at the Anchorage, under the Brooklyn Bridge, from 10 P.M. to 6 A.M.
For those who have never heard of Soundlab, this group of multimedia artists, technology whizzes, writers, musicians and disk jockeys involved with it may be the most innovative and important underground cultural collective working in Manhattan. At previous Soundlab parties, musicians known for their work in the avant-garde in the 1970's learned to accept the disk jockey as an equal in improvisation while music fans learned that sound can't always be separated from visual and spatial stimuli. For information: (212) 726-1724.

HEADLINE: FINANCE BRIEFS

 BODY:

Debt
 
CIT Group Holdings Inc., Livingston, N.J., is selling $200 million of medium-term notes due in 1998 through CS First Boston. The notes are priced at 99.841 to yield 6.586 percent. The noncallable issue is rated Aa3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc., A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corp. and AA- by Duff & Phelps Credit.
 
Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $100 million of bonds due in 1997 through Dean Witter and Aubrey G. Lanston & Co. Callable quarterly beginning Oct. 23, the bonds are priced at par to yield 6.215 percent. 

Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., known as Freddie Mac, is selling $60 million of debentures due in 2001 through Lehman Brothers. Callable in one year, the issue is priced at par to yield 7.5 percent.

Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is selling $100 million of medium-term notes due in 2001 through First Tennessee Bank. Callable beginning July 17, 1998, the notes are priced at par to yield 7.25 percent.

Federal National Mortgage Association is selling $50 million of medium-term notes due in 2011 through Smith Barney. Callable in three years, the issue is priced at par to yield 8.15 percent.

Common Stock
 
Mitek Systems Inc., San Diego, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 4.07 million shares. Cruttenden Roth will be the lead underwriter.

Technology Modeling Associates Inc., Sunnyvale, Calif., filed to sell 3 million shares in an initial public offering. Hambrecht & Quist will be the lead underwriter.

HEADLINE: Pollution Backsliding in New Jersey

 BODY:
The people who live in New Jersey care about the environment. They have voted for some of the toughest pollution controls in the country. Their Congressional delegation, including many Republicans, has honorably resisted the G.O.P.'s yearlong effort to dismantle the nation's basic environmental laws. There is no mystery to this. New Jersey is a densely populated state with an economy dominated by petrochemical complexes and other heavy polluters. It has more Superfund sites than any other state, and 85 percent of its waterways remain unfishable and unswimmable.
For obvious reasons, New Jersey residents do not want to move backward. But, environmentalists complain, the state's Governor, Christine Todd Whitman, does. In keeping with her campaign pledge to make New Jersey more "business friendly," Mrs. Whitman has proposed changes in the state laws governing water quality and waste disposal that, her critics say, would erase 25 years of slow but steady progress. 
 As detailed in a recent account by Jennifer Preston of The Times, the new rules would allow private industry and municipal waste treatment plants to discharge more toxic substances into state waterways than they can under current law. Maximum fines and penalties would be reduced.
Meanwhile, in her budget for the next fiscal year, Mrs. Whitman has ordered major staff reductions at the state's Department of Environmental Protection, including lawyers who prosecute violations and scientists who monitor air and water quality. This angered even some Republicans in Trenton, and last week legislators voted to restore $7 million of Mrs. Whitman's proposed $17.2 million cut. Mrs. Whitman, unrepentant, said she would not use the money to prevent layoffs.
The Governor makes no apologies for her basic strategy. She says the old-fashioned command-and-control approach to environmental regulation requires industry to obtain dozens of individual permits to stay in business, encourages endless litigation and drives prospective employers away. Instead of closely regulating what comes out of every sewer line and smokestack, Mrs. Whitman prefers a more flexible system in which all the "stakeholders" -- government, industry and environmentalists -- sit down together and establish general goals. Regulators would monitor the end results but not oversee every step of the process.
On water pollution, her plan is to move away from monitoring individual discharges to what she calls a comprehensive "watershed approach," managing not only industrial and municipal discharges but all sources of pollution, including runoffs from farms and lawns.
 In theory, there is nothing wrong with Mrs. Whitman's strategy. Indeed, Carol Browner, administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, as well as other state governors, have been looking for ways to replace the old system of regulatory micromanagement with broader, more cooperative approaches.
In practice, however, there is one serious flaw in Mrs. Whitman's plan. It is not even close to becoming a reality. Except for one working group, which has met infrequently, there is no machinery in place that would enable business, environmentalists and regulators to set common goals. There are no "watershed" programs, even on paper. The idea of resolving disputes through mediation instead of the courts is in its infancy.
Until Mrs. Whitman can add real substance to her ideas, it would be sheer folly to weaken existing regulations and cripple the agencies that enforce them.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Pressured by Fears That Strength Hurts Exporters

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly lower yesterday, pressured for a second day by fears among big United States exporters about the currency's strength and by a growing conviction that Germany was unlikely to lower interest rates soon.
In late trading yesterday in New York, the dollar stood at 110.30 Japanese yen, unchanged from Tuesday. The dollar traded at 1.5250 German marks, down from 1.5263 marks. The British pound rose to $1.5525 from $1.5490. 
 The dollar continued to be weighed down by concerns expressed by big American exporters that the currency's recent strength against the yen is hurting them by making their products cost more in Japan. The dollar touched 111.16 yen Monday, its highest level in nearly two and a half years.
Donald V. Fites, the chairman and chief executive of Caterpillar Inc. told a business meeting in Japan on Tuesday that the current level of the dollar against the yen could erase the recent signs of improvement in the trade imbalance between the United States and Japan.
Yesterday, Mr. Fites released a survey of American executives showing they would like to see the dollar trade between 90 yen and 100 yen. And Albert M. Chambers, a senior official at the Ford Motor Company, said that the current exchange rate was hurting American auto makers in Japan and that the United States Government knew it.
"The dollar has been moving off of what U.S. corporate leaders are saying," said Lizbeth Goldberg, an assistant vice president at the New York branch of Hypo Bank.
Other analysts, however, said the statements by the executives were merely justifications to sell the dollar and lock in its recent gains. They said the dollar was more vulnerable to weakness if United States or Japanese monetary officials expressed similar concerns.
"Someone like Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan has a lot more pull than some guy who wants to sell more tractors," said Tad Haley, a trader at the New York branch of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd.
Further pressuring the dollar was sentiment that Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, would choose to keep interest rates unchanged at its regular policy-making council meeting today.

HEADLINE: Japanese Trade Practices on Trial

 BODY:
The United States and Japan meet today in Geneva to begin a process of resolving their latest trade dispute without the destructive bombast that has marked their previous disagreements. The Clinton Administration properly decided to take its unfair trade practices case against Fuji Photo Film and the Japanese Government to the World Trade Organization rather than imposing sanctions. American sanctions would violate international trade rules and make Washington's bullying tactics the issue rather than Japan's suspicious trade activities.
The Eastman Kodak Company, with considerable supporting evidence, says that the Japanese Government conspired with Fuji to block Kodak's access to the Japanese film market. The conspiracy began, Kodak says, in the late 1960's after Japan agreed under pressure from its allies to open up its economy to foreign investment. But as Kodak documents show, the Japanese Government rigged rules so that the likes of Kodak would be shut out. 
 Kodak offers a bill of particulars to support its claim. The company asserts that the Japanese Government helped build a distribution system for film that excluded Kodak, and that Japanese rules prevented Kodak from investing in Japanese enterprises, blocking an easy way to break into a foreign market. Laws prohibiting large retail outlets denied Kodak access to stores with enough shelf space to carry foreign brands. Finally, Kodak could not easily undersell Fuji because Government officials helped Japanese companies fix retail prices.
Fuji disputes Kodak's evidence point by point, charging that marketing incompetence, not Japanese conspiracy, limited Kodak's market share. Fuji also contends that Kodak has shut it out of markets in the United States -- a charge that was undermined this week when Fuji announced that it had outbid Kodak to buy the photo finishing plants of Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer, and to provide Wal-Mart with photo finishing supplies.
The W.T.O. was created to sort out trade disputes. The antitrust violations at the heart of the Kodak case do not fit comfortably within the W.T.O.'s jurisdiction. But the United States can make the compelling argument that Japanese behavior over three decades effectively nullified its promise to lower tariffs and other trade barriers. The Administration can further argue that Japanese rules favor domestic companies, which is a clear violation of W.T.O. standards.
The Kodak case asks the W.T.O., in effect, to pass judgment on the way Japan does business. That may be a stretch for the fledgling organization, but resolving tricky disputes in an impartial manner was precisely why more than 100 countries created it. The United States will now put the W.T.O. to its first important test.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
China Shuns U.S. Partners for 100-Seat Jet

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: PARIS, July 10

 BODY:
China's main manufacturer of civil aircraft announced today that it would team up with European and Singaporean partners to build a planned 100-seat commercial jet, dealing a blow to the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
"The partners have reached consensus to research and manufacture the 100-seat aircraft," said Li Jianduo, spokesman for the manufacturer, Aviation Industries of China. 
 The partnership announced today represents a significant step forward in China's effort to become a key competitor for the potentially huge business in Asian aircraft orders. Talks with South Korea on an alliance to develop a passenger plane for the Asian market broke down last month.
The long-awaited decision is regarded as a boon to the European partners -- British Aerospace P.L.C., Aerospatiale of France and Alenia of Italy. The project will give them greater access to the Chinese and Southeast Asian markets, where air traffic is expected to grow most quickly. Singapore Technologies will be the other partner in the project.
European and American jet makers had competed for two years to join China in building the 100-seater.
"In the long term, it's a big deal for the Europeans and for Airbus," said Wiener Barnaby, an analyst with Credit Lyonnais Securities, referring to Airbus Industrie, the European consortium owned by Aerospatiale and British Aerospace in partnership with Deutsche Aerospace and Construcciones Aeronauticas of Spain.
For Boeing and McDonnell Douglas, the Chinese decision represents a setback as they try to expand in Asia.
"Boeing is disappointed," said Zheng Ling, a spokesman for the American company in Beijing. "Right now, we are evaluating the market, and we haven't decided to go ahead with production of a 100-seat aircraft." Boeing does not now make a passenger jet that small.
Last month, Boeing officials conceded that they had lost the race to join China in building the planes. In April, Aerospatiale, a French state company, signed a preliminary agreement with China.
Don Hanson, spokesman for the Douglas Aircraft division of McDonnell Douglas, told The Associated Press that the company did not enter into serious negotiations with China for a 100-seat jet.
The Chinese project has been estimated at $2.5 billion. While the details of the partnership were not disclosed, The South China Morning Post of Hong Kong reported today that the Chinese company would hold a 45 percent stake, the European partners, 40 percent, and the Singapore company, 15 percent.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	Airline Suspends Orders
LONDON, July 10 (Reuters) -- British Airways, which is in talks with its pilots to avert a threatened strike, said today that it had suspended aircraft orders. "The board decided to defer all aircraft investment decisions until the financial consequences of the dispute could be assessed," a spokeswoman said.
British Airways has about $10 billion worth of orders with Boeing and has informed that company of its decision, she said. The airline has 44 planes on order with Boeing and options for 24 more.
Talks between British Airways and the pilots' union continued today in an effort to resolve a pay dispute that led to last week's vote authorizing a strike on July 16.
In New York, shares of Boeing fell 12.5 cents today, closing at $90.25.

HEADLINE: Hartford to Seek Voluntary Desegregation

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

 BODY:
Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut said yesterday that he wanted to use voluntary measures to remedy the segregation in Hartford schools that the state's high court ruled unconstitutional, such as letting urban parents choose to send their children to suburban schools.
"The real solution to better schools is still, in my opinion, more discipline, more parental involvement, and school choice responds to a lot of those issues," Mr. Rowland said while discussing the decision on a WTIC radio talk show. 
 Connecticut's Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that racial segregation in Hartford's public schools deprived students of the equal educational opportunities guaranteed by the state Constitution, and it asked the state's General Assembly to find a way to desegregate Hartford's schools. But it offered no remedies itself.
In the wake of the ruling, many politicians agreed with the Governor that voluntary measures were preferred, and that achieving desegregation by assigning students to travel between city and suburbs was unacceptable. Whites make up less than 5 percent of Hartford's public school enrollment.
The already daunting challenge of desegregating Hartford's schools is complicated by the changing demographics of suburbia. Just as whites began leaving Hartford for the suburbs after World War II in a voluntary movement that led to segregated city schools, a wave of minority families have been leaving Hartford for its suburbs since the late 1980's.
In the seven years since the desegregation lawsuit known as Sheff v. O'Neill was filed, so many minority families have moved to the older suburbs bordering Hartford that their schools are now confronting racial-balance issues of their own. In East Hartford, for example, the percentage of minority students rose to 49.3 percent in 1995, from 23.1 percent in 1989. In West Hartford, the proportion rose to 22.7 percent, from 12.1 percent.
The implications of this latest population shift can be seen in the problems besetting Project Concern, a 30-year-old voluntary integration program between Hartford and its suburbs that is often mentioned as the obvious model for quickly responding to the court order.
Since 1966, the nationally heralded program has enabled 6,000 black children from Hartford to attend suburban schools; at its high point in 1978, 1,175 children were voluntarily bused to 13 suburban districts, some of them among the most highly regarded in the nation.
But when school resumes at the end of summer, fewer than 500 children will be enrolled. The decline, said the program's administrator, Mary Carroll, is due to problems that would be difficult to overcome even if the Legislature seized on Project Concern as a solution.
The greatest problem, Ms. Carroll said, is that suburban districts are running out of classroom seats as their enrollments surge while the city's falls, leaving no room for new Project Concern students. The movement of minority families from the city to suburban towns, made possible by declining rents throughout the economically stressed region, has also diminished the appeal of an integration program for those towns.
West Hartford, for example, once had more than 350 Project Concern students, but as it has struggled with crowding and racial balance in its own schools, the number has fallen to 80 as the town accepts only half a dozen new students each year. Manchester, where the minority enrollment has more than doubled since 1989, had 98 students as recently as 1992 but no longer takes new ones.
And as families that can afford to leave Hartford do so, the increasing poverty of those who remain means fewer Hartford children qualify for Project Concern, Ms. Carroll said. Many children have social or developmental problems that disqualify them, or lack the strong family support needed to commute to a distant school, she said.
A decline in financing has left the program itself less able to help; once it employed 56 paraprofessionals to work with the children in suburban schools, but now it has 7.
"The city is spiraling down and we're trying to draw from that population without any support for them," Ms. Carroll said.
The biggest minority group in Hartford schools -- Hispanic children, 49.9 percent of the enrollment -- is largely excluded from Project Concern. Historically, the program has been aimed at blacks, the dominant minority group in the 60's. In addition, suburban schools don't have bilingual programs and so do not accept children who aren't fluent in English, she said.
"We can't expand without the support services, and we can't do it without opening it to the Hispanic community," she said.
Yesterday the Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, was still studying the court ruling before deciding whether to ask the Supreme Court to reconsider it. "We believe the court would be very unlikely to grant a motion to reconsider," he said.
The decision cannot be appealed to the United States Supreme Court because the suit was based on Connecticut's constitution and was tried in state courts.
After speaking on several radio shows, Mr. Blumenthal said, "People are reacting very reasonably and positively, and that fact is reassuring."
The Connecticut Education Commissioner, Theodore S. Sergi, said: "I think there's general agreement that nothing the court said really has an effect on school in Connecticut in September. There shouldn't be any sense out there of confusion or concern about that."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Poland Joining O.E.C.D., A Step Further Into Europe

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WARSAW, July 10

 BODY:
In a major psychological boost for its increasingly healthy economy, Poland is set to join one of the world's premier capitalist clubs, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
At a ceremony on Thursday in Paris, the Poles are expected to sign an agreement to join the O.E.C.D., a group of 25 relatively wealthy nations that acts as a meeting place and research center for the industrial world. 
 Poland, with a population of about 40 million and a fast-growing economy, will be the third formerly Communist country to become part of the O.E.C.D., following the Czech Republic and Hungary.
Membership confers a stamp of approval on Poland's free-market reforms, which resulted in 7 percent growth last year, the most robust in Europe. Growth is expected to slip to about 5 percent this year and pick up slightly in 1997.
Poland was the first country in Eastern Europe to recover from the severe slump in growth after the fall of Communism in 1989, according to the research unit of Deutsche Bank, which added that private business there now generated about 60 percent of the gross domestic product.
In April, Standard & Poor's, citing Poland's economic growth and improved balance of payments, raised Poland's credit rating to BBB-, an investment grade, from BB.
In another sign of confidence in the Polish economy, European and Asian investors snapped up a $164.4 million Eurobond issue by Poland on Tuesday. Deutsche Morgan Grenfell and CS First Boston jointly led the deal, Poland's second such issue.
To become an O.E.C.D. member, Poland had to meet the organization's principal policies, which required considerable legislative changes. Many of these changes, ranging from freeing the movement of capital to lifting quotas on foreign audiovisual material, have been seen here as a trial run for what Poland hopes will be its eventual membership in the European Union.
"We feel pretty good about the steps Poland has taken," said David Aaron, the American representative to the O.E.C.D. in Paris. "They have accepted basic things that are important to us."
Mr. Aaron said Poland had gone further than some current European Union members to meet some of the requirements.
But not all the changes, which were opposed by some political factions in the coalition Government of former Communists and the Peasants' Party, were as sweeping as some foreign investors in Poland would have liked.
Under procedures introduced to comply with the O.E.C.D. policies, a foreigner can now buy an apartment and as much as 4,000 square meters of urban land without a special permit. Mr. Aaron said the Polish Government had pledged to put foreign investors who wanted to acquire larger parcels of land on a fast track for a permit.
But American lawyers working with foreign investors in Warsaw, said the easing of restrictions on real estate ownership was not enough. Under European Union regulations, a foreign company can purchase real estate without any permit.
In banking matters, the Polish central bank now gives licenses for foreign bank branches only to those ready to invest in troubled Polish banks. The Warsaw Government won a concession from the O.E.C.D. that would allow its banking industry time to improve before allowing the unrestricted opening of foreign bank branches. That will be delayed until the end of 1998.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The S.E.C. says it happened: a corner in the Treasury market.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
CORNER the Treasury market?
It sounds impossible, but Federal regulators said yesterday that it was done three years ago by Fenchurch Capital Management, a Chicago company that runs two commodity funds. 
 Fenchurch, without admitting or denying anything, agreed to pay a $600,000 fine to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, and Fenchurch's president, Marcus A. Hutchins, agreed to pay a $200,000 fine levied by the Chicago Board of Trade. Fenchurch also consented to a Federal court injunction sought by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
In a corner, an investor gets control of so much of a specific security that others cannot obtain it, or at least cannot do so without paying an outrageous price.
The C.F.T.C. said that in June 1993, when that month's futures contract for 10-year Treasury notes was expiring, Fenchurch cornered the market in a key Treasury note. The result was that its pools made a lot of money while traders on the other side lost a lot.
"Manipulation of this sort can and did affect improperly the value of the bargain struck before trading had expired," said Geoffrey Aronow, the C.F.T.C.'s director of enforcement. He added that the enforcement action, taken in concert with the S.E.C. and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, would "let market participants know that we will act to insure the markets remain free of illegitimate forces."
The futures market in 10-year Treasury notes is a large one, although not as large as in some other contracts. A buyer of a futures contract is betting that interest rates on such notes will decline, while a seller is betting they will rise. Most traders in futures contracts close out their position before the contracts expire.
But if the contracts are not liquidated, the sellers of each contract must deliver actual Treasury notes to the owners of the futures contracts.
The Board of Trade, where the contracts trade, has a list of what Treasury notes can be delivered to satisfy each month's futures contract. Brokers routinely keep track of which Treasury note would be the cheapest to buy to satisfy a contract.
As the June 1993 contract was expiring, Fenchurch held 12,700 contracts -- covering $1.27 billion of notes -- and it wanted delivery of Treasury notes. The cheapest to deliver was the note maturing in February 2000, with a coupon of 8.5 percent. (Don't ask why a note with less than seven years to maturity can satisfy a contract for 10-year notes. That is just one of the mysteries of the financial futures market.)
Those who had sold contracts, and were required to deliver notes, began to scramble to find the February 2000 notes, seeking to either buy or borrow them. But there were few to be found. As a result, many had to buy the next-cheapest note, an 8.875 percent note that matured in May 2000.
By the C.F.T.C. account, getting that note cost an extra 5/32 on the price of a bond, or 15.6 cents for $100 face value. Fifteen cents is not enough to make a phone call, but that translates into $156.25 a contract. And Fenchurch ended up getting the better Treasury notes to satisfy 4,800 of its contracts. That calculates to an advantage for Fenchurch of $750,000.
Was Fenchurch just lucky? Not the way the regulators see it. While the February 2000 note was originally issued in a volume of $10.7 billion, a lot of the notes had been cut up by Wall Street to produce zero-coupon securities, and others were tied up in accounts that did not trade them.
As the June contract expired, Fenchurch controlled $1.4 billion of that issue. In the next few days, it bought or borrowed enough of them to put its position over $2 billion.
The C.F.T.C. noted that during that period Fenchurch was borrowing money and paying the normal interest rate on transactions secured by Treasury securities. But so desperate were the sellers of the contracts to get their hands on the February 2000 issue that they were willing to lend money at negative rates -- that is, pay someone to borrow -- if the borrower would post as collateral that issue. But Fenchurch chose not to take them up on that offer.
Fenchurch issued a statement that emphasized the settlement would not affect the funds it managed, and added that "we decided it was in our best interest and the best interests of our investors to settle this matter so we could move on." For the next two years, the C.F.T.C. will get detailed reports of Fenchurch's trading.
While there has been talk of cornering newly issued Treasury securities -- that was the foundation of the Salomon Brothers scandal five years ago, although no corner was proved -- this is the first time anyone has been charged with actually cornering an issue, even for a brief time. With players able to borrow billions for speculation, it appears that even the largest securities market in the world -- Treasury securities -- is vulnerable to manipulation.

HEADLINE: Punish Employers, Not Children

BYLINE: By George J. Borjas; George J. Borjas is a professor of public policy at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Four million illegal aliens reside in the United States, and their number grows by 300,000 every year. This is on top of the three million granted amnesty in the late 1980's.
The costs of illegal immigration in both economic and social disarray are high. That is why California voters backed Proposition 187, which denies many social benefits to illegal aliens -- including public education. 
 Now Congress has joined the fray. The House recently passed the Gallegly amendment, which would give states the right to bar illegal aliens from public schools; the measure faces a tougher time in the Senate.
Such a ban on schooling probably would prompt some people to think twice before crossing the border illegally. After all, we know that illegal immigration from Mexico responds to the price of tomatoes in the United States: there are more Border Patrol apprehensions when the price is high and farms pay more to harvest the crops. If aliens respond to the price of tomatoes, they may well respond to the cut in education benefits.
Still, is this an effective way of stopping the illegal flow? Imagine the emotional outrage when the evening news begins with a scene of two burly Border Patrol officers preventing a sobbing 7-year-old from entering a public school. This image alone, and the shameful history it evokes, suggests that this policy is not a serious attempt to curtail the illegal alien flow, for it is unlikely ever to be enforced.
The policy also fails to address the real underpinning of the illegal immigration problem: the wage gap between the United States and Mexico -- the largest between any two contiguous countries. The incentives for Mexicans to migrate are enormous. And American employers benefit from the entry of illegal aliens; a vast pool of workers keeps wages down.
So both illegal aliens and their employers want to see the tide continue. Few are penalized for breaking the law. When an illegal alien is caught, the Border Patrol sends the person back across the border; typically, the migrant tries again. Once people make it to the United States, they can easily buy fake documents and be hired by an employer who will do no more than give the papers a cursory inspection.
Illegal aliens go to emergency rooms, send their children to public schools, apply for welfare, get driver's licenses. They have frequent contact with government agencies. Yet nobody is held accountable for this large-scale law-breaking.
We need deterrence, but barring illegal aliens from our public schools is not an effective way of stopping illegal immigration. For one thing, it would have no effect on the migration of single people and childless couples. In addition, many children who live in undocumented households were born in the United States and are American citizens courtesy of the 14th Amendment, so they are automatically entitled to public education.
We could deter many more illegal aliens if we imposed substantial penalties on the employers who hire them. These companies -- agricultural enterprises, sweatshops -- get the bulk of the gains from illegal immigration but bear few of the costs.
What would happen to the demand for undocumented workers if we billed the owners of the fields where the migrants toil, and the families who hire illegal domestic help, for the expenses incurred by public schools and Medicaid?
Finally, any serious proposal must offer a way of establishing who is an illegal alien. Regardless of where we choose to catch them -- the school or the workplace -- we need to be able to tell them apart from legal immigrants.
We have yet to grapple with this troublesome detail, which raises the specter of a national identification system. But we cannot tackle the problem of illegal immigration as long as we skirt this issue.
We do need to discourage illegal aliens from entering the country, and encourage those already here to leave. Barring them from public schools, however, is more symbol than substance.
The fact that it has become the centerpiece of the current debate implies that Congress is not yet serious about stopping the tide of illegal immigrants.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Rise Again; Fed Rate Action Is Doubted

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended higher yesterday for a second consecutive day, bolstered by speculation that the Federal Reserve was unlikely to raise interest rates in the next few weeks.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 17/32, to 86 22/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 7.08 percent, from 7.13 percent on Tuesday. 
 With little economic data available to give direction, the market focused its attention on an article in The Wall Street Journal yesterday about a new Federal Reserve study. The study, according to The Journal, discusses a new approach to monetary policy, arguing that when inflation is relatively low, as is the case now, policy makers should refrain from taking action.
The study reflects the thinking of several top Fed policy makers, although the theory -- called "opportunistic disinflation" -- does not represent current Fed policy, The Journal said.
Some market participants interpreted the news of the study to mean that the Fed was not in any rush to raise interest rates, as had been expected following Friday's surprisingly strong employment report.
If the Fed were to adopt such a policy, said Jack Ablin, director of fixed income and senior fund manager at the Private Bank at Bank of Boston, "it puts a rate increase on hold and that means the Fed will rely on the market to slow the economy down."
Bond prices bounced higher in the afternoon after a speech by Thomas M. Hoenig, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, comforted the market. Addressing executives and bankers in Montrose, Colo., Mr. Hoenig did not say anything new about Federal Reserve policy, but bonds traded higher on relief, said Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston.
The market is expecting the Fed to raise the Federal funds rate, the lending rate between banks for overnight loans, to 6 percent from 5.25 percent.
"If you look at where the market is today, it is in the center of a range that has been traveled over the past two years," he said.
"There is no staying power, because it has been a difficult market to trade all year, choppy and with little participation, and the monthly jobs data determining the top and bottom.
"Most market participants may be right about where the market is headed, but because the trading is so choppy, it is difficult to stay in the game without getting stopped."
Larry M. Berman, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data of Boston, was more optimistic.
"The technicals have aligned bullishly," he said, "and we cannot rule out a test of resistance in the 6.90 percent yield range again."
In the Treasury futures market, the September 30-year bond contract finished 2/32 off the session high of 107 18/32. It closed up at 107 16/32.
Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst with Thomson Research of Boston, said the rally was likely to meet resistance at 107 23/32 to 108.
"The first approach into the region was met with enough selling to lay it sideways," she said.
"But what is noteworthy about the horizontal price action is that it was lacking the consensus of a fair price, and this tells us there is possibility for another strong run-up today," she added.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Big, Bold, Outside: Billboards Back in Fashion

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
All of a sudden, it seems, outdoor advertising is growing again to be as big as -- well, all outdoors.
For decades, outdoor billboards, signs and posters, once a vibrant and integral part of the American consumer economy, have been perceived as dull and dowdy offspring among the family of media. Television is glamorous, radio is intimate, magazines are slick, newspapers are immediate and outdoor is, at best, plain-spoken ("Eat here. Get gas.") and visible (a polite way of saying in-your-face). 
 Worse yet, outdoor advertising became embroiled in disputes over issues such as its dependence on revenue from marketers of alcoholic beverages and cigarettes, the clustering of signs for products like fortified wines and malt liquor in inner-city neighborhoods and the eye pollution caused by signs that obscured landmarks and scenic attractions.
It was all a far cry from the days when brands like Campbell's soup, Coca-Cola and Wrigley's gum were built on bold, bright images plastered on billboards along the nation's highways and so-called spectaculars in Times Square -- giant, extravagant neon signs with smoke rings and waterfalls -- came to symbolize the wonderful cacophony of New York City.
But now outdoor advertising appears to be enjoying a renaissance, reconstituted as part of a category known as out-of-home media, which also includes transit advertising and sales pitches at nontraditional sites like airports and shopping malls.
The industry's revenue last year rose 8.2 percent from 1994, according to the Outdoor Advertising Association of America, a trade organization. That represented the largest one-year gain in more than a decade -- and it outpaced the growth of most other media.
The revival has attracted the attention of Wall Street as well as Madison Avenue.
In recent months, a spate of acquisitions has served to consolidate what is still a fairly fragmented industry. The most recent came late Tuesday, when Outdoor Systems Inc., a small company that completed an initial public offering of its stock only three months ago, agreed to buy the largest outdoor advertising concern in North America, the Gannett Outdoor unit of the Gannett Company.
The deal delighted investors, who pushed Outdoor Systems' shares up 32.8 percent to a close of $48.125 in trading on Nasdaq, a gain of $11.875. Gannett's shares closed at $70, up 50 cents, in New York Stock Exchange trading.
"I don't know of another time in our industry when there's been such momentum and energy carrying us forward," Nancy J. Fletcher, president and chief executive of the Outdoor Advertising Association, said yesterday in a telephone interview from Washington.
Though outdoor advertising still faces significant drawbacks -- including persistent complaints about the exploitation of spaces that ought not to be commercialized -- the medium looks as if it is bouncing back.
"When you're outdoors, you're part of the environs," said Peter Arnell, chairman and executive creative director at the Arnell Group, an advertising agency in New York. "That's very different from having someone purchase something like a magazine to see your ad." Arnell has produced innovative outdoor ads for Donna Karan apparel, which featured painted skylines of Manhattan, and for Samsung home electronics products -- produced on mesh nets that are draped on the sides of buildings and "roll up," Mr. Arnell said, "like big venetian blinds."
The reasons for the seeming outdoor bounce-back include: new technologies like computer graphics, which make possible innovative signs like Samsung's and represent a marked improvement in reproduction quality over conventional paper; the wooing of advertisers like movie studios, cosmetics makers and radio stations to reduce the reliance on so-called sin products like liquor and cigarettes; success in convincing marketers to make outdoor ads integral aspects of their brand-building image campaigns, and better maintenance methods that keep signs from turning seedy.
"It's a cool medium," said Alan J. Gottesman, who follows the advertising industry as managing director of West End Communications/Consulting in New York. "A lot of it is very mundane: 'Buy pizza here now.' But I think there's a lot more life in the outdoor business than most people give it credit for.
"As all other media fractionalize, that has not diminished one iota the strategic vitality of outdoor," he added. "People still spend a lot of time in their cars."
In cities, they spend a lot of time in buses and subways, as well: Outdoor Systems will pay $690 million in cash for the Gannett outdoor operations, which include transit advertising in New York City.
"I thought it was cheap," said Arte Moreno, president and chief executive of Outdoor Systems in Phoenix, laughing.
"We went public to pay down debt and position ourselves for the big acquisition," said Mr. Moreno, who began in outdoor advertising in 1979 at Eller Outdoor and five years later joined with a partner, Bill Levine, now the chairman of Outdoor Systems, to buy up outdoor companies.
"I've been at this a long time, and the medium works," Mr. Moreno said. "It does a great job for the advertiser. We don't try to do everything, but we do try to make your name big and bold and do it efficiently."
Karl Eller, for whom Mr. Moreno once worked, endorsed his bullish view of the industry.
"The values have gone up, the prices have gone up, the multiples have gone up," said Mr. Eller, now chairman and chief executive of the Eller Media Company in Phoenix. In another outdoor mega-deal in August, he bought Patrick Media -- which traces its roots to a century-old outdoor company, Foster & Kleiser -- from the GE Capital unit of the General Electric Company. That purchase price: $518 million.
The numbers are big for a medium whose roots are in simple pitches posted along roadsides -- billboards like the famous rhyming signs for Burma-Shave, which delighted travelers memorized:
The bearded lady
Tried a jar
She's now
A famous
Movie star
Burma-Shave
"The industry has come back in vogue," said Mr. Eller, who has worked in outdoor advertising for 44 years and put Gannett in that business when he sold Eller Outdoor along with the rest of the Combined Communications Corporation to Gannett in 1979. "Things go in cycles," he added, "and right now we're in a good cycle."
Among others who are behaving as if they share Mr. Eller's beliefs is H. Wayne Huizenga, the Florida entrepreneur who founded Blockbuster Entertainment; he is forming a billboard business as part of a conglomerate he now runs, Republic Industries.
"Outdoor is having a resurgence because it offers an explosion of different possibilities," said Jack Hanrahan, senior vice president and worldwide director for out-of-home media at the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago.
Burnett buys the most outdoor advertising of any agency in America, according to the trade publication Advertising Age, spending $140.7 million in 1995, up 11.8 percent from $125.8 million in 1994. Burnett clients active on the outdoor front include the Kellogg Company, for Nutri-Grain breakfast bars; the McDonald's Corporation; the Philip Morris Companies, for brands like Marlboro cigarettes and Miller Lite beer, and Reebok International Ltd.
Among the attractive traits of outdoor advertising, Mr. Hanrahan listed "the ability to get reach and get it fast," the relatively low cost of outdoor campaigns compared with a more expensive medium like television and the flexibility to use outdoor as a mass medium or as a narrowly focused medium.
For instance, a focused test campaign for one Philip Morris brand, Altoids mints, has used outdoor advertising almost exclusively, concentrating on posters with offbeat images like an old-fashioned body builder and this two-word headline: "Nice Altoids."
"We were able to use integrated marketing data on a ZIP code basis," Mr. Hanrahan said, "buying poster panels and bus shelters in neighborhoods where our target audience of white-collar, more affluent consumers lives, works and plays." Sales of Altoids rose more than 50 percent in the markets where those outdoor ads appeared, he added.
For all the positive signs in sight for the outdoor medium -- Ms. Fletcher of the Outdoor Advertising Association answered her telephone yesterday by saying "It's a wonderful day in the neighborhood" -- problems remain.
James Dougherty, an analyst who follows agencies and advertising for Dean Witter Reynolds in New York, cited two worries.
One, he said, is that "tobacco is still a very important source of revenue, and as tobacco consumption continues to go down, advertising follows consumption." Figures compiled for the Outdoor Advertising Association by Competitive Media Reporting in New York, which tracks ad spending, show tobacco remains the second-largest ad category.
"And there's recurring governmental intervention to restrict billboards," Mr. Dougherty said, "though that's a problem more in Canada than the United States."
Mr. Hanrahan of Burnett said that clients still raise objections to the outdoor medium. One is that "to make outdoor work, you've got to have just the right creative," he said -- "short on words and impactful on visuals."
A second problem is what Mr. Hanrahan called "servicing issues: inspecting to make sure the paper isn't falling down or a tree hasn't grown in front of the billboard."
The replacement of paper with vinyl has helped keep signs tidy, he said; still, Mr. Hanrahan maintains a staff of 21 workers to inspect clients' outdoor ads.
And there is always the reality that cyclicality goes both ways.
"It's like the mid-80's," Mr. Eller said of the prices being paid for outdoor companies.
He paused. "I hope it doesn't crash and burn down the road," he added.

HEADLINE: Senate Acts on Labor Measures Opposed by Clinton and Unions

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
The Senate delivered a setback today to one measure that would undermine the strength of labor unions, but approved another that would give companies greater leeway in setting up their own employer-employee groups.
Both bills were strongly opposed by the Clinton Administration and organized labor, which said the intention was to undermine the power of unions. 
 The two votes came a day after the Senate acted on another contentious labor bill, approving an increase in the minimum wage.
The Senate rejected, 68 to 31, an effort to cut off debate and move toward final action on a bill that prohibits labor contracts to require that all employees pay union dues as a condition of employment. It fell 29 votes short of the 60 votes needed to end debate and move legislation toward a final vote.
The sponsor of the legislation, Senator Lauch Faircloth, Republican of North Carolina, said that such a law, which is now in force in 21 states, should be nationalized because "compulsory unionism violates a fundamental principle of individual liberty."
But Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said the bill was a "direct attack on the ability of working people to protect their economic interests."
The Senate next voted, 53 to 46, to send to President Clinton a measure that would allow employers to form groups with workers to discuss such issues as quality control.
The bill, sponsored by Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, is identical to legislation narrowly passed by the House last September. The President has said he will veto it.
Mrs. Kassebaum, who heads the Senate Labor Committee, argued that her bill only made it easier for employers and employees to cooperate in nonunion settings.
"It only represents common sense," she said. "It's not in any way designed to be a destroyer of unions."
But the Administration, in a statement, said the President would veto the legislation because it could lead to employers' creating company-dominated unions that "would undermine a 60-year tradition of collective bargaining."
Mr. Kennedy, the ranking Democrat on the Labor Committee, said there was no need for the legislation because 30,000 employers had already set up teams with workers, and the National Labor Relations Board rarely objects.
Republicans earlier tried to attach the bill to legislation to raise the minimum wage, but the President said the labor relations measure was a "poison pill" that would precipitate a veto. The Senate and House have passed the wage increase, and the President has said he will sign it.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A rigid Japan Inc. could tumble from the top industrial ranks.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
AFTER shuffling in place for much of the 1990's, the Japanese economy is growing again. But before the Japan bashers get a chance to sound the alarm, consider this analysis of the economy's long-term prospects by Robert Alan Feldman of Salomon Brothers.
"Japan will face major difficulties in maintaining living standards over the next 30 years," he wrote last month in a report to Salomon's clients. "At recent levels of productivity growth, per capita income cannot even be kept flat in the face of an aging population." 
 Mr. Feldman may be excessively pessimistic. But his story of a Japan at risk of slipping from the first rank of industrial powers is both plausible and, from the American perspective, just a bit reassuring. For what the Japanese economy apparently lacks is what the American economy has in spades: a freewheeling culture that allows rapid change and encourages bottom-up technological innovation.
Output per worker in Japan, which grew at an annual pace of 6 percent to 8 percent for much of the century, began to decelerate in the early 1970's. Indeed, Gary Saxonhouse, an economist at the University of Michigan, noted that Tokyo lowered its official estimate of long-term growth potential for the economy to 4 percent from 6 percent in the mid-1980's and, most recently, to just 3.5 percent.
That does not shock economists enamored of the "convergence hypothesis" -- the idea that productivity tends to equalize in industrialized countries. What may be surprising is that Japanese growth seems to have stalled prematurely, at a point where output per worker is well below American levels. The current burst of growth, it is generally agreed, merely represents a return to full use of economic resources after a long recession.
What may be even more surprising is that Japanese productivity growth has gradually slowed in spite of a sustained investment effort that exceeded the pace of American capital accumulation even during the last recession. This suggests that the average return on new investments in Japan is well below the return on this side of the Pacific.
Part of the explanation is straightforward. Most recent growth in advanced economies has been based on productivity change in services, where Japan lags far behind. "They have four million more people working in retailing than they would need" were the sector as productive as its American counterpart, calculates David Hale, an economist at Zurich Kemper Investments in Chicago.
Of course, Japan is still very prosperous. And even modest continuing growth in living standards ought to sustain civility and social cohesion. But Mr. Feldman of Salomon Brothers suggests that such sanguinity may be premature.
Like other advanced economies, Japan has a rapidly aging population. But after decades of low birth rates and rising life expectancy, Japan is far ahead of the curve. Salomon Brothers projects that the labor force will shrink by 14 percent in the next 20 years while the population will grow by 4 percent. Unless Japan can raise its anemic rate of productivity growth -- six-tenths of 1 percent -- or raise consumption at the expense of savings, living standards will actually decline.
Mr. Feldman argues that clipping coupons from Japan's accumulated investment abroad -- now about $800 billion -- will not be nearly sufficient to close the gap between expected domestic output and current levels of consumption. Nor is Tokyo likely to ease the demographic crunch by liberalizing immigration, say, by admitting skilled working-age foreigners from Hong Kong. Indeed, if economic convergence is to continue, he suggests, it will depend on a combination of increased work from would-be retirees -- a matter of necessity for many since Japan's pension system is even less well financed than the Social Security system in the United States -- and revolutionary changes in the way the Japanese economy works.
Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, agrees. Along with breaking the logjam on productivity growth in services and letting Japan's grotesquely inefficient agricultural sector wither away, he argues that "Japan must become friendlier to innovation." A culture that so heavily relies on the group, glorifies consensus and concentrates financial decision-making in the hands of a few giant institutions is going to have a tough time producing its own Silicon Valleys.
Since the mid-1970's -- just when Japanese productivity growth began to tail off -- Americans have been simultaneously envious and fearful of Japan Inc., the fabled interlocking directive of business and government that keeps the production lines running on time. Now it appears this Confucian version of central planning is a grand barrier to achieving the material quality of life taken for granted in the affluent West.

HEADLINE: Late Rally Spurs Stocks, With Dow Climbing 21.79

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A late afternoon technical rally pulled stocks out of a sharp decline yesterday, allowing blue chips to finish higher.
But weak technology shares and uncertainty about the future of the economy kept the broader market mixed. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, which had been down nearly 50 points, turned around in the last hour of trading thanks to computer-generated buying programs and bargain hunting.
The Dow closed 21.79 points higher at 5,603.65. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.31 points, to 656.06.
But declining issues still outnumbered advancers on the New York Stock Exchange by a margin of 4 to 3. And the technology-rich Nasdaq composite index fell 12.40 points, to 1,141.19, nearly a three-month low.
"It did come back quite quickly and for a while quite vigorously, but with today's close it really has not resolved some of the near-term damage created by weakness in technology and last Friday's 115-point drop" in the Dow, said Eugene Peroni, director of technical research at Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia.
Yesterday's early declines were touched off by Motorola, the big semiconductor and telecommunications company, which warned after the market closed on Tuesday that its second-quarter profits were far short of analyst estimates. The company attributed the weakness in part to slack demand for semiconductors. Shares of Motorola fell 32 percent in early trading.
The earnings shortfall erased any optimism generated by the semiconductor industry's monthly book-to-bill report for June, which showed the third straight increase in the ratio between new orders and previous orders that were billed.
Motorola recovered slightly from its low for the day but still finished 8 5/8 points lower at 57 7/8.
Motorola was the latest of several computer and technology companies that have been releasing disappointing earnings reports or forecasts in recent days.
Mary Farrell, market strategist at Paine Webber Inc., said many analysts failed to reduce their earnings predictions when the economy was moving at a slower pace earlier this year.
"These disappointments are the result of overoptimism about how many companies would be able to get through the slowdown with their earnings intact," she said.
Weakness in stocks came despite another strong day in the bond market, which has recovered some ground from Friday's steep selloff. The stock and bond markets tumbled that day on fears over inflation and interest rates generated by a surprisingly strong employment report.
"Obviously, there was widespread shock and surprise at last week's employment numbers. said Eric Miller, chief strategist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities in San Francisco. "But now there's more a sense of confusion" about the true pace of the economy and inflation, he said.
Corporate earnings reports yesterday were not all disappointing. Abbott Labs, the drug maker, gained 7/8, to 42 1/2, after besting analyst expectations by 1 cent a share. Safeway, the supermarket chain, beat expectations by 3 cents and gained 1, to 35 1/8.
Among other individual issues, shares of Procter & Gamble closed up 1/4, at 88 1/2. Procter & Gamble told analysts that per-share earnings would rise at a slightly slower pace in the current quarter than the quarter a year earlier.The company also announced that it planned to buy back up to $1 billion of its common stock and that its board had raised the annual dividend by 12.5 percent, to $1.80 a share.
Technology stocks were weaker following Motorola's warning. America Online slipped 1/2, to 39 1/2; Texas Instruments fell 3/4, to 48 1/2; Intel dropped 1/2, to 72 7/8, and Broderbund Software Inc. slumped 1, to 31 3/4.

HEADLINE: Crime (and Punishment) Rages Anew in China

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: ZHONGSHAN, China

 BODY:
The corpse of the taxi driver was still warm in the back seat when Liao Yongxiong, age 29, pulled up in front of the Lian Yuan Street branch of the Industrial and Commerce Bank here in the car he had just hijacked.
He concealed his pistol under his jacket and went inside. The three women tellers greeted him; he was a familiar face as one of the security guards who delivered cash each week from the main office. 
 Perhaps he was smiling when he asked, "Could I use the restroom?" because the women were all too willing to unbolt the door to the security area where they were working.
He killed them swiftly, just as he had the taxi driver, with point-blank shots to the head or chest. Only one of the tellers, right before she died on the blood-spattered floor, was able to press the alarm button near her desk as Mr. Liao was escaping with a bag full of cash and securities.
Scenes like this one, which occurred on April 16 on a leafy side street here in this southern Chinese boom town, had been virtually unheard of in China during most of the last five decades. Now, suddenly, gangsters are staging a comeback in China and major crime seems out of control.
This has provoked the largest nationwide crackdown on crime in more than a decade and a wave of executions that has alarmed human rights organizations.
Serious crime and crimes involving firearms are rising at more than 20 percent a year, with more than a third of those cases involving gangs.
"We were used to seeing this kind of crime in the movies, but such things have never happened here," said Su Leting, who had just opened a new seafood restaurant and was concerned, as many members of the Zhongshan business community are, that fear of crime would drive foreign investors away. "Many foreigners have started to get nervous about social stability," said Hu Baishou, the editor of the Zhongshan Daily, whose front page carried the police composite drawing that led to Mr. Liao's arrest 54 hours after the robbery.
Before China opened to the outside world in the late 1970's, totalitarian social controls had all but eliminated major crime, drug trafficking and prostitution. But with the decentralization of authority, the disappearance of Communist-organized neighborhood committees and the reappearance of wealth, a criminal reawakening is under way.
Although the overall crime rate in China remains modest in comparison to that of United States and other Western countries, its rapid rise and a sudden surge in major crimes, including murder, armed robbery and drug trafficking, have triggered a response from Communist Party authorities.
In December 1995 and February of this year, criminal gangs in Guangdong province and in Beijing staged spectacular armored car robberies with precision planning and sophisticated arms. Together they netted more than $2 million in cash.
The holdups prompted the Ministry of Public Security to rewrite its budget plan for the next five years to buy more armor, better alarms and global-positioning devices that use satellite signals to pinpoint the location of cash-carrying vehicles, many of which are not even armored in China.
The day before the Zhongshan bank robbery, the police in Guangdong province stopped five jeeps and a truck trying to smuggle 1,200 pounds of heroin into Hong Kong for shipment to the United States and Europe. It was one of the largest single hauls of heroin in history.
In the country's rich coastal provinces, well-armed highway gangs have used prostitutes to lure truck drivers into robbery and murder traps. Kidnappers are preying on the families of China's new rich and the heroin trade has spread to all of China's large cities.
But it may have been Mr. Liao's murderous bank heist in this city where Sun Yat-sen, the father of modern China, was born that shocked the Communist leadership in Beijing into ordering a nationwide crackdown on major crimes and gangs.
The so-called "Strike Hard" crackdown has led in its first two months to tens of thousands of arrests and at least a thousand executions, more than at any time since the 1983 crackdown on crime when, diplomats say, 10,000 were put to death within a few months.
One of those executed in the current campaign was Mr. Liao, who was shot in the back of the head on April 30 by a police executioner, 15 days after the crime. Before he died, he was paraded before 5,000 Zhongshan residents at a sports stadium, where he was denounced as a "barbarian" by local Communist Party officials.
"This was a big case, so the masses' reaction was very serious," said Mr. Hu, the newspaper editor, who is also the deputy chief of propaganda for the Communist Party committee in Zhongshan. "After Liao was arrested, the people were very happy and they appealed to execute him right away."
Mr. Liao's last words to a state television interviewer were, "I do not fear death," and his dramatic appeal to his older brother to care for his 3-year-old son was captured by a local photographer.
Around the country, so many city and provincial governments have been staging execution rallies that human rights organizations are having trouble keeping an accurate tally.
Even before the crackdown, the human rights group Amnesty International was estimating at least 2,000 executions a year in China, with the death penalty being applied in many cases "as a result of political interference" and "with hardly any safeguards against miscarriages of justice."
In Shanghai, China's largest city, Fu Changlu, an administrative judge of the city's First Intermediate People's Court, said in an interview that "within the realm of the law, we have to be as severe as we can" on the perpetrators of major crime.
"Anyone who may be executed, will be executed," he said. "We will not simply give capital punishment to all criminals, but those who deserve it will get it."
An internal Public Security document issued in April characterized the rising crime rate as a outgrowth of "the accumulation of social wealth and a growing gap between rich and ordinary people" that is "forcing us to take measures to more effectively track and crush crime."
Crime is also making news. Many local Communist Party newspapers have dropped some of the dull essays on party theory from their front pages to make room for the latest criminal outrage.
One "vampire gang" in northeastern China, a newspaper reported, enslaved homeless children and sold their blood to hospitals. And in Hebei province, a night security guard was reportedly sentenced to life in prison for ringing up $6,000 in international telephone charges to telephone sex lines in the United States.
Even the Communist Party flagship paper, The People's Daily, which likes to chronicle the sins of Western society, was forced to give prominent display last winter to the murder of Li Peiyao, the vice chairman of the National People's Congress, China's parliament. Mr. Li was murdered during the burglary of his home by one of his body guards from the People's Armed Police.
Chinese experts say the number of gangs and "secret societies" are growing faster than the police can count them. One nationwide police tally found that in 1991, there were about 500 known criminal gangs comprising a few dozen members to more than 100. By 1995, the tally had leaped to about 10,000 gangs with a total membership of 500,000 to one million members.
Cai Shaoqing, a professor at Nanjing University who studies China's criminal history, says most gangs are made up of unemployed youths and former prisoners.
Not since 1983, after the first stirrings of capitalism in China had revived criminal opportunities in a huge population accustomed to deprivation, have Communist Party leaders been so compelled to whip up a national campaign against crime.
Their decision has prompted speculation about its larger political meaning.
Some experts say this crime wave provides the younger generation of Chinese leaders an opportunity to demonstrate their toughness on law-and-order issues, which are becoming more important as China's economy develops.
But the new campaign carries the unmistakable echoes of earlier power struggles in which popular revulsion to the seamy side of capitalism were exploited by party conservatives to improve their standing. This revulsion was the impetus for the 1983 crackdown.
In the culture of the Communist Party, crime is associated with the chaos and corruption of the pre-Communist era. Even the family of Deng Xiaoping, the country's paramount leader, was a victim. As a young revolutionary, Mr. Deng got word in 1938 that his father had been set upon by bandits and killed in their native Sichuan.
But the crackdown has fostered alarm among legal scholars that China's efforts to establish the rule of law in its criminal justice system could be undermined by the overtones of a "mass movement" -- a term associated with the political persecutions of the Maoist era -- against crime.
"The leaders are not yet putting this crackdown forward as a movement," said Jiang Ping, one of China's most prominent legal scholars and former head of the Politics and Law University in Beijing, "but it has the smell of a movement because the whole party is behind it and the whole nation is involved."
Mr. Jiang, like many legal scholars, also questions whether China's heavy reliance on the death penalty has had any effect.
"The first crackdown really began in 1984, and you could say that for these 10 years or so, the more we crack down. the more serious the crime situation becomes," he said. "This time the crackdown may be connected with the need to insure stability as the economic and social shortcomings emerge" in China's reform era and create "disaffection among the masses that can lead to the spark that sets off trouble."
For now, the crackdown appears to enjoy popular support.
Even Mr. Liao's neighbors in Wuguishan village could not argue with the death penalty verdict against him. "It was fair," said a friend of the family, as he sat in Mr. Liao's courtyard home under portraits of his ancestors and the ashes of incense sticks recently burned before them. "If you kill a man, you should pay compensation with your life."
