HEADLINE: New Israeli Leader's Visit Elicits Curiosity and Ambivalence

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
When Benjamin Netanyahu arrives in New York today for his first visit to the city as Prime Minister of Israel, he will be greeted by a Jewish population excessively acquainted with his American-style political sagacity but deeply ambivalent about the direction he may lead Israel.
Given the anxiety about how extreme a departure the new Prime Minister may represent, his three-day visit to the city regarded as the epicenter of Jewish life in the United States has stimulated unusually intense interest. Hundreds more people than can be accommodated have clamored for seats at his public appearances. 
 Many have seen him repeatedly before. In the 1980's, when Mr. Netanyahu was Israel's delegate to the United Nations, it was nearly impossible to navigate the television talk shows without witnessing him, and he became a familiar and popular figure in many New York Jewish circles. But the "Bibi" so omnipresent then was not the Prime Minister, and that makes all the difference.
"We know him, but we don't know him," said Rabbi Ismar Schorsch, chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary in Manhattan, who sees the trip as important in establishing the tone of the relationship with Jews in New York.
"We're wondering, is this the old Bibi, the new Bibi, or what Bibi?" said Phil Baum, the executive director of the American Jewish Congress. "I think American Jews are looking for some reassurance that the Likud Government is not some off-the-wall, right-wing government. I hope we get that. There is a lot of apprehension."
The two issues of foremost concern to many New York Jews are his harder-line views on the Middle East peace effort and his suggestions that his Government will significantly strengthen the authority of Orthodox Judaism in Israel.
During his crowded schedule, Mr. Netanyahu, 46, is expected to draw heavily on his reservoir of political guile and charisma to try to rally support and approval from a highly disparate population with tangled emotions that probably harbors more opponents of his ideology than supporters. In this first trip, most of the welcomers anticipate a steady dose of social felicities and palliatives from the Prime Minister and relatively little in the way of substance.
"It's Mr. Netanyahu's opportunity to make nice-nice and say all the right things about the relationship between America and Israel," said Rabbi Gerald Skolnik of the Forest Hills Jewish Center, a large Conservative synagogue. "Some will welcome him as a conquering hero, which I personally don't see him as. They will greet him as the next incarnation of the Messiah. The others, like me, who disagree with him, will greet him respectfully."
The visit, while punctuated with political courtesy calls and some talk-show appearances, will revolve around meetings with Jewish leaders and business executives.
There has been pronounced interest in hearing what he has to say. More than 600 people responded to invitations to a meeting this evening for which the host is the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations. Since there was room for 400, 200 were relegated to a waiting list.
"Even Congressmen are calling up for tickets and can't get in," said Malcolm Hoenlein, the executive vice chairman of the organization. "It's the first visit of a new, young Prime Minister who has a rapport with the New York community."
Another session this evening, sponsored by the Jewish Community Relations Council, with a capacity of 3,000, was fully subscribed within 48 hours. Hundreds were turned away.
"There's a lot of interest in how Netanyahu is going to square the circle on a number of issues," said Gary Rosenblatt, editor of The Jewish Week.
Rabbi Schorsch, who opposed Mr. Netanyahu, said he is somewhat less troubled on the issue of the peace effort than he was just a month ago. "I think he has played his cards very well," he said.
But he remains worried that the Prime Minister will slow the trend toward religious pluralism in Israel. "The issue that concerns American Jewry is the status of Reform and Conservative Jews," he said. "They constitute overwelmingly the majority of American Jews."
Rabbi Skolnik added: "There are a lot of people in favor of the peace process who would like to see it slowed down. I don't think most American Jews will fight him on that. But I care about the religious pluralism issue. It affects me tremendously. I'm not allowed to go to Israel and officiate over a wedding. And that does bother me a lot. In two and a half weeks, I'm taking 40 people from my synagogue to Israel on a tour. I would like to have an equal share in the Jewish state."
Mr. Netanyahu has strong support in Orthodox circles, but many in the Conservative and Reform movements feel cut out of the loop with the new Prime Minister, and regard his visit with tepid interest.
"I believe the Jewish community will give him a very warm reception, which I respect but do not participate in," said Rabbi Rolando Matalon of B'nai Jeshurun, a Conservative synagogue on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. "I do not have any warm feelings for him or his platform."
On the other hand, for people like Rabbi Avi Weiss of the Hebrew Institute of Riverdale, who is a hawk on insuring Israeli security, the election of Mr. Netanyahu has whisked them back into the mainstream. "In the past, I felt discounted, marginalized by Israeli officials," he said. "I didn't count. Now I feel I count again."
Many others, however, find him indecipherable. "He's still a mystery," said Alon Grotch, an Israeli-born psychologist in New York. "The dilemma I feel about him is you look at his whole history and his position has been consistently right wing. But his campaign was very American, based on images. That suggests a pragmatic, consummate politician who will do whatever it takes to stay in power. I saw him on 'Larry King Live' and he says a lot and he says nothing. I'm still trying to find out who he is."
The Prime Minister will arrive in the city under heavy security. He is traveling with 20 Israeli agents, double the usual allotment, and they will be augmented by Federal agents and New York police officers. A police helicopter equipped with high-resolution video cameras will track his movements within the city and sharpshooters will be poised on rooftops. Three floors are being sealed off at the hotel where he is staying, the Stanhope on Fifth Avenue and 81st Street, across from the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
At the Stanhope, he has meetings scheduled today with Gov. George E. Pataki, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Bob Dole, the presumed Republican nominee, and is to meet at the Sheraton New York Hotel with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
Keen to draw further investment to Israel, he will have lunch at the New York Stock Exchange with 200 business leaders seeking reassurance about the Israeli economy. After the large evening sessions with Jewish leaders, he will be the guest at a private dinner held by Ronald S. Lauder, the wealthy businessman and cosmetics heir.
Tomorrow, his schedule is media-laden. He is to have breakfast with 30 journalists, meet with Jewish and Israeli journalists and conduct television and radio interviews.
On Saturday, he plans to attend morning Sabbath services at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun on East 85th Street, the modern Orthodox synagogue at which he worshiped when he lived in New York. He will walk to and from the synagogue, posing perhaps the most significant security risk during his visit. Those blocks will be cleared of vehicles and lined with police officers. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein lamented, "I'm going to have to move my car."
After the service, the Prime Minister may do some sightseeing. He is considering taking his family to the Central Park Zoo. Mr. Netanyahu will leave after sundown, the end of the Sabbath, to return to Israel.
Though many expect the Prime Minister to be asked some tough questions during his visit, few anticipate that he will get too stiff a buffeting on his first trip. "The game hasn't started," Rabbi Schorsch said. "We're just warming up."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Scanlon Leaves Firm That Handled Crises

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
John Scanlon, the longtime public relations executive who has been at the center of several corporate controversies, is leaving Abernathy MacGregor Scanlon, a financial and crisis communications agency in New York where he has been a partner since June 1993.
James L. Abernathy and James T. MacGregor, the agency's managing partners, said in a statement sent to their clients that the agency would return to a previous name, the Abernathy/MacGregor Group Inc. The statement said Mr. Scanlon, 61, would rejoin Edelman Public Relations Worldwide, where he had worked from 1983 to 1988. 
 But Michael Morley, president at Edelman in New York, said yesterday: "It's no secret we have been in discussions with John Scanlon about his return to Edelman. But no agreement has yet been reached nor will be until John has taken a well-earned break through the month of September at his home in Ireland."
Mr. Scanlon could not be reached for comment. He has been the subject of intensive news coverage for his work for a New York law firm to advise the Brown & Williamson Tobacco unit of B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. on ways to discredit Jeffrey S. Wigand, former head of research at Brown & Williamson. Mr. Wigand, who appeared on the CBS news program "60 Minutes," has accused Brown & Williamson executives of lying about whether cigarettes are addictive.

HEADLINE: U.S., Enforcing Cuba Curbs, Punishes Canadian Company

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
The Administration struck today for the first time against foreign companies operating in Cuba, informing the top executives and the biggest shareholders of a Canadian mining concern that they and their families will be barred from the United States, State Department officials said.
The action against the company, the Sherritt International Corporation, is the first application of the Helms-Burton law, which President Clinton, against the advice of many of his closest advisers, signed this year. It has raised a storm of protest throughout Europe and Latin America, and Canada has told its companies to ignore American threats and has warned it may retaliate with countersanctions. 
 [A Sherritt official in Calgary, Alberta, said the company would continue investing in Cuba. "We are staying the course," a Sherritt vice president, Patrice Merrin Best, said in an interview with Reuters. About nine officials and large shareholders are thought to be involved.]
American officials in Washington said executives from telephone companies in Mexico and Italy would be informed in coming days that they will also be barred from visiting the United States and from sending their children to visit or study here.
While today's action seemed to represent a harder line by the Administration, behind the scenes the White House is debating whether to bow to the protests abroad by suspending enforcement of another provision of the law that could cost foreign companies hundreds of millions of dollars.
President Clinton faces a deadline of Monday to decide whether to allow American companies whose properties in Cuba were seized by the Government of President Fidel Castro to file suits in United States courts against foreign companies that are now using them.
The State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, said today that "there is a good deal of discussion about that issue" and that no decision had been made.
The issue is fraught with election-year risks.
Mr. Clinton signed the Republican-sponsored sanctions bill reluctantly in February after Cuban warplanes shot down two small civilian planes flown by an anti-Castro group based in Florida.
The economic isolation of Mr. Castro is an enormously charged issue within the Cuban-American community in Florida, an important state in the November presidential election, and political advisers of Mr. Clinton are urging him to take a hard line against companies doing business with Cuba.
But a hard line could also hurt Florida's economy. A coalition of Canadian church, labor and relief groups urged Canadian tourists today to boycott the state unless the United States relents on Helms-Burton. About two million Canadians travel to Florida each winter, spending about $1.3 billion.
Mr. Clinton's economic advisers, including Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and the chairman of the National Economic Council, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, have made it clear that they are worried about retaliation against American companies.
"I have some real concerns about the extraterritorial application of American law," Mr. Rubin said in a telephone interview today from Texas, where he was reviewing border controls. "But you have to balance that with our interests in bringing pressure to bear on countries like Cuba and Iran. Over the next few days we're going to have to make some decisions."
Traditionally, the United States has been opposed to proposals that punish foreign companies as a way of pressing their governments to change national policy with what is called a secondary boycott. Washington vociferously argued against similar measures in the 1970's, when Arab nations boycotted companies that did business with Israel.
But Mr. Clinton has made clear in recent weeks that he will sign legislation penalizing companies that invest in Iranian or Libyan oil projects worth more than $40 million. Differing versions of the bill have passed the House and the Senate by overwhelming margins. That bill has also been the subject of enormous opposition in Europe, especially in France and Italy.
The Helms-Burton law, named for Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, and Representative Dan Burton, Republican of Indiana, was intended to drive foreign investors out of Cuba in an attempt to bring down the Castro Government, which is already starved of cash.
It requires the Administration to bar from the United States top executives and major shareholders -- and their families -- of companies found to be "trafficking" in American property confiscated by Mr. Castro in 1959, soon after he took power.
Sherritt International operates properties that were seized from the predecessor of what is now Freeport-McMoran a New Orleans-based mining concern.
The Mexican telephone company Grupo Domos and the Italian telecommunications holding company Societa Finanziaria Telefonica per Azioni, or STET, use properties that once belonged to the ITT Corporation.
[The Mexican Government said late Wednesday that it had sent a diplomatic note to the United States Government protesting the Helms-Burton law. "The Government asked the State Department to pass on its concern to the President of the United States and urge him to suspend the entry into effect" of provisions of the law, the Foreign Ministry said in a statement quoted by Reuters].
Under the law, the officials who received the State Department letters would be banned from entering the United States starting in 45 days. Canadian officials would not release their names, but the list was said to include a number of prominent British investors in the company.
"We're bracing ourselves for a torrent of criticism from our allies," said a senior State Department official. "It's going to be very messy."
While banning individuals from the United States is the major symbolic action in the law, the big money rests in the provision that allows American citizens to sue foreigners and foreign companies that "act to manage, lease, possess, use or hold an interest in" property confiscated by Cuba from people who are now American citizens. That includes many Cuban-Americans.
Several foreign governments have said they will challenge that provision in international tribunals, including the World Trade Organization, because it gives American courts the authority to seize assets of foreign comapnies for actions that took place beyond American borders.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Read Their Lips: The Other Guy Is the Candidate in Favor of Big Tax Increases

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
Turning to what both sides said would be a central issue in the Presidential race, the Clinton and Dole campaigns today introduced television advertisements in which each portrayed the other's candidate as a steadfast proponent of big tax increases.
The attack on President Clinton had been expected, because ever since entering the race Bob Dole had described him as an adherent of high spending and high taxes. 
 But Mr. Clinton's decision to engage Mr. Dole directly on an issue that Republicans have long viewed as an Achilles' heel for the President came as a surprise, all the more so since the Clinton advertisement drew on Speaker Newt Gingrich to make the case that it was Mr. Dole who was the advocate of higher taxes.
In that commercial, which Democratic aides said was completed today and would be televised beginning on Thursday evening, the announcer intones, "Republicans called him the tax collector of the welfare state" -- Mr. Gingrich's onetime description of Mr. Dole.
In conscious imitation of a commercial that Steve Forbes used against Mr. Dole in the Republican Presidential primary in New Hampshire -- much to Mr. Dole's annoyance, according to his aides -- this one offers viewers a scroll of various tax increases that Mr. Dole supported during his three and a half decades in Congress.
It ends by showing him proclaiming at a campaign stop, "You're going to see the real Bob Dole from now on," while the tag line reads: "The real Bob Dole. 35 years of higher taxes."
For its part, the Dole campaign went on the air this evening with a commercial that tried to make much the same case about the President. In a segment shot in black and white, this advertisement showed Mr. Clinton saying in a campaign debate in October 1992, "Now, I'll tell you this: I will not raise taxes on the middle class to pay for these programs."
It went on to say that upon becoming President, Mr. Clinton had embarked on a program that "gave us the largest tax increase in history."
"Higher income taxes," it said, including "increased taxes on Social Security benefits. More payroll taxes."
"Under Clinton, the typical American family now pays over $1,500 more in Federal taxes," it said. "A big price to pay for his broken promise."
Clinton campaign aides immediately attacked the premise of the Dole advertisement, noting that almost all the tax increase at issue had fallen on the wealthiest 1 percent of taxpayers rather than on the middle class.
Accordingly Mr. Clinton's aides, and independent tax experts as well, disputed the advertisement's assertion that "the typical American family now pays over $1,500 more in Federal taxes." They argued that in fact the only provision of the Clinton tax increase that had really affected middle-class families was a 4.3-cent-a-gallon rise in the Federal tax on gasoline, amounting to about $36 a year for each such family.
What is more, the tax increase that the President championed -- totaling about $250 billion over five years, part of a 1993 deficit-reduction effort -- is, adjusted for inflation, less than the tax increase enacted under President Ronald Reagan in 1982.
Whatever the differences over the numbers, today's squabbling, and the advertisements themselves, were a vivid illustration that the matter of tax increases would occupy a prominent place on the Presidential election landscape this year, and that the White House was not prepared to concede an issue that has proved regularly effective for Republican Presidential candidates for a generation.
After learning of the Clinton advertisement, Mike Murphy, a Dole strategist, said this evening, "This is a huge strategic victory for us."
Mr. Murphy maintained that the Republicans had succeeded in shifting the campaign debate from Mr. Dole's equivocal remarks on the addictiveness of tobacco "to a fight on taxes."
"We're spending our money making this election about our issue of taxes," he said, "and the Democrats are making it about our issue of taxes."
Mr. Clinton's aides saw it differently. The Republicans, one political adviser to the President said, believe that if they win the debate on taxes, they will have won "the whole ball game." But "we're not going to cede it," this adviser said. "No way."
Consequently the Clinton commercial listed Mr. Dole's support of measures like the income tax increase enacted in 1990, during the Bush Administration, and the 1983 increase in the Social Security payroll tax, during the Reagan Administration.
But the President's aides declined this evening to offer any examples of tax votes cast by Mr. Dole with which Mr. Clinton now disagreed.
"The purpose of this ad is to expose the hypocrisy of Bob Dole and the Republicans' talking about the President," said Joe Lockhart, Mr. Clinton's campaign spokesman. "And that's what the ad is about. We're not talking about any particular tax increase. The ad is designed to expose his hypocrisy when he's talking about Bill Clinton and taxes."
Both commercials will be televised on CNN and in local markets within states that are expected to be closely contested this fall. The Democratic National Committee learned of the Republican commercial this week as Mr. Dole's aides began distributing it to local television stations. A copy made its way to Democratic operatives in Washington, who immediately began finishing a response advertisement on the subject that had been waiting on a shelf.

Clinton Uses Sanctions Against Canadians
The Clinton Administration took specific action for the first time against foreign companies operating in Cuba, informing top executives and shareholders of the Sherritt International Corporation, a large Canadian mining concern, that they and their families would be barred from entering the United States, State Department officials said.
This is the first application of the Helms-Burton amendment, which President Clinton signed despite the warnings of close advisers. The provision has fired protests throughout Europe and Latin America. Canada told companies to ignore the threats. [Page A1.]
 
Hewlett-Packard Sees Slow Demand
In news that could roil technology stocks again today, Hewlett-Packard said that new orders for all of its products were slowing and would probably hurt the company's profitability for the current quarter. Hewlett-Packard said it planned to close its two computer disk-drive plants and take a pretax charge of $150 million. The announcement was made after the stock market closed. [D2.]

Corner the Treasury market? Federal regulators said it was done three years ago on a futures contract for 10-year Treasury notes by Fenchurch Capital Management of Chicago, which runs two commodity funds. Fenchurch and its president agreed to pay fines without admitting wrongdoing.

A late-afternoon technical rally pulled stocks out of a sharp decline, allowing blue chips to finish higher. But weak technology shares and uncertainty about the future of the economy kept the broader market mixed. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Political Briefing;
THE CAMPAIGNS AND THE ISSUES

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

 BODY:

The Republican Primaries
A Bonus Proposal For Late Contests
The Presidential primary and caucus season has steadily been growing shorter as, over the years, more and more states have tried to schedule their primaries earlier and earlier in an attempt to gain greater political leverage in the nominating process. 
 This year, the season was the most frenetic ever, with so many states voting one-after-another in the first six weeks or so that voters often complained they were being forced to make a decision without proper time to contemplate.
On the Republican side -- there was, of course, no contest on the Democratic side -- it was clear well before half of the primaries and caucuses had been held that Bob Dole would almost certainly be the nominee. Voters in the remaining states felt politically left out and primary and caucus turnout plummeted.
Things may be different, come the next primary and caucus season, in the year 2000.
A study task force set up by the Republican National Committee is recommending that the party offer bonus national convention delegates to states that schedule their primaries and caucuses late in the season.
The task force suggests that the season run from the first Monday in February through the third Tuesday in June, with states that schedule voting after March 15 qualifying for delegate bonuses -- ever larger for ever later dates.
For example, states voting between March 15 and April 14 would receive a 10 percent increase in delegates. Those voting between April 15 and May 14 would receive a 15 percent increase. And those voting on or after May 15 would receive a 20 percent bonus.
What's the outlook for the proposal, which will be put to a vote in August at the 1996 Republican National Convention in San Diego?
A big, politically powerful state like California, which moved its primary date forward this year, might be enticed to move back in 2000 in return for even more convention clout.
But a small state like New Hampshire would gain relatively little convention clout with a bonus, however big, and, anyway, probably would prefer to keep its nationally prominent position as one of the earliest states to vote.
Before the task force proposal can be put to a floor vote in San Diego, it must first make its way through a committee process, much as a piece of Congressional legislation. At that level, every state, big or small, gets two votes.
 
Campaigning in Cyberspace
Vermont Candidate Petitions Web Users
Politicians long ago discovered the World Wide Web, establishing sites where interested cybersurfers could retrieve information about candidates and causes. Just yesterday, Vice President Al Gore announced that a "Clinton/Gore '96" site was up and running.
But perhaps the most unusual political cybersite seen thus far in 1996 is the one established by August St. John, a Vermonter who, when he's not dabbling in politics, commutes down to New York to teach marketing on the Brooklyn campus of Long Island University.
Professor St. John is running for Governor of the Green Mountain State, as an independent and a self-described "futurist." But in order to get on the November ballot, he must submit nominating petitions signed by at least 1,000 qualified Vermont voters, no easy task for a candidate who says he has little money and hardly any staff.
His solution?
A web site -- what else for a confirmed futurist? -- from which voters can download a copy of his petition, then print it out, sign it and send it in.
"I'm trying to prove you can run for office if you have a lot of interest but not a lot of money," the Professor says.
No count yet on how many signatures he has pulled in with his offbeat on-line approach, which state election officials only recently approved. But even if he gets on the ballot, as a relatively unknown candidate he still will face a steep uphill political struggle, especially against the incumbent Governor, Howard Dean, a well-regarded Democrat who is seeking a third two-year term.
Republicans, who will choose a candidate in a September primary, recently lost their strongest hope when Lieut. Gov. Barbara Snelling suffered a stroke and announced she would not seek nomination. With her out of the race, political experts now give the edge in the primary to John Gropper, a computer consultant from Rochester who unsuccessfully sought the nomination in 1994.
 
The Nader Strategy
Stealth Candidate Poses a Threat
He's hardly campaigning, a stealth candidate if ever there was one, but Ralph Nader is already on the Presidential ballot as the Green Party candidate in half a dozen states -- Alaska, California, Colorado, Maine, New Mexico and Oregon.
What's more, efforts are under way to get the noted consumer crusader listed in six more states, all of major political importance -- Illinois, Michigan, New Jersey, Ohio, Pennsylvania and, as of Tuesday, New York.
"People are tired of voting for the lesser of two evils," Mark Dunlea, the head of New York's Greens, said in kicking off the campaign to get the 15,000 petition signatures needed to get the Nader name on the Empire State's ballot.
Nobody expects Mr. Nader to be elected President, not even Mr. Nader. But his candidacy carries a certain credible threat. Because of his long presence on the national scene, he has a constituency and, polls indicate, he has the potential to pull votes away from President Clinton.
In a closely fought fall contest in big states like New York or California, this could pose danger to the President. To counter the threat, Mr. Clinton might be forced to trim his political sails on reform of economic policy, election law and environmental protection, all Nader crusades. B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: CONSTITUENCIES;
After Dole's Snub, N.A.A.C.P. Greets Clinton Warmly

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 10

 BODY:
President Clinton and the N.A.A.C.P. warmly embraced each other today as Mr. Clinton, in an address to the organization's annual meeting, touted his Administration's economic record in creating jobs, condemned a wave of arson against black Southern churches and vowed to veto Republican efforts to roll back gun control legislation.
"I will say one thing that the Republican candidate for President did not say, and probably will not and cannot say," Mr. Clinton told the delegates. "I will veto any attempt to repeal the assault weapons ban." 
 Mr. Clinton's likely Republican rival, Bob Dole, backed away on Tuesday from efforts to repeal the ban on 19 kinds of assault weapons. Today, Mr. Clinton appeared to be challenging Mr. Dole to match his veto promise.
On these and other points, the President enjoyed a vigorous, positive reception. Though the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is ostensibly nonpartisan, the 3,000 delegates meeting here greeted Mr. Clinton with a standing ovation and repeated chants of "four more years!"
In part, of course, that is because most of them are liberal Democrats. But the enthusiasm for the President might also reflect the group's anger over the decision on Tuesday by his likely Republican rival, Bob Dole, turning down an invitation to speak to the group. As a result, Mr. Clinton's mere presence carried as much weight as his words, perhaps even more.
"Had Dole come I don't think the reaction to the President would have been as partisan as it was," said Julian Bond, a member of the group's board of directors.
Jonas Byrnes, a delegate from Kansas City, Mo., said he believed Mr. Dole had made a mistake in bypassing the meeting. "If he expects to get the black vote, he should at least have shown the courtesy of showing up to discuss the issues," Mr. Byrnes said. "Just don't write people off."
Not everyone was impressed with the President, however. Braimeh Kanu, president of the N.A.A.C.P.'s Springfield, Ill., chapter, asserted that many of the new jobs the President said had been created lacked "permanency," and chided Mr. Clinton for not being more specific on how he would further black economic development in a second term.
"A lot of us clap but don't chew on the meat of what he is really saying," Mr. Kanu said.
For his part, Mr. Clinton was as relaxed as if he were "in the home of a old friend," as Sallie Lee, a delegate from Jamaica, Queens, put it. He called N.A.A.C.P. officials by their first names, joked that Benjamin L. Hooks, 71, a former executive director, was looking "younger and handsomer than ever," and called the group's organist, J.R. Williams, "Brother Williams."
On the subject of church burnings, Mr. Clinton touted the Justice Department's indictment of two white supremacists on charges of burning down a church in Alabama. But the President's tone was preacherly and professorial, comparing the burnings with the ethnic violence in Rwanda or Bosnia and the sectarian strife in Ulster.
"There are people all over the world who look like they can't exist unless they go out and kill somebody who is different from them; or at least keep them at arms length," Mr. Clinton said.
The mood -- indeed the prospects -- of the N.A.A.C.P. are far brighter than they were just two years ago.
During the past 12 months, the organization has whittled its debt to about $800,000 from $3.2 million, said Francisco Borges, the group's treasurer. Mr. Borges said that the bulk of the debt was reduced by negotiating payment plans -- in some cases paying less than the full amount -- with vendors like hotel chains who had not been paid for rooms and services associated with the N.A.A.C.P.'s 1993 convention in Chicago.
By reducing obligations to vendors, laying off staff and closing several regional offices, the group has cut its spending to about $11.4 million last year from $18.6 million in 1994, according to a report submitted to its budget committee.
"We are current now, relative to our obligations," Mr. Borges said in an interview.
But the report also indicates how much the discord that has wracked the civil rights group in recent years has hampered its ability to raise money. Revenues plummeted to $13.7 million in 1995, down from about $15 million the year before. In the first five months of this year, the group has raised $6.4 million, indicating that contributions and dues have rebounded.
Under the leadership of its new president and chief executive officer, Kweisi Mfume, the N.A.A.C.P. has also begun to streamline and modernize its operations.
For example, the group has moved to computerize its membership rolls under a contract with the Saturn Corporation, a software company that has upgraded the membership and direct mail capabilities of major environmental, religious and relief organizations.
The system will allow the N.A.A.C.P. to track the names and addresses of more than 1.2 million current and former members. The new system also will give the group the capability to contact members in any given Congressional district so they can put pressure on members of Congress when it is needed.

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
On Palisades, 2- and 3-Family Homes

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: NORTH BERGEN, N.J.

 BODY:
Here on a ridge carved from the Palisades and overlooking the Hudson River, an enclave of two- and three-family homes is beginning to rise.
Bergen Ridge will consist of 34 houses, ranging from 3,000 to 3,800 square feet, for a total of 90 residences. The development signals a return to a housing form that has long characterized this Hudson County township. The houses will be grouped in clusters along a central slice of the six-acre site, off Bulls Ferry Road, not far from Boulevard East, where the cliff rises behind it 80 feet. The property sits 100 feet above River Road, which runs parallel to the Hudson's west shore. 
 Each of the 12 two-family houses will have a 2,000-square-foot, three-bedroom residence for the owner on the first and second levels, topped with a two-bedroom, 1,000-square-foot rental apartment. The 22 three-family homes will be similar the two-family houses, but they will also have a one-bedroom, 800-square-foot ground-level rental, cut into the cliff. Each apartment will also have its own private front entrance. All the homes will have a one-car garage as well a two-car driveway and two street-level parking spaces.
The $8 million project, being developed by the Applied Companies of Hoboken, underscores an increase in building activity in this 5.3-square-mile community after a four-year lull. It is also another indicator of the renewed interest of developers in housing in riverfront towns in Hudson and Bergen Counties, where a spate of new and revived projects have just been completed, are planned or already under way.
The Bergen Ridge project is a revival. It was conceived during the building boom of the last decade as a 120-unit, five-story condominium building. But the local developers were able only to blast clear the ridge before the project faltered. The Bank of New York, which took back the property through foreclosure late in 1994, sold it a year and a half ago to the new developer for just under $1 million.
Applied -- which is involved in three other riverfront projects with 2,000 rental and condominium apartments -- redesigned Bergen Ridge for several reasons. Low-rise buildings are easier and less costly to build, "making the construction economics more cost-effective," said Michael I. Barry, a company vice president.
The market also has a supply of condominiums and more are planned. "Two- and three-family homes fit in North Bergen and can be easily absorbed," he said.
Henry Gomez and his wife, Susan Rogler Gomez, would like to buy a house and move with their 2-year-old son from their rental apartment in the township. "A two-family appeals to us because of the security of the rental income," said Mr. Gomez, a public relations director at Home Box Office in Manhattan. Mrs. Gomez is a vice president at the Union Chelsea National Bank in Manhattan. "Based on the size," Mr. Gomez said, "we feel it's an excellent value."
A two-family house, he added, will "hold its value better than a condo and stands a good chance" of appreciating over time.
North Bergen welcomes the construction. Over the last four years the township has lost $100 million in revenues from properties with the departure of industries and tax appeals, said Joseph Auriemma, North Bergen's business administrator.
Besides Applied's move into Bergen Ridge, another developer has taken over the unbuilt portion of a project on one of the last buildable tracts along North Bergen's half-mile-long waterfront. The Barrett Companies of Ridgewood plans to turn the 14-acre site into twin 12-story buildings with a total of 500 apartments. Thomas J. Barrett, the company's president, said the first building would be marketed as a rental and the second as a condominium.
"This activity is the beginning of a resurgence for us," Mr. Auriemma said. "It is the type of development that will be a benefit to the township and a real opportunity to put ratables back on the tax rolls."
At Bergen Ridge, the brick-and-vinyl clapboard homes will be centered in the middle in four clusters, each with six to 16 units that follow the natural contours of the site.
The project will be reached from a road that will snake behind the homes. "The idea was to optimize the river views," said Erica Tishman of Peter DeWitt Architects of Manhattan, which did the site planning and building design for the project.
To fit all 34 houses on the site they will be attached, rather than separated by side yards. But buyers own the land beneath the house, and a 25-by-25-foot backyard. The project will also include an outdoor pool. Owners will pay a $100 yearly fee for the upkeep of the pool and common areas.
Prices are expected to start at $285,000 for the two-family houses, and at $345,000 for the three-family homes. The monthly rentals will be $800 to $1,000 for a one-bedroom apartment and $1,200 to $1,400 for a two-bedroom. Mr. Barry said mortgages at competitive rates with 5 to 10 percent down would be offered to buyers through two mortgage companies. Sales are to begin the week after Labor Day, he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Hurt by Stock Slump And Rate-Rise Hints in Europe

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly lower against leading currencies yesterday, weakened by a stock market slump and fresh signals that European nations might be ready to raise interest rates.
Investors also appear to have tired of waiting for the dollar to rally against European currencies, which have held firm as the dollar has risen against the Japanese yen. 
 In New York, the dollar settled at 110.35 yen, up from 110.30 on Wednesday. The dollar fell to 1.5216 marks from 1.5250. The British pound rose to $1.5533 from $1.5525.
"Some of the dollar selloff was born out of frustration." said Dennis Pettit, foreign exchange manager at the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan. "It's a combination of people worrying about stocks and also thinking maybe it's time to adjust stale long positions."
The dollar kept to narrow trading ranges in overseas markets, restrained by heavy purchases of option contracts betting on a continuing lack of price volatility.
But as the stock market began to sink in early New York trading, dropping the Dow Jones industrials as much as 133 points during the session, the dollar fell in sympathy.
"We saw modest selling pressure, mostly from speculators," said Marc Chandler, senior foreign exchange analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. "But today's move was exaggerated by thin market conditions and a few chunky orders."
The dollar tested technical support at 110 yen and 1.52 German marks, but ultimately found buyers at those levels.
Investors began to speculate that European interest rates might soon rise after the Bundesbank declined to cut German interest rates at its regular meeting.
There was also speculation that Belgium and the Netherlands were considering raising rates, which would make dollar-linked assets less appealing.
"That is perceived as negative for the dollar if it signals an end to the cycle of lower interest rates in Europe," Mr. Chandler said.
Talk that the Federal Reserve may delay an expected increase in United States short-term interest rates also weighed on the dollar.
The Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday that a new Federal Reserve study discussed a theory that when inflation was relatively low, policy makers should refrain from taking action.
"People would not appreciate the Fed taking such a laissez-faire approach," Mr. Pettit of the Long-Term Credit Bank said.

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
A Soft Landing?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
To most Americans it is an obscure corner of the world, not on the radar screen of concerns. But the Korean Peninsula in fact presents one of the most dangerous and difficult challenges to U.S. policy today.
The danger is of an unusual kind. It comes from the economic decline of a country whose totalitarian regime we detest, North Korea. We might take satisfaction in the troubles of an odious system, but neither American nor South Korean officials are indulging in such Schadenfreude. For the decline could lead to menacing instability, even military aggression. 
 For six years now, since it lost its subsidies from the Soviet Union and China, North Korea has had negative economic growth. Floods last year made an already bad food problem critical; recent escapees have reported incidents of starvation. A shortage of oil has cut the generation of electric power.
The fear in Seoul and Washington is that the Kim Jong Il regime could provoke a military conflict with South Korea as a distraction from its failure. Or, in another scenario, a collapse of the system could put an enormous economic and humanitarian burden on the South.
South Koreans used to see reunification of the peninsula under their system as a goal devoutly to be desired. Now they are not so unthinkingly enthusiastic. They know what absorption of an economically backward East Germany cost the German economy, and North Korea is a far worse case.
The South's economy grows as much every nine months as the total of North Korea's annual gross domestic product. Since the Korean War, per capita income here has grown from less than $100 a year to $10,000. It is the disparity in the two Koreas -- success and openness against failure and obsessive isolation -- that creates danger. No one can be sure what the Pyongyang regime may do under the pressure of failure.
The Clinton Administration's answer to the danger is a policy of "engagement" with North Korea. Two years ago it negotiated an agreement for Pyongyang to freeze its nuclear program in return for provision of non-menacing nuclear reactors and an interim supply of fuel oil. We have on the table, unanswered by Pyongyang, a proposal for four-party talks with the two Koreas and China on a Korean peace treaty.
Just now the U.S. promised $6.8 million in emergency food aid. But both Seoul and Washington have said that any more substantial assistance will be conditioned on North Korean willingness to talk about the four-party treaty proposal.
The aim of the engagement policy is to bring about change in North Korea with a "soft landing." The U.S. Ambassador to Seoul, James T. Laney, explained in an interview that the idea is to have North Korea open itself increasingly to foreign investment, make economic reforms and in return receive enough help to get through the immediate crisis.
"Military deterrents worked when the North Koreans had something to lose," the Ambassador said, meaning a functioning economy. "Now the problem is their descent into possible instability, with the chance of desperation or accident.
"The North is wobbly. If it wobbled onto the South, the consequences would be catastrophic.
"We have to find new ways of risk management. We don't do it out of any romantic notion that they've changed heart or that they deserve our assistance. They don't. It's a self-interested policy to reduce the risks of irrationality."
The thesis is that drawing North Korea gradually into the world, and the world into its economy, would give the regime a stake in more reasonable behavior. But can it be trusted to keep agreements?
"It's not as if we had no experience with their keeping an agreement," Ambassador Laney said. "We do, an important agreement," the nuclear freeze. American experts are now in North Korea encasing 8,000 spent fuel rods so they cannot be reprocessed into plutonium for bombs. And South Korean technicians are in the North surveying a site for a power reactor that Pyongyang at first refused to let the South supply.
"Their isolation is unsustainable," Mr. Laney said. "They have no choice."
But the question is whether Kim Jong Il and his colleagues will believe that their regime can survive "engagement," however rational it seems to us. Some here think they will not risk letting the world into North Korea.

HEADLINE: Democrats Drafting a Platform With a Corner for Dissent

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 11

 BODY:
Ostentatiously unified, a group of Democratic Party officials today finished the first stage of drafting a party platform that reflects President Clinton's policies across a range of issues but tries to remain broad enough so that Democrats who disagree with the President on particular points will not be antagonized.
Not one voice of dissent was raised in the two days that the party's Platform Drafting Committee met here. 
 The most vigorous advocates of abortion rights embraced new platform language worked out by the White House that states that the party, while unequivocally supporting legal, Government-financed abortions, respects "the individual conscience of each American on this difficult issue."
Advocates of gay rights did not complain that the rough draft under discussion today completely avoided the questions of same-sex marriages and homosexuals in the military.
Labor leaders accepted a section favoring trade expansion and extolling the President's push for the North American Free Trade Agreement, which the unions had strenuously opposed.
No one blinked an eye over the statement in the draft that "the era of big Government is over" -- a direct quotation from the President's State of the Union Message this year, but an observation that would have been unimaginable in a Democratic platform as recently as eight years ago.
The drill-team precision is quite a change for a party used to sit-ins, walk-outs and even riots over platform issues like civil rights and the Vietnam War.
This new-found unity comes on the 100th anniversary this week of the adoption of a party platform that laid the foundation for the Democratic Party of the 20th century, creating enthusiastic supporters on the one hand but driving legions of defectors into the laps of Republicans.
The party's convention in July 1896 in Chicago was where William Jennings Bryan gave his famous "Cross of Gold" speech, insisting on putting more money into circulation by the free coinage of silver. It was there that the party first adopted a platform advocating a graduated income tax. And it was there that the platform placed the party squarely on the side of labor unions and against big business.
But this year the Democrats are determined to stand peacefully on the sidelines and watch Republican platform battles over such issues as abortion and environmental protection.
"The tables are reversed this year," said Donald L. Fowler, the Democratic national chairman. "We're enjoying unity. They're miserable in their division. We're enjoying that a great deal."
The rough draft of the platform that was discussed by the drafting committee here this week will be modified and then voted on by the full Platform Committee at a meeting in Pittsburgh on Aug. 5. A final draft will go before the Democratic National Convention in Chicago on Aug. 27, the second night.
Unlike the situation in some parliamentary democracies, party platforms in the United States are hardly binding and, in fact, are often forgotten between one election year and the next. But they do help define the parties.
However the final wording turns out, the Democratic platform this year will undoubtedly favor legal abortion, support gun control, oppose discrimination against homosexuals and emphasize environmental protection.
The Republican platform, which is to be written in San Diego the first week in August, will surely advocate outlawing abortions, oppose gun control, oppose statutory civil rights for homosexuals and stress economic development over the environment.
Democrats are overwhelmingly in favor of free choice on abortion. But to avoid any rift over the matter like the one that has dominated Republican platform discussions, the White House produced a paragraph that seems destined to get into the final platform untouched. It states: "The Democratic Party is a party of inclusion. We respect the individual conscience of each American on this difficult issue, and we welcome all our members to participate at every level."
This comes right after the paragraph stressing the party's support for legal access to abortion regardless of a woman's ability to pay for it. And it comes just before a paragraph supporting contraceptive research and family planning.
Mr. Fowler interpreted the meaning this way: "We are a committed pro-choice party. That implies that people can choose for themselves in accordance with their own conscience."
The Democrats' platform this year has the same themes as the one in 1992, but several passages have been changed to conform with the politics of the last four years.
For instance, the 1992 platform supported equality for homosexuals in the military; the issue is not mentioned this year. The 1992 platform proclaimed the "right" of all Americans to "quality, affordable health care." The rough draft this year calls only for assuring that Americans have access to health insurance.
"This reflects reality today," Mr. Fowler said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Stock Decline Helps Bonds Rise 3d Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities gained for a third consecutive session yesterday as investors focused on inflation data due today and a swirl of opinions about Federal Reserve monetary policy.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 10/32 , to 87. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to yield 7.05 percent, from 7.08 percent on Wednesday. 
 Traders said investors took profits in early trading yesterday after the previous day's rally, pulling prices lower. But bonds recovered as stocks tumbled, prompting a flow of money out of stocks and into the short end of the Treasury market.
"Much of the flight to quality went into the bill market, which is the shortest and fastest and most liquid place to park assets while you're waiting for the next shoe to drop," said Jack Regan, chief market strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross.
Short-covering by investors who had bet that Treasury prices would fall also bolstered the market, he said, as did buying of longer maturities by hedge funds.
"But initially it was the money from the selling of stocks going into the bill market that propelled Treasury prices," Mr. Regan said.
Bill and note prices rose, with the rate on the six-month bill falling to 5.28 percent, from 5.31 percent on Wednesday, and the rate on the two-year note falling to 6.25 percent from 6.28 percent.
The market continued to be buffetted by speculation about the Federal Reserve's next step on interest rates. An article in The Wall Street Journal on Wednesday suggested to some investors that the Fed would hold steady on rates. It said a Fed paper took a new approach to monetary policy, arguing that when inflation is relatively low, as is the case now, policy makers should refrain from taking action.
An article in The Washington Post yesterday also reported on the paper and while both articles said that the study did not represent current Fed policy, the market did not see it that way until yesterday.
Other speculation about the Fed weighed on the market. A report by Johnson Smick, a Washington consulting firm led by former Fed officials, suggested that the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, would have raised rates if he had had the jobs report in hand at the meeting of Fed policy makers last week, said Kim Rupert, an economist with MMS International of San Francisco. The report said that Mr. Greenspan "gambled" by holding rates steady.
"That's what I believe took the market down early today," Ms. Rupert said. "Because the report was released late Wednesday night, the market did not get around to reacting to it until this morning."
At a time when investors are so uncertain about the direction of interest rates, such reports and speculation can have a greater effect on prices than at other times.
The market will turn its attention today to the latest inflation numbers. "We believe the Producer Price Index and retail sales for June will be market friendly," Mr. Regan of Josephthal, Lyon & Ross said. He expects an increase in the price index of one-tenth of 1 percent.
Today's retail data have "the potential to surprise on the strong side," Ms. Rupert of MMS International said, "especially considering recent strength in building materials and furniture sales."
But she said that the most recent weakness in the Johnson Redbook data and a slowdown in auto sales suggested that the retail reports would be soft.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Up 18,000 in Week

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits jumped by 18,000 last week, the Labor Department said today. The size of the increase surprised economists, who had been looking for a more modest gain of around 3,000.
New applications for jobless benefits totaled 369,000 for the week ending last Saturday. In the previous week, claims fell by 3,000. 
 The increase last week came after three weeks of improvement. The four-week moving average for claims also rose to 357,750, its highest level since April. It had been 355,500 the previous week.
Analysts cautioned against reading too much into the one-week change as the June unemployment rate hit a six-year low of 5.3 percent.

HEADLINE: Schoenberg Archives to Leave U.S.C.

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
The University of Southern California has agreed to give up its vast collection of musical scores, papers, drawings, writings and tapes of the composer Arnold Schoenberg and to pay half the cost of transferring the collection elsewhere, ending a bitter dispute with the Schoenberg heirs.
Spokesmen for both sides confirmed yesterday that the university, in Los Angeles, would turn over the archives, worth some $50 million, by the end of 1998. 
 While the family has not decided who will get the collection, several European institutions have made offers to the Schoenbergs, who are also talking to the New School for Social Research in Manhattan.
The family contends that the university repeatedly violated pledges it made 23 years ago to help preserve the legacy of Schoenberg, an inventor of 12-tone music and one of the most influential composers of the 20th century, who died in 1951 at 76. The archives contain 6,000 pages of Schoenberg's music, drawings, and writings; some 2,000 published volumes of music, and books, diaries, letters, and even a piano and his desk in a replica of his study.
In lawsuits and countersuits that cost the two sides hundreds of thousands of dollars, the heirs accused U.S.C. of violating its 1973 agreement not to use the institute building for purposes unrelated to Schoenberg's music. The family demanded that U.S.C. relinquish the materials and pay to have everything transferred to another site, including items given by other donors after the institute opened in 1977.
The university denied the family's charges and challenged many of the rights the family had claimed under the 1973 agreement. After a state court judge barred U.S.C. in January from using the institute for activities unrelated to Schoenberg, negotiations began toward yesterday's agreement.
The battle has drawn much of its heat from bitter animosity among key figures, as well as from differing assessments of Schoenberg's place in the ranks of great composers. The dispute also highlights the frequently sensitive issue of how much control donors should have over their gifts to institutions, and for how long.
Finally, it reflects the perils of shifting tastes. U.S.C. paid a high price to acquire the collection, only to find that over time, public interest in Schoenberg and his work had waned. "Schoenberg is simply not Beethoven," said a music scholar at U.S.C. who insisted on anonymity.
E. Randol Schoenberg, the composer's grandson, who represented the estate, said that "enticing" offers for the archives had come from the Hague, Vienna and Berlin, but that the Mannes College of Music, of the New School for Social Research, was also being considered as a new home for the archives, a possibility confirmed by Mannes. Officials at several other institutions said they had ruled out a bid for the collection, citing the Schoenbergs' stringent conditions, which, in one case, included a request that the institution pay up to $500,000 in legal fees incurred by the family in its battle.
Schoenberg scholars are dismayed at the prospect of losing the archives to Europe, which the Jewish composer, born in Austria, fled after the Nazis came to power.
"Because Schoenberg was also a teacher, painter, writer and theorist of music, the archives are a true slice of 20th century culture," said Walter Frisch, a music professor at Columbia University.
Claudio Spies, professor emeritus of music at Princeton, said it was "revolting" that the Schoenberg family, "three imbeciles who know nothing about music," would even consider transferring the collection to Berlin or Vienna, where Jews were so viciously persecuted. But Ronald R. Schoenberg, the composer's eldest son, said that the archives must go where they would receive the greatest respect.
U.S.C. officials said that however enthusiastic they were about the archives, keeping them under the conditions outlined in the 1973 agreement no longer made economic sense, given "shrinking funds for higher education," said Lloyd Armstrong Jr., U.S.C.'s provost since 1993. "We asked the family in the spring of 1995 for changes that would make the institute more cost-effective from an academic standpoint, but they refused."
To win the collection in 1973, U.S.C. pledged to found a Schoenberg Institute of Music to house the archives, and construct and staff a building. The institute, U.S.C. further agreed, would be used solely for concerts, lectures, research and events related to the music of Schoenberg, who lived for 17 years in Los Angeles before his death.
Under its first director, Leonard Stein, who had been a student of Schoenberg's, the institute held numerous conferences and recitals, and published a scholarly journal. When Mr. Stein retired in 1991, U.S.C., with strong prodding from the Schoenberg family, hired Paul Zukofsky, a highly regarded violinist and former director of chamber music at Juilliard.
But Mr. Zukofsky and the Schoenbergs soon clashed when, several people familiar with the dispute said, the new director began quarreling with the staff, shut down the institute's lectures and concerts and encouraged the disbanding of the Friends of the Arnold Schoenberg Institute, a 200-member group that raised money for the institute.
Mr. Zukofsky said in an interview that he had done all of these things at the family's urging. Whatever the case, the Schoenbergs accused Mr. Zukofsky of trying to eliminate their role in the institute. In a 1994 memo to a U.S.C. administrator, Mr. Zukofsky wrote, "I stipulate that I am intensely irritated by the Schoenbergs." While the institute's $350,000 annual budget -- less than one-twenty-fifth of one percent of U.S.C.'s annual budget -- was "perhaps too small to matter," he wrote, "I really have to ask why we are putting up with this."
U.S.C. seemed to agree. In a letter to the university's board in 1995, Mr. Armstrong, the provost, complained that the institute's recital hall was seldom used and not much visited by scholars. "We can't spend more than $300K per year," he wrote, "on an activity that has marginal positive impact on the university or the community beyond."
The lawsuit has cost U.S.C. hundreds of thousands of dollars; the university refuses to say how much. "If they had spent that money on the institute," said Judith Rosen, the founder of the now defunct friends' group, "there would be no problem." Meanwhile, U.S.C. announced in June that it had reached the halfway mark of a $1 billion endowment drive.
Several scholars said the rupture between U.S.C. and the family was caused partly by a clash of "visions" between the heirs and Mr. Zukofsky.
Ms. Rosen, who had supported Mr. Zukofsky on the U.S.C. search committee, said that once he got the job, he "antagonized everyone." "He totally misread the city," she said.
Ms. Rosen said she also blamed U.S.C. for the impending loss of the archives. "If Schoenberg had written music for a football marching band, we would have been a lot more successful," she said.
Mr. Zukofsky and U.S.C. officials said that the university had lavished attention on the institute, spending more than $5 million in the last 22 years on building and expanding its operations. Instead of mounting poorly attended concerts and lectures, he said, he had concentrated on "getting material in the archives published" and on creating an inventory of Schoenberg's letters, of great use to scholars.
Most parties agree that, in retrospect, the university was probably ill advised to have made the commitments it did in its 1973 contract. The clash, they note, coincided with a public decline in Schoenberg's music and growing attention to more popular culture.
"Maybe that is really what shocked the Schoenbergs," said Mr. Frisch of Columbia, "that the reverence for high musical tradition was no longer shared by everyone, particularly those who control money at universities."
