HEADLINE: A Market Ripe for Manipulation;
Laxity in London Opened Door for a Sumitomo Trader

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Anyone who has taken Economics 101 knows that the price of goods and services is determined by supply and demand.
But not in the copper market. Not until recently, at least. 
 The headlines last month trumpeting the dismissal by the Sumitomo Corporation of a copper trader who had racked up at least $1.8 billion in losses underscored what metals traders have known for years: The copper market, largely centered here in the frenetic "rings" of the London Metal Exchange, is more a gentlemen's club than a trading pit.
Loosely regulated and opaquely run, the exchange apparently gave the trader, Yasuo Hama naka, the cover he needed to masterfully manipulate the laws of supply and demand for perhaps as long as a decade, according to a number of traders and others familiar with the way the market operates.
Armed with Sumitomo's billions and what must have been a cast-iron stomach, Mr. Hama naka took huge positions, through the exchange and on the even less regulated over-the-counter market, in both physical copper and contracts for its future delivery. Capitalizing on weak disclosure rules, he was able to mask when and how much he was buying and selling on behalf of Sumitomo, the world's biggest supplier of processed copper. That let him confuse other traders about the true size of his holdings and thus the real level of global demand.
Indeed, Mr. Hamanaka seems to have come as close as any trader ever has to controlling a global market for an extended period of time, earning the moniker "Mr. Copper" for his ability to affect prices. Usually, he would use that power to push prices up. If a wave of selling put downward pressure on his position, he appeared to have an almost limitless ability to keep buying and thus prop up the price.
For years, those maneuvers presumably filled the coffers of his employer in two ways. One was through sales, by another arm of the company, of processed copper at the premium price. The other was from big bets that Mr. Hamanaka placed in the futures market -- bets that the price would indeed rise.
"No one is bigger than the market, but Hamanaka was bigger than the market at times and he used that to keep prices high," said one longtime London Metal Exchange trader who spoke on condition of anonymity.
But the laws of supply and demand can be manipulated for only so long, even in the murky world of copper. Regulators here eventually got on the case, prodded by their American counterparts as well as by recent scandals involving other "rogue" traders. And convinced that Mr. Hamanaka had manipulated the market into an artificially high zone, hedge funds and other short-sellers ganged up on him, throwing huge sums of their own into a game of chicken to force the price down.
"At some point this spring, it was obvious that the battle was unwinnable" by Mr. Hamanaka, one trader at a major American investment bank said. "You could detect a sense of desperation in his trades, a wildness that indicated things weren't working out quite like he had calculated."
When Mr. Hamanaka lost the game in mid-May, and copper prices started to collapse, the effect was devastating to both him and his company. His whereabouts undisclosed, Mr. Hamanaka has issued no public statements. Sumitomo, which insists that Mr. Hamanaka's trades were unauthorized and that his losses were just as much a surprise to management as they were to the public, may be out as much as $4 billion when all the dust clears, some traders said.
Whether Sumitomo came out a net winner or loser during the Hamanaka years is not known, however, since he is thought to have made plenty of money for the company before the collapse.
But everyone else has had to foot the bill, at least in a small way. Mr. Hamanaka artificially raised the price of copper an average of 5 cents a pound on the spot market during the last five years or so, the longtime London Metal Exchange trader estimated, a period when it traded at between 73 cents and $1.46 a pound. The added expense would have been passed on from traders to processors to manufacturers of goods containing copper to, eventually, consumers.
Mystery still surrounds the debacle, with many in the business puzzled about numerous aspects of Mr. Hamanaka's operation and increasingly skeptical that Sumitomo could have been in the dark for so long. In fact, Merrill Lynch & Company, which maintained two trading accounts used by Mr. Hamanaka, has said those accounts were authorized by his superiors, an arrangement that Sumitomo denies. It is not even clear whether anything Mr. Hamanaka did was illegal.
 
A Lack of Oversight
Self-Regulation With a Twist
What is clear, however, is that the copper market's loose structure enabled, if not encouraged, the kind of over-the-top trading that could lead to a multibillion-dollar loss:
*The London Metal Exchange, like many other British financial institutions, has been largely self-regulated, unfettered by the degree of government oversight that American exchanges receive. Historically, the London exchange's top officials hold interests in both the trading and mining of copper and other metals, leaving the exchange open to questions about possible conflicts of interest. The current chairman, Raj K. Bagri, together with his family owns a $600 million copper processing company, Metdist Ltd. When he took the chairman's job, which is unpaid, in 1993, Mr. Bagri assigned day-to-day operations to his son. American exchanges have stringent rules governing such holdings, including mandatory recusal from oversight responsibilities if a conflict arises. The London exchange apparently has less rigorous protections.
*The availability of information about trading, or the degree of so-called transparency, is limited on the exchange, which sets the benchmark price for copper. Only positions of 15,000 tons or more must be reported by exchange members, and then only privately to the exchange's chief executive. By contrast, members of the Comex, a division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, are required to publicly report positions of as little as 1,000 tons.
*Much trading here in copper and other metals is done over the counter in the form of futures contracts negotiated between two or more parties outside the official market, and thus beyond the London exchange's purview. In the United States, futures contracts must be traded on an exchange.
*Unlike the Commodity Futures Trading Commission in the United States, which in recent years has pursued even minor trading violations with a Rottweiler-like intensity, the London exchange has relied on more gentle persuasion, typically calling in members and traders for a chat about transgressions. In extreme cases, the exchange has imposed limitations on prices to bring them in line with the real supply and demand, rather than impose sanctions against individuals who might have monkeyed with the market.
*Traders on the London exchange are allowed to meet daily margin calls with credit, rather than cash, letting them amass large positions without attracting the attention of their corporate treasurers, who would otherwise have to cut them checks. The Comex requires cash.
Even before the debacle, the London Metal Exchange was seeking to bring at least some, if not all, over-the-counter trading under its supervision, something that is now virtually a certainty.
But David E. King, chief executive of the exchange, staunchly defended its other idiosyncrasies as essential to London's success as a free and open market. He insisted that charges that it lacks regulatory zeal are merely sour grapes from the Comex, which has lost most of its market share in copper to London in recent years.
"The regulatory structure here since the mid-1980's has been very robust and in fact compares well with the regulatory environment in the United States," he said. "The complaints being made, in my view, are purely for competitive reasons."
 
Market Puppeteer
Smoke, Mirrors, Squeeze Plays
Still, Mr. Hamanaka was able to take full advantage of the London exchange's idiosyncrasies. While traders and regulators suspected that he was hoarding copper, for example, no one could be sure because he spread his trades among brokers, thus eluding the 15,000-ton reporting threshold.
In fact, most of his business was conducted in the over-the-counter market and thus out of regulatory reach. Mr. Hamanaka shunned the Comex, not only because it lacks the liquidity needed for the volume of trading he was doing, but also, he said in past interviews, because its regulations were too stringent.
And the London exchange, when it was first alerted to Mr. Hamanaka's problematic activities five years ago, thought it adequate to hold a discussion to air its concerns with him and another Sumitomo executive. Exchange officials were apparently satisfied with the explanation they received about a request for verification of fictitious trades that Mr. Hamanaka sought from an exchange member, David L. Threlkeld, in 1991. The officials were told that the request had been made only to resolve a tax matter in Japan and was of no relevance to the exchange.
In short, Mr. Hamanaka worked the copper market like a skilled puppeteer. In squeeze plays in 1991 and again in 1993, he used his control of large supplies of copper scattered around the globe to leverage prices sharply higher, traders said. Some even suspect that less blatant manipulation by Mr. Hamanaka kept copper prices at artificially high levels throughout the years that he was a star trader at Sumitomo.
 
New Players
Short-Sellers And Regulators
But late last summer, when Mr. Hama naka was preparing for a third squeeze, he found himself confronting vastly different forces in a market that had begun to develop defenses to his standard manipulation.
Following financial disasters at Kidder, Peabody, Barings, and Daiwa that were apparently orchestrated by rogue traders whose bosses were asleep at the switch so long as profits seemed to flow in, regulators in markets across the world were on red alert.
And since Mr. Hamanaka's last squeeze in 1993, hedge funds and other speculative investors had become active in the metals markets.
Such players as Tiger Management and George Soros's Quantum Fund, two of the largest and most successful hedge funds, looked at the price of copper last August -- when the spot price was $1.35 to $1.40 a pound -- cranked some supply figures through their economic models and decided prices were destined to fall.
They started going short -- borrowing and selling copper with the hope of buying it back later at a lower price, pocketing any difference as profit.
Meanwhile, traders believe, Mr. Hama naka was trying to push prices higher That meant whenever the funds sold, he or someone else had to buy to keep the price up.
The push-and-pull contest took on epic proportions. At one point earlier this year, brokers estimate, the hedge funds held almost one million metric tons of copper in short positions, an amount equal to nearly 8.5 percent of the world's total consumption of refined copper of 11.9 million tons last year.
And still the price did not fall far enough. Quantum finally dropped out of the fight in March, when prices declined somewhat, to about $1.15 to $1.18 a pound. Quantum has not said whether it made or lost money.
 
Numbers Crunch
Alarms Sound About a Glut
But there was more than hedge funds at work. Reports of rising stocks of copper started appearing late last summer, reports that the market initially ignored.
Statistics for copper and other metals had become unreliable for several reasons. The European Union, moving toward a single market in 1997, had begun calculating imports and exports among its member countries differently; the World Bureau of Statistics estimated that the new method resulted in an overstatement of copper consumption by 225,000 tons in 1993 and 250,000 tons in 1994.
The breakup of the Soviet Union also jumbled the data. Sometimes, Russia would not report trade with one or another former republic because it still regarded them as part of itself. And exports from Kazakhstan, a large copper-producing region, were underreported or not reported at all, which led analysts to underestimate supplies in the West.
Peter Hollands, an analyst at Bloomsbury Minerals Economics, a metals consulting firm in London, said that for a period last year, the discrepancy between the high and low estimates of copper stocks was roughly 600,000 tons.
Eventually, a growing number of analysts started sounding alarms about copper supplies outstripping demand.
 
Prodding From U.S.
Turning Up The Heat
Early in 1995, officials at the London exchange began to receive pointed letters from Mary L. Schapiro, then commissioner of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission in Washington. Ms. Schapiro, now head of Nasdaq's regulatory arm, had been trying to raise the commission's profile by cleaning up the commodities business, where someone always seems to be trying to corner a market, as the Hunts tried to do with silver in 1980.
The London exchange drew Ms. Schapiro's interest because of its plan to open a warehouse in Long Beach, Calif., for the storage and delivery of copper. The exchange had warehouses for other metals in the United States, but this one, which opened in April 1995, was widely regarded among traders as nothing short of a bold bid to take away enough business from the Comex to push it out of the copper market.
In a recent interview, Mr. King, the London exchange's chief executive, denied having such a goal. "The rationale for establishing Long Beach was to supply Southeast Asia," he said. "We could not keep up with demand out of our warehouse in Singapore, and while we would have liked to open one in Japan, Taiwan or South Korea, it would have taken more time."
Still, the Long Beach warehouse became a Pandora's box for the exchange, since it gave Ms. Schapiro a reason to look into its activities. Several members of the exchange's governing committee -- some say including Mr. King, who declined to disclose his vote -- had objected to opening the warehouse for just that reason, to no avail. "A considerable number of us knew that it was just going to get up the noses of the Americans," one member said.
In any event, in March 1995, Ms. Schapiro wrote a letter to Mr. Bagri, the exchange's chairman, expressing concerns. About six months later, the C.F.T.C. began investigating copper trading activities in London, seeking to determine their impact on the American market.
Officials of the C.F.T.C. say they started the inquiry because they felt frustrated in trying to obtain information about large market positions from their London counterparts. For their part, officials at the exchange have said British law constrains them from both gathering and sharing some of what was sought.
By late fall, spot prices for copper were vastly higher than prices for future delivery -- a reversal of the normal state of affairs since futures prices typically factor in interest costs and storage charges.
The reversal, a hallmark of earlier Hamanaka squeezes that is known as a backwardation, made no sense in light of mounting evidence that copper supplies exceeded demand. The London exchange and the Securities and Investments Board, something of a super-regulator of Britain's financial markets, joined the American agency in its search for an explanation.
This time, the exchange did not call Mr. Hamanaka and Sumitomo in for a chat. Instead, its board gave Mr. King a mandate to get to the bottom of the squeeze.
Some American traders speculate that the exchange and other British investigators got tougher because Mr. Hamanaka was now funneling much of his business through an American firm, the Global Minerals and Metals Corporation, instead of his traditional broker, Winchester Commodities. Winchester, which one trader described as the "longtime bete noire" of the London exchange, had ties to the British political establishment through Charles (Copper Fingers) Vincent, a member of the English elite who founded the firm.
In any case, Mr. King's investigative committee apparently failed to find a smoking gun. It disbanded without taking action, handing over the information it collected to the Securities and Investments Board.
Meanwhile, rumors that Sumitomo controlled 70 percent of the copper in the Long Beach warehouse -- an amount that would constitute a potent weapon in any attempt to further manipulate prices -- kept the C.F.T.C. in the investigation.
 
Day of Reckoning
Mr. Copper Finally Blinks
On May 17, when the spot price was $1.21 a pound, another rumor swept through the copper market, one big enough to make it move -- and fast. "Hamanaka had been removed from his post; Hamanaka had absconded with millions; Hamanaka had been given a promotion -- whatever version of the rumor you got, it all boiled down to Hamanaka's being out of the market," said one trader.
For reasons that remain unclear, Mr. Hamanaka, or more likely his superiors at Sumitomo, had finally blinked. When the hedge funds and other speculators sold short that day, no one answered by buying. Prices fell 12 percent in two days.
Sumitomo put out the word that Mr. Hamanaka had been promoted and would not be trading any longer. Prices continued to fall. And on June 16, the giant trading company said that "Mr. Copper" had been dismissed. Since then, copper has fallen to a low of 83 cents a pound on June 27, a drop of 31 percent since May 17. [It closed in London Thursday at 88 cents.]
The Securities and Investments Board is now conducting a review of the exchange with an eye toward ending some of its idiosyncrasies. Among other things, London is likely to gain more power to regulate non-members like Sumitomo.
But some fear one more negative result of the Sumitomo scandal -- that in the zeal to reform the market, regulators may go too far and cripple its free-wheeling nature. Its business would almost certainly dry up, for instance, were clients required to put up cash for daily margin calls.
"One of the beauties of the market is that it has limited regulation, which allows it to function fluidly," said Roman Borkowski, managing director of F.L.T. & Metals Ltd., a division of the Polish metals company Impex. "And one of the bad things is that it has limited regulation, which allows people, if they're big enough and rich enough, to abuse it. Somewhere, there has to be at least a narrow path between those two extremes."

HEADLINE: Freeholders Eliminate County Police In Hudson

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, July 11

 BODY:
The Hudson County Board of Freeholders said it had no choice, but when it voted this evening to disband the county's 82-officer Police Department, the officers who packed the meeting room said they had been betrayed.
"I've done good work for this department for 11 years," Officer Donald Dixon said. "We're getting stuck, and it's a hurting pain, because these are people who have lived and worked in this county." 
 In a loud and bitter meeting that lasted through the afternoon, officers and their supporters alternately pleaded and argued with the freeholders. More than 200 people spilled from the hot boardroom out into the hall, many wearing T-shirts that read, "Save the Hudson County Police/To Protect and Serve." But ultimately the board voted, 7 to 2, to eliminate the Police Department.
County officials have said the decision to close the department, whose members patrol the county's parks and roads and operate the county 911 emergency call system, reflects a cold economic reality: expenses rising faster than the county's tax base can support. The County Executive, Robert C. Janiszewski, has said he was forced to make drastic cuts by a $17 million shortfall on a $323 million budget. Closing the department would save about $3 million per year, county officials have said.
But opponents have argued that costs will merely be passed along to municipalities, whose officers will be forced to take up the county force's duties.
At least three other northern New Jersey counties -- Essex, Bergen and Union -- have small county departments that supplement municipal forces, as Hudson's does. But officials in those counties have said they plan to maintain their departments.
The Hudson County force contrasts with a large, full-service county operation like that of Suffolk County in New York State, which acts as the primary law enforcement agency in its area.
But the supporters of the Hudson County department have said the officers provide experienced backup for municipal officers, and relieve them of the burden of patrolling highways and parks. The county public safety director, Glenn Cunningham, told the Board of Freeholders that municipalities would have to begin assigning officers to patrol those areas.
"A sham is being played on you freeholders," Mr. Cunningham said.
In 1995, Hudson County police officers issued 47,800 tickets and responded to 1,916 accidents on the 15 county roads they patrol. They made 579 arrests, including 40 in county parks, and also arrested 154 people on warrants.
One of the blows to the department came from a reorganization of the state courts, which now send revenues from motor vehicle tickets to the municipality in which they are issued rather than to the county. The Hudson County police used to receive $3 million in revenue from traffic summonses, about the same amount the county expects to save by eliminating the department.

HEADLINE: Broader Warrants Issued for 2 Bosnian Serbs

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS 

DATELINE: THE HAGUE, July 11

 BODY:
The United Nations war crimes tribunal issued international arrest warrants today for the Bosnian Serbs' political leader, Radovan Karadzic, and their military chief, Gen. Ratko Mladic, who are charged with genocide and other crimes in the four-year Bosnian war.
The warrants oblige members of the United Nations to arrest the men if they enter their countries. But the warrants are unlikely to have any immediate effect because Western countries have not been willing to have their peacekeeping troops in Bosnia seek the two leaders out. 
 For the first time, the tribunal also called publicly for an investigation to determine whether President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia shares responsibility for war crimes in the Bosnian conflict. The Bosnian fighting has taken tens of thousands of lives, uprooted millions of people and adding "ethnic cleansing" to the world's vocabulary.
By openly extending the tribunal's inquiry to Mr. Milosevic, the three-judge panel has taken a step that some Western officials had hoped to postpone, since they see the cooperation of the Serbian President, who faces a reimposition of sanctions, as vital to the continuing peace effort.
The tribunal has reportedly been secretly gathering evidence about Mr. Milosevic for some time. But today the three judges made formal a decision to investigate whether the Serbian President -- who supported the neighboring Bosnian Serbs in their effort to conquer parts of Bosnia -- should be held accountable for crimes committed in the military campaign, such as deliberate, large-scale killings of civilians.
Judge Claude Jorda of France, who first read out charges against Dr. Karadzic and General Mladic, said the court had no choice but to ask the prosecution "to investigate decision-making responsibility at the same, or higher level."
Documents and testimony in the hands of the court, he said, suggested "that a plan existed, designed at the highest Serbian political and military level, to set up a new state through the use of violence" in Bosnia. Judge Jorda avoided using Mr. Milosevic's name at this point. But in their written decision, the judges referred to communications in 1991 in which Mr. Milosevic and Dr. Karadzic discussed their plans for the coming war.
In an interview, a court official said the call to investigate "higher levels of responsibility" amounted to an announcement that the tribunal was looking into the Serbian President's possible personal responsibility for war crimes.
The issuing of international arrest warrants against the two central figures of the Bosnian war is the strongest measure the tribunal can take, short of trying the accused, which it cannot do in their absence.
Indictments and local arrest warrants for the two men were issued last year and sent to the authorities in Belgrade, Pale (the Bosnian Serb headquarters) and Sarajevo, and to the Governments of Britain, France, the United States and Switzerland. The tribunal is essentially the creation of Western countries, which, however, have been unwilling to have peacekeeping troops in Bosnia arrest the the leaders, or to use economic sanctions to press the Bosnian Serbs or Serbia to hand them over to The Hague, as called for under the Dayton peace accords.
With the new arrest warrants, which are broader than the existing ones, the tribunal hopes to increase pressure on the West to have the suspects arrested. But if a country refuses, the tribunal can do little more than complain to the United Nations Security Cuncil.
Christian Chartier, a spokesman for the court, said that today's decision "puts the burden on the international community to live up to its commitment to the court and carry out its decisions."
The arrest warrants and call for investigation of Mr. Milosevic came a year after the Bosnian Serb takeover of the town of Srebrenica. Western officials believe that thousands of Muslim men and boys were massacred in the following days, an event that figures prominently in the indicments of the two leaders.
As part of its effort to press the West to arrest the Bosnian Serb leaders, for the past two weeks the tribunal has held hearings to present evidence against them. The fate of Srebrenica and of many other Muslim towns and villages was described in detail.
"War and darkness descended upon Bosnia and Herzegovina, a culturally rich and diverse land and the toll in human lives has been enormous," the prosecutor said. "The fury and cruelty of ethnic cleansing have shocked the conscience of the world."
The prosecutors said that in addition to the killing, torture and rape of tens of thousands of civilians, Bosnian Serbs destroyed 1,123 mosques, 504 Roman Catholic churches, 5 synagogues and had also targeted cemeteries and monasteries in their effort to create purely Serbian regions. While some Croats and Muslims also committed atrocities, Bosnian Serb crimes were more systematic and centrally directed, officials have charged.
In his summary today, Judge Jorda said "Ethnic cleansing, it seems, was not the byproduct of the war, but rather its aim."
In announcing today's ruling, the three-judge panel unanimously confirmed the existing indictments against Dr. Karadzic and General Mladic.
In their ruling today, the judges also expanded other charges against Dr. Karadzic and General Mladic. In the indictments, the two leaders have been charged with "command responsibility" for genocide and other crimes of war. But the judges ruled that they are also "personally responsible" for the crimes with which they are charged, a definition which aggravates their culpability. The court's decision said that Dr. Karadzic and General Mladic "were not only informed of the crimes allegedly committed under their authority, but also, and in particular, they exercised their power in order to plan, instigate, order or otherwise aid and abet in the planning, preparation and execution of the said crimes."
The judges said that the offenses were committed in keeping with "a political program and institutional and military organizations."

HEADLINE: Market Place: Stocks Plunge on More Signs of Weaker Corporate Earnings;
Some Wonder if Party's Over For Technology High-Fliers

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The list of corporate casualties in the technology field is lengthening. It's easy to dismiss an Apple Computer or a Digital Equipment as troubled companies bedeviled by problems of their own making. But with two blue-chip bellwethers, Motorola and Hewlett-Packard, surprising Wall Street this week with announcements of slowing business, it raises questions about the outlook for technology shares in general.
Skittish investors expressed their concerns yesterday by driving the price of technology stocks down sharply. The Pacific Stock Exchange index of 100 technology companies fell more than 4 percent yesterday, and the technology index has dropped more than 17 percent in less than two months. 
 Yesterday's selloff was prompted by a statement from the Hewlett-Packard Company late Wednesday, after markets had closed, that orders for its computers and printers were slowing. Lewis E. Platt, the chairman, acknowledged that he did not know whether the slowdown was seasonal or "a fundamental shift in the business climate."
High marks for candor, but head-scratching uncertainty is not what technology investors want to hear from the head of the second-largest computer maker. Hence the rush to the exits. Shares of Hewlett-Packard fell $10.625, to $78.375. And the retreat was indiscriminate, hitting all the major technology companies: Microsoft down $5, to $114.50; Intel down $3.375, to $69.50; I.B.M. off $2.875, to $96, and Compaq down $2.875, to $43.75. .
The easing of technology-stock prices has come in waves, starting with semiconductor shares last fall. Bruce Lupatkin, director of research for Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco, calls it a "rolling correction." But he added: "It's really been in the last three weeks that we've had consistently ugly days. A lot of people feel that it's over for technology stocks."
Investors, Mr. Lupatkin notes, are going to be giving the earnings reports of all technology companies close scrutiny as more of them report financial results for the quarter ended in June. A few of those reports, depending on how the results square with Wall Street expectations, could steady or unsettle the technology sector.
For example, Intel, the chip maker, will report its results after the market closes next Tuesday. Microsoft, the software leader, will announce its quarterly results after the market closes on July 22. Compaq, the leading producer of personal computers, will report on July 24. And I.B.M., the largest computer maker, reports on July 25.
Many analysts insisted yesterday's rout was a hasty overreaction. Technology stocks are notoriously volatile but, they say, the long-term outlook for them remains bright. "I think this is the panic bottom," said Michael Murphy, editor of the California Technology Stock Letter.
The underlying trend of continued heavy investment in information technology, economists say, shows no sign of letting up. Spending on computers and telecommunications now represents 40 percent of total capital spending by corporate America, up steadily from 20 percent in 1981, when I.B.M. introduced its first personal computer.
"I don't know about Hewlett-Packard, but the explosive upward trajectory of investment in information technology is not slowing down," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist of Morgan Stanley & Company. "Corporate America's addiction to technology has never been greater."
The upward trend in technology investment has been mirrored in stock prices. Since October 1990, the Pacific Stock Exchange technology index has increased nearly fourfold, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has doubled.
Yet the long view is often scant comfort to investors on Wall Street, where history is defined as yesterday's trading. Besides, as recently as a few weeks ago, analysts were confidently predicting that the bottom had been reached in technology stocks, only to see things get worse.
"We've seen not only depressed financial results, but they're depressing," said Rick Whittington, an analyst for the Soundview Financial Group in Stamford, Conn. "We need to see encouraging results from some of the leading technology companies in the next week or two."

HEADLINE: In America;
Trampled Dreams

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Ask Cicih Sukaesih about her dreams and you will hear a long, long silence. She has none. In Indonesia, a woman who is 32 years old, unmarried, broke and unemployed keeps her thoughts focused on the short term. Each day is an emergency.
Ms. Sukaesih used to earn about a dollar a day working in a factory that made athletic shoes for one of the world's premier marketers of dreams, Nike Inc. It wasn't much of a living. A study of women in similar circumstances in 1989 had shown that 88 percent were malnourished. 
 In 1991 the legally required minimum wage was raised to a dazzling $1.25 a day. But the operators of the Sung Hwa Dunia factory in Serang, West Java, where Ms. Sukaesih worked, refused to pay it. The staggering wealth of the big shots at the top of Nike's pyramid depends on the laborers at the bottom being paid next to nothing. This time the laborers balked. Six hundred workers who were barely earning enough to feed themselves walked out of the Sung Hwa Dunia plant. The police and the military, trained to suppress labor unrest, were quickly alerted. Investigations were begun. The 600 workers walked back in.
Still, an example had to be made. In January 1992, Ms. Sukaesih and 23 others who had dared to demand that their employers pay the minimum wage were dismissed.
I talked with Ms. Sukaesih by phone Wednesday night. Speaking through an interpreter, she described the working conditions in the factory. "We were not treated with respect," she said. "Many of the supervisors were from Korea. They yelled at us. There were some that liked to hit people, slap people. There were some who would kick the Muslim workers when they were praying during their lunch break."
The factory has since been taken over by different operators (also under contract to Nike) and the name has been changed to Eltri Indo Footwear. The abusive practices reportedly have ceased and the minimum wage, now a little over $2 a day, is being paid. But Ms. Sukaesih and her co-workers have not been rehired. They have sued and their case is now languishing before the Indonesian supreme court.
Ms. Sukaesih will be in the United States next week to tell her story. Her trip is being paid for by labor and human rights activists who want Nike to settle the claims of workers who have been unfairly dismissed, and agree to independent monitoring as a safeguard against abuses in the factories.
Ms. Sukaesih has no money of her own and her prospects are dim. She is already considered old for factory work. "They want young girls," she said. "At my age you have to pay a bribe to a security guard just to apply for a job."
Meanwhile, the women who are working are only marginally better off than Ms. Sukaesih. There is a widely held notion -- and Philip Knight, Nike's chief executive officer, does nothing to discourage it -- that minimum-wage workers in Indonesia are paid enough to live reasonably comfortable lives. That is not so.
Many of the working women live in bamboo or tin dwellings with no running water and nothing in the way of appliances. Apong Herlina, a lawyer with the Legal Aid Institute, tells the heartbreaking story of women from the countryside who have come to the cities for work but do not earn enough to have their children with them. The children remain in the country, being cared for by relatives.
"These women work a tremendous amount," Ms. Herlina said, "but there is not enough money for transportation or time to travel the long distances to visit their children. They see them once a year, during holiday. The rest of the year they grieve."
Dreams fade into nothingness in the long, grim hours in the factories. The workers who live with their children face a struggle each day just to feed them. And then it's back to work in the shadow of the Nike "Swoosh."
The system works fabulously for Mr. Knight and his team of celebrity hucksters, led by the inimitable Michael Jordan. Mr. Knight's holdings were recently estimated at more than $5 billion. I spoke with Mr. Knight on Wednesday, too. He noted that Indonesians were lining up for jobs in factories that make Nikes. And he said that it would wreck the country's economy if wages were allowed to get too high.
"How much would you pay them?" he asked.

HEADLINE: Netanyahu, in New York, Promotes His Views on Peace and Invites Investments

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
Returning with new stature to an intimately familiar venue, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel switched his oratorial skill and boyish charm to full volume yesterday as he urged New York City's Jewish population to embrace his approach to peace in the Middle East and to invigorating the Israeli economy.
In a polyrhythmic opening day of a three-day visit -- his first as Prime Minister -- to New York, the loquacious Mr. Netanyahu spoke in ballrooms packed with Jewish leaders, met with politicians and lunched with businessmen on Wall Street, all in a tightly choreographed effort to find common ground and mitigate differences among a population he feels is important to his success. 
 He sounded many of the same themes that he had evoked during his two days in Washington, but to a decidedly different and divided audience, including many who are deeply skeptical, if not hostile, toward his ideology.
Seeking to calm the apprehensions of many New York Jews, Mr. Netanyahu, 46, spent an hour fielding questions from a gathering of 400 people sponsored by the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations.
He reiterated his emphasis on Israeli security and his devotion to privatizing the economy.
Pressed on his hard-line views on achieving peace in the Middle East, he said: "It is reciprocity. We keep commitments. You keep commitments. We insist the deal be kept on both sides."
Once again, he declared that "Jerusalem has to remain undivided, with one government, not two."
On the matter of Palestinian aspirations, he said: "I'm going to say to the Palestinians, you run your own affairs. We're not interested in running your lives, so long as Israelis gain security."
On another issue of great concern to non-Orthodox Jews, his intimations that he would roll back gains made by Conservative and Reform movements in Israel, Mr. Netanyahu was emphatic: "We'd said we'd preserve the status quo. We stand our ground. We'll keep the status quo."
For the most part, the Prime Minister was nimble in his handling of questions, though not entirely lifting the clouds of ambiguity from his positions.
The audience was polite if not overly enthusiastic in its response. Rabbi Norman Patz of Cedar Grove, N.J., though more liberal in viewpoint than the Prime Minister, said, "I'm very impressed by his ability to think on his feet."
At an address in the evening to a more diverse crowd of some 3,000 people invited by the Jewish Community Relations Council, Mr. Netanyahu received an appreciably more exuberant reception. He was interrupted several times by standing ovations, and the event seemed to take on the feel of a pep rally.
The Prime Minister spoke passionately about the importance of Jewish continuity and unity. "It seems to me that the great task of Zionism today," he said, "is to reinforce Jewish identity." He implored Americans, especially young people, to go to Israel in a "physical and spiritual airlift."
Afterward, his security agents were to usher him quickly from the ballroom at the Sheraton New York Hotel, but to their dismay he jumped down from the stage and waded into the huge crowd, shaking hands and exchanging cordialities.
Much of his day had been devoted to impressing on his audiences his dedication to economic reform.
In a luncheon address before some 150 business and financial executives in the board room of the New York Stock Exchange, Mr. Netanyahu made a strong plea for investment in Israel, which he said would pay bountiful dividends as he carries out his pledge to privatize and deregulate the Israeli economy.
It marked the first time a Prime Minister of Israel had visited the stock exchange, and may well have been the first kosher lunch (grilled chicken) served there.
Introduced by Ronald Lauder, the cosmetics heir who has been an ardent supporter, Mr. Netanyahu, who does not adhere to a Kosher diet, nevertheless made a point of thanking his hosts for the kosher food. "That's essential when you try to keep coalitions together," he said. "Don't knock it."
In a brief talk, he vowed that he would succeed in privatizing state-owned industry, lifting regulatory barriers and lowering taxes. "I think Israel has the greatest potential of any economy in the world," he said. "That's because we have twin curses that become twin blessings." He identified these as the fact that Israel has a strong scientific and technological base because of its large defense industry, and the fact that Israel has not had capitalism, meaning no obsolete industries to dismember.
"My bottom line -- I hate to use the word bottom line -- is I'd like you to come to Israel because it's good for Israel, and I'd like you to come to Israel because you'll make money," he said.
Yielding to the security concerns of the Israeli agents who attended him, he demurred from strolling the stock trading floor, as visiting dignitaries customarily do. But he did make a brief appearance at the floor's podium, at a time when the stock market was 132 points in retreat.
"I don't know what to say: 'Buy, Sell, Buy, Sell,' " he said. Given the turmoil on the floor, the traders screamed, "Buy," and he responded in kind.
Mr. Netanyahu is a comfortable presence in New York City, where he has many friends from the 1980's when he was Israel's delegate to the United Nations. He attended high school and college in the United States and worked as a management consultant during his 16 years in this country.
Throughout the morning, as he held court for local political leaders at his suite at the Stanhope Hotel on Fifth Avenue and 81st Street, several hundred people stood transfixed across the street, cordoned off behind metal fencing, anxious for a glimpse of the young and charismatic Prime Minister.
Mr. Netanyahu began the day with perfunctory visits with Gov. George E. Pataki and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. Governor Pataki said they spoke about trade and peace, and joked about the fact that both of their election campaigns were orchestrated by Arthur Finkelstein.
Governor Whitman, after her brief visit, said that the Prime Minister wanted to know about her privatization and tax reduction efforts in New Jersey.
The Prime Minister also received Bob Dole, who told Mr. Netanyahu that ties with Israel will be stronger if he is elected President. The Prime Minister danced away from even the suggestion of an endorsement. Mr. Dole also jokingly told the Prime Minister that he "wanted to look up his pollster."
In the afternoon, Mr. Netanyahu met with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a friend for 12 years, and told him that he admired some of his moves in shifting city functions to the private sector and planned to borrow from those ideas. "It turns out that New York and Israel are not that different in this matter," Mr. Netanyahu told the Mayor. He also complimented Mr. Giuliani on making the city cleaner and better in several ways than it was when he was living here.
The Prime Minister collected a bevy of mementoes during his trips around the city. After the stock exchange luncheon, the chairman of the exchange gave him a Bull and Bear statue that he said he would take to the Knesset as "the weapon of choice."
The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations gave him two Mets jackets, one for him and one for his wife. He was told that "Mets" actually stood for "Middle East Terrorist Stopper."
"I can only hope these are flak jackets," Mr. Netanyahu said.

HEADLINE: President Announces Plan To Encourage School Repair

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
Seeking to expand the Federal role in repairing public schools, President Clinton announced today that he would ask Congress for $5 billion to help straighten sagging roofs, seal cracked foundations and fix other problems nationwide over the next four years.
While acknowledging that education is a major issue in the President's re-election campaign, officials said formulation of the new program was prompted partly by reports by the General Accounting Office over the last year and a half that found $112 billion in pressing construction needs, including poor heating, broken plumbing, and electrical wiring that is inadequate for running computers. 
 "Too many school buildings and classrooms are literally a shambles," Mr. Clinton said today in the White House Rose Garden. "We cannot expect our children and our teachers to build strong lives on a crumbling foundation."
Administration officials said they were still working on a formula for awarding the money, but that it would be weighted toward the neediest communities. One Administration official said New York State could expect as much as $400 million to $500 million.
The officials said they would ask Congress to allocate the money from the one-time auction of part of the broadcast spectrum.
Under the plan, the Federal dollars would not be spent directly on the schools. Instead, the Federal Government would pay up to half the cost of the interest on the tax-exempt bonds typically issued to pay for school construction.
As a result, Mr. Clinton predicted that the $5 billion Federal investment would prompt a total of $20 billion in school repairs and renovation.
In keeping with the themes of personal responsibility and shared community values that are forming the backbone of his campaign, Mr. Clinton stressed today that he was not seeking to dictate solutions or supplant local responsibilities.
"Our school construction initiative would be flexible," Mr. Clinton said. "It would give communities and states the power to decide how to use the new resources. It would help those who help themselves, requiring local communities to take responsibility for this effort."
Independent groups were quick to praise the plan.
"It doesn't do all things for all people, but it's the first major and most substantial Federal response to school repair needs that we've ever seen," said Michael Casserly, executive director of Council of the Great City Schools, a coalition of the nation's largest urban public school systems. "And it's also significant the way that they've done it: essentially leveraging and encouraging additional efforts locally."
Administration officials said that of the nation's 17,000 school districts, 100 to 125 with the highest number of children in poverty could apply for subsidies directly to the Department of Education. Among these districts is New York City, where many schools still burn coal for heat.
Other districts would apply to the states. Mr. Casserly praised that feature of the plan, saying that at the state level, poor districts "tend to get less than their fair share."
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the President's national economic adviser, said the plan's costs would be covered by the proceeds from auctioning portions of the broadcast spectrum between Channels 60 and 69.
"The new digital technology has essentially freed up some new space on the broadcast spectrum," Dr. Tyson said, "and that means the space can be used without disturbing the TV broadcasting that's already going on."
The Federal Government has traditionally had a minor role in maintaining schools, and officials emphasized that they intended the program to last no longer than four years.
Mr. Clinton originally planned to announce the program today in Tampa, Fla., in a state he narrowly lost in 1992. But with Hurricane Bertha threatening, the White House shifted the ceremony here.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton and Senator Carol Moseley-Braun announced a school-repair plan yesterday. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Council Seeks Raise for Contract Workers

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Upset that many companies doing work for New York City pay their workers the minimum wage, the City Council overwhelmingly approved a bill yesterday that would require those private contractors to pay 3,500 workers far more.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's aides said that he might veto the bill, which is expected to raise the city's contracting costs by $15 million a year. But after yesterday's 41-to-7 vote, City Council members voiced near certainty that they could override a veto and make New York one of the first cities to pass legislation mandating higher wages for employees of city contractors. 
 "I don't think we in the city should be in the business of substandard wages, wages lower than what the private sector pays," said Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed, a Manhattan Democrat who is one of the bill's chief sponsors. "This will give these workers more personal dignity and will mean many of them will no longer need food stamps or welfare."
The bill would require city contractors in four areas -- security, cleaning, food service and temporary office work -- to pay the prevailing rate for private-sector workers doing similar jobs. Council officials estimated that this would raise the wages of unarmed security guards to $7.25 an hour, food workers to $9 an hour and temporary office workers to about $11.25 an hour.
In an interview, First Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers stopped short of saying that Mr. Giuliani would veto the bill, which many supporters call a "living wage bill."
Mr. Powers said: "We have serious concerns about the bill. It increases the cost of the budget, which means we're going to have to cut somewhere else in the budget to pay for the increased cost, and the Council hasn't identified where to cut." He added that the Mayor believes the wage problem should be dealt with through a national minimum-wage bill because "it keeps us competitive if every area of the country is paying high wages."
Several Council members said that the Mayor, facing what would be his sixth veto override, might be thinking twice about vetoing a bill for which church groups and labor unions have lobbied intensely as part of a nationwide effort to have cities, states and Federal legislators raise wages for low-end workers.
In the past, mayoral aides attacked proposals for such a bill on the ground that it would increase the city's budget deficit and send out an image that New York was a place where big government was once again seeking to strangle business. Indeed, in attacking the bill, Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington said, "We might as well dust off the Communist Manifesto."
Sheldon S. Leffler of Queens, one of three Democrats to vote against the bill, said, "Government interference in the wage market will reduce the competitiveness of New York City and discourage investment and economic growth here."
Last year Councilman Sal F. Albanese proposed a version of the bill that would provide employees of city contractors $12.10 an hour plus health benefits. But as the price of letting the bill go to a vote, City Council President Peter F. Vallone pushed to have the wage minimum reduced and the benefits requirement eliminated, partly so it would be less of a strain on the city budget.
Opponents of the bill say that contractors, having to pay higher wages, will pass the cost on to the city by submitting higher bids; some supporters say that contractors will merely swallow the difference.
Nonetheless, Mr. Albanese does not hide the fact that he hopes to use the bill as a weapon in his campaign for mayor.
"When the New York City Council acts, the entire nation watches," said Mr. Albanese. "It's a landmark piece of legislation." He noted that he had been asked to testify before Chicago's City Council next week because it is considering similar legislation.
Similar laws have been enacted in Baltimore, and bills are being considered in Los Angeles and St. Paul.
In New York and around the country, the labor movement has pushed hard for such a law to show its concerns for low-paid workers and to help derail efforts to contract out or privatize municipal work. Very often the main reason that private companies can provide services more cheaply is that they pay lower wages.
"Today's bill is an excellent first step toward assuring a fair wage package for the lowest-paid among us."said Brian McLaughlin, president of the New York City Central Labor Council, the federation of the city's trade unions.

HEADLINE: 102 DAYS TARDY, ALBANY REACHES DEAL ON BUDGET

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Friday, July 12

 BODY:
Finally producing what has become the tardiest state budget in the nation's history, Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature announced a $66 billion spending plan on Thursday that rejects most of the cuts and policy changes that Mr. Pataki had advocated.
The Governor and legislative leaders ended a long, rancorous stalemate by reaching a compromise late Wednesday night on several issues that had held up a final agreement, including Mr. Pataki's plan to overhaul the state's $5 billion workers' compensation system. 
 The budget was due on April 1, but for the 12th straight year, state leaders failed to meet that deadline. The National Conference of State Legislatures believes no other state has ever approved a budget this late.
The Legislature began moving the budget bills toward passage on Thursday night, and the State Assembly met well into the early morning. But until the final bill is passed, probably tonight or Saturday, the record for lateness, now at 103 days, keeps growing.
The Legislature restored about $1.45 billion in cuts that Mr. Pataki had called for, mostly in Medicaid, which pays for medical care for the poor, and for higher education as well as welfare. One result is there will be no tuition increases for SUNY and CUNY students, officials said.
Mr. Pataki also did not get approval of several far-reaching criminal justice and welfare proposals he had offered. He had called for the state to eliminate parole for all violent felons and toughen its treatment of juvenile offenders, but those plans were turned down. He also asked for time limits on welfare and cuts in benefits. The Democratic-controlled Assembly, the Governor's main rival in Albany, responded with its own plan for time limits, but Mr. Pataki labeled it too weak and the two sides could not find a compromise, so the whole idea was dropped.
Mr. Pataki, who as a candidate repeatedly vowed to put a stop to the tradition of tardy budgets, said this afternoon that the people of the state should focus on the contents of the budget, not when it was approved.
"Absolutely, it was worth the wait and worth the fight," he said.
The Governor said the agreement would continue his drive to reduce the state's spending and cut taxes. When counting all the money in the budget, including Federal funds, state spending will actually increase a bit. But Mr. Pataki noted that when only the state's own money was counted, spending would decline slightly. The budget also includes a promise from the Legislature to pass an environmental bond act that the Governor proposed last month. The act, which voters must approve in November, would authorize the state to borrow $1.75 billion for environmental projects.
The deal also keeps in place the second phase of a three-part cut in state income taxes that the Governor pushed through the Legislature last year.
Still, the agreement seemed to underscore that this has been a difficult legislative session for the Governor, who proposed his budget on Dec. 15, a month early, hoping to insure that it would not be late. At the time, Mr. Pataki called for cuts and policies based on the assumption that the Federal Government would revamp rules for Medicaid and welfare.
When President Clinton and Republican leaders in Congress could not agree on those regulations, Mr. Pataki's budget fell apart, and he later had to present a revised plan to the Legislature.
The Governor successfully moved many of his proposals through the Legislature last year, his first year in office. But this time, he found more resistance, even from his Republican allies who are the majority in the State Senate. The Senate and the Assembly are up for election this year, and members of both houses wanted to spend more to curry favor with voters.
Mr. Pataki, who became the state's first Republican governor in a generation when he was elected in 1994, is not up for re-election until 1998. He had proposed the cuts in his original budget plan to help pay for his income tax cut. But with the economy improving, less cuts were needed. Legislative leaders said the state's revenues were running more than $700 million higher than they estimated in December.
The leaders said they would pay for the rest of the proposed cuts through $1.3 billion in one-time revenue sources, including taking $481 million from a fund that pays for medical malpractice settlements. They also lowered their estimates of how much programs like Medicaid would cost the state in the next year.
As they had in past years, fiscal monitors criticized the one-time revenues being used to cover recurring costs. They also bemoaned the inability of the state's leaders to reach an agreement on time, pointing out that the lateness has contributed to giving New York one of the lowest bond ratings of any state. The low ratings raise the cost of interest when the state borrows, which ultimately results in less money for schools and a host of other items in the budget.
Mr. Pataki won concessions from the Assembly on cutting the costs of the state's $5 billion workers' compensation system. The Assembly also agreed to proposals by the Republican majority in the Senate to cut business taxes.
The tax cuts, on real estate sales, petroleum, property and other items, will save businesses about $83 million in the next fiscal year, rising to more than $250 million annually in about three years.
The Governor and legislative leaders also agreed on a amnesty program for people who have not paid their state taxes. The program is expected to yield about $150 million to $200 million, officials said.
One issue that propelled the budget talks to completion on Wednesday night was the expiration of a state law that protects thousands of loft tenants in New York City. Mr. Pataki and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, had threatened to let the law lapse if the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver of Manhattan, did not accede to changes in the workers' compensation system.
Finally, at about 11:45 P.M., the three men emerged from Mr. Pataki's office to announce that they had reached agreement, and Mr. Bruno and Mr. Silver then rushed over to the Legislature to pass a 36-hour extension on the loft law.
As part of the final budget agreement announced on Thursday, the Legislature is to extend the loft law for three years, officials said.
Legislative leaders spent the afternoon praising the aspects of the budget that they believed would appeal to their constituencies.
Mr. Silver, who had crusaded against Mr. Pataki's proposed cuts, repeatedly noted that the Legislature had made restorations in spending.
The budget now "takes care of the working men and women of New York," Mr. Silver said. "It takes care of the middle class of New York, it takes care of the education needs of New Yorkers, it takes care of the health care needs of New Yorkers."
Mr. Silver noted that the agreement included a plan from the Assembly that would cut the state's 4 percent sales tax on clothing for one week next winter for items worth less than $500 as an experiment to see whether it would generate more economic activity.
Mr. Bruno, who has close ties to business groups, praised the business tax cuts that the Senate majority championed, saying that the state had made a serious error by enacting them in the first place.
"We are doing some really great things on behalf of the people of this state," Mr. Bruno said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, briefed reporters yesterday on the budget, which rejects most of Gov. George E. Pataki's cuts. (Associated Press)(pg. B5)
 
Graph: "DEADLINES: Late-Budget Record Lengthens" shows number of days the New York State budget has been overdue from 1980 to 1996. (pg. B5)
 
Chart: "The Long Road to a Budget Agreement"
 
Dec. 15 Gov. George E. Pataki presents his $63.8 billion budget. To close a projected deficit and pay for tax cuts, his plan seeks steep reductions in spending on Medicaid, welfare and higher education. In a foretaste of rhetorical battles to come, the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Democrat, calls the plan "a thinly veiled attempt to destroy the middle class of this state." Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican who is the Senate majority leader and Mr. Pataki's most powerful ally in the Legislature, acknowledges that it might need "fine-tuning."
 
Jan. 3 Mr. Pataki uses his second State of the State address to try to drum up legislative support for his austerity budget, a difficult task in an election year.
 
March 11 Senator Bruno calls on the Governor to rewrite his budget, saying it depends too heavily on Federal actions that seem increasingly unlikely to happen. "If we are going to deal with the budget in the real world," Mr. Bruno says, "then we have to deal with real numbers."
 
March 15 Mr. Pataki goes to Washington to press for changes in Federal welfare and Medicaid laws that could save New York State $2 billion in the coming fiscal year. Despite threatening harsh new cuts if Washington does not help, he is rebuffed.
 
March 16 In a surprise announcement, Mr. Pataki says he has found $1.4 billion in additional money that will enable him to avoid painful new spending cuts.
 
March 28 The Governor and legislative leaders abandon their effort to pass a budget on time because of the budget impasse in Washington. They agree instead to a stopgap spending measure that freezes state spending at current levels for four weeks while also allowing a previously approved tax cut to take effect.

April 1 The state's new fiscal year begins, with no budget.
 
May 6 With the budget six weeks late, Mr. Silver steps up his attacks against Mr. Pataki, accusing him of trying to undermine public schools and of paying skimpy attention to stalled budget negotiations.

May 22 After weeks of negotiations, Republican and Democratic legislative leaders offer a budget proposal intended to jump-start the molasses-slow negotiations. Mr. Bruno and Mr. Silver say their budget will spend $1.2 billion more than Mr. Pataki's, mainly on schools, the state university system and health care programs.
 
May 27 The Governor's budget office attacks the bipartisan budget proposal as $1.2 billion out of balance and filled with irresponsible election-year spending.
 
May 30 Mr. Pataki says he will ask the Legislature to provide aid to public schools through March 1997, a move that would relieve the single greatest pressure on him and the Legislature to reach a budget agreement soon. This plan also dies in the Legislature.
 
June 5 Budget talks collapse in disarray and acrimony. Both houses of the Legislature vow to pass sharply different budgets, though neither plan is likely to be acceptable to the other house -- or to Mr. Pataki.

June 8 At 4:52 A.M., the long-overdue budget becomes the longest-overdue budget.
 
June 27 The Governor and legislative leaders emerge from a three-hour negotiating session saying they were making progress but still trying hard to enact a spending plan by July 4.
 
June 30 The Governor and legislative leaders announce that they have an agreement on a plan to deregulate the state's hospitals. Saying they are making great headway on budget negotiations, they also agree to extend a law protecting thousands of New York City loft residents, many in Mr. Silver's district, for three days while negotiations continue.
 
July 3 Mr. Pataki and the leaders concede that they cannot meet their goal of enacting the budget by July 4 and the Legislature adjourns for the holiday weekend after extending the loft law for another week. The Governor's aides make it clear that he will hold the budget hostage to gain concessions from the Democrats on a plan to revamp the workers' compensation system.
 
July 9 On the 100th day that the budget has been late and workers' compensation talks deadlocked, Mr. Bruno repeats his pledge not to extend the loft law again until there are budget bills ready to be passed.
 
July 10 Just hours before the loft law is about to lapse, Mr. Pataki and the leaders announce an agreement on revamping the workers' compensation system, opening the way for final budget passage.
 
July 11 Mr. Pataki and the leaders announce that they have reached a budget agreement.

HEADLINE: Metro Digest

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
Finally, a State Budget
Producing the latest state budget in the nation's history, Governor Pataki and the State Legislature announced a $66 billion spending plan that rejects most of the budget cuts and policy changes that Mr. Pataki had advocated. Ending a long and sometimes rancorous stalemate, the Governor and legislative leaders released details of the budget, including Mr. Pataki's plan to overhaul New York State's $5 billion workers' compensation system. [Page A1.]
 
The budget deal gave all sides something to walk away with. [B5.]
 
Dismal Look at Welfare Agency
Eight months after Elisa Izquierdo's death highlighted the failings of the city's child welfare system, social workers, housing court judges and government officials say the agency charged with protecting the city's most vulnerable adults is just as flawed. They say its mistakes and oversights in dealing with the very old, the abused and the mentally ill have resulted in continuing abuse, homelessness and, sometimes, even death. [A1.]
 
Freedom, Coffee and Advice
At the corner of Jackson Avenue and Queens Plaza South, beneath a billboard image of the Statue of Liberty, the City Department of Correction releases several hundred inmates a week. In their first acts as free men, some grab a beer or a pack of cigarettes. Others head for a coffee cart operated by Seema Sandhir, who has worked the corner for two years. She offers milk and sugar, and a word of advice: "Don't do it next time. Be a good boy." [B1.]
 
Term Limits Back on Ballot
Three years after New Yorkers voted overwhelmingly to impose term limits on the city's elected officials, they will be asked to reconsider their decision in a vote this fall on whether to extend the limit from 8 years to 12. The City Council, which vigorously opposed term limits in 1993, voted overwhelmingly to place a referendum on the November ballot asking voters to allow the mayor, comptroller, public advocate, borough presidents and Council members to hold office for 12 years. [B1.]
 
The Council approved a bill requiring contractors to increase the pay of 3,500 workers. [B2.]
 
Relations in Awkward Stage
What was left unchanged on Benjamin Netanyahu's first day in town as the Israeli Prime Minister was an awareness among many Jews whose hearts are in both New York City and Jerusalem that their relationship with Israel has entered a new, uncertain stage. To a degree, so has their self-identity. NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]
 
Netanyahu Courts New York
Returning with new stature to an intimately familiar venue, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel switched on his oratorical skill and boyish charm to full volume as he urged New York City's Jewish population to embrace his approach to peace in the Middle East and to invigorating the Israeli economy. [B3.]
Politicians all but lined up to be seen with the new Israeli leader, and he was only too happy to oblige. [B3.]
 
Melee After Boxing Match
Fans and boxing handlers brawled at Madison Square Garden last night after the heavyweight Riddick Bowe was declared a winner by disqualification over Andrew Golota of Poland. The police were called in and evacuated the arena. Minor injuries were reported and the authorities maintained a tight security around the Garden hours after the fight ended. Sports. [B9.]
 
Search for Missing Girl
They were surreal scenes: the lawyers at Lollapalooza, the bankers talking to bouncers, the middle-aged accountant interviewing a child with green spiked hair. They came in their jackets and ties bearing fliers and an urgent question: Has anybody seen a girl named Missy? They were all searching for Melissa Gay, 14, who left her parent's Connecticut home Saturday, took a train ride to New York, and apparently disappeared into the underground world of rave parties. [B3.]
 
Drug Dealer Sought in Deaths
While detectives searched for a convicted drug dealer in the killings of three Queens women, police officials said the slayings were motivated by a $50 drug debt. The police identified the suspect as Allan James Gordon, 24, who lives across the street from where the victims were killed. [B3.]
 
Beating Victim Returns Home
Shane L. Daniels, 21, who was beaten into a coma in May during a fight involving a New York City police officer outside a Long Island bar, spent his first full day back home. [B6.]
 
ABC Carpet and Home is not welcome on Long Island's affluent East End. [B6.]
 
REGION
 
Schools Could Get Millions
Seeking the largest Federal role ever in repairing public schools, President Clinton announced that he would ask Congress for $5 billion for the repairs. One official said that New York, where many schools still burn coal for heat, could expect as much as $400 million to $500 million. National report. [A12.]
 
NEW JERSEY
 
Police Force Disbanded
The Hudson County Board of Freeholders said it had no choice, but when it voted to disband the county's 82-officer Police Department, the officers who packed the meeting room said they had been betrayed. [B5.]

HEADLINE: NYC;
Netanyahu: U.S. Style, Israeli Content

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
ABOUT a year ago, Benjamin Netanyahu was fast-walking on a leafy street in Jerusalem when he bumped into someone who lived there, a man he had met many times before. When the man expressed surprise, Mr. Netanyahu, who was then Israel's opposition leader, explained that he had just moved into the neighborhood.
What street, he was asked. He pointed vaguely somewhere over yonder. Still curious, the acquaintance asked for specifics. Again, Mr. Netanyahu gave an elliptical response, muttering something about security concerns. 
 Now, this particular acquaintance never thought of himself as much of a terrorist threat, and in fact this minor episode probably had nothing to do with security. It was, however, a reminder of something about Israel's new Prime Minister that is often lost in the American-style politicking that he has mastered so well:
He does not like to reveal much about himself.
That may sound surprising, since he seems thoroughly American, down to the smooth public style he has shown to advantage this week. Don't let that fool you. Unlike American politicians, he is not a product of the Age of Oprah, ready to natter on about his childhood and how it shaped him.
All that is fine. Trouble begins, though, when you realize that getting Mr. Netanyahu to fill in the details of his national policies, articulated thus far only in broad outlines, can be as doomed to failure as trying to find out where he lives.
FAMILIAR though his face may have been, Mr. Netanyahu was still something of an enigma to the leaders of major Jewish groups who gathered at the Sheraton New York Hotel yesterday to welcome him for the first time as Prime Minister to this city that has more Jews than Jerusalem and Tel Aviv combined.
Whenever you talk about Israel's relations with American Jewry, you really mean the Jerusalem-New York nexus. It is a powerful bond, forged from a common faith and history, and it stayed firm yesterday. The new Israeli leader strode into a packed room to applause -- more polite, though, than exuberant -- from officials of groups ranging politically from right to left and religiously from Orthodox to nonobservant.
There were no surprises. Mainstream Jewish groups, as a matter of both principle and self-interest, line up behind the Israeli Prime Minister, no matter who he is. But questions put by these officials to Mr. Netanyahu, about central issues like his intentions toward the Palestinians and his ideas on religious pluralism, left them no more informed than when they came in. Many agreed that his responses, while stylishly delivered, came in familiar, generalized terms.
Then again, their opinions may count for the Prime Minister only up to a point. That is certainly the case with many ordinary Israelis, who increasingly have come to the conclusion that the American Jewish experience bears little relevance to their own.
Yes, they remain brothers and sisters, and Israelis will no doubt always value the clout that American Jews have in Washington and in the national news media. But spend much time worrying about how Israeli policies are playing in Forest Hills or on the Upper West Side? Not very likely.
ISRAEL'S President, Ezer Weizman, could not be more blunt about it. Over and over, he tells American Jews who call on him to forget about being a vital part of their people's future as long as they live in the Jewish diaspora.
It is not lost on Israelis that when Palestinian terrorist bombs started to explode in 1994, the first to cancel flights to Tel Aviv -- in droves -- were American Jewish tourists. As for the millions of dollars raised for Israeli institutions by American groups, many based in New York, money indeed can't buy love, especially since those dollars account for an ever-shrinking share of Israel's thriving economy. Some Israeli officials have gone so far as tell American Jews to keep their money -- and their opinions.
Left unchanged on Mr. Netanyahu's first day in town was an awareness among many Jews whose hearts are in both New York and Jerusalem that their relationship with Israel has entered a new, uncertain stage in the last few years. To a degree, so has their self-identity.
"We've sort of gotten past the idea of identifying ourselves just by how much money we contribute to Israel," Gary Rosenblatt, the thoughtful editor of The Jewish Week, told a group of fund-raisers recently. "But we haven't gotten to the next step. We're still floundering around trying to determine what it is."

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Fell in June; Producer Prices Up Slightly

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
Retail sales fell in June, while producer prices rose modestly last month, the Government reported today, in two reports that eased some concerns about inflation and interest rates.
The Commerce Department said retail sales declined two-tenths of 1 percent, to $205.2 billion last month, as demand for everything from new cars to clothing waned after several months of strength. Sales had risen a brisk eight-tenths of 1 percent in May. 
 The Labor Department said the Producer Price Index edged up two-tenths of 1 percent in June, after a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in May. Energy costs fell last month after rising earlier in the year, but food prices strengthened.
Excluding food and energy prices, which are often volatile, producer prices still rose two-tenths of 1 percent after being unchanged in May, the department said.
Producer prices are the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for the products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers.
"Prices are still very well behaved," said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company.
Coming a week after an employment report for June showed unexpected strength in the economy, today's reports, which came in near expectations, helped calm some of the fears raised by the jobs data. The two reports, especially the sales data, suggested that growth might not be as robust as previously believed.
The data on retail sales and producer prices helped bolster bond prices today.
The stock and bond markets have been sharply weaker since last Friday, in large part because investors fear that signs that the economy is picking up speed will prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates sooner -- and more sharply -- than has been expected.
Indeed, some investors have speculated that Fed policy makers will take the unusual step of raising rates before their next meeting on Aug. 20.
"The producer price report provides the Fed no leverage whatsoever for raising interest rates at this time," said Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors.
The drop in June retail sales follows strong gains earlier this year and could point to slower growth in the second half as consumers spend less, analysts said. Most analysts said the economy grew strongly in the second quarter.
"This number shows us the consumer is not Superman, that there is some vulnerability here," said Christopher Low, a senior economist with HSBC Markets. "This weakness comes just at the right moment and the likelihood of a Fed move in the near future has been diminished."
Michelle Laughlin, chief economist at Sanwa Securities USA Inc., said, "The inflation data is not so bad as to suggest the Fed needs to move sooner and at the same time the retail sales data weren't so weak as to suggest the Fed will not move at all."
In its report, the Commerce Department said that excluding autos, sales rose one-tenth of 1 percent in June after a rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in May.
Sales of new cars fell 1.4 percent in June, to a seasonally adjusted $49.7 billion, after rising 1.8 percent in May. New cars account for nearly a quarter of total retail sales.
Sales at general merchandise stores fell four-tenths of 1 percent after a 1.2 percent rise in May. Sales at clothing stores dropped 1.3 percent after increasing nine-tenths of 1 percent in May.
The Labor Department said energy prices fell 2.1 percent last month as gasoline dropped 7.4 percent and heating oil 11.4 percent.
Energy prices over all fell six-tenths of 1 percent in May.
Food prices partly offset the drop in energy prices, rising 1.6 percent after being unchanged in May.
Passenger car prices jumped 1 percent after increasing three-tenths of 1 percent the previous month.

GRAPHIC: Graphs show producer price index of finished goods and total retail sales for 1995 and 1996.
