HEADLINE: Elation, and Deflation, Over AIDS

 BODY:
It is hard not to feel a surge of elation at the rapid progress reported at the international AIDS conference in Vancouver this week. For the first time since the early days of the epidemic, scientists seem actually to be gaining ground in treating a viral menace that has been largely incurable and almost invariably fatal.
The most startling advances have come in drug treatments. Where once there was essentially one major drug, AZT -- moderately effective in slowing AIDS but highly toxic -- now there is an array of drugs in the same family as AZT and a whole new family of drugs that act through a different mechanism. By combining these drugs artfully, doctors have achieved astonishing results in suppressing the AIDS virus in small numbers of patients for limited periods of time. In perhaps the most dramatic result, the virus became undetectable for up to 300 days after participants took a three-drug combination. 
 Nobody knows for sure that the new treatments will work over the long term. They can cause severe side effects, like kidney stones and nausea, and many patients will no doubt find it extremely difficult to take more than 15 pills a day indefinitely, often on an empty stomach and at precise times. It also remains possible that the wily AIDS virus will eventually develop resistance to these currently potent drug cocktails, especially if many patients fail to take their medicines in the strict regimen required. AIDS doctors are rightly trying to dampen the initial hype and optimism over the treatment gains pending bigger and longer clinical trials. There is concern that the new developments may fizzle out as so many others have in the long, gloomy history of AIDS.
But even after all the caveats, it is hard to minimize the dramatic shift in thinking that has occurred. Whereas AIDS victims in the past have faced a dreary prospect of decline toward eventual death, now there is an emerging possibility that those who have access to the new drugs can suppress their infection and live with it as a lifelong, chronic ailment, much like herpes or diabetes. No one is predicting a total cure yet, but when the first subject with no detectable virus is finally taken off drugs, doctors will be watching anxiously to see whether the virus rebounds -- or has been eliminated for good.
The paradox is that, even if the new treatments pan out, the outlook for controlling the global AIDS epidemic remains grim. The treatments are expensive, ranging above $15,000 a year, and thus will be difficult to provide to all those who might benefit in the United States. The cost of providing these treatments in developing countries, where some 90 percent of those infected with the AIDS virus live, is likely to be prohibitive. The only sensible response is better prevention programs and, most important of all, an effective vaccine to protect against infection. That is the goal toward which AIDS researchers must now focus their energies.

HEADLINE: If U Cn Rd This . . .

BYLINE: By Tamara Plakins Thornton; Tamara Plakins Thornton, an associate professor of history at the State University of New York at Buffalo, is author of a forthcoming cultural history of handwriting.

 BODY:
The conventional wisdom these days is that the art of penmanship is vanishing and that the culprit is electronic. As a Michigan teacher recently told The Chicago Tribune, "Handwriting has taken a big beating because of computers and keyboards."
But this is hardly the first time warnings have been sounded about sloppy penmanship. A hundred years ago, it was the typewriter that was spelling the death of cursive. At issue today, as it was 100 years ago, is a fear of modern technology, and a yearning for a simpler past. 
 Early in the century, educators concerned about the reduced emphasis on penmanship and the introduction of typing into the curriculum came up with a novel way of fighting back. The then popular Palmer method of shaping letters promised to meet the typewriter on its own terms by turning the arm into a perpetual motion machine. But the hand was no match for a Remington.
By the 1950's, the alleged decline of handwriting had become something of a national obsession. Penmanship jeremiads appeared by the dozens in educational periodicals and popular magazines. Our "increasing reliance on the telephone, typewriter, dictating machines and electronic brains," commented The Saturday Evening Post in 1955, "would seem to be making handwriting as obsolete as smoke signals."
The cold war had increased American paranoia. Our weakened moral fiber, moralists argued, would make us less able to withstand a foreign aggressor. We had been too permissive. Among other things, we had allowed schoolchildren to avoid the hard work of learning proper handwriting.
By the mid-'60's, America had become worried not only about moral laxity but economic competitiveness as well. Penmanship advocates pointed to the economic costs of illegible inventory lists, sales receipts, packing slips and the like. In 1965, a story in The Pittsburgh Press blamed an engineer's scrawled instructions for a NASA failure.
The championing of self-expression and individuality prevalent in the late 1960's and 1970's prompted plenty of complaints about lack of discipline among the nation's youth, and even some nostalgia for the authority of the long-lapsed Palmer method. As two Palmer-trained pedagogues commented in 1975: "Children are rarely made to do anything in school any more. They have freedom of choice, which is good, but given freedom of choice, who among us would elect the dullness and repetition which characterized the penmanship of yore?"
For these educators, what needed to be recovered was not so much the penmanship lessons of yore as yore itself.
In 1991, when Phil Donahue recalled "the law and order of Catholic school in the 40's" and "the absolutes that enabled us to sleep so well in childhood," he chose the Palmer method to symbolize the comforting certainties of his youth.
"Your penmanship," he wrote in a newspaper essay addressing his teacher, Sister Mary Andrew, was "the excellent standard to which we all aspired." But as Mr. Donahue confessed, he had long since strayed from that model: "This small sin of the flesh is just one reminder of the many shortfalls between doing what you said and doing what I do. My adult life has been, like my penmanship, sliding backward."
Some are drawn to old-fashioned cursive as an antidote to the impersonal nature of the modern world. "It was like a little time capsule," is the way one writer for The Denver Post described a handwritten letter, "friendlier than a letter dashed off a computer. It was a real letter -- the kind people don't have time to write anymore."
In St. Cloud, Minn., a company called Written by Hand employs 150 workers to pen thousands of handwritten appeals for charity. Ballpoint pens are used because they are messy; smudges are seen as a personal touch.
So the ultimate goal of all the hand-wringing over handwriting is not legibility, and never has been. The real motive is to remember a time when rules were rules and people followed them, when machines were just machines and people ruled them. Instead of lamenting the sad fate of cursive, we would do better to think about why it matters so much to us in the first place.

HEADLINE: Venezuela Gets Big I.M.F. Credit, Backing Market Reforms

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Venezuela was awarded a $1.4 billion credit from the International Monetary Fund yesterday, a distinction that also serves as a seal of approval on the country's economic reform package.
Venezuela's plans to create an open, market-oriented economy, free of the stifling controls and regulations that once characterized virtually all the countries of Latin America, were introduced there in April by the Government of President Rafael Caldera. 
 Announcing the loan, the I.M.F. spoke approvingly of Venezuela's "ambitious and front-loaded economic program." It said the program was designed to redress a dismal economic situation in this potentially rich oil-producing country, which has suffered slow growth, 57 percent inflation, a big budget deficit and difficulties in the banking sector.
Under the new program, Venezuela has already lifted price controls on all goods except medicine as well as controls on currency flows in and out of the country and on interest rates. It is now committed to cutting public spending steeply, strengthening its banks and selling off state-owned telecommunications, aluminum, steel, electrical and petrochemical plants.
But the Government will also seek to protect the living standards of the country's 2 million poorest families from the impact of its austerity measures by giving them additional subsidies with help from the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank, the Monetary Fund said.
"All the countries of the region with the exception of Cuba and Haiti are going after what's known as the Washington consensus on economic policy," said Michael Hood, an analyst at J. P. Morgan in New York who specializes in Latin America.
The Venezuelan Finance Minister, Luis Raul Matos Azocar, said, "We are all moving in the same direction now." He spoke at a meeting of New York bankers on Thursday at which he previewed the accord with the Monetary Fund and explained his plans for liberalizing Venezuela's economy.
"We do not really need the I.M.F.'s money because our reserves are strong," Mr. Matos said. "But we want the I.M.F.'s stamp of approval to bolster international confidence in Venezuela."
Since the Latin American debt crisis of the 1980's, the countries of the region have been moving hesitatingly and with varying degrees of enthusiasm away from the closed, regulated economic systems they created in the 1950's and 1960's under the influence of economists like the late Raoul Prebish of Argentina.
Mr. Prebish and his followers had advocated a policy of economic self-sufficency under which these countries tried to build their own manufacturing industries by excluding imported goods, relying on exports of raw materials to earn foreign exchange.
But collapsing commodity prices in the 1980's left Latin America unable to service the big foreign debts it ran up to finance this dash for self-sufficency. And as they were forced to seek assistance from the Monetary Fund, the countries of the region have found themselves under growing pressure from the institution, as well as from successive American administrations, to make their economies more open and market-oriented.
The new trend began in Chile under the military Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who in 1976 set his country firmly on the road toward economic liberalism, advised by economists of the so-called Chicago School who preached the benefits of free trade, deregulation and open competition.
Bolivia took the same path in 1985 with a series of economic reforms that lead to a loan agreement with the Monetary Fund in 1986. Mexico followed suit that same year.
But while Argentina and Brazil also tried to liberalize their economies during the 1980's, Monetary Fund officials say the efforts were half-hearted and the results disappointing.
In Argentina serious economic change only began in 1991 under President Carlos Saul Menem, while in Brazil it did not start until 1994, when Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who was then Finance Minister and is now President, started fighting the country's run-away inflation, though without accepting any I.M.F. supervision over the economy.
In addition to today's loan agreement with Venezuela, the Monetary Fund now has accords with 11 other Latin American countries that offer them credits provided they liberalize their economies according to an agreed schedule. They are Argentina, Mexico, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Panama, Uruguay, Peru, Bolivia, Honduras, Guyana and Nicaragua.

HEADLINE: Alex Manoogian, 95; Perfected Design of Single-Handled Faucet

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Alex Manoogian, the Armenian immigrant responsible for making the single-handled faucet a ubiquitous fixture in modern bathrooms and kitchens throughout the United States and around the world, died on Wednesday at St. John Hospital in Detroit. Mr. Manoogian, who lived in Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., was 95.
Thanks to his realization of the promise of the ball valve joint patented by three inventors, Mr. Manoogian, who came to the United States from Turkey as a teen-ager in 1920, amassed a fortune. He proceeded to dispense it by donating millions of dollars to religious, educational, charitable and cultural institutions and hospitals -- many of them serving the Armenian community -- in scores of countries in North and South America, Europe, the Middle East and Australia. 
 Mr. Manoogian, who founded a small but successful machine shop in Detroit called the Masco Screw Products Company, specializing in automobile parts, was approached in 1952 by the inventors of the ball valve joint, which was capable of making hot and cold water run from a single tap.
They were looking for someone to develop a faucet based on the valve at a time when there were virtually no single-handled faucets on the market.
"It appealed to me," Mr. Manoogian said later. "I said, 'Why wouldn't people want to do something with one hand instead of with two?' "
He signed an agreement with the inventors, and he put his shop to work. Two years later he had a faucet whose handle could be turned left or right for hot or cold water and be pushed or pulled to control the volume. And the faucet was dripless, having no washers to wear out.
Although Mr. Manoogian was intrigued by manufacturing the single-handled faucet, his interest in selling it was minimal. But when plumbing companies told him there was no market for such a fixture, Mr. Manoogian felt he had no choice but to market it himself.
Last year the Masco Corporation, based in the Detroit suburb of Taylor, realized sales of $3 billion from home furnishing and building products, including plumbing and brass goods, kitchen cabinets, appliances, spas and locks manufactured in 100 factories in 15 countries.
The faucets, marketed under such names as Delta, Peerless and Sherle Wagner, are made in single- and double-handled models that range in price from about $40 for a relatively simple chrome fixtures for do-it-yourselfers to thousands of dollars for top-of-the line models made from precious metals. The faucets account for $698 million, or 23 percent of the company's total sales, and the company says its products hold 38 percent of the domestic market for faucets.
Stock in Masco, which barely survived the Depression, was first sold to the public in 1936 for $1 a share. A year later it was listed for sale on the Detroit Stock Exchange, and Masco shares began trading on the New York Stock Exchange in 1969. Masco officials calculate that a $10,000 investment in the stock in 1958 would be worth $25 million today.
Mr. Manoogian, a somewhat shy Old World figure who spoke in lightly accented English, was widely regarded as one of the most prominent persons of Armenian descent in the world. For 36 years he was the international president of the Armenian General Benevolent Union, a worldwide educational, cultural and humanitarian organization. In 1970 he was elected life president, and in 1989 honorary life president.
In such countries as Argentina, Australia, Canada, Iran, Israel, the Netherlands and the United States, institutions created or assisted by Mr. Manoogian's generosity were named for him, his wife, the former Marie Tatian, who died in 1992 after 61 years of marriage, or his parents, Tacvor and Tacoohie Manoogian.
Mr. Manoogian donated the home he had once lived in to the City of Detroit, which uses it as the official residence of its mayor.
In 1990 he received the Ellis Island Medal of Honor, a special award to outstanding Americans, and last year the Republic of Armenia awarded him its National Hero Medal and declared him an Armenian citizen, the first individual outside the country to be so honored.
Mr. Manoogian was born in 1901 in Smyrna, now Izmir, Turkey. The collapse of the Ottoman Empire in World War I promoted so much economic chaos and political repression for Armenians in Turkey that he left in 1920 for the United States, where he was later joined by his parents, two brothers and two sisters.
Mr. Manoogian settled first in Bridgeport, Conn., where he worked in a factory and taught Armenian in evening courses for adults. In 1924 he moved to Detroit, where, as a skilled machinist, he founded Masco Screw Products in 1929.
He is survived by a son, Richard A. Manoogian of Grosse Pointe, Mich., now chairman and chief executive of Masco; a daughter, Louise Simone of Manhattan, who succeeded her father as president of the Armenian General Benevolent Union; six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Extend Price Gains To a 4th Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose yesterday for a fourth consecutive session after reports on producer prices and retail sales eased worries that the Federal Reserve would quickly raise interest rates.
The data on producer prices and retail sales in June suggested that economic growth might not be quite as robust as had been indicated in last Friday's surprisingly strong report on June employment. Treasury prices were also bolstered by a rally in the Treasury futures market. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 9/32 , to 879/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 7.03 percent, from 7.05 percent on Thursday.
Shorter maturities, however, finished slightly lower, as investors looked ahead to what could be a volatile week, with fresh data on consumer prices and industrial production and Congressional testimony from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Early losses in bonds were erased after the Commerce Department said retail sales fell two-tenths of 1 percent, to $205.2 billion in June. Excluding autos, sales rose one-tenth of 1 percent.
Retail sales were soft, "but one month doesn't make a trend." said Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York.
Jack Ablin, director of fixed income and senior fund manager at the Private Bank at the Bank of Boston, said, "Retail sales were positive for the market, showing a large down move after a huge increase the month before."
The Labor Department reported the Producer Price Index edged up two-tenths of 1 percent in June. While the index was at the high end of expectations, Mr. Palash said, a decline in the costs of materials showed no price pressures in the manufacturing pipeline.
Mr. Ablin said he saw yesterday's data as noninflationary.
In addition, bond prices were bolstered by a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, whose index of regional business activity showed a drop to 7.7 in June from 11.6 in May.
Mr. Palash said the economic data weighed the possibility of a moderation in growth ahead and also showed that inflation was well contained.
"The data," he said, "were neutral with respect to Fed policy and not weak enough to close the door on a Fed tightening, nor strong enough to make certain a tightening immediately ahead."
Anthony Chan, chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, said: "Although today's rally was quite impressive, one has to be careful in realizing that market sentiment will continue to remain volatile until Mr. Greenspan lays out his real objectives next Thursday in his Humphrey-Hawkins testimony before the Senate Banking Committee."
In the Treasury futures market, the September bond contract settled at a price of 10813/32 , after opening at 10718/32.

HEADLINE: For an Exclusive With Netanyahu, Just Get in Line

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
He made his debut as the celebrity spokesman for WINS radio's traffic reports. He served as the utility "exclusive interview" of the day. He facilitated the distribution of ice cream coupons. And, figuring "Why not?" on a summer Friday afternoon, he went to the movies.
It was a catch-all type of day for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel yesterday, as he continued his orchestrated campaign to charm, pacify, stimulate and otherwise enrapture a city he dearly wants to count as an ally in his new administration. 
 If plugging a radio station helped, so be it. If the public wants money-saving ice cream coupons, let them have them.
And, hey, even he needs an entertainment break.
On the second day of his three-day visit to New York, Mr. Netanyahu hewed to a less geographically ambitious schedule than he did on Thursday, when he journeyed indefatigably around the city and addressed sizable public assemblages. Yet he was probably no less effective in getting mileage for his message of a tough stance on Middle East peace combined with economic reform.
WINS radio found itself blessed that, in an early-morning interview with the station, the Prime Minister thoughtfully applauded its traffic reports for helping him avoid road congestion during his days as Israel's delegate to the United Nations. WINS was unable to resist playing the plug repeatedly during commercial interludes all day long.
Throughout a schedule somewhat less punishing than Thursday's had been for his aides and security detail, the Prime Minister chose to remain inside the Stanhope Hotel on Fifth Avenue and 81st Street for the greater part of the day, devoting the morning to obliging the news media with sound bites and sitting for two sessions with groups of journalists. Most of the afternoon was taken up by a procession of reunions with American friends.
And so he was heard as an "exclusive" interview on both Fox's "Good Morning New York" and on WCBS radio. He went before the cameras with Bill Beutel as well as Gabe Pressman, in each case saying essentially the same things he had been repeating for days in nonexclusive settings: He would insist on security for Israel in Middle East peace talks, Jerusalem would never be divided and Israel's economy was poised for phenomenal growth.
Over the $20 hotel breakfast with some 40 American journalists (including Mike Wallace, Barbara Walters and Dan Rather), the Prime Minister, brimming with self-confidence, skillfully navigated 45 minutes of questions, scrupulously careful not to make headlines, but graceful in his evasions.
He again sounded the principal themes of the trip: the continuation of the peace process and Israel's business potential now that a market-oriented party is in power. He gently rebuked the United States for not pushing Syria harder toward peace, and declared, "I am prepared to negotiate with Syria without preconditions right now."
He was occasionally funny, in an American-referential way. When he was asked about President Clinton, he deftly ducked mention of their areas of disagreement and praised Mr. Clinton's detailed knowledge of Middle East issues, saying, "He didn't hold up three-by-five cards."
He followed the breakfast meeting with a session with about 20 journalists from Jewish publications.
Mr. Netanyahu gave over the greater portion of yesterday to catching up with some of his many friends and associates from 16 years in the United States, especially his tenure as a delegate to the United Nations in the 1980's.
Those who came calling at the Stanhope included a strikingly diverse assortment of the known and the unknown. One moment it was City Comptroller Alan Hevesi (who discussed the possibility of investing money from the city's pension funds in Israel) and the next it was Rabbi Elimelech Naiman from Brooklyn. One moment it was Laurence Tisch, the wealthy New York businessman and former CBS chairman, and the next it was Rose Mattus, an old friend who is the president of the Mattus Ice Cream Company of Fort Lee, N.J.
As she was leaving, Ms. Mattus gleefully distributed ice cream coupons outside the hotel to anyone who wanted one. Those who did included photographers, security agents and those merely lucky to be passing by. They were good for 50 cents off on Monterey Sorbet or Mattus Original Vanilla.
Late in the afternoon, the Netanyahus, under a solemn cloak of secrecy, went to the movies. They watched a private advance screening of "A Time to Kill," the upcoming thriller based on a John Grisham novel. With them were Richard D. Parsons, the president of Time Warner, the actor Richard Gere and Ehud Olmert, the Mayor of Jerusalem.
All in all, many Jewish leaders who heard Mr. Netanyahu felt he had performed well in this first visit as Prime Minister.
"While he did not reveal any new positions, at least publicly, I think his knowledge of English, his understanding of America and his quite exceptional communications skills created a quite attractive package that I think softened the edges that many of the skeptics have been focusing on," said David A. Harris, the executive director of the American Jewish Committee. "I think what he's accomplished is he's bought some breathing space until the rash judgments are made."
Today, Mr. Netanyahu plans to attend Sabbath services at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, the synagogue he worshiped at when he was at the U.N. and which is just four blocks from his hotel. Things may go a little slower than usual. The synagogue anticipates a crowd of some 1,000 worshipers, more than triple the normal turnout on a summer Saturday.
After the service, if the weather cooperates, his intention is to visit the Central Park Zoo with his wife, Sarah, and their two young sons. He flies back to Israel after sundown.

HEADLINE: Group Disputes G.O.P. Ad on Cost of Tax Increase

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
A central assertion in the Republicans' latest advertisement attacking President Clinton -- that the typical family's Federal tax bill has increased $1,500 under Mr. Clinton -- has been disputed by the nonpartisan organization that the party cited as the source of the information.
The group, the Tax Foundation, said on Thursday that the Republican National Committee advertisement on behalf of Bob Dole's Presidential campaign was "misleading" because it failed to reflect that the increased tax bill resulted largely from economic growth that produced increases in family income. 
 "It surprises and disturbs us," said Stephen Gold, the communications director of the Washington foundation.
The Republican committee had cited a 1995 Tax Foundation report to back up its assertion that, "Under Clinton, the typical American family now pays over $1,500 more in Federal taxes." The commercial did not note that during the same period, median family income increased $6,260 to $52,039 from $45,779 in 1992.
Mr. Gold said his organization had complained to Mr. Dole's campaign that while the $1,500 figure "is technically correct, people need to know more about the figure."
"Most of it really does come from economic growth," Mr. Gold said. "They're not giving credit to the Clinton Administration for higher income, but they're giving it blame for the higher taxes."
Mr. Gold said that by his organization's calculation, the real increase in taxes, adjusted for inflation and increase in income, was about $300.
A Republican Party spokesman, Mary Crawford, said campaign officials believed that the advertisement was not unfair to the Tax Foundation.
"It's their study," Ms. Crawford said, adding that she did not share Mr. Gold's concern about the omission of the income figures. "We don't have to say that."

HEADLINE: After Selloff, Stocks Drop But Only a Bit

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Many investors waded back into the stock market with caution yesterday, stemming two days of heavy price declines, which had led many analysts to wonder if the long bull market on Wall Street was coming to a close.
The Nasdaq composite index, which has fallen nearly 12 percent since its high on June 5, closed the day at 1,103.49, down 2.87 points. The Dow Jones industrial average, which includes larger, more established companies, fell 9.98 points to close at 5,510.56. It has declined nearly 5 percent since reaching a peak in late May. 
 The day's trading, while hardly spectacular, provided bulls with evidence that the selloff earlier in the week was not as dire as many bears had been portraying it.
"What basically happened was that investors got off the sidelines," said Abby Joseph Cohen, a strategist and self-described market bull at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "I think over the last few days investors were in shock."
But it was clear that many investors were still nervous. While bargain hunters snapped up many technology stocks, which had plunged after unexpectedly bad news from stalwarts like Motorola and Hewlett-Packard on Tuesday and Wednesday, there were still more sellers than buyers.
Hewlett-Packard was down 1/4, closing at 78 1/8 yesterday, having dropped 15 percent for the week. Motorola was also down, closing at 55 3/4, down 1/8. Digital Equipment, I.B.M. and Compaq Computer also lost ground.
The big gainers yesterday were oil equipment stocks, which have enjoyed a strong rally recently, along with natural gas producers and health stocks, which bounced back after a warning of disappointing earnings from United Healthcare on Thursday sent them reeling along with the technology sector. Yesterday, United Healthcare rose 2 1/8, to 33 1/8.
The Nasdaq market was helped by a rise in shares of Intel, which announced that in a break with recent tradition it would not be cutting prices on its microprocessors later this year. Many analysts saw this as evidence that Intel was confident that demand for personal computers would remain strong.
"The session started out with a better tone, but most stocks still seem for sale," said Timothy G. Grazioso, manager of Nasdaq trading at Cantor Fitzgerald in New York. "If it had opened with a handful of bad news it would have been a lot less orderly."
As it was, Nasdaq's two biggest technology plays -- Intel and Microsoft -- went in opposite directions. Intel rose 1 3/4 to close at 71 1/4, while Microsoft fell 2 1/8, to 112 3/8.
Mr. Grazioso attributed Microsoft's decline to profit taking. "That is an example of a stock that everybody has had a profit in over the last six months, so they can take some money off the table," he said.
To some analysts, investor worries were apparent in yesterday's reaction to unexpectedly strong earnings from Chrysler. By many accounts, auto stocks should have rallied on the news. Instead, the Big Three auto makers were down. Chrysler lost 1 1/4, to 56 1/4. General Motors dropped 1, to 48 1/4, and Ford Motor fell 3/8, to 30 3/4.
Chrysler's profit gains were seen as a last hurrah by investors, said Jack V. Kirnan, the auto industry analyst with Salomon Brothers. "They are saying: 'This is as good as it gets. All the good news is behind us not ahead of us,' " he said, referring to investor worries about increasing competition, a stronger dollar and the prospect of an increase in interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
While Mr. Kirnan said he did not believe that such worries were yet justified for the car companies, David G. Shulman, the chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, echoed those sentiments about the market as a whole.
"I still think it is possible for the market to make a new high later in the year," he said, though he cautioned that any rally would be confined to larger, more established stocks, rather than the small companies that have caused the Nasdaq's rise in recent years.
"We've drawn blood," he said, referring to the Nasdaq's more recent plunge. The market has shown the population that they can lose money. It will be conservative from here."
Investors should know more next week, he added, when more economic statistics and corporate earnings, including those of Intel, will be issued, and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, will testify before Congress.
Ms. Cohen of Goldman, Sachs said she was even more optimistic. For investors to be worried about an overheated economy, as they were when the Government reported robust employment statistics a week ago Friday, and then to be concerned about weak corporate earnings, as they were this week, is a contradiction that cannot last, she said.
"At this point investors are not willing to pay for 1997 earnings because there is too much uncertainty in their minds," she added. "But over the coming months people will realize that the economy is growing enough to generate profits but not enough to generate excessive inflation."
She predicted that the S.& P. 500 index would reach between 690 and 700 by the end of the year. It closed yesterday at 646.
Earlier, stocks in Japan ended sharply lower. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 236.13 points, or 1.08 percent, at 21,656.45. For the week, the Nikkei was down 575.97 points. In London, the Financial Times Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares fell 20.7 points, or nearly six-tenths of 1 percent, at 3,728.3, a loss of 14.9 points for the week.

HEADLINE: G.A.O. Puts Cost of S.& L. Bailout at Half a Trillion Dollars

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
The General Accounting Office today released the most comprehensive Government study so far on the costs of the savings and loan bailout, placing a total price tag on the debacle of nearly half a trillion dollars, including more than $130 billion from taxpayers.
The figures were roughly in line with previous estimates, and included both direct and indirect costs as well as interest payments that will stretch out for decades. 
 The money went to clean up the financial mess from the failure of more than 700 savings institutions in the 1980's and early 1990's as a result of mismanagement, fraud and an economic downturn in states like Texas and California.
"The bad news in this report is that the cost of the failure of many thrift institutions, with interest, approaches half a trillion dollars and that taxpayer accountability due to bonds issued will continue through the year 2030," said Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, a Republican who is the chairman of the House Banking Committee.
"The good news is that America's financial institutions today are stronger and sounder than in many years, that the bank and savings and loan insurance funds are positively capitalized and that prudent regulation is in place," Mr. Leach said.
The G.A.O., which functions as a financial watchdog for Congress, said the total bill included $87.9 billion spent by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency set up by Congress in 1989 to sell the assets of failed institutions, and $64.7 billion spent by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, which guaranteed deposits.
It also included $7.5 billion in tax benefits granted to healthy savings institutions that acquired ailing savings and loans. Interest expenses included $111.8 billion on two bond issues, and $209 billion in interest on Congressional appropriations.
For all the money thrown at the problem, the books are not yet closed. The Supreme Court ruled this month that the Government could be liable for billions of dollars in damages for arbitrarily changing a set of accounting rules, hurting or forcing out of business dozens of institutions that had agreed to acquire failing savings associations.
Moreover, the current Savings Association Insurance Fund remains badly undercapitalized, and the banking and savings industries are feuding over who should pay to bring it up to a prudent level and also finance interest payments on bonds issued to pay for the cleanup.

HEADLINE: Traverse City Journal;
Utility Customers Put a Premium on Wind Energy

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER 

DATELINE: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., July 12

 BODY:
This time of year, the fields on the high bluff west of Traverse City begin to yield all sorts of crops: cherries, peaches, cucumbers and corn. Seven weeks ago, though, Terry Lautner's alfalfa field sprouted something the neighbors are still talking about: a giant windmill to generate electricity.
But it is not just the windmill's enormous spinning blades or its prodigious size -- it is the nation's largest -- that has people in this upper Great Lakes community buzzing. It is also how it was financed. Traverse City Light and Power, a city-owned utility, readily persuaded 145 families and 20 businesses to agree to pay 20 percent more for their electricity -- an average of $7.58 a month -- to gain a clean source of energy. It is the first time, energy industry experts say, that an electric windmill has been built in the United States by charging utility customers a premium, or green, rate. 
 "I've always been interested in tapping the wind energy in that field," said Mr. Lautner, a 39-year-old dairy farmer whose family has tilled the fields here since 1865. "It's real neat. I became so interested I killed a day watching them put it up when I should have been planting corn."
If there is a place where some people would gladly pay a little more for a cleaner source of power, it is here in northwestern Michigan. While the Traverse region is politically conservative, it is also developing a reputation as one of the most innovative areas in the Great Lakes basin for trying ideas that join environmental and economic goals.
Two years ago, for example, residents of nearby Old Mission Peninsula voted to increase their property taxes to raise at least $2.6 million. That extra revenue, generated in the teeth of national anti-tax sentiment, is being used to protect thousands of acres of scenic orchards and cultivated fields by paying farmers not to develop their land.
"It really wasn't hard to attract customers to the program," said Steven B. Smiley, an energy economist here who guided the windmill project. "We wrote a letter to all of Traverse City Light and Power's customers in June 1994 and told them it would cost a little more each month to put up a windmill. Within a few weeks, we had more customers than we ended up needing."
There was a brief period, in the late 1970's and early 80's, when wind power seemed to be a promising alternative to conventional power sources like oil. Under the Carter Administration, tax credits were established to encourage innovators. The Reagan Administration ended the Federal tax credit in 1985, and the domestic industry began to decline.
The snow-white machine here, erected at a cost of $670,000, is a Danish-built Vestas V-44 600. Its rotors are 144 feet long and spin at 28 revolutions per minute, fast enough for the blades to slice through the air at 145 m.p.h.
The bluff where the machine stands is buffeted by winds from Lake Michigan that average 14.5 m.p.h. The utility expects that its windmill will generate 1.2 million kilowatt hours of electricity a year, roughly what is needed to supply 200 homes in Traverse City.
The windmill, which turns with a gentle whoosh like the sound of the summer breeze in a screen, is a monument to the vision and perseverance of Mr. Smiley, who first introduced the idea to local utility executives in 1989.
Mr. Smiley said that at a cost of 7 cents a kilowatt hour, the windmill produces the lowest-priced electricity of just about any new power source. But it cannot compete with coal-fired power plants whose costs have been amortized over decades.
As a result, Traverse City Light and Power produces and buys electricity for less than 3 cents a kilowatt hour. The utility's executives assured Mr. Smiley that they would support a windmill if he could come up with a means for making up the difference. So he did.
As part of its energy policy, the Bush Administration enacted a tax credit in the early 1990's that is now worth 1.6 cents a kilowatt hour. At Mr. Smiley's urging, the Michigan Public Utility Commission awarded Traverse City Light and Power a $50,000 grant. Mr. Smiley calculated that customers interested in supporting the windmill would have to pay 1.58 cents more per kilowatt hour. Some 263 of the utility's more than 8,000 customers signed green rate contracts; 80 are on a waiting list.
Ever since the windmill went up over Memorial Day weekend, the utility and Mr. Smiley have been receiving fan mail from across the country. Randy Udall, director of the Community Office for Resource Efficiency, a nonprofit advocacy group in Aspen, Colo., sent one of Mr. Smiley's favorites.
"Traverse City, we salute you," Mr. Udall wrote. "Taking energy decisions into your own hands. Putting money where your heart is. Cleaning the air. Saving fossil fuels for our grandkids. Why, that's almost un-American."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Terry Lautner and his family share their alfalfa field in Leelanau County, Mich., with the nation's largest electricty-generating windmill. With Mr. Lautner in the cab of his pickup are his wife, Cathy, and their son Eric. In the back of the truck are the Lautners' daughter, Julie, and son Andy. (J. Carl Ganter for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Boom With a Difference;
Oil Services Get More Savvy

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

DATELINE: LAFAYETTE, La.

 BODY:
Eight years ago, jobs in the oil-service industry were so scarce that a classified ad for a handful of openings drew hundreds of job seekers to the Global Marine Drilling Company parking lot by the time the manager, Bill Watson, arrived at 6 A.M.
"Some had slept in their cars all night," he recalled. One applicant looked so beaten down that Mr. Watson impulsively pulled a $20 bill from his wallet and handed it to him to tide him over until his next paycheck. 
 "There was that look of desperation," Mr. Watson said.
How times have changed. The same skilled rig workers who had to plead for work back then now have their pick of jobs. The man that Mr. Watson took pity on, Gary Dunn, who was once reduced to picking up soda cans along highways for the nickel deposit, now makes $3,200 a month and is building a new home in Tennessee.
He and thousands of other oilfield workers are the beneficiaries of a surprisingly strong recovery of the oil-services industry. And nowhere is the boom having a bigger impact than in southern Louisiana, studded with hundreds of companies that do everything from manufacturing drilling equipment to ferrying materials to oil platforms.
Statewide, employment in the sector has bounced back to 50,000 after experiencing a disastrous slide to 45,000 in 1993 from a peak of 95,000 jobs a decade earlier. The industry is running at full throttle, with an estimated 95 percent of all available rigs drilling for oil, up from a little over 60 percent early last year. The high demand has pushed the cost to oil companies of hiring a drilling platform in the Gulf of Mexico to an average of about $35,000 a day from a little over $20,000 a year ago, according to Jefferies & Company, an energy-research firm.
The engine powering this resurgence is technology. Improved methods of interpreting three-dimensional seismic readings have enabled oil companies to peer ever deeper under the waters of the gulf, and has sharply increased the success rate of their exploratory drilling. And the latest horizontal-drilling techniques have allowed the companies to squeeze more oil from old fields at low cost.
But it is not just technology that makes this oil boom different from the last one. The oil-service industry is much more hard-nosed, and much more sophisticated, than it was in the late 1970's and early 1980's, when oil prices were soaring and some market analysts were predicting they would hit $60 to $100 a barrel. Then, banks eager to get in on the action, loosened the credit lines to the point of soliciting anybody with an oil-rig lease to take out a loan.
Today, still smarting from being saddled with huge inventories of nearly worthless oil-drilling gear and other equipment they inherited from companies that went under, the same banks have shut off financing for any but the most cash-flush borrowers.
"Loans are made on one thing, and that's cash flow," said C. R. (Rusty) Cloutier, president of Mid-South National Bank, which got stuck with a lot of worthless collateral in 1986. "Property and lease rights don't help you very much now."
And while the banks' stinginess may be bad news for start-ups and struggling companies, it is probably good news for the oil industry as a whole because it damps the sort of speculative fervor that fuels the boom-and-bust cycle.
Indeed, the companies that survived the last downturn are a tough-minded bunch whose owners and managers figure they can make money even if the price of oil stays stuck in the range of $18 to $20 a barrel, which has prevailed for the last three years -- or even if the price falls.
"If we can get only $18 to $19 a barrel for the next three years we can make a profit," said James H. Prince , controller of Stone Energy in Lafayette, which has stepped up exploration and development of existing fields.
Rather than dream about quick profits, companies like Mr. Prince's subject themselves to painstaking analysis of everything from geological formations to the cost -- down to a few pennies a barrel -- of extracting oil in a given location. But they are not afraid to go against the common wisdom. William W. Rucks 4th, president of Flores & Rucks Inc. here, says his company has grown steadily since the late 1980's by buying old fields from such majors as the Shell Oil Company and using the latest technology to squeeze more oil out of them.
Mr. Rucks, 38, said rigorous financial oversight and cost-cutting had enabled Flores & Rucks to prosper. "People are very cautious this time around," he said. "You just hope the hard lessons are going to be remembered." Since his company went public at $10 a share in 1994, it has enjoyed a healthy cash flow and has raised more than $235 million from its initial and subsequent public offerings. Its stock has been trading recently in the $35 range.
While Flores & Rucks stock has done better than most, the oil-service industry has outperformed the market over the last year. In the first quarter of 1996, for example, shares of a group of companies followed by Jefferies & Company rose an average of 34 percent, compared with a gain of about 9 percent in the Dow Jones industrial average.
For all the toughness, oil-service companies in Louisiana are caught up in a hiring frenzy. With the departure of tens of thousands of oil workers during the lean years to other industries, often in other parts of the country, the search at times takes on a desperate air.
They are hanging huge "Now Hiring" signs outside their plants and filling local papers with display ads for workers. To retain workers, they are increasing wages for the first time in years, though their obsession with containing costs is keeping the raises modest. They are also gearing up to train new workers and are sending recruiters to campuses of technical colleges.
People who already hold jobs are working harder than ever. Mr. Watson, the Global Marine manager, puts in 12-hour days ordering thousands of items, from drill bits to pool tables, that must be shipped to inland drilling rigs and offshore production platforms. He is so busy, he says, that he can no longer snatch a few minutes to play a video game on his office computer. The office staff has multiplied so fast, to 30 people from 5 in two years, that he can't keep track of all the new faces. "I haven't played golf in two years," he lamented.
Makers of oil-exploration equipment say they have trouble meeting demand. Dailey J. Berard, president and chairman of Universal Fabricators Inc., stretched his arms in frustration in his office in New Iberia, La., at the thought of all the business he has to turn away -- $100 million in orders for drilling and production platforms last year and a projected $100 million again this year.
Even though Mr. Berard has tripled his work force over the last three years to 450 from 160, he is booked for major projects well into 1997. "We can't staff up for it fast enough," he said. "We can't find the skilled work force."
The workers they do find are sitting pretty. "There's jobs everywhere," said Huey J. Herbert, a 26-year-old pipe welder who works up to 80 hours a week.
Mr. Dunn, the man who accepted the $20 bill from Global Marine's Mr. Watson, has experienced a complete reversal of fortunes. For a time in the 1980's, with oil jobs impossible to find, he says, he and his wife, Sheila May, teetered on the brink of homelessness. The bank had foreclosed on their house, and they lived in their battered Nova, driving around southern Louisiana looking for ways to make a few dollars. Sometimes they would walk along the highway with plastic bags, collecting cans and bottles. Other times, they would knock on doors, offering to do household chores. "You'd say: 'I'll rake a yard for $10,' " said Mr. Dunn, who is now 42. "You would do anything to make ends meet."
Through it all, the couple -- who have two children -- held onto their pride. "We never asked for a handout," Mr. Dunn said. "I kept my good credit." Finally, the industry opened up and today Mr. Dunn is an assistant driller on a deep-water rig that is exploring for oil off West Africa. He works 12-hour days for one month, then takes home leave the following month. With his income approaching $40,000 a year, he and his wife recently decided to build a new home in Bradford, Tenn., near her parents.
For Lafayette, a city of 107,000, the oil-exploration boom is just icing on the cake of a recovery that has been under way for several years as local officials attracted industries ranging from apparel and jewelry manufacturing to food processing, and big retailers followed.
Driving his Ford Explorer along Pinhook Road, Gregg Gothreaux, president of the Lafayette Economic Development Authority, points with pride to the strip's economic rebirth. There is hardly a block that does not boast a new mega-store -- here a Home Depot emporium, there a Barnes & Noble bookstore, farther on a Super K-Mart grocery store.
State Route 90, the coastal road where most of the oil-service concerns have their headquarters, is also enjoying a renaissance. Just a few years ago, it was lined with empty corrugated-steel buildings, whose parking lots were overgrown with weeds. Now, new buildings are springing up. "We've already outgrown this," said Mickey McDonald, manager of a division of Hanover Compression, pointing to a large factory where workers assemble 1,000-horsepower gas compressors. To accommodate a work force that has grown to 59 from 9 in six years, Mr. McDonald plans to build a second plant next to this one and has his eye on a Mom-and-Pop outfit nearby.
Mr. McDonald is not embarking on an ill-considered, breakneck expansion. He is cautious in his hiring practices, for example, spending extra time to find skilled workers and then training them to make sure they handle his company's $700,000 machines properly.
Like many oil-service companies, Hanover is controlled by major players who are savvy about the market and unlikely to overextend themselves. Started in 1990 by a group of Houston investors who bought and consolidated three compressor-leasing companies, Hanover subsequently teamed up with two natural-gas giants, the Enron Corporation and Western Resources.
"The days of the little company are over," Mr. McDonald said.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Leadership Backs Out on a Bill To End Preferences

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
Amid continued criticism that their party is insensitive toward minorities and women, the House Republican leadership has withdrawn its support from a bill that would end all Federal affirmative-action programs. The move scuttles any chance that the measure will pass this year.
Instead, House Republican staff members and conservative civil rights advocates said, Republican lawmakers will concentrate on seeking to end programs that give preferences to "disadvantaged" companies in the awarding of contracts. In practice, the benefit has mainly gone to companies owned by members of racial minorities. 
 A bill to end such contract preferences will be taken up next week by the House Judiciary Committee. . That measure is a stripped-down version of one introduced last year by Representative Charles T. Canady, Republican of Florida, and by Bob Dole before he left the Senate, where he was the Republican leader, to campaign full time for President.
The original bill, the one the Republican leadership has now abandoned, would have prohibited the Federal Government from granting any preferences on the basis of race, color, national origin or sex in Federal employment, contracts and any other Federal programs. It would also have forbidden the Government to require or encourage affirmative action by Federal contractors.
The new bill would ban only preferences in awarding contracts.
The quiet abandonment of the broad-gauge attack on all Federal affirmative-action efforts, first reported in The Washington Times today, was a marked contrast to the way the bill was introduced last July. Mr. Canady and Mr. Dole announced their proposal at a crowded news conference where they criticized Government "discrimination."
But in the year since, the Dole-Canady bill, officially called the Equal Opportunity Act of 1996, has run into strong bipartisan opposition, a surprising development given the Republicans' control of Congress. Mr. Dole's affirmative-action stand has come under fire from some Republican moderates, like Gen. Colin L. Powell, the former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
"Republicans have been ambivalent from the beginning about Dole-Canady," a Republican staff member involved in the issue said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "So this is not a surprise."
The Dole-Canady bill also failed to gain the support of either of the black Republican Representatives in Congress, J. C. Watts of Oklahoma and Gary A. Franks of Connecticut.
"When you have both of your African-American members of Congress saying to the leadership that they should not proceed, I think that obviously puts them in a very difficult position," Mr. Franks said in an interview.
The change in strategy means that in this term, the Republicans will no longer oppose affirmative-action programs in employment, which have benefited white women to a much greater degree than members of racial minorities. Federal affirmative-action programs in awarding contracts, on the other hand, have disproportionately aided racial minorities.
Many Federal contracts that have been set aside for economically and socially disadvantaged companies are parceled out by the Small Business Administration under its 8(a) program. Of the 6,000 companies that participated in that S.B.A. program in the last fiscal year, only 32 were not owned by members of minorities.
"Contracting is black," a Democratic staff member involved in the issue said. "They have made the political judgment that they can't take on women."
It is unclear how comprehensive the attack on affirmative action in Federal contract programs will be. While the revised Dole-Canady bill would end affirmative action in the awarding of all Federal contracts, a bill being offered by Representative Jan Meyers, Republican of Kansas, would end only the S.B.A. program.
The small-business program, the largest such effort run by the Federal Government, awards contracts worth about $5.8 billion annually. Other large preference programs in contracting are run by the Defense Department and by the Transportation Department; smaller ones are administered by other Federal agencies.
Ms. Meyers and her staff say they have been given the impression by the House leadership that her bill will be given top priority as a substitute for the Dole-Canady measure.
"Mrs. Meyers's approach is a priority with the leadership at this point," one of her aides said. "Dole-Canady is on the back burner for further consideration."
An aide to Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, said today that while no decision had been made, the leadership was "leaning" toward throwing its full support behind Mrs. Meyers's bill.
The retreat of the House leadership has drawn a vitriolic response from Republican conservatives who say that opposition to affirmative action is both morally and politically right.
"On this issue, the Republican leadership has neither guts nor brains," said Clint Bolick, vice president of the Institute for Justice, an organization that opposes affirmative action.
"This is the Lilliputian approach to civil rights policy. The Republican leadership has consistently been terrified of this issue for unknown reasons."
Linda Chavez, head of the Center for Equal Opportunity, another conservative group that opposes affirmative action, said: "Lord knows why they are doing this. I think they are really stinging from the very successful ploy of painting the Congress as extremist. They want to be on the side of the angels."
But, Ms. Chavez added, "capitulation rarely works."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Retail Sales Fell in June; Producer Prices Edge Up
Retail sales fell in June, while producer prices rose modestly. The two Government reports eased some concerns about inflation and interest rates. Retail sales fell two-tenths of 1 percent, to $205.2 billion last month, as demand for everything from new cars to clothing waned after several months of strength. The Producer Price Index edged up two-tenths of 1 percent in June, after falling one-tenth of 1 percent in May. Energy costs fell last month, but those declines were offset by a rise in food prices. [Page 34.]
 
Treasury prices rose after reports on producer prices and retail sales eased worries that the Federal Reserve would quickly raise interest rates. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 9/32 , to 879/32 . The bond's yield fell to 7.03 percent from 7.05 percent on Thursday. [44.]
 
New U.S. Plan on Data-Scrambling
Under pressure from Congress and the computer industry, the Clinton Administration proposed a series of new data-scrambling policy initiatives that it said would address the Government's national security concerns while also permitting American companies to compete more effectively overseas. [34.]
 
Intel Revamps Chip Pricing
Intel is fine-tuning its pricing practices to try to lift sluggish sales of personal computers to the home market and to increase its profits. The company will make deeper price cuts than previously planned on some of its Pentium chips in August, on a third or less of its lines, analysts predict. But Intel will then hold prices steady through the end of 1996. [35.]
 
MGM Remains on Kerkorian's Mind
Kirk Kerkorian just cannot seem to stay away from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. Mr. Kerkorian, the Las Vegas billionaire who has owned MGM two times before, is joining forces with the studio's chairman, Frank G. Mancuso, and his management team, in a bid for MGM. Also part of the team is Seven Networks, an Australian television company. A person close to the team said the three were offering about $1.3 billion. [35.]
 
Venezuela Gets $1.4 Billion Credit
Venezuela was awarded a $1.4 billion credit from the International Monetary Fund, a distinction that serves as a seal of approval on the country's new economic plan. The I.M.F. said the program would redress a dismal economic situation in a potentially rich oil-producing country, which has experienced slow growth, 57 percent inflation and a big budget deficit. [3.]
 
New Estimate of S.& L. Bailout Cost
The General Accounting Office released the most comprehensive study so far on the costs of the savings and loan bailout, placing a total price tag on the debacle of nearly half a trillion dollars, including more than $130 billion from taxpayers. The figures were roughly in line with previous estimates, and included both direct and indirect costs as well as interest payments that will run for decades. [34.]
 
Milken Settles Lawsuits
Michael R. Milken has quietly settled lawsuits with his former accountant, removing one worry as Mr. Milken's recent business activities continue to be scrutinized by Securities and Exchange Commission investigators. [34.]
 
Putting a Premium on Wind
The city-owned utility in Traverse City, Mich., has persuaded customers to pay 20 percent more for electricity to gain a clean source of energy from the nation's largest windmill. This is the first time a windmill has been built by charging utility customers a premium. [6.]
 
Dollar Gains Strength
The dollar rose against most leading currencies, helped by big purchases by Japanese buyers and by gains in the United States bond market. The strength of the dollar against the yen also helped it advance against the mark and other currencies. [32.]
 
Corn and Soybean Prices Surge
Corn and soybean futures prices surged on the Chicago Board of Trade, following forecasts for scorching, dry weather in the Midwest that threatens to ravage late-planted crops. On other markets, coffee prices fell and natural gas rose. [32.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Chrysler Quarter Profit Surges but Stock Takes a Hit

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 12

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation announced today that its second-quarter earnings surged more than sevenfold, meeting Wall Street's expectations, but its stock fell as investors worried about slowing auto sales and growing competition in key markets like sport utility vehicles and mini-vans.
Chrysler said its net income totaled $1.04 billion, or $2.77 a share, for the quarter. Adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split, effective Monday, the auto maker said it earned $1.39 a share in the most recent quarter. 
 Chrysler's after-tax profits were the third highest ever, after the fourth quarters of 1994 and 1995, when the company had substantial one-time tax credits. The company's pretax profits of $1.72 billion were the highest ever.
Moreover, sales in the latest quarter rose 26 percent, to $15.84 billion.
But traders on Wall Street were not satisfied, driving Chrysler's stock down $1.25 to close at $56.25. The Standard & Poor's index of the Big Three auto stocks has fallen 16.2 percent from a peak on May 22, as worries have spread about slowing sales, fierce competition, a possibly slowing economy and a strengthening dollar that helps Japanese auto makers.
Chrysler earned only $135 million, or 35 cents a share, on sales of just $12.52 billion in the second quarter of last year. But sales and earnings were depressed then by the company's difficulties in introducing a new line of mini-vans that have since proved very profitable.
Officials at Chrysler -- the third-largest American auto maker -- were cautiously optimistic about the future. "Assuming the economy holds, interest rates don't increase substantially and the industry settles with its represented workers without a strike, we're now projecting 1996 U.S. industry sales of 15.5 million units, up from earlier forecast of 15.3 million units," said Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, in a statement this morning.
Chrysler executives played down the possibility that the company's fat profit margins, which were $1,905 a vehicle in the second quarter, would erode as American and Japanese rivals introduce new sport utility vehicles and mini-vans. Chrysler's highly successful Jeep division and the Plymouth Voyager, Dodge Caravan and Chrysler Town & Country mini-vans are the cornerstones of the company's profitability.
James P. Holden, the executive vice president for sales and marketing, said in a telephone conference call with reporters that rivals had introduced new models before with limited success in gaining market share. "We've never had anybody take a bite out of us," he said.
Chrysler was the first auto maker to mass-produce a modern mini-van, and Mr. Holden said that the company was determined to stay the leader in that market. "We understand that segment better than anybody else," he said.
Nicholas Lobaccaro, an auto industry analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company, said that Chrysler remained in a fairly strong competitive position and that the fall in its stock today mainly reflected investor disenchantment with the entire auto sector.
"It's more of an industry concern rather than a Chrysler concern," he said. "We're at about as good as you're going to get."
Shares in the General Motors Corporation fell $1 today, to $48.25, while Ford Motor Company's stock dropped 37.5 cents, to $30.75.
W. Van Bussmann, Chrysler's chief economist, warned today in the company's conference call with reporters that the dollar's recent strength against the Japanese yen threatened to erode the American auto maker's recent gains. He contended that the dollar's strength reflected intervention in currency markets this year by the Bank of Japan and said that the Administration should get in touch with the bank to complain.
But Allen Sinai, the chief economist at Lehman Brothers, said that there was limited evidence that the dollar's rise was the result of any Government intervention.
Chrysler's results for the last quarter include a $101 million gain, or $87 million after taxes, from the sale of the military electronics and aircraft-remodeling divisions. The results also include a $65 million charge, or $100 million after taxes, for losses on the company's investment in the Thrifty Rent-A-Car System Inc.
Chrysler is trying to sell Thrifty along with another auto rental company, Dollar Rent A Car Systems Inc. "We view the rental car industry as one you can participate in quite nicely without owning a rental car company, and with less risk," said Gary C. Valade, Chrysler's chief financial officer.

HEADLINE: Immigration Service Needs a Major Overhaul

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The photographs accompanying your July 9 news article about New York State farm workers were worth thousands of words. No other occupational group in America today would be expected to live with outhouses. 
 Although the only real avenue for meaningful improvement in farm workers' living and working conditions is self-organization, it is naive to suggest, as the article does, that if workers merely "understood how essential they are to the industry . . . they might be less timid about asking for better terms."
There is an oversupply of farm labor in the United States, resulting in high unemployment, underemployment and low wages. Many workers do not speak up because they fear replacement by a more compliant worker. The agricultural industry has perpetuated an oversupply of labor through immigration and labor legislation and by hiring workers who lack authorized status.
Farm labor organizing is made difficult by the lack of resources available to unions, discriminatory treatment of farm workers in labor legislation and the limited government resources assigned to enforce the law against the powerful agribusiness industry. Public support for labor organizing and boycotts against the products of abusive employers helps farm workers overcome these odds.
 
BRUCE GOLDSTEIN
Co-director
Farmworker Justice Fund
Washington, July 10, 1996
