LENGTH: 8563 words

HEADLINE: A Fundamental Problem

BYLINE: By JASON DEPARLE; Jason DeParle is a staff writer for the Magazine, based in Washington.

 BODY:
BOB DOLE DOES NOT MAKE SMALL TALK EASILY, but as his plane idles this campaign morning, he gives it a go. He sheds his suit coat and strolls back to the press cabin, where, in a starched shirt, he stands and starts chatting about his dog. Dole mentions the going-away party that awaits him in the Senate and flatters reporters by promising to have them home early, in time to take the afternoon off.
The geniality does not last. 
 "Senator, a serious question," begins one of the two dozen journalists who have just watched him work a convention of Catholic editors. "Can you tell us about your visit with the Cardinal?" More specifically, the reporter wants to know what Anthony Cardinal Bevilacqua of Philadelphia said about the party's anti-abortion plank, the 98 words of political nitroglycerin that are threatening to detonate next month at the Republican Party's national convention in San Diego.
Dole's mouth tightens and his eyes flicker warily. "Obviously he feels strongly about it," he says. Well yes, Senator, but how about you? How do you feel? During the long pause that follows, Dole looks about as comfortable as Dan Quayle at a spelling bee; the grinding of the mental gears is all but audible as he searches for something to say.
Failing, he simply turns and stalks off. This odd, silent exit is nearly complete when he returns to vent a final word of protest. "If war were declared tonight and I went on a talk show," he growls, "the first question would be about abortion."
The whirring microcassettes replay every word, but the real issue is not abortion, and Dole himself knows it. The debate about platform language has saturated the news for weeks, down to the level of farce, but as a guidepost to action, the platform is all but meaningless. What's really at stake is the formidable coalition that has brought Republican victories in three of the last four Presidential elections and established the party dominance nationwide. More specifically, the question is whether Dole can mobilize the religious conservatives, who are at once the party's most energetic supporters and also its most obstreperous. And can he do it without alienating the other constituents -- economic conservatives and moderate swing voters -- he needs to overcome his daunting deficit in the polls?
Heading toward San Diego, he is more than mindful of his party's mistakes at the Houston convention in 1992, when Patrick Buchanan's call for a "religious war" thrilled the faithful but sent others fleeing the Big Tent. These days, there are intriguing divisions inside the religious right itself, at least at the leadership level and perhaps as the grass roots, too. There are unbowed believers like Buchanan, who demand orthodoxy on abortion and gay rights. But there are others, most notably Ralph Reed of the Christian Coalition, who find Dole's half-loaf offering of old-fashioned, mainstream conservatism preferable to noble defeat. Dole sought the nomination claiming he could unite the party's ideological camps; now, through awkward silences and caustic outbursts, he is mired in the work of proving it.
Dole's ties to religious conservatives have always had an air of ambiguity, despite two impressive credentials -- his solid anti-abortion voting record and his popular, evangelical wife. The movement runs on ideological fervor; Dole is a Beltway operator distrustful of insurgencies. Where the insurgents are earnest, he is ironic. Where they demand conviction, he worships the effective compromise. Before a movement born of preachers, Dole stands a legislator through to the bone. The intraparty abortion wars of the past few months have only magnified the underlying doubts. Dole brokered a peace, then shocked his own staff by scrapping it and lashing out at a prominent opponent of abortion. "I don't know where these people come from, you know," he said.
Perhaps Dole still harbors long-shot hopes of crowning his ticket with Colin Powell, who supports abortion rights. Perhaps he is seeking his own Sister Souljah, some irksome ally he can profitably defy to broadcast his own independence. Or maybe he just figures that with President Clinton as the alternative, religious conservatives have no place to go. Maybe he even believes that beneath the roar, the Christian right is a paper tiger.
But when he arrives in San Diego next month, Dole will be surrounded by delegates disproportionately chosen from the movement's ranks. And they have readied themselves for rebellion, against the leadership of the party and even the conciliators in their own ranks. Earlier this month, Dole riled them again when he said he would have no problem with a Vice President who supported abortion rights. Possible insurrections now lurk on any number of fronts -- including the platform, the treatment of Buchanan and Dole's choice of a running mate.
Trailing this summer by as much as 20 points, Dole cannot live without the foot soldiers of the religious right. But two related questions are as pointed as ever: Can he live with them? And can they live with him?
 
SENATOR INSIDE'S HISTORY WITH THE BELIEVERS
BOB DOLE SWEPT THE FURNITURE from his Senate office in the spring of 1993 and invited a crowd to breakfast. Though the leaders of the Christian right had been blamed for George Bush's defeat in the previous fall's election, Dole wanted to keep getting to know them. A cross-section of the self-described "family values" movement showed up. Among them were Ralph Reed, the fresh-faced Wunderkind of the Christian Coalition, and his older, overshadowed rival, Gary Bauer of the Family Research Council. There were representatives of Phyllis Schlafly's Eagle Forum, Louis Sheldon's Traditional Values Coalition and Beverly LaHaye's Concerned Women for America. While scarcely household names, these were the organizers with the mailing lists and telephone trees, the ones who can light up the Capitol switchboard over Washington's apostasies.
Dole served them fruit, cereal and a videotape lampooning Bob Dole. The sketch, from "Saturday Night Live," featured a caustic Dole (Dan Aykroyd) doing battle on health care with an overbearing Hillary Rodham Clinton (Jan Hooks) as her feckless husband (Phil Hartman) looked on. The Aykroyd character was sufficiently true to Dole's dark side that not everyone knew whether to laugh: "All right, Hillary, one more word outta you and you're gonna be a stain on that back wall." But Dole thought it was a riot. He took questions, joked about the legislative session and sent people home feeling good.
It was May 18, 1993 -- nearly three years before the first primary vote would be cast. Reed was particularly impressed. "What's so smart about it was he knew that most of those leaders would support someone else, either privately or publicly," he recalls. "But the key was: 'Let's stay close, let's have our line of communication.' "
In other words, Dole understood himself well enough to realize that he wouldn't be the first choice of most Christian activists; he understood politics well enough to realize that he couldn't afford to be their last. From the spring of 1993 to his breakthrough in the South Carolina primary nearly three years later, Dole did just enough to get by.
A Republican Presidential aspirant really has no other choice. Fully 23 percent of registered Republicans now say yes when asked if they consider themselves "part of the conservative Christian political movement, also known as the religious right." (The figure is an average from six polls taken this year by CBS and The New York Times.) And larger percentages show up to vote. This year, 29 percent of the primary voters called themselves part of the religious right. In the kickoff state of Iowa, the number was 35 percent. In South Carolina, the gateway to the South, it was 36 percent.
But even those figures may underestimate the disproportionate influence that comes from the advocates' commitment. God is a formidable ward boss, and people whose politics flow from their faith make unusually dedicated grunts. Two years ago, Campaign and Elections magazine did a nationwide survey and concluded that religious conservatives "dominated" the Republican Party in 18 states. (That means a majority of the party's governing body was "directly affiliated" with the movement.) In 13 other states, the movement had "substantial" influence, meaning its members accounted for more than a quarter of the state hierarchy.
Dole presented the Christian advocates with a mixed picture. He is a divorced man who is said to attend the church of the Sunday talk show. Intensely private, he is ill-at-ease with the pulpit's confessional style. And while he has a strong anti-abortion record, he prefers to talk about other things, like deficit reduction or taxes. Moreover, the very quality that made him effective in the Senate -- his skill at forging compromises -- makes him suspect to those seeking ideological steel. "I am willing to be another Ronald Reagan, if that's what you want," Dole said last year, as if to advertise his rubber soul.
On the other hand, distasteful as he might find it, Dole had shown he could play the abortion card when it suited his purposes. Indeed, he was the rare member of the Senate who owed his seat to his exploitation of the issue. He was heading toward defeat in his 1974 race when, in the final minute of a televised debate, Dole assailed the obstetrician he was running against: "Why do you do abortions? And why do you favor abortions on demand?" Dr. Bill Roy, his Democratic opponent, was left speechless, not least (as Richard Ben Kramer reports in his book "Bob Dole") because he loathed abortions and had performed them only on rare instances to save a mother's life. Dole closed the race by telling schoolchildren to "go home and ask your parents if they know how many abortions Bill Roy has performed." He won by a sliver.
And however warmed-over Dole's own faith might appear, his wife has no hesitation in proclaiming hers. Indeed, for the past nine years Elizabeth Dole, the president of the American Red Cross, has traveled the country discussing "the difference Jesus Christ has made in my life." A former Cabinet secretary under Presidents Reagan and Bush, Dole likens herself to Esther, the Old Testament queen who clung to her comforts. She says she, too, was once spiritually drowning in the flood of her secular successes. Then beginning in the mid-1980's, a series of Bible studies and prayer meetings led her back to her faith. "I knew it was time to cease living life backwards, time to strive to put Christ first, pre-eminent -- with no competition, at the very center of my life," she says.
It sounds like something Pat Robertson might say -- and the affection of the televangelist and Christian Coalition chairman gave Bob Dole another hidden asset. The two had grown fond of each other during their unsuccessful Presidential races in 1988. An unlikely match on the surface, the legislator and the preacher have a few things in common, including a generational bond (Dole is only seven years older); the Senate (where Robertson's father also served); law school, and military service.
Though Robertson shuns interview requests (especially when they concern his conspiracy theories about Jewish bankers), I found him one evening at a banquet table honoring Billy Graham. Effusive in his praise of Dole, he launched into a story about a 1988 Presidential debate. With Democrats and Republicans all set to quiz one another, Dole sent an emissary to Robertson's room to warn him of the questions he planned to ask. "He wanted our guys -- namely, the Republican candidates -- to look good," Robertson said. "I just liked him. Bob is a straight-shooting, honest, honorable man." As for Dole's wife, "She's deeply loved by people; she's a dear friend of mine. I think the world of her and I'd love to see her in the White House."
As the 1996 race took shape, Dole got a lift from the abstention of rivals with more obvious appeal to Christian conservatives, including Dan Quayle, William Bennett and Jack Kemp. Then he waged an effective campaign to keep the candidate he considered most threatening, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, from outflanking him on the right.
In part, he did it with hires. Beefing up his staff with movement types, Dole brought a crusading conservative lawyer named Kyle McSlarrow into his Senate office to keep an eye on legislative business and he brought Steve Scheffler and Judy Haynes into his campaign, giving him the services of two top Christian Coalition organizers.
In part he did it with bills. Dole beat Gramm to the punch with proposals to curb affirmative action, rein in Government regulation and bolster private-property rights. And in part he did it with the inherent power of his post as Senate majority leader. When Clinton nominated Dr. Henry Foster as Surgeon General, Dole had another obstetrician to attack; he denied Foster a confirmation vote, citing his conflicting statements about the number of abortions he had performed.
As he tightened his ties to the Christian right, Dole got considerable lift from Gramm's own missteps, most famously his disastrous meeting with James Dobson, the Colorado Springs psychologist and religious broadcaster. Though little known to the general public, Dobson is the Sam Walton of the family values movement, a distributor with unparalleled reach. His daily broadcasts attract more than three million listeners on 1,500 radio stations, and his organization, Focus on the Family, has a mailing list of 2.2 million. In April 1995, he flew to Washington to hear out Gramm.
The meeting was sufficiently important that Ralph Reed, seeking to be useful, stopped in beforehand to warn Gramm that Dobson would want moral reassurances. Instead, Gramm burst in late and proclaimed, "I ain't running for preacher, that's your job." Incensed, Dobson spread the word. Gramm grew so desperate to regain his squandered credibility that a few months later he began mass mailings to announce his anticipation of the Second Coming. "And when He comes back, He won't need government to impose His values," he wrote.
Dole found a better way of courting the religious right: he blasted the morals of Hollywood. The timing couldn't have been more fortuitous. Just as Gramm was self-destructing, Dole was denouncing the "mindless violence and loveless sex" glorified by the entertainment industry. Though Dole himself nearly balked at giving it (as Bob Woodward reports in "The Choice"), the May 1995 speech brought him greater accolades than his campaign had dared imagine. Its glory is that it worked on two levels. Without ever mentioning God or church, Dole found an intimate connection to conservative Christians. But he also found enough secular resonance to land on the "CBS Evening News."
The speech came long before Buchanan's insurgency caught fire and before Reed went quietly scrambling for a fire hose for Dole. But to this day, the Dole campaign regards the speech as both a highlight of the past and a model for the future. It remains in continual search of Hollywood sequels -- double-coded messages that rouse the faithful while also assembling the larger coalition Dole needs. "The foundation of Bob Dole's victory as the Republican nominee was made in the Hollywood speech," Reed says. "That was where he made an explicit and eloquent appeal to religious conservatives, based on a moral issue."
 
PRIMARY DANCE: ONE STEP TOWARD GOD, ONE STEP BACK
A FEW DAYS BEFORE THE NEW HAMPshire primary, Elizabeth Dole battled a blizzard to reach a Christian Coalition rally in Manchester. But she might just as profitably have stayed home. As she labored through her speech with a cheerleader smile, the boredom in the room was palpable. This was Buchanan country, and Buchanan himself had just roused the crowd with a defiant defense of his Houston speech. "There is a cultural war!" he bellowed to chants of "Go, Pat, Go!"
In the aftermath, Dole was left facing the flannel-shirt crowd in a perky lime dress; she looked like a country-club hostess and sounded like a banker. "Now how would a balanced budget affect you?" she said. "Well, for one thing, interest rates would drop 2 percent." Twenty-six television cameras rolled and no one clapped.
Representative Bob Dornan, the Zhirinovsky of the race, happened to be sitting in the front row, where he leaned over and promised Garry Trudeau, the creator of "Doonesbury," "I won't lose their attention." And he didn't. He followed Dole's flop with an incoherent screed about abortion, Jesus and United Nations troops, and he won a standing ovation. It was a bad sign, on the eve of the New Hampshire primary, to earn less applause than Bob Dornan.
But the Dole campaign's relationship with the religious right has just this rocking-horse rhythm: one lurch forward and one lurch back. Every appeal to Christian conservatives seems counterbalanced by a move that ignores, insults or misgauges them, at times even gratuitously so. It could be a Machiavellian plot to establish Dole's steely independence. At times, it could be ineptitude. But William Kristol, the Republican strategist who regularly throws darts at Dole in his magazine, The Weekly Standard, offers a third interpretation: when it comes to those on the religious right, Dole is deeply ambivalent. "He thinks they're very important and he thinks they're very difficult," Kristol says. As a result, Dole finds himself "oscillating between semi-pandering to them and semi-offending them."
The semi-offenses had started long before the primaries. Dole tangled with Christian conservatives over last year's welfare bill, backing cuts that were (slightly) less severe than they desired. He risked their wrath over homosexuality, when he said his staff was wrong to return a campaign check to the Log Cabin Republicans, a gay rights group. He ignored the calls from the Christian right to fire Sheila Burke, his chief of staff and a supporter of abortion rights, whom they assailed as "Hillary Lite." And he ignored calls to sign a pledge, being circulated by Phyllis Schlafly, to keep the anti-abortion plank. "Sign the pledge, sign the pledge," his detractors taunted last September at the Christian Coalition's annual convention.
Dole's troubles with the religious right accelerated last December when he fumbled a question on "Meet the Press." Would he support a constitutional amendment to ban all abortions? "I supported that at one time," Dole said. "I would not do it again." What's more, he added, "My view as a Republican candidate is this shouldn't be a dominant issue in the Republican nomination or the campaign for President in 1996."
He might just as well have gone on the "700 Club" to spit in Pat Robertson's eye. It took several days of Dole "clarifications" to quell the protests from Gary Bauer and Ralph Reed. Dole said he was simply reiterating his longstanding support of exceptions for rape, incest and the life of the mother. But Iowa right-to-lifers were still carrying the clips around two months later on caucus day.
And Dole was tripping on his words once more, on the cusp of the South Carolina primary. A woman stood up during a television debate and asked, "If I am brutally raped by a vicious criminal," would Dole let her have an abortion. First he said no. Then he said yes. Then he said he agreed with Buchanan, who, in much more lyrical terms, had said absolutely not.
As his abortion credentials flagged, Dole did himself further damage with the Christian right: he went on the air with television ads dismissing Buchanan as an extremist. Outside the narrow confines of Christian conservatism, this might seem an unremarkable statement; certainly Buchanan's been called worse. But inside the movement -- indeed, inside factions of the Dole campaign -- jaws were dropping. Christian conservatives had been called "extremists" for years, and many deeply resented it. Dole simply couldn't have picked a more loaded phrase. "These people feel that when you use that term, that it's like the N-word to an African-American," Reed says. "You're shooting at Buchanan and you're hitting the base of the party."
A flabbergasted Buchanan, feeling personally betrayed, began warning that he might not support Dole even if he won the nomination. Reed was quietly seeking to stem Buchanan's surge, but he, too, felt the need to react; avoiding any mention of Dole by name, he warned that such language represented "the curse words of the establishment and the slurs of the chatter class." To this day, Bay Buchanan, the candidate's sister, manager and confidante, sounds like Joe Pesce when she conjures the attack on family honor. "It was a slur against my brother -- Bob Dole knows my brother," she says. "It is extremely insulting."
After airing the ads for nine days in five states, a testy Dole finally pulled them and wrapped himself in semantics. The ads had literally called Buchanan "too extreme," leaving off the suffix. "I haven't characterized him as 'an extremist,' " he said. "I have said 'mainstream or extreme.' " But within a few days, Dole's deputy campaign chairman, Bill Lacy, was out of a job, and his promotion of the E-word, in whichever iteration, was one of the reasons.
In an interview months later, eager to boost Dole's standing, Reed gave him the benefit of the doubt. "I sensed that somebody had written those remarks for Dole," he said. "He didn't know it was code." But in a sense that's worse: by Reed's current logic, Dole is so out of touch with religious conservatives that he can shower them with epithets and not even know it.

AT THE GRASS ROOTS FOR GOD, BUT NOT NECESSARILY FOR DOLE
THE DEPTH OF THE RESULTING DOUBTS about Dole could be seen one April evening in Horseheads, N.Y., a wisp of a town a few miles from the Pennsylvania border. Four hundred and fifty people, from the Mayor on down, had gathered at the high-school cafeteria, where a roast beef dinner would net $20,000 for a local anti-abortion group. Gary Bauer was the keynote speaker. A short, slight, serious man with a nasally voice and bulging round eyes, Bauer had come up the hard way. He was born on the wrong side -- the sinning side -- of the river; his home of Newport, Ky., was a blue-collar gambling den in the shadows of Cincinnati, the birthplace of Ivory soap. His father was a janitor and a lifelong alcoholic.
The younger Bauer found the Baptist church through his maternal grandmother and became a teen-age enthusiast in a Republican crusade to clean up the town's bars. After earning a law degree at Georgetown University, Bauer wound up as a 35-year-old gofer in the Reagan White House, literally "getting people's lunches"; he finished his tour as Reagan's domestic policy adviser and one of his most visible New Right ideologists.
Along the way he met James Dobson, who had joined a White House anti-smut crusade. On the outer edges of Dobson's broadcasting-publishing-counseling empire was a moribund public-policy outfit called the Family Research Council. Dobson brought in Bauer to run it in 1988, and it has since become a buzzing warren of "family values" orthodoxy, with 75 employees, a $10 million budget and a full complement of books, newsletters and targets: from job-training programs to the Beijing women's conference. Though their groups are now legally independent, Bauer still operates as a Washington lens for Dobson, who features him regularly in broadcasts and publications.
The Horseheads crowd greeted Bauer like a star. They carried Jell-O molds and fruit punch to a reception in his honor, toted copies of his books and asked for his autographs. There were two doctors in the crowd, a man who runs a pizza parlor, a stay-at-home mom and a woman who makes jewelry from plastic fetus molds. The conversation quickly turned to the presumptive nominee. A middle-aged man in a business suit said: "I just can't get excited about Bob Dole."
A woman who home-schools her six children said: "He's so wishy-washy!"
A 40-something precinct worker said: "He talks pro-life but he acts pro-death!"
A grandmother asked Bauer what he made of Dole. "The only way to win is if he's clear on our issues," Bauer said. "Which he isn't!" she barked.
Caught in this semicircle of Betty Crocker ward bosses, Bauer gripped his punch glass with both hands and fought off a satisfied smile. "This is the time to let Senator Dole know that if he walks on you. . . ."
"We'll walk on him!" growled an otherwise placid woman in a floral print dress.
Standing in the lobby of the Howard Johnson's the following morning, Bauer had only one lament: if only Dole could have been there! "I think it would have helped him understand that he doesn't have the natural constituency of the Republican party nailed," he said. At least not that portion that pays for dinner with checks adorned with fetuses. "For those people last night, this is the reason they're in politics. And if you play games with the issue, you lose."
 
RALPH REED: MIDDLE MAN, BUT FOR WHOM?
FLYING BACK FROM HORSEHEADS, BAUER changed planes at LaGuardia, where he ran into Ralph Reed. On the surface, they were all smiles, but the underlying strains are no secret. Bauer is the Avis of the pair, perpetually No. 2, trying harder, and resentful of Reed's astonishing new market share; Reed, after all, was still jockeying for position in the College Republicans club at the University of Georgia when Bauer was sitting in the White House.
The two chatted amiably and parted. But a few weeks later, sitting in his office, I asked Bauer about Reed's new book, "Active Faith," which admonishes movement leaders to exercise a new "grace and humility, in speech and deed." Bauer frowned. He did not note that Reed himself used to boast of leaving his opponents in body bags. But he did mention the 1992 fund-raising letter from Reed's boss, Pat Robertson, which said feminism "encourages women to leave their husbands, kill their children, practice witchcraft, destroy capitalism and become lesbians."
"I don't have any objection to the idea of civility," Bauer said. "What's objectionable is to be lectured by someone who seems to think he is noble in this regard and everyone else needs lecturing." A few weeks later, I asked again: had Bauer read Reed's book? "I've been doing so much promotion of mine," he said. "We're up to 363,000 copies!"
There is more than mere ego involved. The two have competing visions of how the movement should evolve, with Bauer valuing purity over practicality. "This is obviously delicate," he said one day, tiptoeing around the subject. "Ralph is probably a bit more interested in being an inside player in the Republican Party."
A bit more interested indeed.
Reed may have been virtually unknown when Pat Robertson discovered him but he had spent his whole life training for the job. The son of a Navy surgeon, he grew up in Miami and Toccoa, Ga., and managed his first campaign in junior high school, his own race for the student council. In 1989, as the famous story goes, Robertson was at an inaugural party for George Bush when he met the impressive young organizer with the impossibly boyish face. He asked Reed for suggestions on salvaging a new grass-roots organization from his leftover campaign mailing list. Reed wrote a memo, and the two were off and running. Reed's telegenic brilliance offered a reassuring public face and it continues to deflect attention from Robertson's often-stated doubts about such matters as the separation of church and state.
Reed, who is 35, says his own "faith experience" occurred in 1983, shortly after his college graduation. He had come to Washington to head the College Republicans when one evening he spied a prominent conservative drinking and chasing women. Wanting to police his own morals, Reed decided to find a church by looking in the Yellow Pages -- under E for evangelical. Why evangelical? "Because I knew from my political involvement that they were solid," he explained recently.
The answer unlocks the essential Reed. While many religious leaders have described how their politics flowed from their faith (Reed's stated idol, Martin Luther King Jr., comes to mind), in Reed's case the reverse held true: his politics preceded -- even determined -- his church. The point isn't that Reed's faith is insincere, only that it is inessential to his vocation. Even when founding the Christian Coalition in 1989, "I did not consider myself a 'Christian activist,' " he writes in his book. "My background was as a Republican political operative."
His foreground still is. "Active Faith" puts the emphasis on the active, with Reed according himself V.I.P. status on nearly every page. "I ran across the Capitol grounds at breakneck speed and jumped into a waiting car, which squealed out of the parking lot and headed for the television studio," he writes in a typical passage. Like many others on the Christian right, Reed likes to describe himself as a member of a persecuted minority. But his recorded responses to the moments of alleged bigotry are revealing. There is nothing of the anxious trembling, the nauseating self-doubt, that has greeted the truly persecuted -- Gandhi, say, as he peered out at the British Empire. There is no internal bleeding. There is only the adrenaline rush that comes from glimpsing a tactical edge. When a Democratic Congressman attacked the religious right a few years ago, Reed joyously dashed off a press release. "That was all the opening we needed," he writes.
For the past several years, Reed has been admonishing his movement to broaden its reach and relax its ideological severity. With a doctorate in American history, he is painfully aware of the self-marginalizing political instincts evangelicals have shown, from William Jennings Bryan to Jerry Falwell, and he does not want to follow their path. As early as 1993, Reed published an article in Policy Review, the journal of the Heritage Foundation, arguing for a new Christian right. For religious conservatives "to win at the ballot box and in the court of public opinion," he wrote, they must embrace "the concerns of average voters in the areas of taxes, crime, government waste, health care and financial security."
Notice the words "to win." Reed is not indulging in philosophical rumination; he is counting votes. Like Dole, Reed knows that Christian conservatives, for all their vaunted influence in some Republican primaries, cannot win real power on their own. They can turn out voters and capture school-board seats. In close Congressional elections, they can make a difference. But the broader the race, the more their power fades -- especially when their own influence and ideology become the issue. Witness the defeats of Mike Farris, Jim Miller and Oliver North, three movement figures who ran for statewide offices in Virginia. All went down in flames in the Coalition's backyard.
The group's most celebrated victories tell the flip side of the same story. The Christian Coalition may have helped Newt Gingrich capture the House, as Reed often says, but the Republicans' Contract With America gave them virtually nothing in return. As a prime example of the group's electoral muscle, Reed often points to the 1992 election of Senator Paul Coverdell of Georgia. And the Coalition's support may have indeed made the difference; the group claims to have spread more than two million voter guides across Georgia. But as Reed acknowledges, Coverdell supports abortion rights! What Reed has called a symbol of his movement's "remarkable effectiveness" is simultaneously a symbol of its limits. It is "remarkably effective" only when tempering a central belief.
The 1996 campaign brought Reed a predicament -- "all dressed up and nowhere to go," he said recently. There was no obvious figure to support. Buchanan, of course, is the very definition of a social conservative: adamantly anti-abortion, anti-gay rights and vociferous on the traditional values themes. He is also precisely the kind of divisive, marginalizing figure that Reed considers a prescription for defeat. Though Reed had previously avoided public derogation, in "Active Faith" he goes as far as saying that Buchanan's campaign "recalled the pro-family movement's previous status as the red-headed stepchild of American politics."
What ensued is what Reed himself has called "a delicate dance." Officially, the group remained neutral. Behind the scenes, Reed said in an interview, "I had a very self-conscious strategy to have Christian Coalition operatives working in every Presidential campaign." The better to cover his bets. ("I think early on he was watching Gramm," Bay Buchanan says.) But what Reed finally appeared to bet on most of all was the success of the front-runner.
The subject is a touchy one. Reed adamantly denies any tilt toward Dole. "We didn't do anything to advocate the election or defeat of Dole," he says. "I was not tacitly for anyone. I was neutral." But there are three things to keep in mind. By the time he hit South Carolina, Dole was on the ropes; Reed considered the surging Buchanan a threat to his movement, and the Coalition's South Carolina network was crucial in helping Dole turn Buchanan back. Speaking of Reed, Bay Buchanan says, "There's no question in my mind that he was involved, to make certain Pat wasn't the nominee."
The details make for a long he-said, she-said exchange between the Buchanans and Reed. The Buchanan camp is especially bitter about the Coalition's voter guides, the main weapon in the group's arsenal. To preserve its credibility, not to mention its tax-exempt status, the Coalition clings to the fiction that the guides are strictly informational, with no endorsement intent. But Democratic candidates have long considered them the paper equivalent of a hit and run. And so now does Bay Buchanan. The guide omitted Dole's support of Nafta and GATT; it was silent on Dole's refusal to sign the Schlafly abortion pledge, and it neglected his support of Clinton's Supreme Court choices, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen Breyer, both of whom are supporters of abortion rights. Indeed, of the 14 issues listed in the guide, Dole and Buchanan are shown holding the same position on 12. "The conclusion, from the editing, is that there is no difference," Bay Buchanan says.
Reed defends the guides by saying that Dole aides were correspondingly upset that the guides noted Dole's support for rape and incest exceptions and his refusal to condemn Congressional pensions. "The Christian Coalition distributed nonpartisan voter guides that favored no candidate," Reed says.
Bay Buchanan is equally miffed about the grass-roots jockeying in South Carolina. While much of the credit for Dole's win has gone to David Beasley, the Governor, and Carroll Campbell, the ex-Governor, Dole's Coalition connections were also a key. Reed's former deputy, Judy Haynes, had been working the state for Dole for a year. "She basically moved to South Carolina," says Scott Reed, the Dole campaign manager (and no relation to Ralph Reed). On most of her trips, Haynes stayed with Roberta Combs, the Coalition's South Carolina director. While Combs has said she stayed officially neutral, Scott Reed puts it differently: "She and Judy are the best of friends, and they went down there and put the thing together with Beasley."
Ralph Reed says he had nothing to do with Haynes's work for Dole. But Rod Mays, a Greenville, S.C., pastor, says he received numerous phone calls from other local Coalition leaders urging him to support Dole despite their official neutrality. "What really angered me was an organization that claims to be Christian talking out of both sides of their mouth," Mays says.
Enough people share Mays's perception to leave Reed in a potentially awkward position: some of his troops think he's responsible for the candidate now flouting their concerns. Whether that will drive him harder to bring Dole around -- or at some point denounce him, to burnish his movement bona fides -- is still anyone's guess. Bay Buchanan goes as far as arguing that Reed is "no longer a legitimate leader of the social conservatives in this country." In New Jersey, a Coalition member was so incensed at what he called the tilt toward Dole that he put out an electronic news release with this subtle title: "The New Blasphemy: Rigging the Election Results by Fraud in the Name of Jesus Christ!"
Though a lawyer for the Coalition fired off a letter, warning of libel, Reed now says it's all a sign of progress: "Any leader of a social-reform movement who is on the cutting edge of tactical and strategic shifts by that movement is going to experience some level of ambivalence, and sometimes opposition, from others in that movement. And that is not a sign of anything other than the fact that you're moving the ball down the field."
 
ON ABORTION: DOLE MAKES PEACE -- AND BREAKS IT
ACROSS FROM THE National Cathedral in Washington, the Cafe Deluxe offers meat loaf, martinis and a mahagony bar -- just the sort of a stylish new place where a happy operative might sit and savor a success. On the the second Monday of June, a high prince of the Dole campaign was doing exactly that. He was recounting -- with great detail, understandable pride and an insistence on anonymity -- how the campaign had defused the abortion plank controversy, thereby insuring a harmonious convention in San Diego.
Only a few days earlier, after months of anticipation, Dole had finally stated his position. Despite the growing criticisms of moderate Republican governors, he would keep the strict anti-abortion plank. But he would also add "tolerance language" to assure supporters of abortion rights that their concerns were understood. Dole's statement had achieved the seemingly impossible. It won generous praise from the advocates of abortion rights, like Gov. Christie Todd Whitman of New Jersey. Yet the opponents, including Buchanan himself, declared they were happy, too.
"We're geniuses!" the Dole aides had told one another, as they watched that evening's news. There was just one arcane detail left: where to put this "tolerance language"? Dole had strongly implied, without flatly stating, that it would go in the preamble to the entire platform, not in the abortion plank itself. That way it would acknowledge disagreements in many areas, without suggesting any particular wobbliness in the commitment to the unborn.
From afar this seems like so much talk of angels on a pin -- either way, the plank still calls for a complete abortion ban. But to finely trained ears, it is a matter of, well, life and death. "There's no confusion here," Deep Bistro told me as he munched his Caesar salad. "We're talking about the whole platform, not the plank."
What the Dole aide didn't know was that, at the very moment we were eating lunch, Dole was going on CNN to fire-bomb his hard-won peace. The conversation was over, Dole said; the disclaimer goes directly in the plank. "It has been resolved," he said. "I made that decision. It is not negotiable."
And hundreds of anti-abortion delegates immediately vowed to fight him. Representative Henry Hyde, Dole's choice to head the platform committee, even warned that he might resign. What could Dole have been thinking? There are two possibilities: a) he wasn't or b) the plank itself is so unpopular that Dole felt he had to find a way to further distance himself from it, even at the risk of inciting the right. Dole's erratic campaign style points toward the former, but the polling data hint at the latter.
While the anti-abortion forces have fervor on their side, two-thirds of the party favors keeping some form of abortion legal. The plank, by contrast, calls for a constitutional amendment to ban all abortions. There are no stated exceptions for rape or incest; there are no stated exceptions for the life of the mother. There are, it appears, simply no exceptions. According to The Philadelphia Inquirer, when the National Republican Senatorial Committee polled the party this spring, it found that as many as 40 percent of Republicans were considering a vote for Clinton because their own party was so strident on social issues.
Reed saw the problem coming and he wound up the first to be burned. When he sent "Active Faith" to press last winter, he included his own stab at an alternate plank and quickly found himself labeled a Judas. By accident or design, Reed's language was perfectly ambiguous on the central issue of the debate: whether the plank would call for a constitutional amendment. It pledged to "seek by all legal and constitutional means to protect the right to life." But does that mean under the current Constitution? Or under an amended one?
The unveiling of Reed's plank happened to coincide with a news conference Bay Buchanan had organized to threaten Dole, but she now had Reed in her cross hairs as well. "We are saying no words can be changed," she said. "We will fight them inside the convention hall. We will fight them outside the hall. We will fight them on radio, on TV, in the mail, on the phones. We will fight and fight and fight until we win. There is no compromise. There is no negotiating. There is no appeasement."
Within a few days, Reed was calling it all a great misunderstanding; he had written his plank merely as an intellectual exercise, he said, not as a trial balloon. "I think that my pro-family and pro-life credentials are, you know, beyond reproach. For anyone to suggest that I was planning on going to San Diego to water down the platform is laughable." Bay Buchanan puts it differently: "That prodigal son didn't get to the end of the block."
Reed's experience in touching the third rail eerily presaged Dole's. The campaign started searching for a compromise as early as April, when the moderate governors began threatening a floor fight. The Dole aides then found the tolerance language in a particularly thrilling place: Ronald Reagan's 1980 platform. Who would quarrel with the Gipper? Dole gave the go-ahead and they released the statement of June 6 to rave reviews.
Four days later, Dole snatched defeat from the jaws of victory. His vow to single out the abortion plank itself for tolerance language was especially galling to the religious right, since it came during an interview that was mostly devoted to praising their nemesis, Colin Powell. "In my heart, he's a great guy," Dole said. Though Powell has stated he will not join the ticket, he is widely thought to be Dole's first choice as a running mate. And he unambiguously supports abortion rights. Smelling a conspiracy to lure a moderate onto the ticket, the right issued all manner of dark warnings.
By the next day, Dole had had enough. He was stepping down from the Senate, capping a 35-year career on Capitol Hill. He was about to make his last address in the legislative chamber he loved; he was thinking back on his proud battles for food stamps, disability rights and deficit reduction. He made time for a morning interview with a Kansas City television station and was promptly asked about . . . Abortion! The plank! Something Gary Bauer just said!
Gary Bauer? "What's the difference if it's in the preamble or the platform," Dole barked. I mean, this is a moral issue."
Dole went on: "I don't know where Gary Bauer's been all his life, but I've always know that we have had pro-choice Republicans and pro-life Republicans."
And on: "If he's not tolerant, he ought to say so. I happen to be tolerant. . . ."
And even that wasn't enough to get it off Dole's chest. Bauer "misinterprets about everything I say -- I mean, I think he looks for reasons to put out press releases."
Was Dole searching for his Sister Souljah? If so, he didn't quite find her. The rap singer, recall, was advocating the murder of white people; Clinton's rebuke of her during the 1992 campaign was effective but not particularly risky. Dole by contrast might consider Bauer just the kind of unelected, publicity-seeking nag he disdains. But when it comes to abortion, Bauer speaks for a powerful, well-organized faction of the party, whose support Dole needs.
The tumult unfolded according to script. Bauer dashed to the "Crossfire" studio. Dobson interrupted the previously scheduled broadcast across his 1,500-station archipelago. "When you're talking about killing babies," he warned, "there's not a whole lotta room for compromise." Weary of managing the unmanageable, the Dole aides didn't even try to dress up the mess with a positive spin. Their subsequent silence sent only one message: When it comes to this abortion debate, there's no telling what Dole will do.
 
WILL SAN DIEGO BE '92 REVISITED?
AS DOLE GIRDS himself for San Diego, he might stop and think of the Alamo -- or, more precisely, the Alamodome. Sixteen thousand Texas delegates gathered there on a 103-degree day last month, intent on making a statement. The statement was not one of even tepid support for the party's presumed nominee. The statement the delegates made was one of fierce, anti-abortion zeal.
A movement was afoot to keep Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison from joining the 123-member delegation Texas will send to San Diego. Never mind that Hutchison, who won her 1994 election with 61 percent of the vote, happens to be one of the most popular politicians in Texas. She also supports abortion rights. "We are not here to play political games," said Colleen Parro, a leader of the insurrection. "We are here to stamp out a great moral evil: abortion."
The dickering went on for three days, and in the end Hutchison squeaked through. But not by much. After a voice vote proved too close to call, she was declared a victor by the chairman's eye-count of thousands of standing bodies. And Hutchison notwithstanding, the delegation Texas is sending to San Diego cares more about abortion than it cares about Dole. The two Texans who will join the platform committee, David Barton and Betty Lou Martin, are stalwarts of the religious right. Barton is best known as the author of a book called "The Myth of Separation." Of church and state, that is.
So much for the outbreak of "tolerance."
Similar scenes have played out at state conventions across the country. In Washington State, the chairman of the Republican Party got ousted as a delegate after refusing to let Buchanan speak. In Minnesota, two members of the delegation vowed to vote for Alan Keyes if Dole picks a running mate who wants to keep abortion legal. In South Carolina, Carroll Campbell scarcely got himself elected a delegate; though the ex-governor is one of the most popular politicians in the state, he finished 12th in the balloting, behind a slate of unknown Christian Coalition members.
Beyond the abortion plank, there's the question of Buchanan: will he be allowed to speak? Bay Buchanan keeps a map of San Diego on her desk and surveys her options like a SWAT-team captain. "He is owed both an apology and he's owed a prime-time spot," she said. "We expect the address to be prime time inside the convention hall." She stabbed the map. "Otherwise, it'll be prime time outside the convention hall. I have no problem with that. I think the press would be quite interested in a Pat Buchanan speech outside the convention hall."
Reed's role in the endless negotiations is a wonder to behold. He flew into San Antonio by charter plane and veered from provocateur to peacemaker in the course of a single evening. When a fund-raising dinner for the Christian Coalition filled a ballroom with 2,000 people, Reed served red meat. They will not "cower behind the stained-glass ghetto."
"We are Christians!" Reed thundered, and the crowd was on its feet. "And we honor and serve our God. We are not going to apologize for being Christians anymore. To anyone!"
What Reed didn't mention was that he was also neck-deep in the behind-the-scenes efforts to allow Hutchison to become a delegate, despite her support for abortion rights. And when the dinner was over, he retired to a suite the size of a modest train station and talked of possible deals with Dole. He had more angles in mind than I. M. Pei. Where could the tolerance language go? "You could put it at the beginning, you could put it at the end," he said. "You could have it in a declaration of principles. There's been some talk about having a preamble, and then having a declaration of principles, and then having a platform itself.
"We're trying to get to the same place," Reed added. "I am optimistic."
Before heading to San Antonio, I stopped to chat with another "senior official" in the Dole campaign. This one, let's call him Deep Reassurance, scoffed at the idea that Dole has a problem with the right. While a handful of zealots might try to cause trouble, he insisted that religious conservatives were not fixated on abortion. "They live lives like everyone else," he said. "They're interested in taxes, crime, honesty in government."
The plank controversy will eventually get settled, he said, and Dole will then return to events like the Hollywood speech, messages that offer a double bang for the buck. Like time limits on welfare recipients. Campaign polls show that 75 percent of the moderates support them -- as do 85 percent of the religious conservatives. The same goes for term limits for Federal judges. Or a tax credit for families. "And there's economic angst and cultural decline," he went on, in happy anticipation of the misery to milk. "And by doing these things, doing them correctly, you can both energize your base and build a broader electoral coalition."
Candidates shouldn't get too worried about cantankerous members of their base, he added. Democrats like Walter Mondale and Michael Dukakis spent too much time worrying about unions and minorities, and they lost. Similarly, George Bush spent too much time in 1992 worrying about religious conservatives. "He paid them so much attention, to the exclusion of other things like jobs and the economy," he said. Clinton, by contrast, often kept his base at odds in 1992, not just with Sister Souljah, but with his calls to end welfare and his support of the death penalty. And he's doing it again this year with homosexual supporters, by refusing to defend gay marriage. "Bill Clinton has shown you can walk pretty far from your base and still not lose them," the Dole aide said.
But can Bob Dole walk that walk? He has a different party, a different personality and a much more contentious issue. On the very day the Texans were jeering the mention of his name at the Alamodome, Dole was in Michigan, trying to get the focus off abortion and on to farm policy. Working a rope line, he came across a middle-aged woman in a flowery blouse holding a placard. "Challenge Clinton, Not Bauer," it said. Seeming not to notice, Dole paused to shake her hand.
"I'm worried about the babies, sir," she said.
" 'Bout what?" Dole asked.
"The babies."
Arrghhh -- one of those! "Yeah, I'm worried too," Dole said, moving on. "Check my record."
"Yeah?" the woman shouted at the back of his head. "Don't waffle so much."
Dole twisted his mouth toward a sardonic smile, but he didn't look back. "We don't waffle," he said.

HEADLINE: Q. & A.

 BODY:

Tenant's Refusal To Pay
 
Q. I own a co-op apartment that I rent out to a subtenant. Recently, in accordance with the sublease agreement, the subtenant's rent increased by 10 percent. However, the subtenant does not want to pay the increase and has sent rent checks for a lower amount with the following endorsement written on the back of the check: "In full payment of all rent due this month."
Can I deposit such checks but still sue the subtenant for the overdue balance? Is it better to retain such checks as evidence to be used in a non-payment proceeding? . . . Hilda Saibon, Brooklyn.
 
A. Samuel Himmelstein, a Manhattan lawyer who specializes in landlord-tenant matters, said that assuming the apartment is deregulated and the rent increase is legal (which it would likely not be in a rent-stabilized or rent-controlled apartment), "my advice would be to reject the money and sue for nonpayment of rent for the full amount."
If the owner cashes or deposits the check, Mr. Himmelstein said, there is a likelihood that a court would view acceptance of the check as an agreement with the endorsement it contains.
Moreover, he said, it would be equally unwise for the owner to retain the check without cashing it.
"There are many court cases that say that retention equals acceptance," Mr. Himmelstein said, explaining that while courts vary in their interpretation of how long a check must be held before it is considered accepted, it is always better to err on the side of caution.
"Any landlord's lawyer will tell you that a prompt return of the money to the tenant is critical," he said.
 
Insurance Protection For Mortgages
 
Q. Is there such a thing as mortgage payment protection insurance that covers mortgage payments in the event a homeowner becomes unemployed or unable to work due to illness or disability? . . . Dobie Gresham, Manhattan.
 
A. David Steppat, marketing director for Minnesota Mutual Life, an insurance company in St. Paul, said that such insurance was available in various forms from various sources.
One such product, Mr. Steppat said, is called mortgage disability insurance. Generally, he said, such insurance provides for the payment of mortgage payments in the event the policyholder becomes sick or disabled during the policy period.
"The payment periods will vary," Mr. Steppat said, explaining that the insurance will typically cover mortgage payments for a period of one or two years. Unlike ordinary disability insurance -- under which payments are made to the policyholder -- a mortgage disability insurance policy will typically provide that payments be made directly to the mortgage holder.
The cost of such coverage, he said, depends on the size of the monthly mortgage payment and the age and health of the policyholder. On average, Mr. Steppat said, monthly premiums amount to about five percent of the mortgage payment.
Another form of mortgage payment insurance provides protection against the loss of a job.
"There are some products out there called involuntary unemployment insurance policies," Mr. Steppat said. Such policies, which provide for mortgage payments during a specified period of unemployment -- caused by dismissal or layoff, not by resignation -- typically cost more than disability policies and often impose a waiting period of up to a few months before payments start.
Both forms of coverage, he said, are typically offered through direct marketing channels -- either by mail or telephone solicitation -- and through individual mortgage lenders.

HEADLINE: FROM THE DESK OF;
Getting My Two Cents In Corporate America

BYLINE: By WILLIAM DORNBURGH; William Dornburgh is a former associate professor of economics at St. Peter's College in Jersey City.

 BODY:
THE big-ticket business decisions -- the downsizing, the optimizing, the cost-cutting, the mega-mergers-- are all quantified in terms of multimillions, if not billions, of dollars. In this age of deal-making and the computer, no one cares too much about what happens to the right of the decimal point.
Still, we like to think that common sense is a reasonable criterion in financial matters, that there should be some correlation between, say, the cost of a transaction and its underlying value. 
 Alas, this is not always the case, as I discovered recently as I was preparing for retirement and a move from New Jersey by making certain financial adjustments.
I wrote to the First Chicago Trust Company of New York to advise it that I was ending my participation in one of the dividend reinvestment plans it administered. I soon received a stock certificate for the accumulated shares in my account.
In a separate envelope, I received a check for 18 cents, compensating me for the 0.005 share that remained in my account. With some embarrassment, I deposited it into my bank account. After all, if First Chicago was going to go to the trouble of spending 32 cents on postage to send me 18 cents, the least I could do was to accept its generosity.
Of course, it cost more than 32 cents to send me that check. The banking system had to clear it through my bank in North Carolina -- where I spend my winters -- and through the Federal Reserve Banks of Richmond and New York and finally back to First Chicago. Still, 18 cents is 18 cents.
I also had an I.R.A. investment management account, consisting of government bonds, at United Jersey Bank, which I decided to consolidate with an individual retirement account at T. Rowe Price. Following my instructions, United Jersey sent me a check for the account balance, payable to T. Rowe Price as custodian for my I.R.A. A couple weeks later, United Jersey sent me another check, payable to T. Rowe Price, representing accumulated interest on the bond account. The amount: 2 cents.
Thinking T. Rowe Price might be a bit sticky about accepting such an investment, I decided not to forward the 2-cent check. Instead, I had it framed, at a cost of $15.
When I left my home in New Jersey, I dutifully paid all my obligations to vendors and utilities, including what I thought was a final bill from Bell Atlantic.
But the next month, Bell Atlantic sent me a bill for 19 cents. While I am scrupulously honest, I am also frugal and saw no reason for burdening the banking system with a check for 19 cents. Consequently, I taped two dimes to the Bell Atlantic invoice. With my usual magnanimity, I wrote across the invoice, "Keep the change."
You guessed it. A couple weeks later, I received a check from Bell Atlantic for 1 cent. I still haven't decided whether I should spring for another $15 frame.

HEADLINE: A Grungy Shocker on Heroin Comes Ashore

BYLINE: By MICHAEL DWYER; Michael Dwyer is the film correspondent of The Irish Times.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
A FEW WEEKS AGO THE PARTnership for a Drug-Free America introduced its first national campaign aimed at fighting heroin. "You have a whole new group of young people who don't know the terror, the horror, the tragedy of heroin," explained Richard D. Bonnette, president of the organization.
Will they learn from "Trainspotting," the much-talked-about new British film opening in the United States on Friday? At one point in the movie, a junkie rhapsodizes about heroin: "Take the best orgasm you've ever had, multiply it by a thousand, and you're still nowhere near." 
 Though the film also goes on to show one character dying of AIDS and another quitting drugs cold turkey, it never does condemn heroin abuse. When you're off heroin, says Renton (played by Ewan McGregor), the addict who has sung its praises, "you have to worry about bills, about food, about some football team that never . . . wins, about human relationships and all the things that really don't matter when you've got a sincere and truthful junk habit."
The film, which opened in England in February, has become a phenomenon, its content inspiring heated debate about post-Thatcherite slackers and their aimlessness. The film's anti-Masterpiece-Theater style has spawned a popular soundtrack album by Blur, Lou Reed, Primal Scream and Iggy Pop, among others. And, because of its louche look, the film has inspired ads for sneakers, clothing and other movies.
The question is whether "Trainspotting" will have the same kind of impact in the United States, where the film has already received a lot of advance publicity, just as "Kids" did last year, when audiences were primed to rush out to see a movie about American drug-taking teen-agers that was heralded as the end of Western civilization. (Audiences instead chose to go see "Die Hard With a Vengeance," again.)
Will Americans identify with a film full of Scottish slang? A film that -- no matter how charming or rude -- at one point assumes a familiarity with the importance of Archie Gemmill's soccer goal against Holland in 1978?
"Trainspotting" portrays a group of Edinburgh friends with names like Renton, Sick Boy, Spud and Begbie who steal, take drugs (and try not to take drugs), struggle not to become employed, play and watch soccer, drink, pick up girls (one of them seriously under age), descend into Edinburgh's sewers to retrieve some opium and discuss the films of Sean Connery.
The movie has not only climbed to the No. 3 spot in all-time earnings for a film made and financed in Britain but has inspired a storm of protests on one hand and won rabid fans on the other. Its grim tone has invited comparisons to another work of British pop nihilism, the 1971 Stanley Kubrick film "A Clockwork Orange," in large part because of Renton's narration: a rapid-fire monologue full of vulgarisms and delivered in a Scottish brogue so thick, some of it had to be rerecorded for the American release. (A sample: "Choose life. Choose a job. Choose a career. Choose a family. Choose a [expletive] big television, choose washing machines, cars, compact disk players and electrical tin openers.")
The phenomenon that became "Trainspotting" began in 1993 with the publication of a novel of the same name by Irvine Welsh about heroin addicts in an economically depressed Scotland. (In the 80's, Edinburgh became what John Arlidge, a newspaper columnist at the London-based Independent, called "the heroin and AIDS capital of Europe.") The novel became a cult hit and inspired a successful stage play on the West End and elsewhere. The title, which is ironic and derogatory, refers to a British hobby of collecting locomotive numbers off passing trains, and, in the context of the film, suggests a life bereft of purpose.
To write the script, John Hodge, a soft-spoken 31-year-old doctor, returned to the book, a collection of loosely related stories that he originally thought could never be made into a movie. His solution was to pull the book apart, meld some characters, invent others and rely heavily on voice-overs to provide the interior monologues.
"Trainspotting" is the second movie from the director Danny Boyle, the producer Andrew Macdonald and Mr. Hodge, the team whose previous movie was the dark Scottish comedy "Shallow Grave." It was Mr. Macdonald, whose grandfather was the renowned producer and director Emeric Pressburger, who decided that they should adapt Mr. Welsh's novel to the screen.
"After the success of 'Shallow Grave' we received any number of offers from Hollywood," Mr. Macdonald said as he and his two colleagues sat, casually dressed, in the very formal St. James's Club here. "But we thought it was more important to stay in Britain and make another contemporary film. The only thing we had to do was to keep it relatively cheap, so we could keep control over it." The movie, shot in less than two months, cost only $2.5 million.
Mr. Boyle, a young-looking 39, and his team researched the film by meeting heroin users in the Edinburgh suburb of Leith, where the story is set, and by meeting former addicts at the Calton Athletic Drug Rehabilitation Center in Glasgow. "I always think that art tries to catch up with life," he says, "and occasionally a book like 'Trainspotting' comes along, which tries to view the experience from the inside."

IN WORKING ON THE FILM, MR. Boyle said, he came to realize that for people inside the drug world, "it becomes about survival, about getting on and getting what you want, whether it be a fix or a girl or whatever."
"You have to deal with that," he added. "You can't just take the old position of 'You touch drugs, you die. They will damage you.' In the long run, of course, there's probably terrible damage waiting."
The dizzying pace of the movie is set in the opening scene. The camera follows store detectives as they chase Renton and a friend through the streets while Iggy Pop's "Lust for Life" pumps up the soundtrack. Mr. McGregor, who stars in the film, had previously played the journalist in "Shallow Grave" and turns up next month as Frank Churchill in the period film "Emma."
While many British films, like those of Ken Loach, embrace a form of social realism, "Trainspotting" favors the surreal: set pieces attempt to show what addicts feel when they overdose (a carpet seems to open up like a grave) and when they go through withdrawal (babies seem to crawl on the ceiling).
The film's boys-will-be-boys attitude might never have survived if the picture had been backed by a commercial studio. The "big decision," Mr. Macdonald said, was to let the adventurous television network Channel 4 finance the film.
"We worked so well as a team with them on 'Shallow Grave,' " he said. "If we had been involved with a more commercial backer like Miramax or Polygram, it would have been a lot more difficult, I think, and would involve a lot of compromises." Miramax is distributing the film in the United States.
In the end, the film makers say they did not make any compromises, and that may be why the movie touched a nerve in Britain, with commentary spilling over from the entertainment pages to the opinion columns. The Daily Mail, for example, condemned the film's "irresponsible, lofty refusal to judge or condemn" heroin addiction.
Mr. Hodge disagrees. "The film doesn't condone drug taking," he insisted. "It just accepts bounds of reality. I think it's a responsible film because it shows what goes wrong if you take heroin."
"There's so much hypocrisy," he went on. "People are quite happy to ignore the damage that alcohol does. In the film, Begbie is the most dangerous, and his drug is alcohol. We've all had the misfortune to sit on the train next to someone like Begbie."
Mr. Boyle also rejects criticism of "Trainspotting." "I just thought the book was an amazing experience," he said. "People say it's about heroin, but like all great books, it's actually about how complex humanity is, and how we just evade definition."
Writing in The Times of London, the columnist Magnus Linklater suggested that the "starkest message emerging from the 'Trainspotting' phenomenon is the rift it reveals between the generations on the subject of drugs and their insidious appeal." Young audiences accept it as a genuine portrayal of life in the raw, he said, while most of their elders are appalled.
To date, "Trainspotting" has taken in more than $18 million at the box office in Britain, a remarkable achievement in view of the fact that the film's rating denies admission to anyone under 18. Of the British-made films, only "Four Weddings and a Funeral," which has taken in $40 million, and "A Fish Called Wanda," with $20 million, have been more popular.
Next, Mr. Boyle, Mr. Macdonald and Mr. Hodge will collaborate on a romantic comedy adventure called "A Life Less Ordinary," about a Scottish cleaning man who loses his job when he is replaced by an automatic vacuum cleaner. "There are no drugs involved," Mr. Hodge promised.

LENGTH: 793 words

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/39 and 41 Commerce Street;
Two 1830's Homes, and a Garden Big Enough for a 3d

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
THE rain leaks into the house at 41 Commerce Street through loose mortar, peeling paint and holes in the roof -- indeed, it looks as if little has been done since 1832, when the structure was built as one of a curious pair with 39 Commerce Street. Now the owner is spending $60,000 on the little building, but if things go right, a passer-by won't be able to tell the difference.
In 1830 Peter Huyler of Hackensack, N.J., bought the end of the block that was created as Commerce Street turned north to meet Barrow Street. And in 1832, as the former suburb of Greenwich Village was being absorbed by the larger city, Huyler built the two houses that now stand at 39 and 41 Commerce Street. 
 Early tax and building records indicate that the original houses were two-and-a-half stories high, with dormers in a peaked roof, a typical model for structures of the period.
What is unusual about 39 and 41 Commerce Street is the large garden they share. The blockfront is 72 feet long, but the houses take up only 45 of those feet, and the garden space could have easily accommodated a third house. Although both houses now have their main doorways facing the garden, early photographs and plans show that the original doorways faced the street and that there were few windows on the garden.
There are several popular explanations for this unusual pair of houses, the most common of which is that Huyler built them for his two sisters -- a story for which no evidence exists. And yet the garden seems so generous, in relation to the rest of the city, it invites such mythology. The answer, however, may lie in how the city itself has changed.
Maps and other records indicate that most of the houses on the block had small adjacent plots -- it was, after all, still part suburb. So the gardens seem prominent only in the context of later, more intensive rowhouse development of the city.
Huyler never lived in New York, but he did not sell the buildings -- he held them for rental. Regina Kellerman, an expert on 19th-century New York, says that building for long-term investment was common in the West Village. The first identifiable tenant at 41 Commerce Street was Peter Burdett, who moved there in 1842; at 39 Commerce it was William Halsey, described in directories as a "captain," who moved there in 1848.
In 1873 the Huyler heirs had the architect Daniel T. Atwood alter the roofs of both 39 and 41 Commerce, creating a full third story under a slate mansard roof. The Huylers sold 39 Commerce in 1877, and No. 41 in 1899. The 1900 census shows a family of six and two boarders in No. 39, and a family of four with six boarders in No. 41. The six included a Mary Moody, 30, who made umbrellas.
A 1905 photograph at the New-York Historical Society shows 41 with its Commerce Street doorway, heavily shuttered windows -- perhaps because of the summer heat -- and a solid board fence along the garden.
The doorways were moved to the garden fronts at some point before 1932, when a city survey shows the present arrangement, along with a skylight in the top floor of 41. Although census records in the 1920's show occupants of the houses with jobs like baker, laborer and teamster, the new popularity of the village soon brought tenants like Mabel Swerig, a librarian, at No. 39 and D'Arcy Dahlberg, an artist, at 41.
Both buildings had been divided into four apartments each by that time, but in 1948 a new owner of No. 41, James G. Lambrakis, combined the four apartments to create a private house. No. 39, however, has remained divided. In 1969 the Landmarks Preservation Commission included the entire area in the Greenwich Village Historic District.
Although No. 39 has been spruced up in the recent past, No. 41 could be an Edward Hopper painting. The mansard is spotted with tar, there are holes its cornice and sheet-metal window surrounds. On the first two floors, the pointing on the brick crumbles with a pass of a finger, and ancient paint curls up off the brick like the cracked surface of a bone-dry mud flat.
This year a new owner, Ruth Scheuer, retained the architect Richard Ayotte to stop a growing number of leaks in the house. His mission is not to remove but to somehow preserve the peeling paint.
"The owner bought an old house, and she wants an old house," Mr. Ayotte said, pointing to an ancient "Ball Playing Not Allowed" sign, almost completely rusted away, that he will keep intact.
Looking across the street at a recently restored 1880's flat building, 68 Barrow Street, Mr. Ayotte said, "You can't tell if that was built last year, or 100 years ago." At 41 Commerce Street, Mr. Ayotte will repoint the brick and replace the slate and galvanized iron roof trim; otherwise, his work will be invisible.
