LENGTH: 1392 words

HEADLINE: Notes From Under Cover

BYLINE: By James Chace; James Chace is the Henry Luce Professor in Freedom of Inquiry and Expression at Bard College and the editor of World Policy Journal. He is completing a biography of Dean Acheson.

 BODY:

REFLECTIONS OF A COLD WARRIOR
 From Yalta to the Bay of Pigs.
 By Richard M. Bissell Jr. with Jonathan E. Lewis and Frances T. Pudlo.
 268 pp. New Haven:
 Yale University Press. $30. 
 Dean Acheson was against the creation of the Central Intelligence Agency. In July 1947, he warned Harry Truman that once it was established neither the President "nor anyone else would be in a position to know what it was doing or to control it." But in the spirit of the times, which were driven by an obsession with national security, the agency came into being. A year later, at the suggestion of George Kennan, an office was created to send agents into the field -- not simply to discover the intentions of foreign governments but also, if need be, to intervene covertly in their domestic affairs.
Such "covert ops" became especially useful during the Eisenhower Administration. They were cheaper than direct military intervention and, so it seemed, successful in advancing Washington's goal of global containment of Communism. John F. Kennedy increased spending on conventional forces to allow for greater flexibility, but the emphasis on covert operations, and its stepchild, counterinsurgency, prospered -- even though it led to the greatest humiliation suffered by the Kennedy Administration, the slaughter of C.I.A.-financed Cuban exile guerrillas on the swampy shores of the Bay of Pigs.
The man who eventually took charge of covert operations -- arguably the most intellectually gifted of any of the C.I.A. operatives -- was Richard M. Bissell Jr. (1909-94). "Reflections of a Cold Warrior" is his story (written with the assistance of Jonathan E. Lewis and Frances T. Pudlo). Like many of the early gung-ho spymasters who helped run the agency in the halcyon era of the 1950's, Bissell came from a privileged background -- the Groton School, Yale University. He remained at Yale to receive a Ph.D. and to teach Keynesian economics; he counted among his most outstanding students the Bundy brothers, William and McGeorge, and the Rostow brothers, Eugene and Walt.
But service in World War II changed everything for him -- as it did for many of his gifted students. The feeling of power and purpose that young men experienced in the mortal struggle against fascism and totalitarianism was not easily shed. And when the advent of the cold war sounded another call to action, Richard Bissell heard the trumpet. He went to Washington to help write the Marshall Plan, and in 1954 he joined the operatives around the avuncular, pipe-smoking Allen Dulles, the Director of Central Intelligence, whose exploits as a wartime spy and taste for derring-do rivaled James Bond's.
As assistant to the director, Bissell soon became involved in a covert operation designed to overthrow the regime of the democratically elected President of Guatemala, Jacobo Arbenz Guzman. The Eisenhower Administration believed that Arbenz was a Communist tool and that an Arbenz alignment with Moscow would constitute, in Bissell's words, "a major threat to regional stability." Once Arbenz sought arms from the Soviet bloc the way was open for Dwight D. Eisenhower's operatives to topple him.
In a plot worthy of a Woody Allen movie, the C.I.A. used broadcasts into Guatemala to exaggerate the unimpressive military forces of an exiled former army officer named Carlos Castillo Armas, whom the agency had built up as an alternative to Arbenz. In addition, a small agency-run "rebel" air force was able to fly unopposed over Guatemalan territory, where it engaged in widespread bombing, often with little more than empty Coca-Cola bottles. But these few decrepit planes were not enough to bring down Arbenz, and Eisenhower, even at the risk of betraying the Administration's policy of "plausible deniability," made additional aircraft available for the rebel air force. In the end, the Arbenz regime collapsed.
At the time, Bissell hardly questioned the need to overthrow Arbenz. Yet the result has been decades of one of the most repressive regimes in Central America. In retrospect, he admits that "U.S. interests over the years might have been better served if Arbenz had remained in power." But then he concludes that because Washington had destabilized a democratically elected government, we had a great "moral obligation" to "try to do something about the underlying situation" in that country.
What that means is left unanswered. Should we have bought the country? Should we have attempted to convert Castillo Armas into a statesman? The real answer is not to overthrow a democratically elected government in the first place, no matter what its alignment, unless it poses a direct military threat to the United States.
In the aftermath of Guatemala, Bissell saw the need to develop a high-altitude reconnaissance aircraft -- the U-2. As the man who brought this project to a successful conclusion, he deserves high marks. The U-2, with its ability to overfly territory without detection, provided valuable photographs of Soviet defenses. By 1960, the information it had gained had persuaded the Eisenhower Administration that the United States was not falling behind Russia in missile technology.
Unfortunately, as a kind of reward for this achievement, Bissell was put in charge of covert operations in 1959. In this capacity, he had the responsibility for explaining to President John F. Kennedy the Eisenhower Administration's plan for landing exiles on Cuba, where they were expected either to stimulate an uprising or to disappear into the mountains and become the nucleus of a guerrilla force that would ultimately overthrow Fidel Castro.
The story of the Bay of Pigs, as related by Bissell, is as disheartening as ever. Once again, the Rube Goldberg aspects of the plan are stunning: Cuban exiles, who had been trained in Guatemala (by now a friendly regime) and later in the Southern United States, were to touch ground on a beach known as the Bay of Pigs. Air support would be supplied from aging B-26's, flown by Cuban exile pilots. But the plan's success depended on air strikes against not only Fidel Castro's communications but also Cuba's small air force, to keep it from destroying the invaders. Although Kennedy acquiesced in the plan, he was a reluctant commander. At the last moment, he sharply reduced the number of air strikes -- largely to be able to conceal Washington's involvement -- and this doomed the landing force.
Unlike Eisenhower, who had been willing to supply the extra aircraft when the Guatemalan operation was in danger of collapse, Kennedy backed off. It simply never occurred to Bissell that when the chips were down, Kennedy would not come through with the needed air support. It was, after all, the longest of long shots that 1,000 exile soldiers were going to be able to overwhelm some 200,000 members of Cuba's armed forces.
The failure was absolute. The exile army was destroyed. The mountains they were supposed to hide in were some 80 miles away from the beaches, across a virtually impenetrable swamp. Kennedy was humiliated and, worst of all, he had just lost a round to Fidel Castro, which made him more determined than ever to get him.
Bissell was through. As he recalls, Kennedy told him: "If this were a parliamentary government, I would have to resign and you, a civil servant, would stay on. But being the system of government it is, a Presidential government, you will have to resign." Eventually, Bissell left the Government to work in the private sector, and to ponder the role of the C.I.A.
In his meticulous but unexciting prose, he concludes that covert action is compatible with democracy. Yet it is hard to see where the C.I.A.'s so-called successes in this field did not eventually turn into malevolent ghosts that ended up causing more lethal problems for us than the original difficulties.
After the failure of the Bay of Pigs, that supreme realist, Walter Lippmann, stated an enduring truth about the making of an effective American foreign policy: "A policy is bound to fail which deliberately violates our pledges and our principles, our treaties and our laws." He reminded us then -- and it is a good thing to be reminded once again -- that "the American conscience is a reality. It will make hesitant and ineffectual, even if it does not prevent, an un-American policy."

HEADLINE: The Mess in Mexico

BYLINE: By Sarah Kerr; Sarah Kerr writes frequently about Mexican politics and culture.

 BODY:

 Bordering on Chaos
 Guerrillas, Stockbrokers, Politicians,
 and Mexico's Road to Prosperity.
 By Andres Oppenheimer.
 Illustrated. 367 pp. New York:
 Little, Brown & Company. $25.95. 
 Pity the journalist who covers Mexico. In 1992, the year Andres Oppenheimer started research for this book, our southern neighbor was an international darling. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, saluted for opening his country's markets to foreign goods and arranging to repay its foreign debt, was a model, we were told, for any leader trying to nudge a weak economy up into the ranks of the first world. But as Mr. Oppenheimer's title hints, early on in his writing all kinds of catastrophe struck, and what had begun as an inquiry into the Government's success soon came to feel like an inquest into its failure.
To recap the disasters: On New Year's Day, 1994, ski-masked guerrillas led an uprising in the destitute southern state of Chiapas. Later that same year, as Mr. Salinas's term in office wound down, the presidential candidate and the congressional leader of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, were assassinated, and in December, three weeks after a new president, Ernesto Zedillo, took over, the currency collapsed. The emperor had turned out to be not only naked but rashly misguided in policy and quite probably corrupt. In February 1995 Mr. Salinas, by now a figure of scandal, ducked out of the country under cover.
It's been a grotesquely eventful period -- a few years as unsettling, in their own way, as the late 1960's in the United States -- so that covering it all is rather like trying to sum up shockers in this country as disparate as the Watts riots, Charles Manson and the 1968 Democratic National Convention in Chicago. In "Bordering on Chaos," Mr. Oppenheimer, a correspondent for The Miami Herald, attacks each issue with the confident common sense and sometimes -- though this may be inevitable in a book tackling current events so soon after they occurred -- the rushed generality of a daily reporter.
Topic No. 1 is the Chiapas uprising, a story he believes most American journalists naively mishandled. The Zapatistas' articulate green-eyed leader, Subcommander Marcos (Rafael Guillen), seduced the foreign press into believing that the movement was an innovative "post-modern" attempt to better the lot of Mayan Indians, whose grievances are indeed legitimate. But Mr. Oppenheimer demonstrates (though he is certainly not the first to do so) that the rebellion was led by a club of intellectuals trained in the same stale, intransigent Marxist dogma that has tied up the Latin American left for decades.
As for the two recent assassinations of PRI leaders, Mr. Oppenheimer speculates that both internal party warfare and drug trafficking may have played a role. But he disagrees with the theory favored by Mexican and American academics (and, again, often uncritically accepted by American journalists) that the fighting inside the PRI represents an ideological split between the so-called dinosaurs (the corrupt old guard) and younger free-market reformers. According to Mr. Oppenheimer the chaos is nothing more grand than a jostling for turf. The real problem is that the PRI has held power for more than seven decades and its leaders, always corrupt, have lately become reckless and hubristic. He likens the situation to hereditary decay, as when a royal house, after centuries of inbreeding, starts giving birth to deformed and even insane heirs.
Mexico's greatest hope, Mr. Oppenheimer believes, is for President Zedillo to quit the PRI altogether and start over with a new, more democratic party. Barring such a courageous move, he sees promise in the entrepreneurial, self-sufficient spirit of the National Action Party, or PAN, a right-wing party of middle-class, industrial and Roman Catholic interests that has recently gained a few governorships in the north. But he cautions that some kind of safety net needs to be extended to the poorer south to head off future disasters like Chiapas.
A persistent theme, and Mr. Oppenheimer's most useful point, is that despite all the recent turmoil, Mexicans are not the hot-blooded potential revolutionaries many Americans have assumed them to be. According to pollsters, their biggest worry is unemployment; in one poll asking them to name their most personally pressing concern, he notes, "the Zapatista rebellion ranked lower than traffic jams."
SUCH results are a necessary reminder of who Mexicans are not, but one sometimes wishes Mr. Oppenheimer could bring us closer to who they are than multiple-choice answers to a survey. Again and again he has to concede that Mexico tends to stump conventional American journalism. In the Chiapas jungle, hoping for access to Subcommander Marcos, he bribed a young guerrilla liaison with cigarettes, crackers and T-shirts, only to discover that the boy was not a guerrilla at all but an impostor and a thief. A PRI senator, after giving a detailed inside account of a scandalous 1994 meeting of Mexican moguls (where he claimed Mr. Salinas requested that they donate $25 million each to the party), published a book essentially saying of his revelations, "Just kidding."
Stopping to untangle a conspiracy theory that certain Zapatista rebels are actually Government agents and a rumor that President Zedillo is not exactly who he claims to be but the son of a mysterious man who drifted out of the picture when he was a child, Mr. Oppenheimer throws up his hands. "I was, as most journalists in Mexico often are, at a total loss. . . . Were the Zapatistas real Zapatistas? Was Zedillo a true Zedillo? How could one write about a country where one could not only not trust what people said, but wasn't even sure whether people were who they were supposed to be? Studying Mexico, as one U.S. academic had once told me, was like working in Plato's cave: you only saw shadows and never knew which shadow belonged to whom." As useful as Mr. Oppenheimer's summary is, in the end it is these moments of bewilderment, more than any single insight, that stand out. For now, it seems, we're still looking at shadows.

HEADLINE: Class Consciousness

BYLINE: By William Julius Wilson; William Julius Wilson is the Malcolm Wiener Professor of Social Policy at Harvard University. His new book, "When Work Disappears: The World of the New Urban Poor," will be published in September.

 BODY:

THE REMEDY
 Class, Race, and Affirmative Action.
 By Richard D. Kahlenberg.
 350 pp. New York:
 A New Republic Book/Basic Books. $25. 
 In the face of growing attacks on programs of racial preference, some analysts have called for a shift from an affirmative action policy based on race to one based on economic class or need. Richard D. Kahlenberg's book "The Remedy: Class, Race, and Affirmative Action" is by far the most comprehensive and thoughtful argument thus far for that position. Mr. Kahlenberg, a fellow at the Center for National Policy in Washington, strongly supports antidiscrimination laws, like the 1964 and 1991 civil rights acts, to fight race and sex discrimination. He is also in favor of the noncontroversial traditional approach to affirmative action: enlarging the applicant pool so that women and members of minority groups are not excluded from consideration by the workings of the old-boy network. But he feels that preferences in hiring or admissions should benefit only the economically disadvantaged, regardless of race, ethnicity, sex or sexual orientation.
Racial preferences, Mr. Kahlenberg maintains, were not part of the original national affirmative action policy designed by the Johnson Administration. Rather, affirmative action, combined with antidiscrimination initiatives, was conceived as a program of social mobility "to insure that members of all races had a fair chance to compete." Nor did Martin Luther King Jr. or Robert F. Kennedy ever endorse racial preferences. Indeed, in the middle to late 1960's, thoughtful and progressive advocates of racial equality reached two basic conclusions: to overcome the legacy of previous discrimination, it was necessary to move beyond the formal equality of opportunity embodied in the civil rights act; and compensatory programs to achieve racial justice had to involve the disadvantaged of all races.
In 1968, Martin Luther King and Robert Kennedy were assassinated and Lyndon B. Johnson served his last year as President. King, Kennedy and Johnson viewed compensation for African-Americans as part of a broader and more ambitious effort to promote a Great Society of genuine equal opportunity, color-blindness and integration; after their departure, civil rights thinking dramatically shifted, in two ways. The first, Mr. Kahlenberg writes, "focused on a narrow zero-sum effort, pitting the very groups King had sought to unite against each other and following a theory of compensation that many Americans refuse to accept." The second, which emerged in the late 70's, subtly shifted the justification for affirmative action from compensation to diversity -- "from racial preferences as a temporary bridge to color-blindness to racial preferences as a permanent way of life."
Mr. Kahlenberg feels that the first approach often does not help disadvantaged applicants because if the goal is equality of group result, a child of a black Supreme Court Justice would tend to be preferred over the child of a white Appalachian miner. And since the second approach rests solely on the notion of social utility rather than on past wrongs, it "often benefits groups that have never been discriminated against (WASP's) and hurts groups that have (Asians, Jews and homosexuals)."
For Mr. Kahlenberg, only an affirmative action based on class would correct for society's injustice and provide genuine individual equal opportunity. While eliminating benefits for advantaged minorities, it would enhance benefits for both poor people of color and poor whites. Moreover, class-based affirmative action programs would hasten racial integration, "but without the increased racial prejudice and hostility associated with racial preferences."
Mr. Kahlenberg has clearly done his homework, and in laying out his argument he draws on the work of many analysts in the field, including my own. He asserts, correctly, that blacks would benefit disproportionately from an affirmative action based on class because "as a group" they are "more disadvantaged than whites." I would argue, though, that the shift could actually result in the systematic exclusion of many middle-income blacks from desirable positions because conventional measures of performance are not sensitive to the cumulative effects of race. By this I mean having one's chances in life limited by race, regardless of class, because of the effects of living in segregated neighborhoods -- that is, being exposed to styles of behavior, habits and the particular skills that emerge from patterns of racial exclusion -- because of the quality of de facto segregated schooling and because of nurturing by parents whose experiences have also been shaped and limited by race.
Thus, if we were to rely solely on the standard criteria for college admission, like S.A.T. scores, even many children from black middle-class families would be denied admission in favor of middle-class whites who are not weighed down by the accumulation of disadvantages that stem from racial restrictions and who therefore tend to score higher on these conventional measures. The extent to which standard aptitude tests like the S.A.T. and tests used for the promotion of police officers are measuring merit or real potential to succeed, not privilege, is not readily apparent.
Mr. Kahlenberg is fully aware that standardized tests fail to measure such important attributes as character, creativity and leadership. Nor do they predict who will become a good doctor, businessman or lawyer. "But until someone devises such tests," he states, "we are stuck with muddling along and doing the best we can."
Since race is one of the components of "disadvantaged," should not the ideal affirmative action program be based on class and race? Mr. Kahlenberg rejects this idea. In his formulation, class-based preferences are designed to replace, not supplement, race-based preferences, except in those rare cases where racial remedies address the problem of documented injury due to discrimination. He would probably argue that the complex calculus of disadvantage he would use to determine class eligiblity for affirmative action addresses the problem of the cumulative effects of race. This calculus includes not only parental income, occupation and education but net worth, family structure, the quality of secondary education and neighborhood influences. Although the use of this more complex calculus would increase the proportion of African-Americans in the pool, it would still result in the systematic exclusion of many of those blacks from middle-income families who are nevertheless still suffering the cumulative effects of race. This could create a situation in which, for example, African-Americans who are admitted to Harvard represent the bottom half of the socioeconomic continuum in the black community, while those who are above the median are excluded, because they no longer fall within the affirmative action pool. They are therefore left to compete with middle- and upper-income whites who are not burdened by the handicaps of race -- as their higher scores on the conventional tests reflect.
Finally, Mr. Kahlenberg is very sensitive to the political problem that whites are overwhelmingly opposed to the standard race-based affirmative action. But it should be pointed out that some race-based programs are supported by a substantial majority of the white population. While they oppose "preferential" racial policies like college admission quotas or job hiring and promotion strategies designed to achieve certain numerical outcomes, most white Americans, according to recent studies, approve of "compensatory" affirmative action programs, like race-targeted programs of job training, special education, special scholarships for black students who maintain good grades in school, and special recruitment efforts.
It would not be a leap of faith, therefore, to assume that a strong and convincing case could be made for a program of class- and race-based affirmative action. Such a program would feature a broad definition of disadvantage, couched in language that promotes the notion of enhancing opportunity, not the narrow racial preference discussed in this book.

HEADLINE: Paying Their Own Way

BYLINE: By BRIAN HANSON-HARDING 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
RAYMOND MAKORI, 19, has his eye on a car, a sporty used Mitsubishi Starion. So at 3 P.M. five times a week -- more often, if he can get the overtime -- he takes a bus from his home here to the gatehouse at the sprawling Panasonic headquarters in Secaucus to begin an eight-hour shift as a security guard.
There would be nothing unusual about Raymond's $6-an-hour job, or his dream of new wheels, if it were not for the way he plans to use them. "I need a car so I can get a second job on weekends," he said the other day. "I have to pay part of the household bills and the rent." And he has to pay nearly $3,000 a year for tuition (and help pay it for his younger brother and sisters) at St. Aloysius High School in Jersey City, where he will be a senior in the fall. 
 Raymond Makori, a tall, polite, soft-spoken young man who emigrated from Kenya just this year, is one of a growing number of urban students who not only attend Catholic school but also pay their own way. Of the 3,000 students at Jersey City's seven parochial high schools, the poorest thousand or so go to three -- St. Aloysius, St. Anthony's and St. Mary's -- where the tuition is less than $3,000 a year, low enough to be within reach of a teen-ager who earns money flipping burgers or selling clothes at the mall.
Adults at these schools say perhaps a quarter of the students are paying some or all of their tuition. "It used to be that a few kids worked to buy nice clothes or luxuries," said Robert Gleeson, a longtime math teacher at St. Al's. "Now they're working out of necessity."
Catholic school officials in other cities are noticing a similar phenomenon. "Our students who live in Trenton will do literally anything to go to this school," said Joseph Lemme, principal of McCorristin Catholic High School, where at least 5 percent of the students depend on their own income to pay tuition.
Why they do it -- why they work long hours, often at great cost to their social lives, their grades and even their health, to get an education they could get at no cost in public school -- is a question packed with implications about the lives of the students, their families and the cities themselves.
For the students, parochial school keeps them out of a world they see as too large, too anonymous, riddled with gangs and peer pressure. They say they need the structure and discipline of Catholic school to succeed.
"In public school you find people taking drugs," said Raymond Makori, sounding almost apologetic. "It's safer in private Catholic schools." said Raymond Makori, sounding almost apologetic. "It's safer in private Catholic schools."
Often it is pressure from parents and from cultures that motivates students to pay for a Catholic education -- an education that in Jersey City includes one mandatory religion course per year, plus prayers at the beginning of each day and each class. In many immigrant families, especially Hispanic ones, an older sister is expected to sacrifice herself to pay for the education of a younger brother, said Peggy Orenstein, author of "Schoolgirls: Women, Self-Esteem and the Confidence Gap" (Doubleday, 1994).
"There's a big expectation from the outside world that they will get pregnant and drop out," she said. "It can seem as a responsible, affirming thing if you're bringing in money and sending a little sibling to school."
Whatever the reasons, it is clear that more and more students are taking this route to an education. "When I first came here, there really wasn't any student who had to pay his or her own tuition," said Nancy Heymer, a guidance counselor at St. Aloysius. "It's been steadily increasing over the 14 years I've been here."
This is no surprise to Bret Schundler, the Mayor of Jersey City, who for years has crusaded for a voucher plan that would make it easier for poor students to attend parochial or private school. "Kids will work to stay in an environment that is safe and where they're able to learn," he said. "In contrast, public schools have a philosophy based on egalitarianism. They have a school culture based on anti-elitism. They say anti-elitism, I say anti-excellence."
People who work and learn in the public schools, of course, reject such generalizations. The idea that students get away with anything they want is "simply untrue," said Tom Favia, president of the teachers' union, the Jersey City Education Association. And Smita Patel, a junior at Dickinson High School in Jersey City, scoffed at the notion that public schools have some sort of monopoly on fear, violence, gangs and drugs.
"There's peer pressure everywhere," she said. "Part of the point of going to school is to learn to distinguish right from wrong. If you're careful, if you don't associate with people who cause trouble, you'll be all right."
Still, even public school defenders say the Catholic schools have some built-in advantages. While "there are some very excellent people coming out of Jersey City's public schools," said Ed Richardson, a spokesman for the New Jersey Education Association, "nonpublic schools can pick and choose whom they want to educate." Mary Murphy, principal of Our Lady of Good Counsel High School in Newark, acknowledged, "We are able to provide a safer, smaller environment because we can pick and choose our students."
What follow are the stories of several who were chosen, and who chose to pay their own way.
 
MIGUEL SANTOS
The Pull of the Gang
Ask Miguel Santos why it was so important to go to St. Aloysius that he worked more than 32 hours a week to pay the tuition, and he stares at the burn scar he got as a member of the Visaya Boys gang.
"In public school, I think I would have dropped out, ended up selling drugs," said Miguel, 18, the son of a Guatemalan political refugee. "At St. Al's, they call your house; they make sure you're in school."
Of his five best friends who attended Dickinson (not to mention the 65 members of the gang), he was the only one who finished high school and was accepted to college; he is attending the Educational Opportunity Fund summer program at Montclair State College, where he was accepted for the fall term. "I'm the only one in the gang who made it this far," he said.
Going to Catholic school through eighth grade did not keep Miguel out of gangs or out of trouble. But when his parents had to economize by sending him to public school for his freshman year, Jersey City became for him a landscape of "safe" and "hostile" zones, defined by his gang affiliation. Afraid of trouble with rival factions at his local high school, Lincoln, he tried to move in with a friend in order to go to Dickinson, a school of 2,600 students in Jersey City Heights, where his gang was based.
"My mom saw that," he said, "and she decided to go halves with my older sister, Erica, to pay for my tuition" at St. Aloysius in December of that year.
Going to St. Al's, a parochial school of 300 students on a gritty but bustling commercial block downtown, was "like coming home," he said. "I had a safe learning environment. When I went to Lincoln, the little while that I did go, kids would scream, they would smoke marijuana in the hallways and the bathrooms. You would never find that in here."
Still, the pull of the gang was strong. And when he met his gang buddies after school each day, they would tease him about his school uniform. "My friends used to say, 'You're a crossover, you're a pretty boy, you're a prepster.' "
At the end of his freshman year, his mother learned that he planned to run away to live with a friend and go to Dickinson to be with his gang. "When I came back to pick up my report card, she was waiting for me outside. The next day, she put me on a plane for Guatemala to live with relatives."
When he got back at the end of the summer, his parents insisted he act more responsibly and pay his tuition at St. Al's. So he got a job working 31 hours a week at a Waldbaum's supermarket in the Newport Plaza strip mall, where he started as a cart boy earning $5.05 an hour and over three years moved up to cashier and assistant runner, at a dollar an hour more. Miguel gradually drifted away from the gang and toward a new group of friends who earned money as D.J.'s at parties in New York, and he would help out, earning $60 a party.
At first he thought paying for school wasn't worth it. "I'd have way more fun at Dickinson," he said. "But at the same time, I still had a lot of close friends here. They weren't into gangs. They really kept me into school a lot."
So Miguel Santos scraped by. With a final average of 79, he was accepted to Montclair State College and hopes to study law. He credits the school: "The teachers made the difference." But he also thinks working his way through school helped.
"I pay to be here," he said. "If I don't take advantage of the opportunity, I waste all my money."

ANDREA DOUGLAS
In Bed by 3
 Working to pay tuition since age 14 has certainly taught responsibility to Andrea Douglas, a quiet, serious St. Al's student bound for Douglass College. "If I went to public school, I wouldn't care if I got a C," she said. "Now if I get a C, I get a heart attack."
Even though her mother's night job at the post office was barely enough to support Andrea and her two brothers, she wanted to avoid the public Snyder High School. "There were drug transactions going on right in front of the school," she said. So she got a job working 20 to 25 hours a week at a clothing store in the Hudson Mall in Jersey City to help pay tuition.
Working that much sometimes made Andrea feel she was missing out. "The people who don't have to work are out partying," she said. "If you have to work, you can't have that fun."
The job takes its toll in other ways. "As soon as I get home, I have to wash up and get ready to go to work, so I'll be doing homework till 1 or 2 in the morning," she said. "I try to be in bed by 3 o' clock. If there's a hard test, I study the night before, but all the other studying I do in the morning, in homeroom, between classes."
Such grueling schedules can have physical effects. "You see their skin tone change," said Margaret Lanni, the director of guidance at St. Al's. "They're tired; they're not eating right; they don't keep themselves well." Mr. Gleeson, the longtime math teacher, said: "It's very difficult for them. I don't know how they do it, to be honest."
Working 30 hours a week stocking shelves at Shop Rite has had an effect on Miguel Valentin, 17, whose family rejected Ferris High School in favor of St. Mary's High School in downtown Jersey City.
"I come home tired," he said. "If I got a test the next day, I go to sleep and worry about it in the morning." While he got B's and C's his sophomore year, Miguel barely passed this year. And after slipping two months behind in his tuition, he couldn't afford to cut back on work.
And now there seems to be even less chance he can work fewer hours. After his sister was slashed in the face with a razor blade at school, his parents plan to put her in St. Mary's too.
Still, many adults who work with young people say that those who must work to pay their own tuition will probably do better in school. "Young people working for tuition are looking at the long term," said Alan Zuckerman, executive director of the National Youth Employment Coalition, a job-training research group in Washington. "When they do that, they're more motivated, and their chances of succeeding are greater."
Mr. Gleeson agreed. "Some of the best students are the ones who work," he said. "They get a feel for the real world, it shows them what they're up against, and it makes them want to study that much harder."
If Andrea Douglas's spirit ever flagged, she always had a cautionary tale in her best friend, a decent student during sophomore year at St. Al's, who began attending Dickinson in her junior year when her family could no longer afford tuition.
"She started worrying about her wardrobe, she wanted names -- Calvin Klein, Tommy Hilfiger, Polo Ralph Lauren," Andrea said. "She was always cutting school to be with the crowd. After a while, she was flunking out of math, and nearly flunked the whole year."
She paused. "If I went to public school, I probably would have cut school with her."
 
DIGNORA AQUINO
Working, and Winning
 Eighteen-year-old Dignora Aquino is confident and well-spoken, and she has a sophistication born of working several years as a receptionist that makes her seem more like a teacher than a student.
"I knew that if I went to Dickinson, I wouldn't get out with good grades," said Dignora, the oldest of three children of Dominican immigrants. "I didn't want to get into all the peer pressure. There were four kids in my building who all graduated public grammar school together, and I'm the only one that graduated high school. If I hadn't gone to a parochial school, I probably would have ended up the way they did."
Dignora put herself through the last three years of high school completely on her own. "My father just refused to pay the tuition," she said. "He said, 'Just do it yourself.' "
And she does. She graduated fourth in her class last month and was accepted to St. Peter's College on a full scholarship; Michael Cunningham, her employer at Cunningham Graphics in Jersey City, called her "literally one of our best employees."
Next year, in addition to going to college full time, she intends to pay tuition at St. Al's for her youngest sister, Amabel.
At St. Al's, far more girls than boys are paying their own way. And when boys do get jobs, says Ms. Heymer, the longtime guidance counselor, there is a greater chance that they will assert their independence and cut school. (Miguel Santos, for instance, thought that since he was paying tuition, he could come and go as he pleased, and racked up more than 25 absences in his junior year.)
Families are more demanding of girls," Ms. Heymer said, "even to the point that the girls are almost accountable if the brothers don't behave or do well in school."
But when it comes down to choosing which sibling will go to parochial school, it will usually be the brother. "My parents thought that if I went to Ferris I'd hang out with the wrong crowd," said Miguel Valentin, a junior at St. Mary's. "They have more confidence in my sister."
Sometimes even the best students are caught between the pressures of work and school, their grades slipping. "They're afraid to speak to the boss because they need the job and are afraid of losing it," said Ms. Heymer. "They will not go and say, 'I have exams this week,' or 'I'm really working too many hours.' And sometimes it's their parents who are putting the extra pressure on them by counting on their income."
Working for high school tuition helps students become more mature and responsible, she went on. "But I think it still takes its toll on them, either academically or socially."
Of course, there are always the exceptions, like Dignora Aquino, who managed to work 35 to 40 hours a week, maintain high grades, and still go out dancing every Friday night. "Dignora is the absolute deviation from the norm," said Ms. Lanni, the guidance director. "She goes and goes and goes."
Next year, with a full scholarship to St. Peter's and free room and board in the dorm, she plans to hold down a full-time job.
"Anything in particular?" she was asked.
"I want to be a police officer. I've already passed the exam."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
In Danbury, a Short Street That's Long on Hope

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: DANBURY

 BODY:
THE rehabilitation of a short street named for one of this city's notable natives, the late composer Charles Ives, has provided a focus for its effort to rejuvenate its downtown, which went into a sharp decline following the opening of the 1.5-million-square-foot Danbury Fair Mall in 1987.
Under the stewardship of its 43-year-old, four-term mayor, Gene F. Eriquez, the city committed itself seven years ago at the start of his first term to the creation of a downtown core of mixed uses and attractions within walking distance of one another. 
 Derelict, vacant buildings that lined the narrow, two-block Ives Street have been converted to restaurants, dance clubs and theme bars.
Ives Street's business owners have banded together in a promotional campaign, posting signs all over town pointing the way to the "Dining & Entertainment District," which eventually will cover the area bounded by Main, Liberty and White Streets and Patriot Drive.
The signs also appear on Interstate 84, directing motorists off the highway at Exit 5.
With an unemployment rate at 3.7 percent, a population that remains constant at 70,000, and a moderate tax rate of $19.13 per $1,000 of assessment, Danbury's economic health is almost robust. Its 11 million square feet of industrial space is 93 percent occupied, and 4 million square feet of office space has a vacancy rate under 15 percent, according to figures compiled by several local real estate offices.
Over the last four years the city spent $8 million downtown, building the 556-car Patriot Municipal Parking Garage, planting a town green where a crumbling parking lot once stood, upgrading the sewer and water systems and installing decorative street lighting, benches and paving.
Next on the agenda is Cityworks 2000, a proposed $14.9 million bond issue to enlarge City Hall by 25,000 square feet, renovate and enlarge the 40,000-square-foot public library by 4,000 square feet and update the computer, electrical and climate-control systems at Rogers and Broadview Middle Schools and Danbury High School.
Tom Devine, one of the entrepreneurs who has contributed to the revival of Ives Street, arrived 15 years ago to take a job as restaurant manager. Seven years later he leased a restaurant on Ives Street and went into business for himself as the owner of the Ciao Cafe.
"The city was starting to make improvements," he said. "They were putting in brick sidewalks, burying utility lines, and the banks were very supportive about lending money to new restaurants. Not a lot of people were investing in downtown Danbury then."
TWO months ago he paid $700,000 for a restaurant in a 1920's former firehouse across the street and reopened it as the Two Steps Downtown Grill.
The Hat City Alehouse, a four-month-old Ives Street bar, is a second establishment for Tom Kennedy, who also owns T.K.'s American Cafe in another part of the city. "We wanted to have something downtown because we saw what was going on here," he said.
The bar's walls are covered with old photographs of Danbury and its numerous hat factories, and dangling from the ceiling are Mallory, Lee, and Stetson hats, memorializing the industry that gave Danbury the name of Hat City.
Tuxedo Junction, a popular Ives Street nightclub, will soon be joined by Retro, whose parent company, Bopper's, has clubs in Waterbury and Stamford. Retro has leased a 6,500-square-foot building.
Included in the downtown mix is Liberty Terrace, a moderate-income housing development that opened in 1993.
Developed by the late George Davon, the 36 condominium apartments units of 1,100 to 1,250 square feet were sold for $78,000 to $98,000 to buyers who earned no more than $52,000 if single or a couple or $59,800 for a household of three or more.
The city has approved development of the largest indoor ice-skating center in the region on a vacant two-acre lot between Liberty Street and the Patriot Garage. Financial arrangements for the 85,000-square-foot complex, which is to be called the Western Connecticut Sportsplex and cost more than $8 million, are expected to be completed by the end of the month. It is expected to open late next year.
The developers are Goodfellow Ashmore Financial Group, a division of Goodfellow Ashmore Real Estate in partnership with Dr. Randolph Trowbridge, a local physician, and a recreation-center company that Todd Payne, owner of the real estate company, declined to name. The group plans an Olympic-sized rink for figure skating, a smaller rink for hockey, banks of lockers, food concessions and a second-floor video and entertainment center.
Central to the entertainment component is the proposed restoration of the 1929 Palace Theater on Main Street, which retained all but 180 of its 2,000 seats when it was converted to a triplex in 1992. The triplex was shuttered a year ago after Sony opened a 10-screen theater on Eagle Road off I-84.
"We hope to find a developer to bring it back as a performing arts center," said Mayor Eriquez. "We are looking to establish an arts organization to lease it with an option to buy."
One of its functions would be to provide a winter venue for the outdoor Charles Ives Performing Arts Center of Western Connecticut State University.
Within the last two months a newly built 14,000-square-foot Walgreen's opened on Main Street, adding to the service businesses, financial institutions and medical offices that have taken over former retail establishments, and the old Union Station re-opened as the Danbury Railway Museum after a 42-month, $2 million restoration.
The 17,000-square-foot depot, built in 1903 and surrounded by an additional 17,000 square feet of wood-canopied platforms, had been abandoned for 10 years. Its museum's exhibitions relate to the city's history and ecology and its gift shop is filled with railroad-related merchandise.
UNTIL a new Metro-North station -- under construction by the Connecticut Department of Transportation -- opens in October, the ticket window in the old depot will remain in operation. Late this summer a restaurant will open at the new station, created out of a 1940's dining car and club car that are being refurbished in the Danbury railroad yards by Paul Lamson and Harry Schuesner, both restaurateurs.
Much of what has been accomplished was done in a joint effort by the city and a group of downtown property owners who formed a special services taxing district in 1988. About 130 of them currently pay an aggregate of $140,000 a year for street maintenance, security and promotion. The district extends from the railroad tracks at Franklin Street, along Main Street, through the Dining & Entertainment District, south to Boughton Avenue.
"We feel that the downtown is coming back strong," said Robert V. Macklin, president of Ridgefield-based Village Bank, with branches in Wilton, New Milford and south Danbury. "It's already happening, and we want to be part of it." The bank is building a new 17,000-square-foot branch next to the Patriot Garage, scheduled to open next summer.
Union Savings Bank, a Danbury-based institution with 17 offices in western Connecticut, built The Galleria, a 40,000-square- foot brick office building that fills a former vacant lot on Main Street. Earlier, it had renovated a deteriorating building next door and leased it to Danbury Hospital
"The city has spent a lot of money to fix our streets and build the garage," said Charles Frosch, president of the bank. "This was a private effort to show we don't expect government to do everything."

HEADLINE: SCHOOLS;
It's Hot, Boring, Slow and Necessary. It's Summer School.

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: EDISON

 BODY:
First, the heat: it spreads through the halls like ether, dulling the senses and slowing down time. Eyes glaze over, heads droop low and the textbooks spread across sticky desks go unread.
In steamy classrooms around the state, summer school has begun. 
 It is a little-loved ritual, one that never seems to change. Unless they want to repeat a grade or take extra courses in the fall, students who fail a class must return to school in early July for five weeks of catch-up.
Since this is New Jersey and air conditioning in public schools is rare, they sit in classrooms as humid as rain forests, memorizing vocabulary words and math theorems while summer passes them by.
"It's hot; it's boring; it's slow," said Omar Leak, 17, who is repeating geometry and American history at J. P. Stevens High School here. "I want to be on the beach."
There is no rule requiring Mr. Leak and his peers to show up, since New Jersey students have the option of repeating classes during the regular school year. But most follow the advice of their guidance counselors, spending 60 hours in summer school to make up for a failing grade. (If they fail two classes, they must put in twice as much time.)
New Jersey does not have a standardized curriculum for summer school, so the offerings vary from district to district. Most summer programs fall into two categories: remedial, for students who have failed a class, and enrichment, for those who want to dabble in art, creative writing and other elective-type classes without earning credit. Many districts charge tuition for enrichment classes. In Edison, prices range from $35 for a 14-hour creative writing class to $90 for a 30-hour ceramics class.
The State Department of Education does not monitor summer programs or keep track of enrollments, so it is not clear how many students attend each year or exactly what they learn. One thing is certain, though: many districts have eliminated summer programs because of budget cuts. In districts with no summer school, struggling students must either do without or pay several hundred dollars to attend another district's program.
Edison, one of the state's largest districts, offers two summer school programs, remedial and enrichment, because it has so many students, said Donald Flor, who oversees the programs. About 650 are attending the high school remedial program this year, and about 10 percent come from neighboring towns, paying $300 a course. The money helps Edison sustain its program, which costs about $90,000 a year, Mr. Flor said.
"When you're talking about budget cuts, summer school is one of the first topics to come up," he said. "Every year we think we might lose the funding, but every year it comes through."
On Tuesday, the sixth day of Edison's remedial program, the mood at J. P. Stevens High was grim. In an algebra class, one student dozed while others scowled at their workbooks. Some prowled the halls; others sneaked outside to glimpse the sun. Algebra is the most common summer class, said John Russell, the head teacher, with geometry a close second.
In the cafeteria, more than 300 sweaty teen-agers hunched over tables while three teachers patrolled, making sure no one talked. This was Credit Completion Summer School, for students who passed their classes but had more than 13 absences. Tanya Foster, who said she had missed so many classes she lost count, was putting in time for the fifth summer in a row.
"If you do your work it's not bad, but if you want to fool around, it goes by slow," she said, grateful for the opportunity to talk without being shushed. "Yesterday it rained, and it was the slowest day ever."
About 20 Edison teachers are teaching summer school this year, and Mr. Russell said far more applied for the job. They are paid $42 an hour and teach up to five hours a day from July 1 to Aug. 2. The job is popular for economic reasons. But Mr. Russell said that even with the short hours, it is not necessarily easy.
"These teachers are earning their money," he said. "You get all the kids who didn't do well. They don't want to be here. You're doing a lot of fighting."
Like most other school districts, Edison does not offer a remedial program for elementary pupils because of financial limitations.
But increasingly, parents who can afford it are enrolling young children in for-profit summer schools. Huntington Learning Center, a national chain based in Oradell, has 13 centers in New Jersey. About 1,500 New Jersey children are enrolled this summer, said Al Prior, a spokesman.
At Huntington, parents pay $100 for diagnostic tests, then $35 an hour for classes that usually focus on math and reading skills, Mr. Prior said. Most children spend two to four hours a week at the centers, and most sign up for the entire summer, he said. Most are middle and high school students, but a growing number are ages 5 to 7, he added.
"Parents don't want their kid to go into that summer vegetation mode anymore," Mr. Prior said.
If Laura Gundry, an English teacher in charge of Edison's Credit Completion program, had her way, there would be no need for costly summer programs. In an ideal world, she said, New Jersey's public schools would all remain open in summer. (Two elementary schools in Trenton are already on a year-round schedule, as are more than 2,000 nationwide.) Since so many parents work and cannot afford to provide their children with educational opportunities in summer, she said, year-round school makes perfect sense.
"Let's get realistic: it's an idea whose time has come," Mrs. Gundry said. "Parents can't entertain their kids all summer anymore, and we shouldn't be closing schools for 10 weeks anymore."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Children whose first language is not English prepare for first grade in a class at North Edison High School, left. Older students attend mandatory make-up classes at Edison's J. P. Stevens High School. Algebra and geometry are the most common courses. (Photographs by Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE GREAT OUTDOORS;
Underfoot, a 750-Foot Test Mixing Ashes and Asphalt

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: ELIZABETH

 BODY:
To get to the giant Ikea store here, you may have to drive over your own garbage.
Despite the objection of environmentalists, 750 feet of Center Drive has been paved with a mixture of asphalt and ash from Warren County's incinerator, in an experiment designed to make incineration more financially viable. 
 "This may be a case where recycling this material rather than disposing of it may be worse for the environment," said Richard Denison, senior scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund in Washington. "Virtually no work has been done looking at long-term consequences. The heavy metals will be there in just as high a concentration in 50 years as today, so what's to stop that from showing up in the playground of a school in its next life?"
Only a decade ago, incinerators were hailed as an environmentally friendly way to dispose of solid waste, generating electricity while preserving dwindling landfill space. Seventeen percent of the nation's garbage is now burned, but burning it has not proved cost-efficient. Too many incinerators have been built, recycling has been more successful than expected, and the landfill shortage is not as severe as feared.
In New Jersey, where there are incinerators in Warren, Essex, Gloucester, Camden and Union Counties, it costs about $100 a ton to dispose of garbage in an incinerator, more than double the cost of using a landfill, said Bart Carhart, executive director of the Pollution Control Financing Authority of Warren County. And landfills still end up with leftover ash that may contain toxic lead, cadmium and chromium.
"These are the nuclear power plants of the 90's, both for the economic and environmental hazards," said Judith Enck, senior environmental associate with New York Public Interest Research Group in Albany.
To reduce costs, incinerator companies have helped sponsor projects to find uses for the ash. At the State University of New York in Stony Brook, Frank Roethel, a chemistry professor at the Waste Reduction and Management Institute, supervised the building of a boathouse in 1990 with 14,000 ash blocks. So far there have been no noticeable adverse environmental effects.
There have also been ash-paving projects in New Hampshire, Florida, Massachusetts, and now the one in Elizabeth, directed by a six-agency consortium headed by the state Department of Environmental Protection and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
"The amount of material being used is not enough to cause any kind of problem," said Warren Chesner, president of Chesner Engineering, in Commack, L.I., and coordinator for the Elizabeth project, where 15 percent of the asphalt mixture contains ash. "And you need to put it in a real-world traffic environment; if you put it out in the boonies, and you don't do it rigorously, you'll just have to do it after."
So far ash has not been an easy sell. Across the country, more than 280 municipalities have rejected ash-paving plans, according to Ellen Connett, who, with her husband, Dr. Paul Connett, publishes Waste Not, an anti-incineration newsletter in Canton, N.Y. The Elizabeth project was originally proposed for several Warren County locations, including a stretch of Interstate 80 -- but was rejected each time. When the Port Authority suggested putting the road on its own property on Center Drive, Union County and Elizabeth passed ordinances trying to prevent the use of ash on local roads, to no avail.
Supporters say that it is important to assess the potential risks and benefits of recycling ash.
"There are bad uses and good uses for ash, and asphalt is probably O.K.," said Marian Chertow, director of the Program on Solid Waste Policy at the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies. "Let's re-use the waste: this is the essence of industrial ecology, where one company's waste is another's feedstuff."
Opponents of the Elizabeth project have no plans to quit, no matter what conclusions officials draw about this project.
"They have a vested financial interest in seeing this stay afloat," said Madelyn Hoffman, director of the Grass Roots Environmental Organization in Flanders. "There's virtually no possibility that anything coming out of these tests will be other than a glowing recommendation."

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 7; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
More Arduous Than Childbirth, It's the Time to Pick a Swimsuit

BYLINE: By DEBBIE GALANT 

DATELINE: WEST ORANGE

 BODY:
Linda Basch brings me a bathing suit that she says has been working for women who want to attract attention, well, upward. No wonder. The bottom of the suit is plain black, but the top third is a wacky, bold, black-and-white checkerboard on a weird slant, somehow reminiscent of the Op Art movement of the 1960's. Well, maybe it works for some women, but the leg on this suit is cut so high that it reveals parts of my body I've never noticed -- probably because of strong psychological defense mechanisms.
I draw open the curtains and the verdict is swift. Mrs. Basch wrinkles her nose and assumes a strained smile, as though she has just smelled something offensive. 
 Next suit.
We're in the rear dressing room of Helen Hirsh, a locally famous store that claims it has the biggest selection of swimsuits in the country, 5,000 in all, ranging from size 4 to size 54, and bulging to EE. And the only thing standing between me and a flattering fit is about $70. Because Mrs. Basch, the store's manager, and Betty Paskow, the store's owner, will bring me pile after pile of striped, tropical and classic black suits -- along with an equal measure of advice, criticism, reassurance and wisecracks -- until I am happy.
If Helen Hirsh were a big corporate conglomerate, it would surely hire the Gallup Organization to demonstrate statistically what every woman instinctively knows: that buying a bathing suit stands second only to giving birth as one of the most dreaded chores in the female curriculum. But because this is a small family business, it relies simply on a mug, used as a pencil holder, that a customer once brought in. "Things could be worse -- we could be trying on swimsuits," it says.
(The real Helen Hirsh, who sold the business in 1956, died at age 95 last year. She started in the lingerie business, a line that now keeps the store afloat outside of the summer and the winter cruisewear season.)
For most women, buying a bathing suit is truth time. Every potato chip and piece of chocolate you've ever eaten is now quite visible on your hips and, moreover, taunting you from the mirror. And unlike that power Armani suit, there's scant fabric in this suit to hide behind (or to hide your behind). "People are at their most insecure," Mrs. Basch says. "I would say that out of a thousand customers, one is happy with what she looks like."
That's where Mrs. Basch, Mrs. Paskow and 12 other fitters come in. Unlike most department stores, where you face the mirror and brutal fluorescent lights on your own, Helen Hirsh provides not one, but usually several doting, motherly types to size you up, run for more suits and eventually find the yard or so of Lycra that will best cover your flaws and flaunt your assets.
That may sound like mental cruelty, but the women who work here have at their disposal such a large inventory of bathing suits, and such extensive experience at fitting bodies of all shapes and sizes, that the process of trying on suits, opening the curtain and waiting for their pronouncements actually becomes (dare I suggest it?) fun.
Although most customers try on between 10 and 30 suits before they select one, Mrs. Basch recalls one client who literally stayed all day and tried more than 300 suits before settling on one she liked. "A department store will not give you any help," Mrs. Basch says. "It's a seasonal business for them and a primary business for us."
It helps that there's probably someone in the fitting room who's twice your size. Nor is your body -- or the fact that you might not even like it -- anything unusual at Helen Hirsh. In fact, the bathing suit ladies say, it's usually the size 6 women who are most uptight. "They always think they're fat," says Leah Mendelson, who has been fitting the hard-to-fit for 25 years. Mrs. Basch says she probably sees three certifiable anorexics a week.
Mrs. Paskow, the resident comedian, often breaks the tension of shopping for bathing suits by reminding her clientele that they're not making life-and-death decisions.
To the 60-somethings who worry about, say, too much cleavage, she points out: "They're not looking at you. They're looking at the 18-year-old with the long legs up to her neck and the 34 triple-D." Asked to sum up their own problems looking for bathing suits, Mrs. Basch reluctantly admits that she's larger on the bottom than than she is on top, while Mrs. Paskow openly confesses to the opposite problem. "Between the two of us, we make a perfect person, two perfect people," Mrs. Basch says. "God's variation on a theme," Mrs. Paskow says.
Of course, you must come to Helen Hirsh prepared for unflinching honesty. I thought the first suit was great. I thought I looked skinny. I thought I had done the impossible, found the perfect fit on the first try.
Wrong. Linda Basch shook her head, frowned and directed my attention from my legs and abdomen, which seemed astonishly svelte, to the two empty points that puckered out in front. "You don't fill it out," she said without a trace of embarrassment.
Eventually she did find me a suit I could fill out, and at its first appearance at the swimming pool, the compliments flowed. But I must have tried the same suit on four times before I finally bought it, fussing each time about one detail or another. The last time I fretted that perhaps it made my stomach look too big.
Mrs. Basch informed me that it was my panty line, not the suit, that was causing the problem. Then came the most humiliating experience I have ever endured in the service of journalism. In one brisk move, Mrs. Basch reached under my suit and tugged my underwear down to mid-thigh, thereby eradicating the panty line, my dignity and my last reservations about the suit. I was speechless.
But Mrs. Basch had a grin the size of Brooklyn. "The ultimate punishment!" she declared triumphantly.

GRAPHIC: Photos: At Helen Hirsh, one size does not fit all. At far left, Betty Paskow, the owner (in jumper), helps a customer sift through the racks. At far right, she and the store manager, Linda Basch, offer dressing-room guidance. Denise Fuchs, center, tried on different black-and-white suits. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)
