HEADLINE: Political Briefing;
THE STATES AND THE ISSUES

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

 BODY:

California
Brown May Have Last Laugh Yet
Willie Brown has now been gone from the California State Assembly for the better part of a year. But his machinations linger on. 
 Mr. Brown, a Democrat who served as Speaker of the nation's most powerful and important state legislative body for a record 15 years, was forced by term limits to abandon Sacramento, though he deftly managed to land on his feet as Mayor of San Francisco.
Just before he left the capital for the City by the Bay, the Republicans, as a parting shot, finally came up with enough votes to gain control of the 80-seat Assembly for the first time in almost 20 years. But before they could formally take over, the unsinkable Mr. Brown, as his own parting shot and Machiavellian gesture, stole away a couple of the Republicans' wavering members and snatched back control.
Then he rewarded one of the heretics, Doris Allen of Huntington Beach, with the title (but not the real power) of Speaker. Still later, in a confusing game of musical chairs, he tapped another of the heretics, Brian Setencich of Fresno, to succeed her.
Furious Republican leaders successfully mounted a campaign to have Ms. Allen recalled in a special election, and replaced her with a solidly faithful party member, thereby narrowly regaining effective control of the Assembly, Mr. Brown having left for San Francisco. Then when Mr. Setencich sought re-election, the party spent heavily in the spring primary and denied him the nomination, giving the nod instead to a political unknown, Robert Prenter Jr.
Now, as though straight from the Willie Brown play book, Mr. Setencich is undertaking some machinations of his own, bent on sweet revenge.
The Democrats have nominated no candidate to take on Mr. Prenter in November. So Mr. Setencich, scenting opportunity, plans in the fall to wage a ballot write-in campaign in hopes of regaining his old seat.
He'll make a concerted appeal to Democratic voters. Should he succeed, and should control of the Assembly, post-election, once again come down to a narrow vote or two, Republicans may once again find themselves cursing Willie Brown -- and wondering whether he might have left his heart in Sacramento.
 
Initiatives
A Hot Voter Issue Is How to Hunt
Most ballot initiatives deal with heavy-duty social and economic issues -- affirmative action, gay rights, city charters, taxes. But this fall, a number of state ballots around the country will also include initiatives that deal with hunting rights, an issue that in recent years has begun to add some political steam to its always-present emotional wrench.
Increasingly, groups like the National Rifle Association and the Humane Society of the United States, along with conservation groups, are focusing their considerable organizational, monetary and political resources on the ancient debate over how much game should be taken and with what equipment and methods. At issue, now, is the particularly controversial use of leg traps, dogs and bait to take such animals as bear, cougar, bobcat and lynx.
In initiative votes over the past two years, conservation and animal rights groups in Oregon managed to ban the use of dogs and bait in bear and cougar hunting, while in an initiative vote in California, conservation and animal rights forces managed to retain a ban on the hunting of mountain lions.
This fall, Oregon hunters and sportsmen, better organized now, will attempt again, via an initiative, to win approval of the use of dogs and bait in bear and cougar hunting.
In Idaho, by contrast, conservationists and animal rights supporters have managed to get an initiative on the ballot that would end not only the use of dogs and bait in bear hunting but also would do away with the spring bear-hunting season.
Alaskans will be asked to vote on whether to outlaw the use of airplanes to hunt wolves and whether to require hunters who have flown to a hunting site to delay a day before actually firing at a wolverine, fox or lynx.
In Colorado and Massachusetts, animal rights groups and conservationists are collecting petition signatures for an initiative that would ban leg-hold traps and snares in hunting, while in Michigan and Washington, other conservation and animal rights groups are pushing for a ballot item that would ban the use of bait and dogs in bear hunting.
Generally speaking, for conservationists and animal rights groups, these fights tend mainly to turn on "responsible" bag limits and humane hunting methods.
Hunters and sporting groups, on the other hand, often contend that conservationists and animal rights groups overstate their case and, at heart, want to impose so many hunting regulations that going into the field will not be worth the shot and powder it takes.
 
Indiana
Steamrollering Big Government
When Representative David McIntosh, a conservative Republican from Muncie, Ind., first arrived in Washington two years ago, Speaker Newt Gingrich sensed immediately that he was an ideological soul mate, a committed enemy of Big Brother government. He took the freshman legislator under his wing.
Soon, Mr. McIntosh became chairman of the subcommittee on regulatory affairs of the House Government Reform and Oversight Subcommittee.
Roll 'em back, Mr. Gingrich instructed Mr. McIntosh.
He has, with vigor.
Just the other day, for example, he moved to gut a Federal regulation that requires anyone laying asphalt on a Federal highway to wear long pants.
Fresh asphalt is very hot, and a splash or two on a leg can have real bite. Still, employees of E&B Paving of Anderson, Ind., were willing to put their legs at risk as, under a broiling Midwestern summer sun a few weeks back, they laid down a stretch of blacktop along Interstate 69, near Muncie.
Could they wear short pants, they beseeched the crew boss.
No way, he shot back, recalling that a couple of years ago E&B was fined $2,400 by Federal safety inspectors because some asphalt workers were caught in short pants.
Someone wrote his Congressman.
And now Mr. McIntosh is drawing up a bill.
"This is yet another example of red tape that may make some sense to a bureaucrat in an air-conditioned office in Washington," he says, punching the asphalt-hot inside-the-Beltway button. "If the employees say it's safer to handle asphalt in shorts, I trust their judgment. This isn't rocket science." B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
Dole Calls for a 'Fairer, Flatter' Tax System

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
In what has become his own weekly radio address, Bob Dole today sought to capitalize on the Republican Party's historic image as the party of cutting taxes. He said it was "high time for a fairer, flatter and simpler" tax system, although he did not make a specific proposal, adding that the 1040 tax form should "go the way of the Berlin Wall."
"I believe you should be able to file your tax return on a postcard, or electronically, without paper at all," he said. "And, above all, I am guided by the belief that our tax code should recognize that a family's most important responsibility is raising children and not supporting the bureaucracy in Washington." 
 Mr. Dole, the likely Republican Presidential nominee, has been speaking in the time allotted the Republicans for responding to President Clinton's weekly radio message. Taking over the radio response has given Mr. Dole an official outlet, now that he has left the Senate to campaign full time for President.
The two campaigns are embroiled in an advertising war over which party has cut taxes the most. Mr. Dole today laid out the Republican case, saying that Mr. Clinton's 1993 tax increase was the largest in history. But if adjusted for inflation, it was less than the tax increase enacted under President Ronald Reagan in 1982.
Mr. Dole went on to list the tax cuts enacted by the current Republican Congress but vetoed by President Clinton: a $500-a-child tax credit, a reduction in the estate tax, a reduction in the marriage-penalty tax, a reduction in the capital gains tax rate, creation of a tax credit for adoptions and a tax credit for long-term care of family members.
He said that under President Clinton, Americans were sending more of their paychecks to Washington. "Taxes are now so high that, according to the National Tax Foundation, the typical American family pays more in Federal, state and local taxes than it spends on food, clothing and housing combined," he said.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: POLITICAL MEMO;
Dole's Free-Form Style Upsets Campaign Plans

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
Bob Dole's Presidential campaign has taken to keeping a political calendar detailing the themes Mr. Dole will address each day. Last Saturday was juvenile crime day, Wednesday was reserved for welfare reform, and the topic for Thursday was the United States' relations with Israel.
All of which would have been hard to tell from watching Mr. Dole campaign these past few weeks. From attacking the president of the N.A.A.C.P. to trying to back off his opposition on an assault weapons ban, Mr. Dole has kept his own calendar -- often to the detriment of his campaign. 
 If there is a grand strategy behind all this, neither he nor his aides have been able to explain it. But in his seemingly free-form campaign, Mr. Dole has often found his political calendar set not by his aides but by the questions posed by reporters, who are often encouraged by the White House to bring up certain issues. And he has embroiled himself in the kind of issues that Presidential candidates with Mr. Dole's level of experience usually try to avoid.
All of this has caused obvious dismay among even his own staff, anxious over signs that the candidate and the campaign are adrift, squandering opportunities in the dwindling time left before the Republican convention.
A host of reasons are given for Mr. Dole's recent difficulties, and they involve what Mr. Dole's concerned associates see as shortcomings both of the candidate and his campaign staff. (Most of Mr Dole's aides, aware of the candidate's distaste at seeing his advisers' names in the newspapers, would not agree to be quoted).
As for the candidate, Mr. Dole seems to be having difficulty adjusting from the transition of being Senate majority leader to being a candidate for President. Used to Congress, where he fired off his views with an edgy wit to a regular group of reporters who enjoyed his style, Mr. Dole now seems caught off guard by how a stray remark on an airplane tarmac can become front-page news.
This was particularly clear the past month, as Mr. Dole seemed to work through the fine points of his party's anti-abortion plank in television interviews, almost as if he were still wrestling through legislative differences in the privacy of the Senate cloakroom.
A second factor for Mr. Dole is that he continues to chafe at the modern ways of campaigning -- from using a prompter to disciplining himself to talk in short phrases designed for the news -- pressed upon him by his campaign staff, most of whom, while experienced political operatives, are still decades younger than he is.
Finally, Mr. Dole, in his associates' view, has yet to find a theme to unify his campaign and explain to the public why he wants to be President. This has helped to create the vacuum that has allowed unwanted topics, like Mr. Dole's chance remarks about tobacco, to dominate Mr. Dole's days.
Mr. Dole's campaign staff poses an entirely different set of complications for the candidate. He is surrounded almost entirely by political professionals, as opposed to people who have a grounded loyalty to the candidate or ideology. By comparison, President Clinton was carried in 1992 by a foundation of advisers who shared his centrist political approach.
It was nearly unheard of in 1992 for Mr. Clinton's political advisers to disparage the candidate to a reporter. That is not the case for Mr. Dole. His aides have increasingly taken to pointing out his shortcomings, not to undercut him, but because they want to do in the newspapers what they have been unable to do in his presence: Prod Mr. Dole to change his ways.
That explained the wave of aides complaining about how Mr. Dole would not follow the teleprompter. And after Mr. Dole gave what his own aides described as a "confusing" speech on assault weapons, the candidate's associates prodded reporters to ask him again about the topic, in hopes he would say off the stage what he was supposed to say on it. (He did not.)
Many officials in the Dole campaign learned Presidential politics while working for candidates like Ronald Reagan and Jack F. Kemp. Both of those men were more amenable to the kind of campaign script that dominates American politics today, like remembering to smile or pointing up at the balloons when they drop at a rally.
Mr. Dole has never taken to such instructions, but since many in his campaign are relatively new, they are regularly surprised when he, for example, simply ignores presumably newsworthy lines that have been inserted into his text.
"Half the campaign still thinks they're working for Jack Kemp," one of Mr. Dole's associates said on Friday. "The other half still thinks they're working for Ronald Reagan. And very few people still seem to understand they're really working for Bob Dole."
Some inside Mr. Dole's campaign believe that by the time of the convention, none of this will matter. By then, he will have presumably chosen a running-mate, and will release an economic plan, which will include tax cuts, and which will give the campaign the center of gravity his aides sometimes worry is missing.
But others believe that this period is important, and that public opinions are now beginning to set. Mr. Clinton and Ross Perot were able to make a public case for themselves in 1992, largely because they were unknown. Mr. Dole, by contrast, has been in public life more than three decades, which may mean his window for convincing people to take another look at him will be that much smaller.
There are signs that Mr. Dole is trying to change his ways. His staff has been repeatedly distressed at Mr. Dole's willingness to answer questions from reporters about topics that have only caused him trouble. Thus, it was a small moment when he posed for a picture with foreign policy advisers on Friday and he cut off a questioner who began to ask him if he had the discipline to run for President. "We're here talking about this meeting," he said.
That said, Mr. Dole has been in politics for 35 years. This is his third run for the Presidency. And no matter the lackings of his political style, his aides are becoming increasingly certain of one thing: Little can been done to alter it.
"Dole is Dole," one associate said. "And it's futile to try to change him. You recognize his positives and you recognize his challenges. The staff's job is to maximize one and minimize the other. And I think we will."

HEADLINE: James Plinton Jr., 81; Broke Color Barriers at U.S. Airlines

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
James O. Plinton Jr., one of the first blacks to be named an executive in the airline industry, eventually becoming a vice president at Eastern Airlines, died on July 4. He was 81 years old.
Mr. Plinton, who spent most of his life trying to break down the strong barriers that blacks faced in the airline industry in the 1940's and 1950's, died of cancer at the Lake Wales Medical Center Extended Care Facility in Lake Wales, Fla., said to his daughter, Kathryn Plinton Roman. 
 She said that even as a youth, Mr. Plinton was fascinated by aviation. When he rode in the rumble seat of his father's Model T Ford, he wore a pair of goggles and pretended he was piloting a plane.
Mr. Plinton was born in Westfield, N.J., on July 22, 1914. He had his first major run-in with the color line as a young boy when he was denied membership in the Westfield Y.M.C.A. and told that he was not allowed to use the swimming pool.
After becoming a successful executive in the airline industry, he was elected president of the national Y.M.C.A.
Mr. Plinton's father wanted him to pursue a medical career, and Mr. Plinton graduated from Lincoln University in Pennsylvania with a bachelor's degree in biology.
He worked in the post office and the merchant marine but then pursued his passion for flying by entering the University of Newark's Division of Aeronautics, where he earned a commercial pilot's license and flight instructor's rating.
He went on to the Tuskegee Institute in Alabama and joined the flight training staff of the United States Army Air Corps as one of the first black flight instructors of the 99th Pursuit Squadron.
He trained about 150 pilots, many of whom saw action in World War II and became known as the Tuskegee Airmen.
Mr. Plinton tried repeatedly to be hired as a pilot by major airlines in the 1940's and 1950's. He was turned down by an industry that had a strong bias against hiring blacks as pilots and flight attendants but allowed some blacks to become ground crew workers.
Mrs. Roman said her father was not one to bring discrimination complaints or lawsuits. He persisted in pursuing a career in the industry, though, and after World War II, he turned to airlines outside the United States.
Mr. Plinton helped organize Andesa, the national airline of Ecuador. He also helped Haitian International Airlines.
His big break came in August 1957 when, through the intervention of a pilot and friend, he was able to get an interview at Trans World Airlines. He was appointed executive assistant to the director of personnel and industrial relations, a position that helped him bring other blacks into the industry.
This was the first time that a black had been named to an executive position by a major airline. Mr. Plinton then called the breakthrough a "fabulous opportunity."
In 1971, Mr. Plinton moved to Eastern Airlines, where he was appointed a vice president, then the highest position achieved by a black person in the industry. When Mr. Plinton retired in 1980, Frank Borman, the chairman of Eastern, asked him to stay on as a special assistant for a year.
After his retirement, he remained active as executive director of the Metropolitan Fellowship of Churches in Florida and chairman of the Tacolcy Economic Development Corporation, a nonprofit group of black business and professional leaders.
Mr. Plinton's wife, Kathryn Hancock Plinton, died in 1993. In addition to his daughter, Mrs. Roman of Lake Wales, Fla., he is surivived by a son, James O. Norman Plinton of Miami.

HEADLINE: Perspectives;
On the Playing Fields of Flanders

BYLINE: By JANE LEAVY; Jane Leavy, a former sportswriter for The Washington Post, is finishing her second novel.

 BODY:
On the way to the battlefield they stopped to buy wooden shoes. The 14 American women of the 1920 United States Olympic team, their chaperones and an Army driver were going sightseeing in the killing fields of Flanders where, the poet wrote, poppies grow.
But there were no flowers. Or trees. Or grass. Nothing living at all. Just mud reaching as far as the horizon. It was less than two years after the signing of the Armistice. Europe's Champs de Bataille, or Avenue of Battle, as Belgium is still known, was struggling to return to the land of the living. Ypres, the site of some of the bloodiest fighting, had not been completely cleared of weapons or body parts. But it had become a macabre tourist attraction. 
 "Come visit the battlefields of Liberated Belgium!" beckoned a full-page ad in a pre-Olympic sports magazine.
And so they went. Aileen Riggin was 14 years old, the youngest member of the United States team, when she won the gold medal in springboard diving. She remembers how her feet, shod in the heavy wooden shoes, kept sinking into the mud. And how oil glistened on the surface, making rainbows out of devastation. "It was rather pretty actually," she said.
She remembers this too: Her feet were killing her.
"They warned us the battlefield was a mess," she said recently from her home in Honolulu. "We were allowed to wander around at will. My feet hurt like crazy because they told us to buy the shoes big. The peasants in the fields stuffed them with straw and woolen socks. We didn't know about that. We limped around, peeking in pill boxes and trenches, picking up things, souvenirs we shouldn't have had -- German helmets and cartridge cases, shells.
"I picked up a boot and dropped it immediately. The boot had been occupied."
That eighth grader from Brooklyn is 90 years old now and the oldest living female American Olympic champion, a fate, she notes, "I won't have to bear much longer."
She celebrated her birthday in May by winning six gold medals under her married name, Aileen Riggin Soule, at the United States Masters Swimming Short Course Championships in Cupertino, Calif. She will be in Atlanta for the Games starting tomorrow, where she is among those celebrated in the Olympic Woman exhibition.
She quit diving some 30 years ago because of a detached retina. But she still swims a mile every other day. Her times, she says, are a state secret. Her memories are not. They are virtually all that remain of the 1920 Olympics.
The Great War hovered over the Games. They were awarded to Belgium in homage to its losses and in hopes of reviving its war-ravaged economy. "Belgium was on its knees," said Marc Maes, a member of the 1996 Belgian Olympic Committee. "Well, then, it is always on its knees."
The Belgians had a year and a half to prepare for the Games, which lasted from April to September, combining winter and summer events. They were left $23,000 in debt. For Riggin, it was a grand adventure. For the Belgians, "it was a financial debacle," said Roland Renson, author of "The Reborn Games" and chairman of the Sports Museum of Flanders.
The cornerstone of the Olympic Stadium was laid on July 4, 1919. American soldiers still stationed in Antwerp celebrated by erecting a baseball backstop on the site, the oldest soccer field in Belgium. The Belgians reciprocated by besting their liberators in a tug of war, then an Olympic sport.
When the Games opened a year later, on Aug. 14, the tugs-of-war were still evident in the ruins of the city, and the empty seats of Olympic Stadium. A standing room ticket cost three francs, the equivalent of 50 loaves of bread. The people, in whose honor the Games were staged, stayed away. The few who could afford to come were greeted at the stadium by a plaster statue of a Belgian soldier heaving a grenade.
The United States Olympic team traveled to Antwerp on the Princess Matoika, a rusted old German troop ship that had been handed over to the Americans as a reparation of war. While the athletes waited on the pier to board, the coffins of 1,800 American war dead were unloaded. Dan Ferris, who was secretary-treasurer of the Amateur Athletic Union, said: "The caskets were sitting there on the decks, lines and lines of coffins. The smell of formaldehyde was dreadful. It was a shocking way to start."
The crossing took two weeks, an eternity for the men quartered below in the stinking, rat-infested hold. At night, they sneaked up on deck with their bedding. In the morning, they vied with 13 dressage horses for fresh air, according to several sources, though Riggin has no recollection of the animals. "I'm still troubled about those horses," she said recently. "I don't think I would have forgotten 13 horses on deck."
The athletes tried to train. But the Princess Matoika was small. "We were falling all over each other," Riggin said.
Runners jogged on a cork track laid topside. There were calisthenics on deck but classes were not mandatory and never lasted as long as half an hour. Javelin and discus throwers tied fishing lines and cables to their projectiles and heaved them overboard. "Dick Landon, the high jumper, practiced by trying to kick out deck lights," Riggin said. "The rifle team was tempted but did not succumb to shooting sea gulls."
Swimmers waited in line to take their turn in a pool built out of canvas and two-by-fours, just big enough to hold a single man. The tank was filled by hose with water from the gulf stream. A rope tied around the swimmer's waist held him in place while he raced against the clock. Riggin says divers were lucky to get wet.
When the team finally reached Antwerp, there were no accommodations for the 272 American men. Housing was scarce, a crisis made worse by the arrival of all 2,668 Olympic athletes. American Olympic officials tried to persuade the men to remain on board, precipitating the "Mutiny of Matoika." The men threatened not to compete unless they were allowed off the boat. Officials found them beds, sacks filled with corn husks and straw, in an abandoned schoolhouse. The women stayed in a Y.W.C.A.
The Games opened with a Catholic mass, honoring athletes killed in the war. Later that day, when the white doves of peace were released, an Olympic first, they were greeted with volleys of cannon fire. Gabrielle Goris Cnoops, a daughter-in-law of one of the organizers and a special guest at the opening ceremony, is now 94 years old.
"It was an apotheosis," she said recently in Antwerp. "We were happy to see all those nations together."
Except, of course, the Axis powers, who were not invited.
The Olympic flag made its debut, as did the oath, taken by a Belgian war hero and fencer, Victor Boin. "His voice was firm, like a fencer's," Cnoops said.
Many of the athletes were soldiers and marched in uniform. The American women marched in men's straw boaters stuffed with paper. No one had remembered to bring hats for them. Women's groups outside the stadium protested their exclusion from more "manly" sports.
The swimming and diving competitions were held in the moat that surrounded the ancient city. Spectators, such as they were, sat on benches erected on ancient ramparts. The water was dank, dark and frigid -- welcoming only to rats and frogs. "And the rats swam faster than the men," Maes said.
"We nearly died when we saw what they had for us," Riggin said. "Then, we got in the water where we could have died. It was dangerous, it was so cold. Fifty-two degrees."
There were no hot showers. Riggin remembers several water-polo players being pulled out of the water on the verge of hypothermia and that "the women seemed to be able to handle it better than the men."
Sunlight pierced the surface infrequently. "The water was almost black," Riggin said. "On a sunny day, you could look up and see a glimmer of the sun. On a rainy day, you couldn't see a thing."
And it was always raining. The rain stirred up the sludge and their fears. "You'd be out of breath going down as deep as we did and you'd get fuzzy in the head, disoriented," Riggin said. "I was always scared I'd swim the wrong way."
She didn't practice any more than she had to, especially from the platform, where she finished fifth. It was hard making herself go up the tower and harder staying up there: at 65 pounds she was no match for the wind. "When you hit the water your hands come back and hit your forehead. In practice, we wore sponges to soften the blows. I had a terrific headache the whole time."
She left Antwerp with a gold medal, two German army helmets and a cartridge case. Her journey ended as it began, on a transport ship loaded with the dead. Riggin and her teammate, Helen Wainwright, six weeks older, watched the mournful procession of pine coffins.
"Two little girls standing at the railing, crying," Riggin said. "The soldiers were very gentle with them. They observed all the rules. Each one got a salute."
In the last three quarters of a century, Riggin has skated in the movies with Sonja Henie, swum for Billy Rose's Aquacade and covered sports for the New York Post. She won two more Olympic medals in Paris in 1924, a silver in diving and a bronze in the 100-meter backstroke. Three years later, she toured the States with Gertrude Ederle, the first woman to swim the English Channel. In retrospect, she is not sure which was more terrifying, diving into the moat in Antwerp or into a six-foot-deep glass tank so narrow she had to pull in her arms in order to do a swan dive. For this, she earned $500 a week and was once almost electrocuted.
She has been back to Antwerp twice. But she never saw the Olympic diving venue again. "No one seemed to know where it was," she said.
By 1923, the Belgian Olympic Committee had gone bankrupt. Olympic officials sold every artifact of the 1920 Games -- starter pistols, warmers, chronometers, even their own building -- to help recoup the deficit.
Today, all that remains of the Olympic Stadium is the cornerstone laid in July 1919, hidden in a dank corridor behind a pub in a decaying stadium that is still home to the oldest soccer club in Belgium. The fate of the plaster sculpture of the Belgian soldier remains unknown.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The 1920 Olympics in Antwerp were to be a chance for rebirth from the ravages of the Great War. For Belgium, they turned out to be sparsely attended, financially disastrous and conducted in chilly, Spartan conditions; hypothermia was said to threaten players in the water polo event, left. But for Aileen Riggin, above, now 90, they were the stuff of golden memories for a 14-year-old diver from Brooklyn. HEADLINE: Moynihan's Tax-Break Bill Could Foil Dreams of Fields

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
At a time when New York City has mounted a major drive for new stadiums for the Yankees and Mets, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan may have thrown a wrench into its efforts with a bill that would eliminate Federal tax breaks for new professional sports arenas.
Mr. Moynihan, the senior Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee, said in an interview on Friday that the intent of his bill was to withdraw the Federal Government from the business of underwriting team owners and sports franchises as many teams, like the Yankees, have threatened to relocate unless their host cities build new stadiums. 
 Federal tax subsidies for stadiums, which take the form of tax deductions for people who buy the municipal bonds used to finance construction, would in effect be transferred to educational institutions under Mr. Moynihan's plan. The Senator has introduced another bill that would increase the amount of tax-exempt financing available to medical schools and large, research-oriented universities.
"Taken together, these two bills correct a serious misallocation of our limited resources," said Mr. Moynihan, who introduced both bills on June 17 and provoked immediate protests from cities like Nashville and Pasadena, Calif., where officials said the mere suggestion of eliminating tax breaks forced them to postpone stadium projects.
In New York City, where construction of stadiums for either the Yankees or Mets is at least a year away, the reaction from City Hall has been no less critical.
"We have communicated to the Senator that this is not at all helpful," said John Dyson, chairman of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Council of Economic Advisers, who has led the effort for a new stadium for the Yankees on Manhattan's West Side.
Although the Mayor has not ruled out the renovation of the existing Yankee Stadium in the Bronx, he and George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the Yankees' principal owner, have made clear their preference for a West Side stadium. Consultants estimate its cost at $1.08 billion. Mr. Steinbrenner declined comment on Senator Moynihan's proposal.
Plans for a new Shea Stadium in Flushing, Queens, to cost an estimated $437 million, have won vigorous support from the Mayor, who hopes two new stadiums would attract the Olympic Games to the city in 2008. The new Shea would be built across a parking lot from the existing one.
Senator Moynihan's bills have provoked more muted criticism in Albany. State officials said the proposed cut in Federal tax breaks would undermine any stadium project for the Yankees or the Mets.
"The Senator raises a good question -- whether public funds should be used to subsidize professional sports," said Charles Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation. "But the bill needs to be refined. Localities will continue to build stadiums, and this will just make it more expensive."
Mr. Gargano and other officials said Mr. Moynihan's proposal was too broad and would eliminate tax-exempt financing for work on parking lots and other public improvements necessary to accommodate new stadiums. It would also make projects ineligible for tax breaks even when professional sports teams shared stadiums with the public for amateur or recreational events.
Senator Moynihan's bill wouldmake building new stadiums or updating existing ones more costly because tax-exempt municipal bonds have traditionally been the least expensive way to finance large-scale public projects.
Experts said the most likely alternative would be to issue taxable bonds, but since investors would not benefit from tax deductions they would have to be paid higher interest. Mr. Dyson estimated that the interest rate on taxable bonds would be at least two percentage points above the prevailing rate on tax-exempt bonds, with the difference in the tens of millions of dollars.
Senator Moynihan's bill has struck a sensitive chord in cities where officials were preparing over the last month to sell bonds for stadium projects. Nashville, which had planned a $60 million tax-exempt bond sale the first week in July for a new stadium, postponed the sale because of uncertainty over whether bond holders could be assured of tax deductions.
Critics say the Senator's proposal has severely hampered stadium plans across the nation, even though it is not expected to come to a vote in the Senate this year. That is because rules governing the sale of municipal bonds require a pledge that the bonds will always be tax exempt. That assurance cannot now be given. Senator Moynihan's bill, if approved, would be retroactive to the date of its introduction in June. Lawyers on the Senator's staff said they had made the proposal retroactive to prevent a "rush to market" by cities trying to sell bonds ahead of a vote on the bill.
Although frustrated by the timing of Senator Moynihan's proposal, Mr. Dyson and Mr. Gargano dismissed the suggestion that Mr. Moynihan was using it as a political maneuver in an attempt to undermine Republican administrations in New York City and Albany.
"We have great regard for the Senator and usually agree on principle," Mr. Dyson said. "I just wish he would have waited until we got our financing in place before he introduced this bill."
Senator Moynihan said his proposals rested on a long held belief that too much Federal support was being extended to professional sports while university research, particularly at medical schools, was being reduced.
"Professional sports teams are commercial activities and Columbia-Presbyterian is not," he said. "Universities are where the brain stuff comes from, and that is what deserves our support."

HEADLINE: U.S. to Send Holbrooke to Discuss Indicted Bosnian Serb Leaders

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
Richard C. Holbrooke, the Clinton Administration's former chief negotiator in the Balkans, will return to the region next week in an effort to convince Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia to live up to the peace accords reached in Dayton, Ohio, and bring about the ouster of two Bosnian Serb leaders, a senior Administration official said today.
The decision to send Mr. Holbrooke was reached on Friday at a White House meeting of President Clinton's senior national security advisers, after a recommendation by Secretary of State Warren Christopher, the official said. 
 Mr. Holbrooke will leave on Monday for Belgrade, and will also travel to Sarajevo and Zagreb, the Croatian capital. In recent weeks Mr. Holbrooke has been outspoken -- more so than the Administration -- on the need to fully carry out the Dayton accord and remove the Bosnian Serb leaders from power.
"Although there are serious issues in all three capitals, the primary issue is Milosevic," the official said. "We will read him the riot act and make clear that his behavior is inconsistent with the promises he made in Dayton."
In particular, Mr. Holbrooke will press Mr. Milosevic to fulfill his promises on insuring that the two Bosnian Serb leaders -- Radovan Karadzic, the political leader, and Gen. Ratko Mladic, the military commander -- are removed from power.
This week the International War Crimes Tribunal at The Hague issued arrest warrants for both men, who have been indicted on charges of war crimes.
Elections viewed as critical to Bosnia's future are scheduled for September, and the Western powers backing the Balkan peace accord want the Bosnian Serb leaders removed before the elections are held.
The thinking in asking Mr. Holbrooke to return to the region as an envoy is that he, more than any other figure in the Administration, has been able to wrest concessions from Mr. Milosevic. Despite Mr. Holbrooke's decision after the Bosnian peace agreement to leave public office, he has remained an official consultant.
Under the guidelines of the NATO mission in Bosnia, the NATO troops there do not have the responsibility to arrest General Mladic and Dr. Karadzic and turn them over to the war crimes tribunal in The Hague. In his discussions with Mr. Milosevic, Mr. Holbrooke will raise the issues of "both of removing them from power and facilitating their arrest," the official said.
At a meeting in London this week, the United States and the four other nations responsible for bringing peace to Bosnia -- Britain, France, Germany and Russia -- failed to reach agreement on whether to impose economic sanctions on Serbia because of President Milosevic's failure to live up to this aspect of the Dayton agreements.
The Clinton Administration has still not given Mr. Holbrooke specific instructions on whether the United States is prepared to move forward immediately with new sanctions against Serbia.
"The specific threat of sanctions has not yet been decided," the official said.
There was no discussion of a military response, the official said. The Pentagon, fearing reprisals against American troops, remains adamantly opposed to forcibly arresting the two Bosnian Serb leaders, particularly General Mladic, who commands the Bosnian Serb army and has a loyal following.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
The Second Daley's Legacy

BYLINE: By BRENT STAPLES 

 BODY:
Downtown Chicago is an architectural dream, a place where bold skyscrapers stand mirrored in Lake Michigan and vivid against a vast Midwestern sky. But encircling this scene is a calamity of staggering dimensions -- the poorest and, until quite recently, worst-run public housing system in the United States.
The Chicago Housing Authority is landlord to about 100,000 people, 95 percent of whom live on welfare, in prison-like towers that depress property values and frighten away the middle class. Generations of black Chicagoans have grown up in the C.H.A., cut off from mainstream culture and opportunities. The city's legendary boss, Mayor Richard J. Daley, built much of modern Chicago, including many of its high-rise cages for the poor. There is a pleasing symmetry in the fact that his son, Mayor Richard M. Daley, is involved in a movement that could eventually eradicate them. 
 The opening chapter of the plan centers on the Cabrini Green housing project on Chicago's Near North Side, not far from the Gold Coast. If the funding plan solidifies and Cabrini tenants cooperate, the projects will be partly demolished and replaced with a mix of town houses, single-family houses, modest flats and mid-rise apartments. The development will be economically integrated -- 30 percent low-income, 20 percent subsidized moderate income and 50 percent market rate. Mr. Daley has committed 50 acres of city-owned real estate for private development to shore up the effort. In addition, the city will build schools, parks, a police station, a public library and other amenities. The Cabrini development should be the easiest to institute given its proximity to the rich. The challenge will come with hellish enclaves like Robert Taylor Homes, a deep-ghetto project in a neighborhood that was destroyed to build it.
The Daley initiative is remarkable given the city's history. As both the courts and urban historians have consistently pointed out, Chicago's public housing was deliberately used to segregate blacks who streamed into the city in the 1950's and 60's. Plans for public housing in white areas were killed by City Hall. The strategy left Chicago the most segregated of America's major cities, a place where demographers say blacks and whites are less likely than elsewhere to even encounter each other on the street.
In the late 1960's a group of tenants sued, charging what everybody knew -- that public housing was discriminatory. The case was named for Dorothy Gautreaux, who died before the case was finally decided. The city was ordered to make public housing available in white areas and was forbidden to build further in black areas, except on court approval. The Federal Government has earmarked about $40 million this year to institute the Gautreaux decision. Some of that money could end up in the Cabrini plan.
The three decades since the suit have seen public housing get steadily worse. Things began to look up only last year, when the Housing and Urban Development Secretary, Henry Cisneros, took control of the C.H.A., prompted by a management crisis and a series of crimes involving ever-younger children. The decision to hold the Democratic National Convention in Chicago this year obviously played a role as well. HUD installed Joseph Shuldiner, a former general manager of the New York City Housing Authority, as executive director.
His first-year results are promising. A quarter of the apartments have been placed under private management, improving services and letting administrators concentrate on deeper problems. Once a scandal, the voucher program for the poor who live outside the projects has been revamped and will produce a surplus this year. Evictions of disruptive tenants are up by a third, and unpaid rents down by a quarter. The C.H.A. has a balanced budget for the first time in memory, thanks in part to a tough new inspector general. Faced with tangible improvements, and honest management, tenants who feared redevelopment now embrace it.
Mayor Daley has been looking for a way to make his imprint on the city his father built. If he can transform public housing -- and sweep away those high-rise cages -- his legacy will be secure. BRENT STAPLES

HEADLINE: River Runs Wild and Town Finds Profit

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: COPPERHILL, Tenn., July 12

 BODY:
Who says you can't improve on Mother Nature?
Many in this town in the southern reaches of the Appalachians straddling the Tennessee-Georgia border are questioning that bit of conventional wisdom as they prepare for an influx of thousands of people this month for the whitewater kayaking and canoeing events of the 1996 Summer Olympics. 
 The course for the events, through a 1,700-foot stretch of twisting, churning water on the Ocoee (pronounced o-COE-ee) River, is the first Olympic whitewater course on a natural river. But it is natural only to a point. Over the last three years, engineers and designers have resculptured it, gingerly positioning boulders weighing up to six tons to narrow the river here or create eddies there, or carefully "enhancing" the rocky features of the river's bed usually left dry by diversion of the water to make power.
In the process, they have created a course that has drawn rave reviews from paddlers worldwide and has local residents contemplating a tourist-clogged future that could surpass the economic boom that accompanied the arrival here in the 1800's of the copper mining industry, long since defunct. And Olympic officials noted that tickets to the events at the site in the Cherokee National Forest two and a half hours north of Atlanta were among the first to sell out.
"There is nothing not to like about this course," said Joe Jacobi, one-half of the United States team that won the gold medal in the two-man whitewater canoe event in Barcelona, Spain, in 1992 and who last year moved from the Washington area to Copperhill to be near the Ocoee. "I'm the only paddler who can truthfully say that I have the best whitewater route in the world in my backyard."
The signs of change are all around the tiny mountain town of 362. But those signs are often at war. Along the main street, two new coffee shops -- Loving Chocolates and Small Planet -- demurely advertise cappuccinos and lattes. Just a few doors away at the Nugget, the town's not-so-new pool hall/tattoo parlor/bar, "Tattoos" blares out in five-foot letters over the door.
"It's getting yuppified, and they are trying to run me out," complained Paul Blair, the Nugget's owner, as he described what he termed repeated harassment by city officials.
Whitewater kayaking and canoeing crashed into the region quite by accident. The Tennessee Valley Authority had harnessed most of the 40-mile-long Ocoee as it runs from Georgia, where it is called the Toccoa, into Tennessee, for hydroelectric power. The agency dammed it into reservoirs and or diverted through tunnels or along miles of wooden flumes that allowed the water to plunge hundreds of feet and turn turbines. One day in the early 80's, a truss holding one flume broke, and the Ocoee returned to its natural course for a few miles.
Ferris Maloof, a Copperhill businessman, recalled that the accident reproduced "a beautiful, wild whitewater river" that quickly spawned a thriving commercial rafting industry. When the T.V.A. had repaired its flume and sought to resume its power generation on that section of the river, the new and growing industry fought them. Eventually a lease and permit system was established, allowing flows on designated sections of the river 116 days a year. The flows support a $40 million annual industry that last year attracted nearly 300,000 people to the area.
"It was a godsend," Mr. Maloof said of the collapse of the flume, noting that it paved the way for the area's being considered as the site of the Olympic whitewater events and the creation of the new course.
The $25 million refashioning of the river began three years ago as a joint effort by the T.V.A., the United States Forest Service and the Tennessee Ocoee Development Authority. As a first step, Mark Mobley, a T.V.A. engineer, and John Anderson, an architect-designer, built a 300-foot-long scale model of a stretch of the river. With the aid of computer modeling, sprayed concrete and wire, they duplicated at one-tenth scale every rock shelf, depression and hydraulic jump, where some of the water turns back on itself. Then they manipulated the flow with sandbags and modeling clay.
Meira Crawford, a spokeswoman for the Forest Service, said that in altering the river's banks with native limestone boulders, all individually positioned and cemented with sand-toned, pebble-flecked concrete, the agency sought a natural a look and a route over which the river could easily wash when swollen by rains.
Mr. Mobley said that in remodeling the river he and Mr. Anderson had encountered large boulders in the once-dry riverbed spray-painted with graffiti. After sandblasting the rocks clean, they decided to preserve the essence of the graffiti in some names for the course's features. Thus, a point where the current sluices between two boulders near the start is called Smiley Face for the picture on one of the now-submerged rocks.
Scott Shipley, a 25-year-old member of the United States team who is the 1995 world champion in the one-man kayak event, said recently after a practice run that the course had features that were minefields for paddlers. One is a "hole" called "Humongous" where the foamy clash of rushing water can hold a kayaker in place interminably. Last September in the world championships on the course, he saw a Swedish kayaker become so tired as she vainly tried to paddle out of the swirl that she eventually jumped from her boat and swam to the bank.
It is such dramatic features, said Reed Sisson, a spokesman for the state development agency that will operate the course after the Olympics, that make residents think the location will attract future events and more tourists. And unlike the copper mines whose shafts made Swiss cheese out of the mountains, the whitewater industry creates few environmental concerns.
Until about two years ago, unemployment had been as high as 15 percent, Mr. Sisson said, and residents had been leaving since the last copper mine closed in 1985. But with the whitewater phenomenon, unemployment is now about 4 percent.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The whitewater kayaking and canoeing events at the Summer Olympics will be conducted on a stretch of the Ocoee River near the Tennessee-Georgia border. Two athletes practiced on the run last week. (Robert Abrahamson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Long Beach Rent Battle Focuses on Vacancy Rate

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
A DISPUTE between landlords and the City of Long Beach over the continuation of rent stabilization there could, according to lawyers representing both sides, lead to new guidelines for all municipalities that have adopted the Emergency Tenants Protection Act of 1974.
Lawyers say that the state statute never laid down clear rules on how municipalities determine whether a rent emergency continues to exist and that the Long Beach controversy could clarify some of the issues. 
 The Emergency Tenants Protection Act applies only to Rockland, Westchester and Nassau Counties. Like the separate rent control and rent stabilization laws applying to New York City, it expires next June, when the State Legislature must decide whether to renew or amend it.
The state law gives municipalities the option to adopt rent protections if a survey reveals that vacancies in rental buildings are 5 percent or less.
However, should vacancies subsequently exceed that threshold, rent stabilization must be lifted, the law says. But it does not specifically require periodic vacancy studies. Also, the Emergency Tenants Protection Act applies only to buildings completed before Jan. 1, 1974.
In Nassau, 24 municipalities, including Long Beach, have adopted rent stabilization. Long Beach initially included only buildings of 100 units or more, but added those with 60 to 99 units in 1979. Twenty-two buildings with 1,553 apartments are now rent stabilized.
In the current dispute, four essentially identical lawsuits were filed in May by landlords and others against the city and the City Council.
They claim in part that a rent emergency no longer exists in Long Beach because the vacancy rate now exceeds 5 percent.
Two of the actions were brought in State Supreme Court in Mineola and two in United States District Court in Brooklyn because constitutional issues have been raised.
Several condominium owners and homeowners and a co-op corporation have joined with the landlords. The additional plaintiffs are collectively seeking $4.5 million in damages from the city on the claim that their property values have declined because they must pay higher taxes to make up for the reduced taxes paid by apartment house owners. Landlords are seeking $24.2 million in damages.
But lawyers on both sides agree that the main issue before the courts is whether the city is illegally maintaining rent stabilization if, as landlords contend, vacancies now exceed 5 percent.
"This case is about the 5 percent," said Herbert Rubin, a Manhattan lawyer who represents the landlords' group. "Seventeen years have gone by and the city has done nothing to ascertain whether 5 percent vacancies still exist or don't exist." In New York City, a vacancy study is undertaken periodically. It has always found the vacancy rate to be under 5 percent.
Martin A. Shlufman, a Garden City lawyer who also represents the plaintiffs, said a survey done by landlords late last year found at least 90 vacant apartments in rent-stabilized buildings -- establishing that more than 5 percent of apartments were vacant, he said.
ALL 22 buildings were not surveyed, Mr. Shlufman said, "because all we had to do was come up with a figure in excess of 5 percent," or 78 apartments.
But tenant groups contend that landlords have been warehousing apartments to inflate vacancy figures. Landlords say that is not the case. In January, the owners formally requested that the city conduct its own survey.
Before that can be done, several key issues on which the law is "silent," have to be resolved, said Joel K. Asarch, corporation counsel for Long Beach. "As far as I'm concerned, a silent statute doesn't put a duty on somebody," he said.
For example, is a municipality obligated to do a survey just because a landlord requests one?
Must all vacant apartments -- even those not on the rental market -- be counted? The law does not address the warehousing issue, he said.
And which buildings are included? Some courts have held that subsidized rental housing that is owned and managed by a local housing authority must be counted even though such buildings are not subject to rent stabilization.
In Long Beach, that would add 288 units of fully occupied subsidized housing for the elderly.
Conversely, 25 West Broadway, a rent-stabilized building, is undergoing a major renovation in which 66 of 89 apartments are empty and will shortly go on the rental market. Should the building, which still lacks a certificate of occupancy though it has existing tenants, be counted?
"From a legal point of view, there are a lot of points that these cases are going to raise," Mr. Asarch said. "We need the court's guiding hand so that we can do the proper thing."
Rent stabilization has always been a simmering issue in Long Beach. In 1974, landlords challenged the city's adoption of the rent law, but lost. Later, however, they won large tax reductions on the claim that rent stabilization reduced their buildings' market value.
Landlords say that rent increases allowed by the Nassau Rent Guidelines Board are not enough to cover the cost of operating and maintaining their buildings, especially in an oceanfront community where the weather is particularly damaging.
Last year, the guidelines board approved a 1.5 percent increase for a one-year lease and a 2.5 percent increase for a two-year lease. Increases for the current year have not yet been decided. Landlords also say that when they make major capital improvements it takes years to recoup their investment.
"I am in an economic war pure and simple, and I am going to do everything I can to defend myself," said Samuel Walton, a Melville developer who is a lead plaintiff in two of the four lawsuits. His 276-unit Executive Towers at Lido on East Broadway is one of the major rent-stabilized buildings in Long Beach.
BUT tenants maintain that Long Beach is such a desirable place to live that rents would skyrocket without protections. They also assert that even with stabilization, rents are continuously rising.
"When I moved here 20 years ago, I paid $300 a month, and now I'm paying almost $800," said Shirley Weber, who occupies a one-bedroom apartment at the Executive Towers complex.
Units similar to hers where there has been greater turnover are renting for $1,100 a month or more, she said.
Edwin L. Eaton, the City Manager of Long Beach, said that concerns that vacancies might have crept over 5 percent prompted the city to suggest a compromise earlier this year: vacancy decontrol, under which existing tenants continue to receive rent protection but apartments that become vacant are removed from rent stabilization.
"Given our fears, we felt it was a good compromise because it allowed us to protect people and also give landlords a little bit of what they were looking for," Mr. Eaton said.
Landlords were satisfied, but tenants so vigorously opposed the idea at a public hearing held April 16 that the City Council decided to table all further discussion indefinitely. The first two lawsuits were brought by the landlords' group on May 19.
Mrs. Weber said she and fellow tenants opposed vacancy decontrol because they were fearful it would open the door for harassment to get them out.
"These are rental units, but they are our homes," Mrs. Weber said. "It's a terrifying thing to feel your home is in jeopardy."
Vacancy decontrol also destroys a community, said Michael McKee, director of development for the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, a tenants' advocacy group. He has been counseling tenants in Long Beach.
"No one who could not afford to pay a market rent could ever again move to Long Beach, and middle-income people would be squeezed out," he said.
Now that landlords "have thrown down the gauntlet," said Mr. Asarch, the city's Corporation Counsel, "we intend to fight tooth and nail to protect the citizens of this town."
"All eyes will be on Long Beach," said Mr. Shlufman, the landlords' lawyer. "This is the kind of case that probably will make new law, because the courts will now have to interpret the statute and what it intended and what it required."

The current figure, however, includes an $80 garage charge; the apartment is $661.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Attached Housing Comes Back in Detached Country

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
CHARLES INGENITO and Regina Hrostek, who are getting married in September, set their sights on living in North Jersey to be near their jobs and families. He is a lawyer in Bergen County; she is a saleswoman for a Stamford, Conn., information technology consulting concern.
After searching the area's housing market the couple found that, for what they would pay to rent an apartment, they would be better served buying a home and building equity. But single-family detached homes were too expensive or needed too much work, Mr. Ingenito said. They settled on a town house at Franklin Heights, a 420-unit community being built in Mahwah in Bergen County. It cost less than $200,000, their price range. 
 Steven Schwartz and Susan Robolino, who plan to marry next year, tell a similar story. The couple, who work for a Morris County incentive concern -- he as director of computer operations, she as a meeting planner -- are buying a new condominium duplex apartment in the 140-unit Cambridge Heights at Clifton complex. The price was less than $140,000.
Both couples are helping to once again fuel the market for attached housing, as are single men and women, empty-nester couples and some young families. That market was overbuilt in the mid-80's construction surge and came to a near-halt during the recession, when buyers were worried about declining prices and their ability to resell units.
Since then, as the state's residential market has slowly improved, helped by reasonable mortgage rates, so has attached housing. Much of the oversupply of such homes has been absorbed and prices, though lower, have stabilized, said David J. Schoner, vice president of the new homes division at the Coldwell Banker brokerage.
"I don't think we can sell in five years and make a huge profit, but we can make a little," Mr. Ingenito said, adding that he and his fiancee also liked the lifestyle town houses offered.
Ms. Robolino and Mr. Schwartz were also worried about resale value. "But we bought at a lower preconstruction price and feel we can at least make back what we pay for the unit," she said, adding the key for them was that it was new and affordable.
Builders are hoping other buyers who cannot or choose not to buy a one-family detached home will also view attached housing at less than $200,000 as a viable alternative. Some 100 such new and existing projects, with 16,000 units, are under way in the state's 14 north and central counties, according to Coldwell Banker. Some projects also mix in single-family homes on small lots.
"Attached housing has come back," said Robert Burchell, a professor at the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. "But it has a limited window of opportunity." To draw buyers, he added, the units must be well located, sell for one-third to one-half less than the price of new detached homes in the area and give buyers newer features than they would get in older single-family resales.
Builders are adding features not found in attached houses at these prices built in the 1980's. Among them are basements and garages. They are also larger.
OTHERWISE, they are in direct competition with one-family detached resales, Dr. Burchell said, adding that "the single-family home still predominates the market."
But producing attached housing people can afford, many developers said, is becoming more difficult because of the growing scarcity of available land for multifamily housing.
Indeed, developers with current projects have been able to respond to demand because many have taken over already zoned sites or projects with all their approvals in place. One is K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank. "Towns have shut the door on attached housing," said Merle Huseth, president of its northeast region. "But it is still desirable." He said people who bought condominiums or co-ops years ago now wanted to "move up to something affordable, and affordable becomes attached housing in densely populated areas."
Two of the company's projects illustrate the point. At Franklin Heights off Franklin Turnpike in Mahwah, sales began nine months ago. Of the 420 condominium apartments and town houses planned, including 81 income-restricted Mount Laurel units, 197 have been built and all but 18 sold. In that time, prices have risen by $2,000 to $4,000, with the two-bedroom, 1,236-square-foot condominiums now selling for $143,950. Two- and three-bedroom town houses, with 1,338 to 1,662 square feet, cost $156,950 to $169,950. Basements are included, but garages are not, Mr. Huseth said.
Off Route 22 in Bridgewater in Somerset County, Hovnanian is building Stratton Meadows, a 487-unit development, including 97 Mount Laurel units. It will have 120 condominiums of 1,250 to 1,600 square feet each and 259 town houses 1,500 to 2,000 square feet with garages. There will also be 108 single-family homes of 1,800 to 2,900 square feet on small lots. Prices are $120,000 to $185,000 for the attached units and $196,000 to $240,000 for the single-family homes. In the six months since sales began, 148 homes have been sold, Mr. Huseth said.
Just off Chimney Rock Road in the Martinsville section of Bridgewater, work is under way on Loft Farm, with 148 town houses, 17 of them for low- and moderate-income buyers. Prices for the units, with 1,600 to 2,400 square feet of space plus garages and basements, are to start at $179,000. "This is affordable for the area and people will buy if they perceive value," said Jeffrey Freireich, a principal of Westminster Homes Inc., an affiliate of the Kushner Companies, both of Florham Park, which is developing the project. Sales are to start this summer.
Pricing along with location is drawing buyers to Cambridge Heights at Clifton, said Joseph L. DiBernardo, senior vice president at Whiteweld, Barrister & Brown. The Manhattan-based real estate concern is developing the gated condominium community under its residential arm, Town and Country Developers in Woodcliff Lake.
The company bought the 9.5-acre site on Myron Street two years ago with an approved site plan. It is adjacent to a neighborhood park and close to shopping and an N.J. Transit train station with direct service to Manhattan.
"The area's large population of tenants created a demand for this product, as did empty-nesters who want to sell their single-family house and put their equity into a condominium for the convenience and to stay in the area," said Jack Vaughan, vice president of marketing for Town and Country.
THE two-bedroom apartments will have 1,007 to 1,600 square feet as well as 40- to 55-square-foot decks. The larger units have lofts. Prices, which have risen $14,000 to $27,000 since sales opened in March, are now $127,900 to $154,900. Deposits have been taken on 73 units, Mr. DiBernardo said.
A revived town house project in the Toms River section of Dover Township in Ocean County, called Saratoga at Toms River, is also attracting buyers. The developer is the Menk Corporation, part of H. Hovnanian Industries of Tinton Falls, whose head is Hirair Hovnanian, brother of Kevork Hovnanian, chief executive of K. Hovnanian Enterprises. Menk took over the development two years ago after 144 of the original 400 units were built and sold.
The company has reduced the remaining units to 232 "to make them larger and add one-car garages," said Vram Yegparian, president of Menk. The units, which also offer optional basements, have 1,650 to 2,050 square feet of space and are priced from $101,990 to $122,000, Mr. Yegparian said, noting that one-third of the units had been sold. "The market," he added, "is telling us there is need for this type of housing."

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
You Work at Home. Does the Town Board Care?

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER 

DATELINE: MADISON, Conn.

 BODY:
WHEN many government officials peek behind bedroom doors, institute "don't ask, don't tell" policies or ask people to "come out of the closet," they are not prying into residents' sex lives -- they are just trying to exercise some control over the booming growth of home offices.
With downsizing at American corporations coinciding with the advent of easy-to-use, relatively cheap telecommunications equipment, more and more professional workers are trying out entrepreneurial skills by setting up offices in spare bedrooms and basements. 
 Hardly a suburban neighborhood is without a marketing consultant or a graphic designer working full time at home or a corporate manager who telecommutes a few days a week.
As many as 40 million people work at least part time at home, with about 8,000 home-based businesses starting daily, according to IDC/Link of New York, an electronics information research group. Of those, some 1.5 million claimed deductions averaging $2,000 each for home offices on their tax returns for 1993, the last year available, according to the Internal Revenue Service.
For local officials, then, the question is whether to ignore all this or to enforce zoning or tax regulations that place home-based businesses in technical violation of the law.
Many communities see no threat to their residential nature as long as home businesses stay out of sight; they are content with a "don't ask, don't tell" strategy that places a fig leaf of ignorance on a potential enforcement problem.
Others, like this suburb on the Connecticut shoreline, gently nudge those with home offices to declare themselves and submit to regulation. Still others, though, are cracking down tightly, fearing that today's low-impact business could turn into tomorrow's neighborhood nuisance.
And many towns are struggling to rewrite ordinances to recognize the changing ways in which Americans work, to blend inoffensive home offices into the community and to clarify the line between home and business.
As communities debate the issues, many people with home offices play a cat-and-mouse game with neighbors and local officials, minimizing the outward signs of commerce -- the visiting clients, the nonresident employees, the delivery trucks -- that draw attention.
The virtual cop on the home-office beat is a neighbor who takes umbrage, justified or not, at any hint of illegality.
In Connecticut, an executive working out of her home with no visiting customers, signs or noise was hauled before her condominium board in the last year to answer complaints by a neighbor that she was violating local regulations. Earlier, a St. Louis minister's wife who gave children piano lessons faced a fine and a possible jail sentence because people objected to "clients" coming into her home; the authorities relented but her home association took action against her anyway.
Sharon Kersten, a Miami Beach resident who is trying to get the city to legalize home-based businesses like her public relations operation, said, "I have a next-door neighbor who would turn me in in a heartbeat" if she knew about the home office.
"Commercial real estate interests are real strong here, and they are afraid of losing business because people find it cheaper to work at home," said Ms. Kersten, 44, who is married and has a 14-year-old stepdaughter. "I am going public because I feel it is a family-values issue -- parents can work at home and be with their children."
Others with home offices are organizing on local, state and national levels to lobby for protection and swap information on everything from tax strategies to handling the loneliness of the cloistered office.
"Many existing residential zoning laws prohibit home offices for anyone other than licensed professionals like doctors, lawyers and architects," said Ron Wohl, a director of the American Home-Based Business Association, a Maryland group that is trying to expand its national membership of 1,000. When most laws were written, he noted, the personal computer and the virtual office were barely a dream. The old laws, he said, were intended to block businesses, like bustling sales offices or noisy repair shops, that were incompatible with residential neighborhoods.
"The result," he said, "is people are forced to operate outside the law, and so an economy producing billions of dollars has been driven underground."
The easing of zoning rules to allow broader uses -- as long as a home remains primarily a residence -- has liberated many thousands of entrepreneurs who had lurked in the gray areas of legitimacy.
Suburban officials, recognizing that the growing cadres of home-based workers can benefit local bankers and merchants more than those who go to an office in another town, are more accommodating than cities faced with expensive office space sitting empty, said Abhijeet Rane, an analyst at IDC/Link.
Moreover, he said, working at home solves child-care problems for two-paycheck couples and helps reduce break-ins in what had been bedroom communities that emptied during the day.
"The question of how much and what type of work can reasonably be done at home is going to be a big issue for the next 10 years," Mr. Rane predicted. "There are too many social benefits and too much support from big businesses who will reap the benefits of telecommuting."
A SURVEY conducted by Home Office Computing magazine found that some cities were at the forefront in providing a friendly climate for home-based businesses. Phoenix ranked first in the survey, which was based on factors like public and private efforts to assist the home-office worker.
Second on the list was Gaithersburg, Md., in Montgomery County in suburban Washington. The county passed a zoning law six years ago that opened residences to a range of occupations if conditions were met. That ordinance and subsequent ones in other communities generally set limits for nonresident employees, visiting clients, inventory and storage facilities, parking, outdoor signs and the amount of interior space devoted to work. Businesses that generate traffic, noise, odors and visual pollution remained outlawed.
Running a business from an apartment depends on the tolerance levels of nosy or cranky neighbors, Mr. Wohl pointed out, and condominiums and property owners' associations with bylaws that supersede local zoning regulations can be hostile to anything but pure residential use.
Mr. Wohl, a management consultant, and his wife, Myrna, who runs a sign-language service, run separate businesses out of their house in the Montgomery County community of North Potomac and, he said, have yet to hear a neighbor complain.
"We have two personal computers, three modems, two faxes, 14 phone lines, cellular phones and beepers, and no one driving by would ever know anything was going on inside," he said. "By contrast, the most hideous example of a professional business going haywire in Montgomery County was a husband-and-wife team of psychiatrists in North Chevy Chase who ran a 24-hour group therapy practice in a neighborhood of Victorian homes. They paved every inch of grass in their yard for parking and installed huge lights to illuminate the entire property before the neighbors knew what was happening."
Carol J. Newton has no comparable surprises for her neighbors in Madison, a community of 16,000 on Long Island Sound, about 15 miles east of New Haven.
A former marketing communications specialist and kindergarten teacher, Ms. Newton, who is 38, has run a part-time interior-design business since 1989 from her two-story frame house with an outdoor pool on a wooded lot.
Madison has a fairly liberal zoning law that permits unobtrusive businesses like hers. But the town also has a one-time $25 fee for a "customary home occupation" permit for home offices and, more important, Connecticut has a personal property tax on business equipment and materials that is levied at the same rate as the property tax.
MS. NEWTON, whose husband, Hunt, runs telecommuting training seminars for the Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation, said she figured she had little to lose when she received a permit last year, because most of her work was done on a telephone. "My office had a board for a desk, two file cabinets and swatches of materials," she said.
Her extra annual tax is $20.
But others with more expensive furnishings and sophisticated equipment are reluctant to declare themselves to the tax collector. Only 314 home-occupation permits have been issued in the last 20 years, and many of those have expired, town officials reported, while no one knows for sure how many residents work in home offices. Unlike surrounding communities, Madison, where the average house costs $240,000, has no malls or extensive shopping areas. Office space is restricted to the Boston Post Road and a few smaller strips.
Yet there are at least 1,078 concerns doing business in Madison, many or perhaps most of them home-based, according to Margaret M. Sprague, owner of a printing company here, called 2 Ems. She keeps a data base of local business ventures.
Ms. Sprague acknowledges that she is a beneficiary of this boom. She started a desktop publishing business on her dining-room table in 1980, moved it to her basement when she needed more room and leased downtown office space when she hired assistants. She now has two full-time and two part-time assistants, including her husband, Kent, who lost his job in industrial chemical sales when his company shrank.
"My own business flourished because people who were being downsized out of jobs were starting their own businesses at home and needed strong office support," she said. "It opened business to me that didn't exist before. Storefronts in Madison that were vacant are now filling up, and I have to believe it's because there are a lot more people around who used to spend their days in New Haven or New York."
On a recent day, she said, she received printing orders from three new clients, all new home-based operators: a manufacturer's representative, a medical communications specialist and a graphic designer.
TOM RYLANDER, first selectman of Madison, said that the businesses whose operations were visible to outsiders were complying with the permit requirements and that tax laws and enforcement were not a problem. "Those not visible can probably skirt it if they wish," he said.
Mary Haburay, a zoning official in Madison, said those with home offices complied with the law only when a neighbor complained. "We're not out there looking for them," she said. "We have a lot more pressing things to do."
That is not the attitude of Pat Hedwall, the town tax assessor. "Frankly," she said, "many residents with offices in their homes either don't know they're supposed to file a personal property tax declaration every year or somehow 'forget' to do it and hope we'll never find them."
Ms. Hedwall said tight town budgets had made it her duty to be vigilant about these businesses.
"By state law if I find them I can audit their books for three years," she said with the feigned fervor of a suburban Inspector Javert. "But frankly, the way most of them keep books they're not worth much. And it costs me $200 to run an audit, so it may not be practical."
Still, she said, she scours the local newspaper and telephone books for clues to residential businesses and often uncovers clandestine home offices while conducting routine property assessments.
"A guy the other day got a building permit for a garage with a room over it he called living space. I took a look at it and said, 'Wait a minute, that's obviously intended for business.'
"I told him to fill out the tax forms or else have me guess what the value is. And I have a very creative imagination."
At the local tax rate, she said, $8,000 worth of home equipment would translate into a yearly tax bill of $124.32, not much for a thriving business but a thorn to one on a shoestring.
In wealthy Greenwich, closer to New York, the pace of telecommuting and home-office operations has been torrid for several years, said Bruce Dixon, the assistant zoning enforcement officer.
"We issued 1,100 building permits last year," he said, "and more than half of them, I'd say, involve additions or alterations for home offices."
Last year, Ms. Newton and a friend, Michelle Murphy, started a Connecticut chapter of the American Home-Based Business Association, which has since spawned three local chapters.
"There's an absence of support services for people doing what we're doing, namely running a business and caring for a family under one roof," said Ms. Murphy, a freelance writer and mother of three. "Issues like isolation in the home and assistance with technical services are very much in the forefront of our lives. Networking helps take some of the stress out of it for people used to working in offices with support systems you took for granted."
Now when her fax machine jams, she said, "instead of tearing my hair out and calling an '800' service number, I call one of our chapter members."
She is also more relaxed about letting clients know she works from home instead of a fancy office somewhere.
"In the beginning when I was on the phone with someone and the babies started crying and whining, I raced from room to room with the portable phone one step ahead of them to keep the other party from hearing," she said.
"Now that other party is just as likely to be working from home, so it's no big deal."
