HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Market Dip Sparks Recession Talk

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The only thing we have to fear is everything.
That could be the message of the stock market in July 1996. First it got scared that the economy was too strong. Then it grew very fearful that the economy was too weak. 
 As it happens, this is a market that has gone a long time without being afraid of much of anything. The mutual fund portfolio managers have acted as if the biggest fear they had was of not being able to get money invested fast enough. And the individuals who funded the mutual funds seemed to be afraid only that they might miss out on a huge bull market.
Is this merely another example of how Wall Street psychology can turn on a dime? Is it more proof that professional traders tend to be manic-depressives? Or is it a signal that something fundamental has changed?
Perhaps it is the latter. While much of Wall Street has been focusing on the Federal Reserve, as if Alan Greenspan controlled the world, the real power has been held by millions of individual Americans. Since 1990, and particularly since the end of 1994, mutual fund investors have taken every sign of worry on Wall Street as a buying opportunity. Money poured in, usually the next day, and prices soon were rising again.
That comfortable pattern is not working now. Monday, which should have seen an influx of cash after the 114-point debacle on July 6, in fact was a poor day. There was a bit of a rally on Tuesday, but it was downhill from there. After Thursday's selloff, there were repeated attempts at a rally on Friday, but they failed.
Still, the Dow is down just 4.6 percent from the peak of 5,778 it reached in May. Not since 1994 has there been a 5 percent retreat, based on closing figures. The index has traded below that drop, as it did on both Thursday and Friday, but it has always rallied. Birinyi Associates, a research firm, says the Dow has never gone so long without such a setback.
The market is acting, for the first time in quite a while, as though it thinks a recession is possible. Cyclical stocks have come under some of the heaviest pressure in the current downturn.
Chuck Clough, the Merrill Lynch strategist, thinks the market is right. He sees signs that corporate profits are beginning to weaken, that the capital spending boom is over and that the extraordinary level of retail buying of early this year is fading. "There could be a recession by the end of 1996," Mr. Clough said on Friday. "If we're not in a statistical recession, we'll be in a profits recession for at least several quarters."
That is distinctly a minority view. Most of the seers think profits will do quite decently, thank you. "The equity market will do well if bonds do well," argues Abby Joseph Cohen, the Goldman, Sachs strategist. "The economy will decelerate, but earnings will still grow." And she thinks that as people gain confidence, they will begin to pay for stocks based on estimates of 1997 profits.
At the moment, you have to squint to see evidence that the economy is seriously slowing. The worry last week was set off when Motorola and Hewlett-Packard, two technology companies, said profits were disappointing. But technology companies are not reliable economic indicators, coming from an industry that, for the last couple of years, has been exceedingly strong. Had the whole economy grown like technology, we would be in a boom the likes of which have never been seen. It's about time for some weakness there. A lot more evidence is needed.
Still, the last two weeks have seen the Nasdaq composite lose 6.9 percent of its value, leaving it 11.7 percent below the peak it set last month. That is getting close to the worst correction of the last three years, the 13.7 percent dip that occurred in 1994.
One essential point for investors is that the Fed doesn't know a lot more than the rest of us, and therefore is unlikely to provide the needed clues. The excessive attention given the Fed reached a peak last week, when reporters seized on a report by a couple of Fed staffers that had previously, and deservedly, been quite obscure. That report, called "The Opportunistic Approach to Disinflation," might indicate the Fed won't tighten. Or maybe it doesn't.
The study basically suggests that the Fed might choose to fight inflation not by trying to choke off growth that gets too rapid but by simply waiting for the inevitable recession to cut inflation and then trying to keep it from rising again. Its relevance to immediate policy is probably minimal.
So don't watch the Fed. Watch your neighbors, and see if they are losing faith in this generation's great belief, that stocks are now, as always, the best long-term investment. That belief has been enough to make historic valuation rules meaningless.
Eventually, valuation will count. And that is why there is a lot to be said for bonds at current levels, which provide a guaranteed return that the stock market may have trouble matching. But signs of a revival of interest in bonds are few. Fear aside, stocks are still popular.
There is one new indicator that will encourage the bears. The Nasdaq stock market has a new president, Albert Berkeley. The last time it got a new leader was a few weeks before the 1987 crash. And Mr. Berkeley took over a couple of days before the latest peak in the Nasdaq composite.
That has not gone unnoticed, Mr. Berkeley says: "My brother calls me 'Top Tick.' "

CORRECTION-DATE: July 21, 1996, Sunday

HEADLINE: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;
At Twin Towers, the Ice Rink Goeth

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
It opened to great fanfare in January: an ice-skating rink between the twin towers of the World Trade Center, heralded as a boon that would attract tourists and new residents alike to lower Manhattan as the neighborhood seeks to recover from the recession that sapped its real-estate market.
 Now, less than six months later, the rink, Recreation World Ice Chalet, is padlocked. And in one of the biggest skating squabbles since Tonya Harding versus Nancy Kerrigan, a court battle has erupted between the rink's operator, Recreation World, and the Trade Center owner, the Port Authority. 

 The Port Authority said it is seeking to end the rink's lease because it was badly run. Recreation World, which had run Wollman and Lasker rinks in Central Park, responded with a lawsuit accusing the authority of failing to live up to its part of the deal. As the two sides argue, the rink, which was supposed to be resurfaced for use by in-line skaters this summer, lies fallow.
 "Unfortunately the rink failed to live up to our expectations," said a Port Authority spokesman, Allen Morrison. "It did not meet expected revenue goals. And the rink is unsightly. It doesn't add to the esthetics of the plaza."
 Recreation World countered that the Port Authority violated the lease by failing to spend $45,000 marketing the rink and by trying to force it to close without due notice. The company is suing for $8 million in damages and the right to continue operating the rink.
 The rink's closing comes as civic groups have stepped up efforts to make downtown Manhattan a recreation destination as well as a residential neighborhood. The city offers tax breaks to developers who convert office buildings into apartment houses; the J.M. Kaplan Fund created Heritage Trails, historical markers to guide tourists on walking tours, and the Alliance for Downtown New York, the local business improvement district, sponsors a free shuttle bus for shoppers and many outdoor events.
 "The rink was a good, creative idea," said Mike O'Connor, the alliance's vice president of operations. "It was a first try. Things don't always work on the first try. I went once at lunchtime. I found it invigorating. But it wasn't crowded."
 A 1993 report by the Department of City Planning found that "the five acres of the World Trade Center's plaza have never achieved their potential to be a major open space resource for Lower Manhattan." It notes that the plaza is uncomfortably windy, cut off from the concourse below and isolated from nearby streets. So the Port Authority, which has commissioned a study analyzing the possibility of selling the Trade Center or privatizing its management, decided to spruce up the plaza. The rink was one step. Another will be the opening of a large Borders Bookstore later this summer.
 What worked so well in the plaza below Rockefeller Center, which opened its rink on Christmas Day 1936, quickly fell apart at the Trade Center. But the Port Authority may try again. "The concept was good," Mr. Morrison said, "but the implementation was not what we expected." MICHAEL COOPER

HEADLINE: Legislator, 72, Defies the Odds

BYLINE: By JOHN RANDAZZO

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THEY call him the Iron Man of politics and "the people's choice" as he campaigns in a wheelchair for an unprecedented 14th term on the County Board of Legislators.
 The sobriquets fit well on Legislator Andrew Albanese, 72, an Eastchester Republican and middle-of-the-road populist who is recovering from a stroke he suffered two years ago, and he is still on the job. 

 The first thing he did the other day after laboriously rising from his wheelchair and firmly gripping a four-pronged cane in his office was to call a constituent whose mother was a stroke patient.
 "Hi'ya," Mr. Albanese said, with his wife, Linda, at his side in the County Office Building here. "Before your mother can enter the rehabilitation center, we must fill out proper papers."
 Then, Mrs. Albanese, who chauffeurs her husband around in a van, wheeled him to a committee meeting a few doors down the hall with Legislator George Latimore of Rye, the minority chairman, and other lawmakers.
 "Andy has personal friends and relationships on both sides, politics notwithstanding," Mr. Latimore said. "He's straightforward, a man in tune with the people."
 But few Democrats on the 17-member Board, and those not on it, seem to share these sentiments. Soon after Mr. Albanese announced for a 14th term last year opposition started.
 Republicans hold a majority of 11 to 6 on the Board. The Democratic leadership would like Mr. Albanese to retire to a home the couple has built in Arizona.
 Critics contend that Mr. Albanese, a well-known restaurateur in Eastchester, is not physically able to represent his 10th District constituency in Eastchester, Tuckahoe, Bronxville and parts of Mount Vernon and New Rochelle. Since late 1983, Democrats had failed to field a candidate to wrest control of the district.
 His attendance at Board and committee meetings, they say, is poor, claiming that he often arrives late or not at all, which Mr. Albanese vigorously denies.
 "President Roosevelt used a wheelchair, too," Mr. Albanese said. "And the other day a person in a wheelchair took part in the Olympic parade in Mamaroneck."
 But Mr. Albanese is no F.D.F., his detractors contend.
 "You've got to admit his 26 years on the Board constitute a superb career for social legislation he initiated and helped pass," said Legislator Thomas J. Abinanti, a Democrat of Greenburgh.
 "There's a paradox there though," Mr. Abinanti continued. "By staying in power so long, he has blocked the input of new blood new ideas." Patricia Fitzgerald Gorski, clerk of the County Board of Legislators, calls Mr. Albanese "an icon of the people regardless of party affiliation." She started on the Board as a secretary 25 years ago.
 Mr. Albanese, one of 10 children of Italian immigrants, and his brother, John, a former Town Councilman who died in 1991, represent almost a half-century of uninterrupted public service in Westchester. John Albanese was also President Roosevelt's bodyguard as a state trooper in the early 1940's.
 The Albaneses' three sons, Raymond, John and Gregory, who have five children among them, have taken part in local entry-level politics.
 There are some indications Mr. Albanese may be having second thoughts about another term.
 "I'm not buckling to pressure. I feel fine, but it's up to my doctor," he said.
 Mrs. Albanese said of her husband, "It's really up to him."
 One of his biggest boosters is County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke. "Andy is a people-oriented, moderate Republican, an iron man really," he said. "I would be glad to fly with him anywhere." That's a private joke between them: recently they flew a B-17 from Westchester Airport to survey land for a project they are working on.
 Together, they lead a drive to cut taxes and expenditures. "Downsizing has resulted in a 20 percent drop in the county work force," said Mr. Albanese, who has pioneered other economies.
 "Our senior citizens," he said, "can't afford high property taxes and are moving out in droves, while young people can't move in for the same reasons."
 Mr. Albanese, citing his achievements, said he had initiated legislation to identify sex offenders in communities; voted for the police in Westchester to carry 9-millimeter guns; endorsed drug and alcohol rehabilitation; was in favor of more safety at ATM locations, and approved of additional gun control mandates.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Andrew Albanese and his wife, Linda, in the restaurant they operate in Eastchester beneath their living quarters. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: John B. Larson;
Universal Internet Access, Fall of '96

BYLINE: By ANDREA ZIMMERMANN

 BODY:
ON Sept. 28, community volunteers are to start wiring Connecticut's schools and libraries, providing access to and home pages on the Internet. The initiative is called ConneCT96 and is being led by John B. Larson, a former gubernatorial candidate, past president of the state Senate and a former elementary and high school teacher.
 Mr. Larson, currently a senior fellow at the Yale University Bush Center for Child Development and Social Policy, said that any school or library that, by tomorrow's deadline, has established a planning team, signed up for the program and raised $600 to $800 for the connection kit, qualifies for the program. The Southern New England Telephone Company will provide 60 hours of free Internet access each month to each participating institution during the 1996-97 school year. 

 Based on a similar endeavor, Net Day in California, ConneCT96 is sanctioned by the state's leaders in education, government and business. Much of the administrative work is being handled by Citizens for Connecticut's Children and Youth in New Haven. But ultimately, Mr. Larson believes, it is involvement on the local level that will be most important. He discussed his work and theories in a recent interview. Following are excerpts from the conversation.
 Q. What is ConneCT96?
 A. ConneCT96 is our effort to link every school, K through 12, public and private, and every library in the state to the Internet. Connecticut, sadly, ranks about 40th of the 50 states in terms of where we are with respect to wiring. And in a state as affluent as ours, and in a state that clearly has an outstanding reputation in the area of education, this just simply won't do.
 We figure between the public and private schools there are approximately 1,500 schools, of which one-third are done, and there's about another 250-plus libraries. So we figure we have about 1,300 units that have to be wired.
 Q. Why is it so important for all students to have access to the Internet?
 A. I think a strong argument can be made in some of the urban and rural areas of our state that there's inequity with respect to education. That gap will only grow exponentially if we don't address the major concern -- access to information, access to the Internet.
 As a father with three children, I do not want to see my children left behind. I do not want them to become one of the "digital homeless."
 Q. What would the benefits be beyond the classroom, economically and socially?
 A. A group in California did research about the cost of illiteracy and what's going to happen to American businesses that find they're going to have to retrain these people -- something that the public education system should be doing from get-go. If a kid in Hartford or a kid in Bridgeport or New Haven has no clue or no access to this kind of technology, where is he or she? And what are the costs overall then to the society?
 One argument is: There are so many changes in technology that we ought to wait until we can put together the perfect system. There's no such thing as the perfect system. The perfect system is evolving. The idea is to jump out in the middle of the pond -- if it's a good idea, people will swim out and help you. It gives this barn-raising spirit to people; that we're all part of the community.
 Imagine the opportunity for someone in Hartford to be able to distance-learn with somebody in India, or Russia, or China, or Europe. You talk about the appreciation and understanding of cross-cultural learning! And then, within our own state, the ability for people to understand and communicate with kids from surrounding towns. Again, it's many-to-many with a lot of different opinions and a lot of different points of view -- but a better understanding that I believe comes about digitally in terms of the person's expanding their universe.
 I grew up in a housing project -- the greatest experience of my life. But I also understand how confining it was in terms of the opportunities that exist. For people to go anywhere in the world from their desk is just an incredible experience that should not be denied any child. And if we don't seize this opportunity to make sure it happens for all our children, shame on us.
 Q. Do you think access to the Internet will necessarily translate into opportunity?
 A. No. Access to the Internet, in and of itself, isn't going to open up doors magically. It still takes personal initiative. But to be left out, not to have that opportunity, is what we're battling against.
 Q. Do you see this as a natural extension of state education policy or does it represent a departure?
 A. I see it as a natural extension, but it's a departure in terms of the tools that we're using. And that's all these are: educational tools. I truly believe, too, once teachers start experimenting themselves, becoming knowledge navigators, more entreprenuerial about how they disseminate information, there's going to be a tremendous growth in educational professionalism.
 You're going to see educators start copywriting a lot of their work. They've always viewed themselves as altruistic, doing the job because of love of children and belief in their profession. Very few of them ever think about taking and marketing their ideas.
 If knowledge is the future currency, and I believe that it is, then it is critical for us to make sure that we have people that are able to provide us with that knowledge, to train us.
 Q. Does the project correlate with the statewide education technology plan?
 A. Yes. By the time we finish with this project in October, we will have positioned ourselves to be further along than any other state in the Northeast. And with the insurance industry retooling, with defense manufacturers trying to diversify, this state has lost a little bit of its identity. This is a way for us to recapture a focus.

 Q. How about a continuing commitment?
 A. One of the things we plan to do is to take all of the information that we gather -- the website and everything else -- and turn it over to the Department of Education or whatever resource they believe can best handle it. We have regional educational councils all across the state. And they may be an appropriate repository as well.
 That, in of itself, will be a major accomplishment. It's going to require a commitment on the part of the state and on part of local communities and on the part of local business. By virtue of the size of our state, we feel that Connecticut can position itself as an appropriate pilot, thereby being eligible for more federal dollars -- especially in the area of teacher training.
 Q. But the Federal Government might not be the only source of revenues to perpetuate the program, is that right?
 A. Exactly. And I don't think they should be. Fifty percent of the education budget in the state of Connecticut would be generated by the local community. Where does the state get its revenues from? Individuals and corporations. The fact that education, the economy and business are inextricably linked is something that cannot be denied. That's what our future is about.
 Q. Are students contributing to the plan to connect schools?
 A. Yes, and we want to get them more involved. We don't have any specific student sitting on our steering committee yet, but we will.
 Q. How can a school become involved?
 A. Very easy. Have the P.T.A. sit down with the principal and plan where the wiring and modem are going to be -- the media room, the library, classrooms. To sign up -- all they need to do is the basic http://
www.connect96.org and -- bingo! -- they're into the web page, can electronically sign up, and they instantly go on.
 There are some communities that don't have any computers. All they have to do is make a phone call to Citizens for Connecticut's Children and Youth (203) 498-4240.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John B. Larson aims to have every school and every library hooked up to the Internet this year. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economic Agency Puts Businesses First

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
WESTCHESTER is open for business. But even more important, Westchester is open to business because the state's business climate has changed, say New York State economic professionals.
 "Under business-friendly Governor Pataki, New York State government isn't looking at business as a cash cow," said Edward L. Arace, regional director of Empire State Development's Mid-Hudson regional office in Fishkill. "Business isn't looked at as something to be arrogantly and punitively overtaxed and over-regulated but something to be wooed." 

 Under Gov. George E. Pataki, four economic development agencies, which were duplicating services and staff, were consolidated under one umbrella, called the Empire State Development agency.
 Under this program, business is put first, Mr. Arace said. "It is to that end that we've streamlined our administration into one unified economic agency, Empire State Development," he said, adding that the revamped economic development program has slashed bureaucracy, cut taxes and eliminated red tape.
 "We did this by consolidating existing agencies and staff, by reducing our product line of programs from over 100 to 200 and by making the application process for those looking for state financial aid or technical assistance much simpler, with only just one form required," he said. "It's one-stop shopping at its best. Products and services are easily accessible through our regional office network where our business customers can get accurate, first-rate answers and decisions promptly."
 Under the new program, Westchester County has a full-time economic-development specialist, Louis C. Kirven 3d. Mr. Kirven, who has an office in the Westchester County Association headquarters, is accessible to any Westchester business seeking his help.
 His efforts are meant to complement services being provided by the Westchester County Association and the Westchester District Exports Assistance Center.
 "What we have is really a partnership between New York State and Westchester County," Mr. Arace said. "We work on everything together, things like retaining existing business, helping others expand, and we are trying to attract new business to the county. The state is committed to Westchester. It's super important to us; it not only has the highest concentration of Fortune 500 headquarters outside of Manhattan, but it has a very well-educated work force."
 The county's strategic location, adjoining New York City, and its concentration of high-tech companies are also tremendous assets, Mr. Arace added.
 "We like to work with local development specialists in each area to get a feeling of the place," Mr. Kirven said.
 "Recently, Mr. Arace and I went on a walking tour of White Plains with Margo Jones, who is the executive director of the White Plains Business Development Corporation, to familiarize ourselves with the city. It's easier to see the buildings and the vacant spaces on foot. We saw space available for new business. We saw locations; we learned the dynamics of the city so we would be able to pass information on to interested parties."
 Mr. Kirven, 33, is a graduate of Georgetown University in Washington, and a lawyer who worked as a corporate attorney aide to Senator H. John Heinz 3d of Pennsylvania, a moderate Republican who died in a plane crash in 1991, and then-Senator John Seymour, a Republican of California. He has also had first-hand small-business experience as a co-founder of a start-up sports goods company in Washington.
 "I knew immediately that this was the ideal job for me," he said. "I've been in Westchester since April and seeing customers respond to the new business-friendly climate is astounding."
 "Customers, that's how we think of business people now," Mr. Arace explained. "Our Commissioner, Charles A. Gargano, has made our job one of customer service. Business, our customer, is to be treated with respect in hopes of making additional sales." The new program, Mr. Arace said, covers a lot of bases.
 He said: "We can provide help to those evaluating business locations or to those investigating options for a new site as well those looking for financial or technical assistance to help their business grow. Our economic professionals, like Lou Kirven, work directly with customers, providing them with business access to our entire array of products and services for business in New York State."
 Mr. Arace's office in Fishkill covers the region that includes eight Mid-Hudson counties and Westchester. The office serves as the focal point for the one-stop-shopping approach for companies already in the state.
 "Fifty percent of the population in our region lives in Westchester," he observed. "Westchester, as counties go, has a wealth of resources and that includes workers that rank among the top in the country. Not only are they well educated but they have a very strong work ethic and a willingness and ability to learn new skills, something business is always looking for."
 Experts in Albany and New York City, he continued, provide the same service to out-of-state companies through Empire State Development's strategic business division. International specialists are also on hand, ready to guide business into import and export ventures around the globe.
 And how has business responded to the new program?
 "Beyond our wildest expectations," Mr. Arace said. "Everyday we are receiving inquiries from companies in other areas and other states who are looking at New York again now that the word is out that we are hospitable to business. For instance, we worked with Oxford Health Plan, who, with 1,000 employees, moved from Connecticut to White Plains six months ago."
 Mr. Kirven has also met and gone to visit a large pharmaceutical company in a neighboring state that he said was "looking very seriously at Westchester with an eye to relocation, and I've seen a chemical company interested in moving its headquarters here, plus a number of smaller businesses including a bakery, a janitorial service and a charter airline company, who all are interested in expansion."
 Ever eager to expand the state's economy, Mr. Arace is taking the Empire State message overseas in October: New York is a better place to do business.
 "We're setting out to drum up business in Europe, selling our state as the place to be for business," he said.
 "We will be meeting with business people in England and Germany and hope to interest them in establishing offices, distribution centers, manufacturing facilities and joint ventures, investments, whatever, in New York State. We are the center of world markets. The richest market in the world is within a radius of 750 miles of New York."
 For more information and assistance, the number to call is 896-0478.
 
The Economic Power of New York
 
 Among attractions that New York offers business, the Empire State Development agency says, are the following.
 *New York's gross state product is $506 billion a year, close to 8 percent of the country's gross domestic product compared with a share of under 7 percent of the country's population.
 *New York's commercial bank assets per capita are almost triple the national average. Seven of the country's leading commercial banks, including 5 of the top 10, have headquarters in New York State.
 *New York leads the nation as the favorite location for Fortune 500 headquarters, with 65, followed by California with 51.
 *New York accounts for close to 18 percent or $761 billion of the Fortune 500's total revenues. The combined purchasing power of the state's residents pushes retail sales in New York to more than $134 billion a year.
 *International investors love New York. In 1993, the state attracted more than $7 billion in foreign direct investment -- far more than any other state. Overall foreign investment was up 87 percent from 1987 to 1992.
 *The New York Stock Exchange alone accounts for approximately 85 percent of the total capitalization in the country. PENNY SINGER

HEADLINE: Plan for a Tower Surprised Board

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 I'd like to clarify your article "Gone Before It Ever Arrived: The Quotron" (July 7), about Community Board 1's opposition to the city's plan to build a tower -- with steel flag and stock quotes -- as part of its conversion of a block of Washington Street into a pedestrian walkway. 

 The article states that the board was "furious" when the Tribeca Trib "reported the million-dollar plan for Washington Street. . . . When they saw a drawing of the Quotron, the board, which has many architects and artists on it, grew angrier."
 Though they believed that the million dollars could be better spent improving Greenwich Street, the board was not angry about the overall plan to turn that block of Washington Street into a walkway. They gave tentative approval to the concept in 1993. They were upset not only because they dislike the tower's design; they also say the Quotron was not part of the plan they approved. And for two months after publication of our article, Economic Development Corporation officials continued to argue otherwise.
 The Tribeca Trib obtained construction drawings for the whole project and published an article that explained the details of the street plan but focused on the board's apparent lack of knowledge that the tower was part of it.
 
CARL GLASSMAN
Editor
The Tribeca Trib

HEADLINE: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN;
Campaign Trail, Over Internet, Up to Vermont

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW

 BODY:
It may seem a bit nutty that Prof. August St. John, who teaches marketing and future studies at the Brooklyn campus of Long Island University, commutes from Vermont. But the 68-year-old academic, who specializes in economic forecasting and is known in his home state as "Dr. Doom and Gloom," rarely takes the conventional route to anything.
 Besides, said Professor St. John, who teaches on Tuesdays and Wednesdays but is off for the summer, those 10 driving hours are the prime moments of a prophet's work. "It's quiet," he said, "and I get these thoughts." 

 On the weekly commute from Manchester, where he has lived since 1987, Professor St. John might consider a prediction that Taiwan will rejoin China in or by the year 2000, work up a forecast of major breakthroughs in the study of gravity or prepare a speech on his theory that all of New England will soon become two "megastates."
 His latest vision is of himself as governor of Vermont. He is running as an independent candidate against the Democratic incumbent, Gov. Howard Dean, and said he had about 500 of the 1,000 signatures required to put him on the ballot for the November election.
 Not surprisingly, his approach to campaigning is unusual: he is stumping on the Internet in what is believed to be the nation's first virtual gubernatorial campaign. Professor St. John, who has taught at L.I.U. since 1963, said that if elected he would request a leave of absence.
 The "St. John for Governor" site on the World Wide Web, accessible at http://www.acmeville.com/
stjohn/, welcomes visitors with, "Congratulations! You are now part of electronic electoral history!" It is sprinkled with sound-byte descriptions of the candidate -- "Manchester's prophet!" and "A real showman!" -- culled from local articles. Site visitors can also find a section where the professor quotes himself extensively ("There is no imagination in this state!"). His Web site, available since early May, trumpeted that 70 visitors had stopped by as of last Tuesday.
 The reaction in Vermont to Professor St. John's bid for governor -- much like the response to his theories and predictions -- is a mix of skepticism and amusement. "He's an entertainer," said Arthur Woolf, an associate professor of economics at the University of Vermont. "He's into self-aggrandizement."
 Professor St. John uses traditional indicators like unemployment, development and investing to make economic forecasts. But he also uses alternative techniques, such as studying utility bills to see how many customers are postponing payments, or cruising through towns looking for smiles. "When people stop laughing and smiling, it's a sign the town isn't doing well," he said.
 Some of his visions of recessions and industry layoffs in New England have come true, although his critics say those events were imminent before his forecasts. "He predicts everything, and when you predict a list long enough, something's bound to come true," said Professor Woolf, who served for three years as Vermont's chief economist.
 What does Professor St. John see for New York? By about 2010, the five boroughs and Long Island will break off from the rest of the state into a new state called New York, New York. "I've always had a problem with New York," he said. "It's aberrational because of all the different life styles. But in a couple of years, I'll have it all laid out." SARAH KERSHAW

LENGTH: 1406 words

HEADLINE: Integration Suit: 7 Years Later

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIZEL

 BODY:
MILO SHEFF was an 11-year-old fourth grader in 1989 when his mother, Elizabeth Horton Sheff, helped bring a landmark desegregation lawsuit on behalf of her son and 16 other plaintiffs seeking racial balance in Hartford's predominantly black and Hispanic public school system.
 So it was no surprise that both mother and son were jubilant after last week's ruling by the State Supreme Court that racial segregation in Hartford's public schools violated Connecticut's Constitution. The decision reversed a ruling last year by Superior Court Judge Harry Hammer, who held that the plantiffs had failed to prove the state was liable for racial imbalance and segregation. 

 Mr. Sheff, now 17 and about to enter his senior year at Weaver High School, said he had been crushed by Judge Hammer's ruling in April 1995, which led to a month of almost daily protests and demonstrations in the state capital. Further angering some people at the time was Gov. John G. Rowland's breaking out a bottle of champagne at a press conference to celebrate the lower court's ruling.
 But Ms. Horton Sheff and her son said there were no thoughts of champagne last Tuesday when they heard about the higher court's 4-to-3 decision that ends, at least for now, a high profile, seven-year court battle known as Sheff v. O'Neill. (Milo Sheff was the first plaintiff listed in the suit and William A. O'Neill was Governor when the suit was filed.) "I realize that it's too late for me to benefit from this ruling," Mr. Sheff said. "But I just want to see some kind of action taken as soon as possible so that other students can start getting the equal education they need and deserve."
 Ms. Horton Sheff and her son said they thought about all they had been through since the lawsuit was filed, how disappointed they were when the initial ruling went against them last year, but most of all how much support they have received over the years. They said they wanted to savor the victory for a while -- and then start thinking about what it really means and how it can be carried out.
 The court's 95-page ruling does not order any specific remedies, but instead directs the General Assembly and the executive branch to "put the search for appropriate remedial measures at the top of their respective agendas." Governor Rowland said he would abide by the latest ruling, although he and others acknowledged that remedial action would take time.
 Ms. Horton Sheff, a former two-term Hartford City Councilwoman and an unsuccessful independent mayoral candidate, said she never doubted that in the end justice would prevail, but admitted to being "completely overwhelmed" when she heard of the decision on Tuesday.
 "I know that change, real change often takes time and happens slowly," Ms. Horton Sheff said. "But today is the day we celebrate that our children's constitutional rights have been upheld. Tomorrow, we can begin the process of coming up with specific solutions. The best remedies will come from a wide range of individuals who must come together in a collaborative effort for all of our children." Ms. Horton Sheff refused to speculate about whether that could lead to the busing of suburban children to urban schools. After a poll taken after last year's ruling found 64 percent of white residents supported the lower court's ruling, she said she was certain what many suburbanites feared was busing. "It's the B word that they're afraid of," she said at the time. "B for busing."
 But busing, at least, will not be part of the remedy, according to Governor Rowland, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal and legislative leaders of both parties, all of whom say they will begin meeting soon to make some kind of long-term plan to meet the court's directive.
 They all also agreed that it would probably be difficult to convene a special legislative session, and that any action would most likely have to wait until the General Assembly convenes for its regular January session.
 As for busing, Mr. Rowland said, "As long as I'm Governor, that is not one of the solutions."
 "The problem of school segregation in our urban areas is a very complicated problem with deep running social and economic causes," he continued. "I do not expect any quick answers and I cannot predict what the remedies will be." The decision, Mr. Rowland said, "has major implications for state policies on education in general, school budgets, municipal government and taxes."
 Mr. Blumenthal, who presented the state's case before the Supreme Court, indicated after the ruling that he would fight to insure that local control of the school system is preserved. He said that he "profoundly disagreed" with the court's ruling and feared what would happen if city and suburban school systems are forced to participate in regional desegregation. "At least for the next school year, the present system will remain in effect, and students will attend the same schools they do now," said Mr. Blumenthal.
 But John Brittain, the plaintiff's lead attorney, said that the court's ruling, particularly the majority opinion written by Chief Justice Ellen Ash Peters, directs the state to take immediate action to correct not only inequities in Hartford, but also those in all the state's urban centers.
 "This decision," he said, "is clearly an historic one that is going to have a far-reaching impact on education throughout Connecticut and will have an inspirational impact across the country." Mr. Brittain, a University of Connecticut law professor, had expressed confidence last year that the initial ruling would be overturned.
 "We have waited long enough for change and have had to stand by and watch the state's committed, but feeble, efforts to eradicate racial imbalance and inequality," Mr. Brittain said. "The fact that Justice Peters uses the word urgency several times, does, I think, mean that the state needs to formulate and begin enacting some kind of a plan within the next six months."
 In her majority opinion, Justice Peters wrote that "the needy school children of Hartford have waited long enough," and that under the existing educational system "every passing day denies these children their constitutional right to a substantially equal educational opportunity. Every passing day shortchanges these children and their ability to learn to contribute to their own well-being and to that of this state and nation."
 In a dissenting opinion, however, Justice David M. Borden said that "the majority has used this court's power to interpret the constitution in order to mandate a vast and unprecedented social experiment, using the state's schools and school children as test data, and thereby to construct what the majority perceives to be the necessary bridge over the racial divide."
 He added: "Without explicitly saying so, the majority has effectively struck down, not just for the greater Hartford area, but for the entire state, the municipality-based school system that has been in effect in this state since 1909." Justice Borden went on to say that "the legislature, if it is to take seriously its responsibilities under the majority's mandate, will have few options, if any, other than a state-wide realignment of school districts, accompanied by a state-wide transportation system."
 Key legislators say that the General Assembly must proceed with caution. "I think we're all a little stunned and taken aback by the ruling and I think the Governor is right when he said we have to take our time with this," said State Senator Judith Freedman, Republican of Westport and a chairperson of the General Assembly's Education Committee. "We have a lot of options that we have to carefully examine, and that's going to take time."
 State Representative Cameron Staples, Democrat of New Haven and the other chairperson of the Education Committee, added that "clearly the ball is now in our court and we have to come up with some kind of integration plan that meets the needs of all of the state's public education people."
 Meanwhile, Ms. Horton Sheff and her son said they were just happy that the case, which went to an 11-week trial in 1992, was finally over. (It cannot be appealed further in the state courts.)
 "Seven years ago I was a naive kid who dreamed about the kind of happy endings you see on TV and in the movies," Mr. Sheff said. "It was tough at times," he added, "but in the end the good guys won."

HEADLINE: Mongolian Democracy Deserves U.S. Gesture

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Three cheers for Mongolian democracy ("Mongolia Swaps Leaders," editorial, July 10)! 
 Mongolia's victorious Democratic Union Coalition now faces the daunting task of reversing Mongolia's slide in its standard of living and of demonstrating that a free, market-based democracy brings tangible socioeconomic rewards, not just greater civil liberties.
But with legislators of the caliber of Hashbat Hulan of the Mongolian National Democratic Party, a landslide electoral mandate and an ally in President Punsalmaagiyn Ochirbat, there is no challenge that Mongolia cannot meet.
Meanwhile, the United States would make a grave error if it passed up this golden opportunity to expand its strategic, economic and cultural ties with Mongolia. President Clinton should not be content with sending various envoys as he has in the past but should go and pay a visit himself. Mongolia deserves no less.
 
ERICH SAPHIR
Tucson, Ariz., July 10, 1996
The writer, a former foreign affairs analyst for the Congressional Research Service, is a visiting scholar at the University of Arizona.

HEADLINE: U.N. Survey Finds World Rich-Poor Gap Widening

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 12

 BODY:
In the wake of reports that gaps between rich and poor in the United States are wider than they have been in half a century, a United Nations survey to be published on Wednesday finds that the phenomenon is worldwide, and that the wealthiest and poorest people -- both within and among countries -- are living in increasingly separate worlds.
Moreover, the United States is slipping into a category of countries -- among them Brazil, Britain and Guatemala -- where economic stratification is most pronounced, with the national per capita income four times or more higher than the average income of the poor, according to the survey, the Human Development Report 1996, compiled by the United Nations Development Program. 
 The ratio of the top 20 percent of American incomes to the poorest 20 percent is now 9 to 1, the study shows.
"An emerging global elite, mostly urban-based and interconnected in a variety of ways, is amassing great wealth and power, while more than half of humanity is left out," said James Gustave Speth, an American who is administrator of the Development Program.
"We still have more than half the people on the planet with incomes of less than $2 a day -- more than 3 billion people," Mr. Speth said in an interview on Thursday. "For poor people in this two-class world, it is a breeding ground for hopelessness, for anger, for frustration."
The Human Development report will be released officially in Tokyo on Wednesday by Richard Jolly, its principal author.
A nation's total wealth is not an adequate guide to how its people live, the survey says. In nations as diverse as the Netherlands, Japan, Bangladesh and Nepal, the gap between average incomes and those of the poorest 20 percent of the population is half that of the United States.
The distribution of private economic assets, in property and investments, widen American differences even more.
Many of the most equitable societies are now in East and Southeast Asia, where economic growth has been fastest but where at the same time the division of national wealth has been the fairest, the report says.
The annual Human Development Report was first published in 1990 as a new way to measure countries' progress by going beyond gross national product to factor in life expectancy, education and adjusted real incomes. The report's Human Development Index ranks countries by health, sanitation, the treatment of women and other aspects of life that give what the authors believe is a truer picture of day-to-day existence.
This year, Canada leads the index with the most advanced overall human development, followed by the United States, Japan, the Netherlands and Norway. On a list of 174 countries, Russia ranks 57th, China 108th and India 135th. Africa south of the Sahara dominates the bottom.
When the list is adjusted to reflect the status of women, the United States drops to fourth place among 137 countries, behind Sweden, Canada and Norway. Japan drops to 12th place, while China rises to 79th.
The 1996 report introduces another new measure of national growth -- or lack of it. Called a "capability poverty measure," this index tries to find hidden or potential poverty by looking at factors like the percentage of children under 5 who are underweight, the proportion of unattended births, the number of children in school and rate of female illiteracy. In other words, is a nation programming poverty and disadvantage into coming generations?
For example, in South Asia -- India and its neighbors, except Sri Lanka -- 29 percent of the people are living in severe poverty when income alone is measured, but more than 62 percent are living in conditions that can negatively affect their futures.
John Sewell, president of the Overseas Development Council, a private policy research organization in Washington, said in an interview that social indicators can no longer be overlooked by any country focused on national economic growth. The era of choosing between a welfare state or a bigger G.N.P. is over; social and economic factors work together, he said.
"It is clear by now in the developing world that the prime responsibility for progress has to fall to those governments and societies themselves," he said. "Nothing much is going to change until countries take the steps to invest in people, educate women and create a health care system that works while also adopting policies that are going to lead to economic growth."
In Asia, as in the Scandinavian countries a generation or more ago, a number of countries -- among them Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore -- have spent significant sums on health, education, the advancement of women and the provision of credit to low-income families and small-scale entrepreneurs. But they also focused simultaneously on national economic growth, and this two-track policy led to "the most sustained and widespread development miracle of the 20th century, perhaps all history," the report says.
At the independent Cato Institute in Washington, Ian Vasquez, director of the Project on Global Economic Liberty, is skeptical about more foreign aid and about reports by agencies with an interest in continuing or expanding assistance programs.
"The evidence over the past 30 to 40 years shows quite clearly that economic reforms, especially of the market-oriented type, help raise the standards of living dramatically more than traditional programs supported by foreign aid agencies like the U.N.D.P.," Mr. Vasquez said in an interview.
"The real story is that the conditions of people around the world have vastly improved over the last 50 or so years," he said. Progress rests with liberalizing economic policies, not outside support, he added.
Among the 1996 Human Development report's other findings are these:
*Worldwide, 358 billionaires control assets greater than the combined annual incomes of countries with 45 percent of the world's people.
*Eighty-nine countries are worse off economically than they were a decade or more ago. In 70 developing countries, incomes are lower than they were in the 1960's or 1970's. In 19 countries, including Ghana, Haiti, Liberia, Nicaragua, Rwanda and Venezuela, per capita income is below the 1960 level.
The Human Development Report 1996 is published by Oxford University Press at $18.95 in paperback and $29.95 in hard cover.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
The Swimmer Who United a Nation

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: RALEIGH, N.C., July 14

 BODY:
She may have been Germany's richest and most famous teen-ager, but Franziska van Almsick was also its most jet-lagged. Her body arrived at the pool with Germany's other Olympic swimmers on Saturday morning, but her mind and her luggage were elsewhere.
After her workout, German television wanted to beam a live interview back to Europe. Germany cannot get enough of this 18-year-old phenom, the winner of four medals as a 14-year-old at the 1992 Summer Games, the world champion in the 200-meter freestyle, the casually outspoken star who has become the photogenic symbol of the possibilities of reunification. 
 Whatever athletic and political needs the Germans seem to have, Franzi, as she is known, appears to fill them. When she checked into the team hotel on Friday, her coach introduced her to a desk clerk as Germany's Michael Jordan.
But the TV interview would require a drive to a nearby studio, and van Almsick had done enough traveling for the moment. She did not want to go anywhere in a car, she told an American attache with the German team. Not that anyone in Germany would forget what she looked like if she declined the interview.
Her face appears frequently on television, on billboards, on the covers of magazines and newspapers. She once had her own TV show. If she is not being written about, or trailed by paparazzi, she is endorsing every product from bread to automobiles. Her sponsorship contracts, German reporters said, total $9 million through 2001.
This time, though, Franzi had nothing to say to her worshipers back home. She slumped onto a bench at the North Carolina State University pool, leaning against a wall with a weariness in her posture and her voice.
"I am very tired," she said.
In a day, or two, she would be fine, of course. She has a teen-ager's resilience, which may be at the heart of why she is so popular at home.
She is pretty. She is a fresh new face in the gallery of familiar German stars like Steffi Graf and Boris Becker. And she has managed to be opinionated while still being regarded as an innocent. But that does not fully explain her appeal as the first big star of German reunification.
Van Almsick serves as a sort of political Zelig, morphing seamlessly into whatever symbol needs validation at the moment. She is an eastern German who provides the hope of success for those who lived in the dismantled communist system. At the same time, she provides comfort to western Germans who were suspicious about the economic and social drain of reunification. For both sides, she authenticated the merging of East and West at the 1992 Games in Barcelona, Spain.
"She is a girl that fits everyone's needs," said the German freestyler Bjorn Zikarsky, who holds a business administration degree from the University of Southern California. "She represents the new face after reunification. She's athletic, young, good looking, cute, rebellious. She says what's on her mind."
"When the wall came down," Zikarsky said, "the West was seen as the winner, the East as the loser. But she showed that the East German character is very strong. She gave a lot of confidence to other East German athletes, politicians, business people."
To western Germans, he said, van Almsick represents a refreshing departure from the former East German system of swimming, whose success, it has since been revealed, was fueled by persistent use of performance-enhancing steroids. "She was a clean girl," Zikarsky said.
Her popularity remains buoyant despite evidence that her mother, Jutta, a coach, served as an informer for the former East German secret police, the Stasi. And despite her own remarks that she was interested in Hitler as a historical figure. Her mother disputes the Stasi allegations. And van Almsick's supporters said she never endorsed the extremist views of Hitler, but suffered when some reporters twisted her words.
Germans take a larger, more sympathetic view of what van Almsick represents to a united country. They relish the cheeky Franzi, who once greeted Chancellor Helmut Kohl in jeans and a leather jacket. And the curious Franzi, who grew up 500 meters from the Berlin wall, once kicking a soccer ball over the top of it, then repeating the act several times when it kept coming back.
"Timing is everything," Zikarsky said. "The West was waiting to see what was in the East. She is a young, fresh character who satisfies the demands for character on both ends. Sometimes she puts her foot in her mouth, but that doesn't seem to bother people. They want someone to look up to."
Van Almsick was only 11 when the wall came down in 1989, and she professes an amnesia about communist life in East Germany, though she continues to live in the eastern part of Berlin. Perhaps it is a convenient amnesia, but few seem to mind.
"My life began as the wall fell down," she said. "I can't remember a time in East Germany."
The tabloid life is hard sometimes, she said, with requests for autographs interrupting her meals, and the papers reporting everything she does. But she is 18, after all, so she understands perfectly what it is to be a teen idol.
"If I see Boris Becker or Michael Jordan, I would like their autographs, too," she said.
While she took four medals in Barcelona, none of them was gold. Gold is the expectation this time, but van Almsick can be as erratic in the pool as she is popular out of the pool.
At the 1994 world championships in Rome, she did not qualify for the final of the 200 freestyle, only to have her teammate Dagmar Hase, a 1992 Olympic champion, give up her spot to van Almsick. Some saw the switch as a buyout. Van Almsick proceeded to win and set a world record. At the recent German Olympic trials, she failed to qualify in the 400 freestyle and finished second in the 100 freestyle. A nation edgily awaits her success or failure in Atlanta.
"I don't think about medals," she said. "I will do the best I can do."
One thing is certain: Even if van Almsick does not win the most medals among the Germans, she will get the most attention.
"Certain people are jealous," Zikarsky said. "They say, 'I wish I could make a third of what she makes.' But who said life is fair?"

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
Enemy At Scarsdale

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
It is hard to imagine war coming to a place so bursting with prosperity and consumerism. Seoul is a city of 10 million now dotted with skyscrapers. Shoppers crowd colorful street markets and new shopping malls.
But the border is just 30 miles from Seoul, and on the other side is a state that vows to overthrow South Korea. It is as if New Yorkers lived with an implacable enemy country beginning at Scarsdale. 
 If North Korea made a sudden attack across the border, it would do devastating damage. It has 11,000 artillery pieces, some of them rocket-launchers that can hit Seoul. It is also believed to have chemical weapons.
But whatever the initial damage it caused, North Korea would surely be crushed in time. Its desperate economy could not long sustain a war. The U.S., which has 37,000 troops here, would respond massively from the air.
For those reasons most people here, South Korean and American, tend to dismiss the possibility of war. The Pyongyang regime would have to be irrational to attack, they say, because it would be destroyed. But will Kim Jong Il and his colleagues define rationality as we do?
Consider the current U.S. policy of trying to engage the North Koreans in negotiations, offering economic assistance in return. The reality is that such aid could not by itself erase the North's accelerating economic decline. The only way to do that would be structural reform in North Korea: ending rigid Communist doctrine in industry and agriculture, and bringing in managers from South Korea and elsewhere.
In other words, turning the economy around would require abandonment of socialism and isolation, the two doctrines that have defined the state's rigid ideology since Kim Il Sung imposed it 50 years ago. And that would undermine the legitimacy of the Kim dynasty. In those circumstances, a war with poor prospects might look more "rational" to the regime than its certain destruction by an inexorable economic slide toward absorption by the South.
No one can know what may be in the minds of Pyongyang's leaders. The toughest analysts here do not argue that war is more likely than not. Nor do they oppose the policy of trying to engage North Korea. They simply say that we should be wary -- and not put our hopes for the policy too high.
Is Pyongyang interested in "engagement"? It has invited U.S. officials to search for the remains of Americans missing since the Korean War ended in 1953. But, tellingly, it has not responded to the proposal by Washington and Seoul last April for four-party talks, with China as the fourth, on a Korean peace treaty. Indeed, Pyongyang has not even accepted an offer to brief its representatives on the idea.
Moreover, North Korea continues its bloodcurdling propaganda against the South. This month among other things its spokesmen have called President Kim Young Sam of South Korea and his colleagues "traitors" and said, "We will make them pay for their crimes a thousandfold."
Optimists on bringing the North into talks argue that China under Deng Xiaoping made major economic reforms without undoing the Communist Party's power. But the Pyongyang regime reflects not just the extreme Communist ideology of the Kims but an extreme North Korean tradition of puritan Confucianism, with rule from the top. And the regime faces a competitor in South Korea quite unlike anything that had to concern Deng Xiaoping.
Top South Korean officials take what seems to be a calm view of the economic crisis in the North and where it might lead. They say they see signs of more pragmatism among younger figures in North Korea. But they are uneasy about the total lack of response from Pyongyang to the proposal for four-power peace talks.
The engagement policy has a difficulty on the American side, too. It is open to demagogic attack as "appeasement" of North Korea. Indeed Bob Dole has already taken that line, calling a recent U.S. offer of modest humanitarian food aid a subsidy to the totalitarian regime.
Republicans in Congress have voted to cut in half the $25 million needed this year to supply fuel oil to North Korea as part of the 1994 agreement for a freeze of its nuclear program. I have met no one here, American or South Korean, optimist or pessimist, who thinks the United States can reduce the risks of the present situation on the Korean Peninsula by breaking its commitments.

HEADLINE: Taking In the Sites;
Each Fed Web Site Has Its Own Form and Flavor

BYLINE: By SCOTT WOOLLEY 

 BODY:
The secretive Federal Reserve, for decades the arbiter of monetary policy and regulator of banks, has recently undertaken a new and very public sideline: developing sites on the World Wide Web.
The Fed's Web sites are home to some of the Government's best on-line economic data and analysis. Unfortunately, as with much of the Internet, the trick for potential users of the Fed sites is first to realize that useful information exists, then hunt through the clutter to find it. 
 The Fed's organizational structure does not help. Each of the Fed's 12 district banks is responsible for setting up its own home page, and there is no standard format. A particular statistic or study available from one bank's site may not exist on its sister sites. And even if it does, it is quite possibly filed under a different section.
The up side of this individualism is the range of features and information available at these sites. Each Fed district has its own economists doing their own research, and much of it is narrowly targeted to issues in its particular region.
For instance, the San Francisco Fed offers opinions on employment in Silicon Valley's computer industry. Meanwhile, the Philadelphia bank's research department surveys that region's manufacturing industries.
The Fed's well-known beige book, which analyzes the overall economic prospects of each of the 12 districts, is now available at the Minneapolis Fed's Web site.
Besides regional economic data, there is also a host of national information available. The New York Fed generates its own estimates of foreign exchange rates and posts them on the Web twice daily. Other information, like recent commercial paper rates, is also on line.
One sign that the Fed has yet to become truly Web-friendly: some of the most up-to date interest rates, including commercial paper rates, are available on a telephone recording within a day of being set. That data at times do not make it to the Web for up to a week.
The St. Louis Fed has one of the snappiest of the Fed's home pages. Its site houses FRED, or Federal Reserve Economic Data, a data base that offers a mix of information as diverse as consumer credit and the money supply. Major Fed studies are supposed to be posted on FRED within hours of release.
One of FRED's new features, F.T.P. mail, allows users looking for data to have it E-mailed directly to them instead of taking the time to pull it off the Web every time it is updated. This feature can be a time- saver for users who want to download data regularly -- chief financial officers, for example, who want the three-month commercial paper rate every week.
Except for the Richmond district, all the Fed banks now have sites, as does the Fed's board of governors in Washington. All the sites are linked, so it is easy to skip among them.
While the scope of the Fed's economic data is not nearly as comprehensive as some other Federal sites -- especially the Commerce Department's Stat USA site -- it does offer access to the central bank's unusual research strengths. And unlike the bigger Commerce site, which charges a $50 annual subscriber fee, none of the 12 Fed sites cost users a penny.

HEADLINE: Capitalist Tools Benefit Ukraine Collectives

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BASHTANKA, Ukraine

 BODY:
Across Ukraine, great plains of tall, tawny wheat are ripening under hot skies and gentle breezes in what was once the breadbasket of the Soviet Union.
Sergiy Arkhipov, one of the nation's new breed of private farmers, is excited by the prospects of a good harvest for himself and the nearly 1,000 other private farmers in the region. 
 But not everything is going his way this season.
Mr. Arkhipov and his colleagues, who have deserted the large, inefficient state farms to blaze their own path to agricultural entrepreneurship, have been shut out, he said, from receiving any of the 600 American combines that are arriving in Ukraine. The state-of-the-art John Deere machines are far superior to the old Soviet ones, which also harvest and thresh the grain but leave up to 30 percent of it behind on the ground.
The new American machines have been going to a state-controlled company that is reselling them, or trading them for grain, to collective farms and Government-run agricultural centers.
The Clinton Administration helped to bring about the transaction, even though critics say it goes against the stated thrust of American policy, which has been to prod Ukraine to adopt a market economy.
The deal, completed earlier this year, is the biggest single export sale ever by John Deere. Altogether, the Illinois-based farm machinery giant is selling Ukraine 1,049 combines, for $187 million.
The sale pleased the Clinton Administration because it represented exports and jobs for an American company, as well as support for a country newly independent of Russia that was giving up its nuclear warheads.
And the deal would not have been possible if the Export-Import Bank, an arm of the United States Government that helps finance American exports, had not opened up its credit windows to Ukraine, which it did after persistent pressure from the White House.
Now, instead of promoting private agriculture, say the critics -- who include some American and World Bank officials as well as Ukrainian farmers and Western agricultural experts -- the John Deere deal is reinforcing the old collective farm system, run by corrupt agricultural bosses.
When the Deere sale was still under discussion, the World Bank representative in Ukraine, Daniel Kaufman, bluntly told American Embassy officials in Kiev that it "flew in the face" of economic reform in Ukraine.
Mr. Kaufman, a strong advocate of private investment in Ukraine, said he was troubled that all the combines were being sold to a single state-controlled company with close connections to the state agricultural administrators and provincial farm bosses, the most politically and economically regressive elements in Ukraine.
David Sweere, a Minnesota agribusinessman who is investing $25 million in agricultural operations in Ukraine, called it "the recapitalization of Communism."
He said the deal could have been structured so that individual farmers or farm organizations were given credit to buy the combines.
Since achieving independence in 1991, Ukraine has received nearly a billion dollars from the United States Agency for International Development and other Washington agencies. Today Ukraine is the third-largest recipient of American aid, after Egypt and Israel.
The aid has been intended to turn the Government away from central planning and toward a market economy, particularly in agriculture, which is one of the country's most important sectors.
But Ukraine's leaders have not always been committed to economic liberalization. Their weak economic performance and their default in 1993 on a $70 million, Export-Import-backed loan to the agricultural sector prompted the bank to suspend loan guarantees for Ukraine.
As a result of the Ex-Im Bank's policy, many American companies were reluctant to invest, in spite of the potential offered by the Texas-size country with 52 million people.
When Leonid Kuchma was elected President in mid-1994, he appeared to be a stronger reformer than his predecessor, and he beseeched Washington to restore Ukraine's access to the Ex-Im Bank, something the White House also wanted.
A "classic Washington bureaucratic battle" followed, said one official familiar with the discussions within the Administration. Some Washington officials remained skeptical about Ukraine's commitment to economic reform and were disturbed about its high level of corruption. Others argued that it was important to reward Ukraine for its tentative steps toward reform.
There was also desire to shore up Ukraine's independence from Russia and to insure that Ukraine finished dismantling its nuclear arsenal. These issues were behind President Clinton's visit to Kiev in May 1995, and it was felt that he had to offer more than words of encouragement. He did -- the Export-Import Bank would be open for credit to Ukraine, he announced during the visit.
A few months later, John Deere and Ukraine reached an agreement in principle and began working on the details.
"The idea was that this was a way of showing Ukraine how to make some money," a Washington official said. It was "a political decision to go ahead with the Ex-Im loan," the official said. "The bankerly caution of Ex-Im was overruled."
There is another disturbing aspect of the deal, free-market advocates say: the company that bought the combines, which is 77 percent owned by the state, did so without competitive bidding, even though Ukrainian law requires tenders for all Government purchases of more than $100,000.
The company, Ukragroprombirzha, is headed by Viktor N. Tymchenko, a somewhat mysterious figure.
Ukrainians and Western diplomats said that Mr. Tymchenko, whose calling card describes him as an "honored economist of Ukraine," has long been a behind-the-scenes power in the Agriculture Ministry, and his friends are collective farm directors and provincial leaders.
According to the Ex-Im Bank, the precise numbers and kinds of farmers who would use the combines are considered proprietary information. But a spokeswoman, Rita Flynn, said it would be inaccurate to say that the combines would not benefit the private sector. She added that the deal met the bank's criteria of reasonable assurance of repayment and promoting jobs in the United States.
Mr. Tymchenko said through a company partner that he was too busy to be interviewed. But in an interview with a Ukrainian magazine, Mr. Tymchenko said that the combines would be sold to farmers for $252,000 each.
This would net a profit of about $50,000 on each machine, according to the calculations of an American farmer in Ukraine, Charles Mitchell.
Mr. Mitchell, who has set up a company called Global Agricultural Management in Kiev, said he had bought four of the same Deere combines for $112,000 for use in Ukraine. He is planning to lease them to farmers but said that if he sold them they would go for about $160,000. Even adding attachments, spare parts and training, the price of the machine should be no more than $190,000, farm experts said.
A John Deere executive, Rudolf Steffenhagan, who has been handling the contract in Kiev, said the company had no say over how Mr. Tymchenko disposed of the combines.
"He knows his friends," Mr. Steffenhagan said. "When you look at the map of where the machines are going, he must have an agreement with all the oblast chiefs," the government leaders in the provinces.
So far, nearly all of the combines have been sold to collective farms or to state-run agricultural centers, which lease machinery to farms, say Western officials in Kiev.
In Bashtanka, in southern Ukraine, for example, three combines have gone to a former hard-line Communist politician, Mikola Bardachov.
When a group of private farmers with large holdings in Bashtanka asked about renting the machines, they were told by Mr. Bardachov's office that the combines were for collective farms only, said Mr. Arkhipov, who is chairman of the local association of private farmers.
In Donetsk, the most populous province in Ukraine, it is the Governor, Vladimir Scherban, who has been given power over 40 combines. In an interview, he said they would go to collective farms and to the state-run agricultural centers.
Mr. Arkhipov said he believes that the private farmers will eventually prevail against the collective farms, like the one in his village, where most of the cattle have been sold and fields lie fallow. But the John Deere deal, he said, prolongs the death throes a bit longer.
