HEADLINE: Central Europe Is Newest Arena For Arms Race

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: BUDAPEST

 BODY:
On a hectic day in June when the Hungarian Parliament was debating a new constitution, Imre Mecs spent the morning listening to a sales pitch from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and American military officers. As the day ended, he hurried to a party organized, he thought, by Lockheed.
It turned out that McDonnell Douglas was the host, but Mr. Mecs can be forgiven for being confused, such has been the fierce competition among American and European aerospace giants to sell advanced aircraft to former Warsaw Pact nations. 
 A McDonnell Douglas corporate jet recently flew Mr. Mecs from Washington to St. Louis. Then it was on to Fort Worth, where after a sedate dinner given by the Mayor and officials of the Lockheed Martin Corporation, the party adjourned to Billy Bob's, a famed night spot. Mr. Mecs donned a white Stetson and was photographed atop a mechanical bucking bronco, a Lockheed vice president sitting behind him.
The end of the cold war brought to a close the global arms race between the superpowers. But it has ushered in a new, equally intense rivalry among arms manufacturers bidding for their share of the world's shrinking military budgets. Central Europe, where Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic are all campaigning to join NATO as soon as possible, has become a primary battleground. Together, the three countries have expressed interest in buying as much as $8 billion in advanced jet fighters.
It is a bonanza the likes of which arms manufacturers, reeling from military cutbacks from Moscow to Washington, have not seen in years, although in recent months, budgetary realities have prompted the three countries to scale back their immediate appetite for new jets.
But that has not fazed the manufacturers, who have come forward with various creative proposals to get around the lack of cash. Some are proposing cost-cutting deals under which local companies would assemble significant percentages of the planes. The United States Government is offering to lease used fighters to the countries in the hopes that this will start them down the road to equipping their air forces entirely with American-made planes.
"We're the pretty girl at the dance," said Mr. Mecs, a student leader of Hungary's 1956 anti-Communist uprising and now the congenial 62-year-old chairman of the Hungarian Parliament's defense committee. After he returned from America, Mr. Mecs raced to Stockholm, a special guest of the Swedish King at a ceremony for Saab-Scania A.B.'s Gripen combat jet. When he can find the time, Mr. Mecs will go to Paris, courtesy of the French Government and Dassault Aviation S.A., maker of the Mirage 2000.
Similar courtships are unfolding in Warsaw and Prague, where American, French and Swedish salesmen are offering deals on top-of-the-line jets.
It remains unclear whether the purchase of expensive fighters is the best use of the countries' limited military budgets. They seem more to be symbols of independence and modernity than rigorously reasoned elements of an overall defense plan.
Asked if his country really needed to buy more than a hundred sophisticated jets, Poland's Deputy Defense Minister, Andrzej Karkoszka, replied, "Can you imagine a nation of 40 million, in central Europe, without such an air force?"
The competition pits not only America against Europe, but American companies against American companies, and even the United States Air Force, which flies the F-16, against the United States Navy, which uses the F-18.
At the cocktail party here, an American admiral in a dark suit mingled with Hungarian pilots, businessmen and politicians as a member of the McDonnell Douglas delegation. Lockheed has Air Force generals on its team. Saab and Dassault can count on support from diplomats and soldiers of their countries.
The plum is Poland, which dreams of buying at least 150 fighters at a cost of nearly $6 billion. By contrast, the United Arab Emirates has opened a bidding war for an 80-jet contract. And when Thailand was in the market recently for just eight jets, the Clinton Administration was so eager for McDonnell Douglas to beat out Dassault that it reversed a longstanding policy and allowed the planes to be equipped with a highly sophisticated missile system.
In Central Europe, the race began in earnest in September when Hungary and Saab signed a tentative $1 billion agreement for 30 Gripen JAS 39's. At that time, American companies were barely at the starting line and the Clinton Administration was still debating whether to sell advanced aircraft to countries that were part of the Soviet empire.
Administration officials opposing the sale argued that such countries would be better advised to spend the money on bolstering their fragile economies. But American diplomats countered that the countries should be allowed to buy the weapons they felt they needed.
In the end, officials in Washington concluded that if the United States did not sell the jets, someone else -- the French, Swedes or the Russians with their top-of-the-line MIG-29 -- would surely do so.
About the time that the Administration was easing limits on weapons sales, officials in Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic began re-thinking their enthusiasm for the expensive jet fighters.
Poland's current military budget is $3 billion, and only 10 percent of that is for hardware, said Mr. Karkoszka, the Deputy Defense Minister. If all of it were spent on planes, it would buy fewer than a dozen.
The Czech Republic, which is hoping to buy at least 24 jets, has roughly $30 million in its military budget for procurement, said Deputy Defense Minister Petr Necas. For that amount, the country can buy one F-18, and have nothing left for the radar, surface-to-air missiles and communications equipment that Mr. Necas said it needs.
In May, the Hungarian Parliament slammed on the brakes, announcing that the Government would not make a decision for another year.
With a precarious budget deficit, Hungary has been placed on a strict regime by the International Monetary Fund, which has forced severe cutbacks in social spending. "In this situation, we simply cannot afford to spend $1 billion on aircraft," Mr. Mecs said.
That has spurred the manufacturers to ever more tempting offers.
Saab, with the backing of the Swedish Government, has said Swedish companies will invest at least $100 million in Hungary to help modernize factories and provide technology. It has also said it will assemble a part of the plane in Hungary.
Officials in Poland and the Czech Republic said they were going to insist on similar terms. In recent weeks, Lockheed and McDonnell Douglas have had teams in Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic aggressively hunting for local companies in which American companies might invest.
But these deals, called offsets, can be nettlesome. A few years ago, as part of a sale of F-18's to Finland, McDonnell Douglas and its partner, the Northrop Grumman Corporation, arranged for a Finnish concern to sell machines to a Wisconsin company, which would otherwise have bought from an American company. That brought a furious protest from Senator Russ Feingold, a Wisconsin Democrat, and the deal fell through.
Indeed, American officials are not even supposed to be present when offsets are discussed, since the bottom line is that jobs and exports for foreign countries are often jobs lost in America.
The Pentagon is determined, however, that American companies prevail, and it has come up with what American officials describe as a "creative option" for Central Europe -- leasing used planes. American officials said Washington had never before leased planes under such circumstances.
On strictly economic and military grounds, the Russian MIG-29 and Saab Gripen are probably best for those countries, officials in the countries said. But politics remain a big factor. Countries in the region believe the purchase of American planes will pave the way for NATO membership, even though American officials insist there is no connection. "They are not a ticket for admission," said a senior American diplomat.

HEADLINE: Storm Brews Along Shore: Amtrak Plans Alarm Boaters;
Threat of Bridge Tie-ups Could Derail an Effort To Add Faster Trains

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

DATELINE: NIANTIC, Conn.

 BODY:
David J. Carol likes to take his son to Dad's Restaurant on Main Street here to sit on the deck and watch the Amtrak drawbridge over the Niantic River open for sailboats and fishing boats and close for trains.
Mostly he likes to see the bridge open, and stay open. For Mr. Carol is in charge of Amtrak's plan to run high-speed trains between New York and Boston, and the final permits needed for the $1.7-billion project hinge on Amtrak's assurances that bullet trains will not interfere with boaters along the Connecticut shoreline. And what piping plovers are to beachgoers, Connecticut boaters have proved to be for Amtrak: part of the protected shoreline system. 
 The problem is not so much ecology, though there are some worries and complaints about the coming electrification of tracks.
It's the economy of the upriver marinas: at five points along less than 30 miles of shore, Amtrak drawbridges and swingbridges stand between upriver docks and open water. Thousands of vessels -- in particular, the big pleasure boats that marinas vie for -- depend on Amtrak bridge tenders to open the spans so they can pass in and out. More trains mean more closings. More closings mean fewer customers. And marinas are barred by Connecticut law from switching to a nonmaritime use, even if their business disappears.
"If they electrify, fine -- we aren't smart enough to know about electrification," said Grant Westerson, executive director of the Connecticut Marine Trades Association. "But we all know that once a train is 10 to 15 minutes out of New York, the schedule goes to hell. So our response is, be realistic. If you put on all those trains, the bridges will never be open."
Upriver marinas had already lost boats to downriver slips because of frustrating delays at the bridges, which often remained closed for long times because trains were behind schedule, or because a bridge itself broke down.
"Waterfront isn't everywhere, you can't just pack it up," said Nancy Morrissey, an association official who found in an informal survey 3,143 slips and moorings above the bridges on the Connecticut, Niantic, Thames and Mystic Rivers, valued at nearly $7 million a year in rent.
On July 3, in Providence, Amtrak had a ground breaking for the electrification project, which Rhode Island, like Massachusetts and the Federal Railroad Administration, has approved. Before work can begin in Connecticut, however, Amtrak still needs permits from the State Department of Environmental Protection, and boat traffic -- protected both by state law and by Coast Guard regulation -- remains an issue.
The result, Mr. Carol said, after two years of studying the issue with boaters, is an operating plan for the bridges that makes Connecticut "the only state in the country that has veto power over Amtrak running more trains."
According to the plan, the 34 Amtrak trains a day projected for the year 2000 -- plus 12 local commuter and freight runs -- will allow bridges to open often enough so that boats wait no more than 20 minutes, the maximum delay permitted by the Coast Guard.
If Amtrak wants more trains, it is pledging to go back to the state for approval. Amtrak is taking other actions that Mr. Carol concedes are decades overdue. The simplest change was put into effect last summer, quickly eliminating many backups: spans are now left open until a train approaches. Before, they were left closed unless a boater requested an opening.
Amtrak is also replacing a signal system so antiquated that bridge tenders operated according to train timetables. "Traditionally, they would close the bridge based on when the train was supposed to be there, rather than on where it was," Mr. Carol said. "They'd close a bridge for a train that was 35 minutes late and keep it closed for 40 minutes."
The bridge schedule is based on a survey of river traffic last summer that found plenty of time for boats that needed a bridge opening, even on the busiest holiday weekends.
Most boats do not require openings, even at the Mystic River Swing Bridge, which has a clearance of only eight feet at high tide. At the Old Lyme Draw Bridge across the Connecticut River, with a 19-foot clearance, only 387 of 1,857 watercraft passing through last Labor Day needed the span open.
That total, however, included everything from yachts to kayaks. But to marinas, big boats are more profitable, and big boats, as well as almost any sailboat, need the bridges open. "There's been a slow exodus to marinas downstream since the first time we heard of Amtrak's plans," said Scott Bowden, general manager of Port Niantic, a marina here with 81 slips and rack-storage for 104 boats. He estimated that 40 percent of his customers needed the bridge open.
"To look for smaller boats is not an appealing alternative," he said. "A 40-foot boat burns more fuel. It generally needs more repairs and maintenance. It generates more revenue not only for the marina but to the local economy."
Across the tricky Niantic Channel, where the current runs at six knots, Bill Engdall, who owns the Niantic Bay Marinas, fears a price war if larger boats start to leave, just as the industry is starting to recover from a recession in the early 1990's.
"If a lot of marinas lose those people, they may lower their rates again and we'll never get back to where we were," he said. "You're going to have marinas fighting each other over $5 or $10 a foot."
In Essex, a popular Connecticut River town where it can be easier to find a boat slip than a parking space, Wally Schieferdecker, owner of the 125-slip Essex Island Marina, said that nearly all of his customers need the Old Lyme Bridge open.
"The bridge operating plan, I believe, is Amtrak's best effort at maximizing the amount of time the bridges can be open," said Mr. Schieferdecker, who serves on an advisory board the railroad has formed with boaters. "They have also agreed to put into effect efficiencies that will improve the bridge operation. So hopefully the combination of the two will give us a decent arrangement -- if they do all those things."
For many people along the shore, however, the question of whether Amtrak can operate a railroad that will not interfere with boats leads to larger questions about the high-speed plan itself: will Amtrak be able to cut an hour off the New York-to-Boston trip, keep trains on schedule and -- its ultimate goal -- increase ridership to five million people a year from two million now.
A Stonington-based citizens group, Citizens for a Sound Environment, is challenging Amtrak's environmental-impact study in Federal court, but its main criticism is simple: the plan will not work.
"They say they're going to increase riders by reducing the time from four to five hours down to three hours," said the group's president, Jason C. Becker. "We agree that the three hours is a nicer time, but if they don't do that, if they end up closer to four hours, they've wasted a lot of money."
State Representative Robert R. Simmons, a Republican from Stonington, said he doubts whether the express trains will be able to speed their way through the dense Metro-North commuter traffic near New York.
"I tend to support trains and train travel," he said, "but at this point I think it's not going to be high speed, it's going to be high cost."
Mr. Carol acknowledges the difficulties. But the Northeast Corridor project is a pilot for all other high-speed rail plans in the country, he said, and every issue that he discovers and addresses provides a lesson for those who follow.
Amtrak, for example, now takes boaters seriously. "We've been able to impress on Amtrak and our bridge tenders that boaters have a right to get through these bridges efficiently and courteously," Mr. Carol said. "And we've told the boaters that we carry two million -- someday five million -- passengers a year, and they have a right to go over those bridges."

SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 5; National Desk 

LENGTH: 860 words

HEADLINE: A G.O.P. Policy Meeting May Put Pressure on Dole

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
Citing the lack of an economic message in Bob Dole's Presidential campaign, some top Republicans are planning a policy meeting in an apparent effort to spur Mr. Dole into announcing and campaigning on a platform of tax cuts.
Jack F. Kemp, the former Congressman and Housing Secretary and a sometimes-supporter of Mr. Dole, said in a television interview on Saturday that several Republican leaders, including Speaker Newt Gingrich, were planning such a meeting in two weeks. He said that they had notified officials of the Dole campaign but that those officials were not involved in planning the event or its message. Mr. Kemp implied that the meeting would go forward with or without them. 
 Interviewed on on CNN's "Inside Politics Weekend," Mr. Kemp said that without a strong message of tax cuts, Mr. Dole, the likely Republican Presidential nominee, could not win the election. Saying some Republicans, including some in the Dole campaign, were simply waiting for "the collapse of the Clinton Administration," Mr. Kemp added, "That's no way to run for President."
The Dole campaign said publicly that it welcomed the meeting as a way to find more ideas to stimulate the economy. But senior Dole advisers privately expressed frustration with Mr. Kemp for acting like what they described as a burr under Mr. Dole's saddle. One adviser said, "This freelancing proves why Jack Kemp has moved from playing quarterback for the G.O.P. to playing a new position -- left out."
Mr. Kemp, a former quarterback for the Buffalo Bills and a onetime Presidential candidate, alienated Mr. Dole earlier this year by endorsing Steve Forbes for President, even after it was clear that Mr. Dole had locked up the nomination. Although some of Mr. Dole's campaign aides are former Kemp loyalists, the endorsement made for bad blood between the two camps.
Mr. Kemp said a news conference was planned for Wednesday to announce the meeting, which will address how to "double" the rate of growth of the American economy, which he described as "anemic." He said he was planning the news conference with Mr. Gingrich; Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader; Senator Connie Mack of Florida, and others.
Mr. Kemp said Vin Weber and Donald H. Rumsfeld, both senior officials of the Dole campaign, were aware of the meeting. Mr. Weber said today that he had not been notified but that he would try to arrange his schedule to attend the announcement even without an invitation "because I know Jack wouldn't wait for one."
The Kemp-Dole relationship aside, several Republicans have been increasingly nervous about what they describe as the drift of the Dole campaign. Many have wondered privately why Mr. Dole has not been quicker to develop an economic program, emphasizing tax cuts.
Ever since Mr. Dole was challenged in the primaries by Mr. Forbes, who promoted a flat tax, he has been saying he wants a "fairer, simpler, flatter" tax system. But he has not proposed any specifics.
A former chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Mr. Dole has been meeting behind the scenes for months with a group of economists. Aides said that proposals were being examined and that a consensus was being sought before any announcement, which they expect well before the Republican convention in mid-August.
"They ought to give us a little time," Mr. Weber said. "This is still midsummer. I understand every day matters, but we have plenty of time for Senator Dole to put forward a growth agenda."
Mr. Dole, who has welcomed Mr. Forbes as an economic adviser, has hinted that he will propose some form of tax relief. But he has a long history of preferring to cut the deficit to cutting taxes, and at times he has appeared to bridle at the assumption that he will abandon that stance. Mr. Kemp's remarks could be seen as a way to prod a reluctant Mr. Dole toward proposing steeper tax cuts than he might be considering.
There is a growing sense of urgency among Republicans that without a strong central economic message, Mr. Dole would continue to be swept away by controversies of his own making, on topics like tobacco and assault weapons.
Gov. George Voinovich, the Ohio Republican, told reporters at a governors' meeting in Puerto Rico that Mr. Dole was taking a meticulous approach to an economic agenda because he was committed to reconciling a tax cut with balancing the budget. Still, he said, Mr. Dole had yet to answer the fundamental question for any Presidential candidate: "Why am I running, and what am I going to do if I am President?" Mr. Voinovich added: "If he does that, he will be elected. If he doesn't he will lose. It is that simple."
Mr. Kemp said on CNN that unless Mr. Dole adopted a platform of tax cuts and made his campaign one of "hope, growth and opportunity" -- the slogan of the losing Forbes campaign -- Mr. Dole would lose.
"We've been on defense," Mr. Kemp said. "There's no doubt about it. Some Republicans believe you can win by default. People can be opposed to Bill Clinton, but that doesn't necessarily mean they're going to vote Republican unless we are the party of reform, change, progress, the future."

HEADLINE: Mayor Finds Old Issue Emerging In New Way

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 14

 BODY:
For more than two decades, Atlanta was led by civil rights giants, men not just respected but revered among blacks for their service to the movement and their barrier-breaking elections.
Maynard H. Jackson Jr., the city's first black mayor, championed the cause of affirmative action and was re-elected twice by overwhelming margins. Andrew Young, one of Martin Luther King Jr.'s top lieutenants, became Georgia's first black Congressman since Reconstruction, represented the United States at the United Nations and then followed Mr. Jackson to City Hall. 
 Now, at perhaps the most visible moment in Atlanta's history, the staging of the 1996 Summer Olympic Games, the city's leader is decidedly not one of the old warriors. At 43, Mayor Bill Campbell sees himself as the vanguard of a new generation of black leaders who embrace a less conspicuous brand of racial politics.
He has paid a political price for that approach among Atlanta's blacks, who comprise two-thirds of the city's population. But Mr. Campbell contends that much of the criticism of his 2 1/2-year tenure has less to do with substance than with the fact that "the old royal court has been deposed."
His agenda is less about the fight for black empowerment than about paving potholes, encouraging job growth, making neighborhoods safer and building downtown housing. That represents an important evolution in this city's political life, and the transition has not always been easy.
"You have to understand," he said in an interview last week, "that not being a part of the old guard or the established political structure, coming from the outside, that there are an awful lot of unhappy campers who view me as an interloper during the most important time in Atlanta's history. And they can't stand it."
Because Mr. Campbell lacks the civil rights credentials of his predecessors, even his top aides say he is still trying to get comfortable with his black constituents. A North Carolina native who moved here in 1977, Mr. Campbell has already attracted a serious challenge in next year's election from a mainstay of the old school, the City Council President, Marvin S. Arrington.
Mr. Campbell, a lawyer, is smart enough to have graduated cum laude from Vanderbilt University in three years with three majors. He is persuasive enough to have won 73 percent approval for the first city bond act passed in more than 25 years.
But the Mayor has also been accused of serious political miscalculations on racial issues.
In what came to be seen as a defining moment early in his term, he made black college students feel unwelcome with a hard-line response to an unruly, traffic-snarling spring gathering known as Freaknik. His appointment of whites to top positions, including his chief of staff, has drawn whispers of derision from black leaders.
"There's this perception that he's not black," said William H. Boone, a professor of political science at Clark Atlanta University.
On the other hand, Mr. Campbell has been a strong defender of affirmative action. But when he said at a recent rally that all black college students and business people owed their success to affirmative action, he managed to offend black and white constituents alike.
Mr. Campbell's problems with blacks have been exacerbated by a style that his critics characterize as arrogant, demeaning and vindictive.
During the interview, Mr. Campbell questioned the mental stability of one of his opponents on the City Council, C. T. Martin. "The truth of the matter is in a more humane society he would be institutionalized," Mr. Campbell said. "I think it's fair to say, you know, psychiatric intervention would be a blessing."
Mr. Martin responded, "I'm not surprised at anything Bill would say."
If Mr. Campbell's predecessors were the fathers of the civil rights movement, the Mayor was quite literally a child of it. At age 7, he was the first student to integrate a public elementary school in Raleigh, N.C. The decision was made by his father, the president of the local N.A.A.C.P., and his mother, a secretary at a black college. Mr. Campbell said he could never have imposed the same decision on his own two children. Older white students, he said, "would beat on me, spit on me, knock me down whenever there was nobody around. It is perhaps one of the great profiles in courage that my father and mother were, in essence, willing to sacrifice their 7-year-old son."
Given their parents' marching and canvassing, politics came naturally to Mr. Campbell and his older brother, Ralph Jr. Mr. Campbell won a seat on Atlanta's City Council only four years after moving to town. A year before he was elected Mayor, his brother was elected state auditor in North Carolina, making him the first black North Carolinian elected to a statewide nonjudicial office.
Being Mayor of Atlanta is not the job it once was. While its suburbs have exploded, Atlanta's population, which is estimated at about 425,000, has declined by 5 percent over the last 10 years. The Mayor now represents fewer constituents than the chief executives of four of the five counties that constitute the metropolitan area. And, to a large extent, the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, a private corporation, has served as a shadow government during Mr. Campbell's term. But as a platform for black politics, City Hall still commands national attention. And the Olympics may make the Mayor an international celebrity, at least for a few weeks.
Mr. Campbell, who was elected with 73 percent of the vote, used the Olympics and his early popularity to push through a $149 million bond act to pay for improvements to roads and bridges, win designation for the city as a Federal empowerment zone, and help his plan to build a new downtown basketball arena.
The Olympics have also provided Mr. Campbell with a moral soapbox. He has vetoed bills that would have allowed bars to serve alcohol 24 hours a day during the Games and allowed a large taxi-fare increase that he called price gouging. Mr. Young, who lobbied to bring the Games to Atlanta, said the Olympics have helped Mr. Campbell by generating civic momentum and tested him by generating scrutiny.
"I think that Bill has been luckier than most of us because he's had the Olympics to take a lot of heat and provide a lot of economic growth," Mr. Young said. "And yet he's had some major problems that he's had to deal with behind the scenes."
One problem is a sewer system so overtaxed that the state may impose a construction moratorium. And while Atlanta recorded fewer homicides last year than in any year since 1985, its crime rate rose and ranked second in the country. Last year, the police department was rocked by a big corruption scandal.
Those problems, Mr. Campbell said, will remain his priority after the Olympic glitter fades. Next year, he hopes the city's voters -- black and white -- will appreciate his delivery of services as much as they appreciated his predecessors' delivery of sermons. "For a lot of people," he said, "the allure of having an international celebrity as Mayor is special. But getting your trash picked up and having the streets patrolled is just as important."

HEADLINE: Falling Yen Puts Car Makers In Japan in the Driver's Seat

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER with ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
For a decade after the dollar began its long slide in value against the yen in 1985, American auto makers and other manufacturers enjoyed a special form of protection from Japanese competitors, whose imported products became almost inexorably more expensive in the United States.
But now the sheltered years are coming to an end. 
 The dollar has soared 39 percent from its trough in April of last year. As each dollar of sales in the United States translates into more yen at home, Japanese manufacturers have found themselves in the catbird seat, with a choice of grabbing bigger profits, cutting prices to build market share or both.
What it adds up to, a growing contingent of corporate leaders and economists say, is a new competitive threat to American companies, particularly auto makers. Even if the Japanese choose to leave their prices in place and collect more profits, the extra earnings could be invested in new factories and product designs that would raise the standard of competition in the United States for years to come. If they choose to cut prices and expand their share of the American market, the resulting price wars could hurt the profits of domestic companies.
The rise brings benefits as well as perils and could prove a boon for American consumers. They could see lower prices, or at least fewer price increases. The potential for lower prices, in turn, helps hold down inflation and interest rates.
Indeed, no one is saying the dollar's rise this time will cause the kind of deep pain that accompanied its big surge in the early 1980's, when it hobbled America's exports of manufactured goods by making them more expensive. The Clinton Administration, which backs a strong dollar, says American industries are healthy enough now to shake off the effects of its current rise.
Nonetheless, problems loom for a number of American companies.
Japanese machine tool companies, for example, are beginning to bid more aggressively for overseas contracts. The Citizen Watch Company, for one, is now enjoying record sales of highly precise machine tools in the United States after lowering prices by 15 percent over the last year as the yen has dropped.
Having raised prices when the yen was rising, "we feel that we must make some kind of response to the currency shift," said Yoshikuni Ku rumato, the general manager of sales at the Okuma Corporation, another machine tool company.
Caterpillar Inc., a maker of construction equipment based in Peoria, Ill., has found that the rising dollar gives a new advantage to its archrival, Komatsu of Japan. Donald Fites, Caterpillar's chairman and chief executive, blunted the dollar's rise at least temporarily on Tuesday when he publicly suggested that Government action might be needed to reverse its ascent.
That rise -- the result of higher interest rates in the United States and a shrinking trade surplus in Japan -- has been strong and steady. Worth just 79.85 yen in April 1995, the dollar burst through the 110-yen level early this month. It closed Friday at 110.80, and was trading around 110.60 early today. While the dollar has also risen against other currencies, it has done so more slowly.
One of the industries most vulnerable to the shift with the yen is the American auto and auto parts business.
Japanese auto makers have been aggressively offering subsidized lease rates and other incentives in recent months as the yen has fallen, and are widely expected by analysts to cut some prices for the 1997 model year. Cars and car parts account for nearly one third of Japanese exports to the United States.
The average cost per vehicle sold in the United States by the top eight Japanese auto makers depends heavily on the exchange rate, said Jay N. Woodworth, a consultant in Summit, N.J., who works for Japanese and American auto makers alike.
Japanese auto makers spend an average of 1.43 million yen to manufacture a car in Japan, plus $2,600 to market and distribute the car in the United States, Mr. Woodworth said. When it took only 80 yen to buy a dollar in April 1995, the 1.43 million yen was equal to $17,875.
But now that it takes 110 yen to buy a dollar, the manufacturing cost translates to only $13,000. That is a huge savings in the auto industry, where cost-cutting is so competitive that Ford Motor Company executives were recently congratulating themselves for saving 25 cents on each Explorer by not painting the inside of the ash tray.
Even for a car assembled in the United States by Honda Motor, Toyota Motor or Nissan Motor, all of which use considerable quantities of American parts, the effect of the currency shift is considerable, Mr. Woodworth said. The savings per car as the dollar has moved from 80 to 110 yen is nearly $2,000, because many parts are still imported from Japan, he said.
Those savings are beginning to become apparent on the showroom floor. After years of rapid price increases, Japanese auto makers have raised their prices by an average of only $91 a vehicle since the beginning of the current model year, according to a recent study by Automotive News. American auto makers have raised their car and truck prices by an average of $226.
Japanese manufacturers wrung their hands with dismay when the dollar fell to 110 yen for the first time in 1993. But they have taken so many steps since then to reduce costs and become profitable at 80 or 90 yen that they now welcome an exchange rate of 110 yen.
"At 105, we still consider it a strong yen," said Ryuji Araki, a Toyota director in charge of finance and accounting, in a May interview. "Only when it's 110 or 120 will our expectations change."
Of course, American auto makers and other manufacturers have been ruthlessly driving down their own costs in recent years. Many are well prepared for another bout of tougher foreign competition. Labor costs remain lower in the United States than in Japan or Germany. And American exports rose this spring despite the dollar's strength.
All those factors are cited by executives who play down the possibility of a rerun of the early 1980's, when an overvalued dollar helped turn the Great Lakes manufacturing states into the Rust Belt, crippling exports and pulling in a flood of imports.
"It's something to watch carefully, but I don't think it's going to revert to the Rust Belt," said Gene Miller, chairman and chief executive of Comerica Bank, the biggest Michigan bank and a large lender to many Midwestern manufacturers.
The Clinton Administration has backed a strong dollar for the last two years, and dismisses new worries about its rise.
"I don't think there's any question about the health and competitiveness of our industries compared with industries all over the world," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said last Wednesday.
Earlier last week, Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers said that the American economy was thriving and did not need the further stimulus that a weaker dollar would provide by helping exports.
Also mitigating the effects of the dollar's rise is the fact that some American manufacturing industries are much less sensitive than others to moves in the currency markets.
Without tremendous shifts in currencies and prices, telephone companies have been slow to change suppliers of their central office switches because of the cost of retraining workers and replacing related equipment, said Chris Padilla, a vice president at Lucent Technologies Inc., formerly the manufacturing arm of AT&T.
What is more, prices for some Japanese products may not fall steeply. Most Japanese companies, including auto makers, did not raise prices in the United States in 1994 and early 1995 as fast as the yen was rising. For that reason, some American operations of Japanese auto makers have been losing money in recent years, analysts believe. That may make them eager to collect some profits for a while.
Seiichiro Iwasawa, an auto analyst at the Nomura Research Institute, said that each yen of appreciation in the dollar's value was worth about $360 million, at current exchange rates, to the Japanese auto industry. He predicted that Japanese auto makers would eventually pass along one-half to two-thirds of their savings in price reductions, while retaining the rest as higher earnings.
Detroit auto makers and their suppliers have responded by lobbying quietly for Government intervention. Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, protested the dollar's strength during a meeting early last month with senior Administration officials at the White House. Auto parts manufacturers expressed the same worry at another meeting two weeks ago.
But some American auto executives continue to take a fairly low-key approach to the yen's weakness. "If it stays between the 100 to 110 level, I don't think it's a major factor," said W. Wayne Booker, an executive vice president at Ford, who later added, "All we're really saying is that the trend is not healthy."
Yet some industry experts say even that view is unduly optimistic. "There are a lot of people in Detroit who forgot about the foreign exchange issue -- the attitude is, 'We dealt with that,' " Mr. Woodworth said. "One hundred ten is kind of an important milepost we've crossed here. The whole thing is back front and center again."
One of the first casualties of the dollar's new strength could be the slow efforts by American car companies to capture a significant share of the Japanese market. Their position in Japan is the mirror image of the Japanese position now in the United States. The Americans must choose between raising prices or accepting smaller profits as the yen they collect in Japan for new cars converts into fewer and fewer dollars.
Keith S. Wicks, the general director of Saturn Japan, rolled his eyes when asked last Monday in Tokyo how the rising dollar would affect his efforts to begin selling Saturn cars in Japan soon.
"Obviously we're hoping the dollar doesn't strengthen very much," he said. "We would like to see it down more from where it is today."

HEADLINE: Clinton Officials Back Broadcasters On Advanced TV

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Technology advisers in the Clinton Administration have sided with broadcasters and consumer electronics makers and against major computer companies, strongly endorsing the broadcasters' preferred technology format as the standard for the next generation of television.
In letters to Reed E. Hundt, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, the White House's Office of Science and Technology Policy and a senior Commerce Department technology expert argued for quick adoption of the standard favored by the so-called "grand alliance" of broadcasters and manufacturers. It is believed to be the first time the Administration has taken a position on the proposed digital television standard. 
 In doing so, the Clinton officials have rejected the arguments of Microsoft, Apple and many other companies in the computer industry that contend that the "grand alliance" standard embraces technology that is already outdated. Government approval for that standard, they say, will inhibit innovation and drive up costs to consumers as the distinction blurs between personal computers and television sets.
The larger issue in the debate is whether a Government-endorsed technology standard will speed the development of a new industry or hurt it. On this question, the broadcasters and their allies, which have thrived under regulation, and the personal computer companies, which have thrived without it, find little common ground.
Not this year or next, but over the next decade digital television is expected to become a huge industry and transform the experience of home entertainment. Yet the often-arcane issue of technology standards will play a key role in determining the winners and losers in this industry of tomorrow, as well as what services consumers receive and at what cost.
In the two letters to Mr. Hundt, Administration officials urged the F.C.C. to approve quickly the proposed standard to aid investment in the new technology and to help American companies compete against the Europeans, who are trying to establish a competing standard for digital television.
It is the second time in the past month that Mr. Hundt has been prodded to get on with a decision affecting broadcasters. In late June, key Congressional leaders sent him a letter telling him to proceed with the allocation of those parts of the broadcast spectrum originally set aside for high-definition television broadcasts. Mr. Hundt, by contrast, had been leaning toward auctioning off those portions of the spectrum instead of giving them to broadcasters.
In the new round of prodding, Lionel Johns, associate director for technology in the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy, wrote the F.C.C. chairman last Wednesday: "There is an ever-diminishing 'window of opportunity' for the U.S. to define a worldwide standard. Having leapfrogged the rest of the world in the early 1990's in the race to deploy advanced television systems, America is on the brink of relinquishing its lead to international competitors."
Later in his letter, Mr. Johns dismissed the concerns of computer companies that a Government standard would stymie innovation. "In point of fact, a technological freeze will be occasioned only upon the failure to adopt a standard."
And in a letter last Thursday, Larry Irving, Assistant Secretary of Commerce in charge of the National Telecommunications and Information Administration, told Mr. Hundt: "Digital television also promises myriad benefits for the U.S. economy. These benefits will accrue, however, only if the commission acts rapidly to adopt a digital television transmission standard so that the transition to digital television can begin promptly."
Companies that have worked on the standard welcomed the support. "This is very positive," said Bob Rast, vice president of technical business development for the General Instrument Corporation. "It appears that the Administration is telling Reed Hundt to get on with this."
The position of General Instrument, a pioneer in digital-television development, and other advocates is that the current proposal represents a reasonable compromise of television and computer interests. The standard is supported by the Walt Disney Company's ABC, the General Electric Company's NBC, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's CBS, AT&T, Zenith, Philips and the communications workers' and electrical workers' unions.
But the computer companies and their supporters believe that the broadcasters and electronics makers are trying to use the Government to seize a competitive advantage in a new industry.
"Ideally, we'd like to see no standard at all," said Jack Krumholtz, Federal government affairs manager for the Microsoft Corporation. "But if there is a standard, we think it should be a minimal one to minimize the real risk of perpetuating obsolete technology."
The computer industry also believes that last week's letters from Administration officials do not necessarily represent the Clinton Administration's final position on the issue. "The public debate on this is far from over," Mr. Krumholtz said.
Technically, the debate is over the transmission technology. Today's televisions receive frames of images every 30th of a second, which are then reassembled, or "interlaced," for viewing. Computers used interlaced technology to display images and text at first, but in recent years moved to a faster, cleaner technique called "progressive scan."
Proponents of the "grand alliance" standard say their approach will make it easier for existing broadcasters to move to digital television, which offers not only sharper images but also Internet services. Computer companies reply that to receive computer-format transmissions, under the proposed standard, would require consumers to buy a costly decoding box.
Besides Microsoft, opponents of the proposed standard include Apple, Compaq, Dell, Intel, the National Cable Television Association, the Consumer Federation of America and the Directors Guild.

Amtrak Plan Worries Marinas

The problem is the economy of upriver marinas: at five points along less than 30 miles of shore, Amtrak drawbridges and swingbridges stand between upriver docks and open water. Thousands of vessels depend on Amtrak bridge tenders to open the spans so they can pass in and out. More trains mean more closings. More closings mean fewer customers. [B1.]

 BODY:

Rising Dollar Undercutting U.S. Business vs. Japanese
As the dollar slid in value against the yen during the decade beginning in 1985, American manufacturers enjoyed a special form of protection from Japanese competitors, whose products became more expensive in the United States. But as the dollar now strengthens, the sheltered years are ending. 
 The dollar has soared 39 percent in just 15 months. As each dollar of sales in the United States translates into more yen at home, Japanese manufacturers have been grabbing bigger profits, cutting prices to build market share or both. Some corporate leaders and economists say this means a new competitive threat to American companies, particularly auto makers. [Page A1.]
 
Deal Seen for King World
New World Communications Group is set to acquire King World Productions, the distributor of "The Oprah Winfrey Show," "Jeopardy" and "Wheel of Fortune," according to several people close to the talks. Boards of the two companies are expected to meet as early as today to approve a deal valued at $1.48 billion. [D2.]

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: July 15, 1996

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1863 words

HEADLINE: As Market Shifts, Bad Old Days Of Finding an Apartment Return

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Finding a rental apartment in Manhattan has become as complicated as, and in many buildings and neighborhoods even more costly than, it was in the mid-to-late 1980's, when soaring rents and prices, sprouting condominium towers and co-op conversions helped define the character of an economic boom.
New York is not, by most measures, having another economic boom right now, and that's where this apartment crunch gets interesting: the smoke is back, without the fire. But this historical echo of the 1980's economy has resurrected a psychology and culture of real-estate obsession that had seemed all but extinguished. Finding a Manhattan apartment has once again become a defining New York experience. 
 "It's horrible, basically," said Ji Lu, a law student at New York University who, along with two roommates, had to sign over more than $11,000 in brokers fees and security deposits -- much of it borrowed from parents -- last week in hopes of getting a three-bedroom, $3,000-a-month apartment in Greenwich Village. And they still weren't sure, until the lease was signed and back in their hands on Friday, that they would get the apartment at all. Landlords, because they can be choosy, are setting higher credit hurdles, like financial guarantors and multi-month security deposits, for would-be tenants.
"It's been the most overwhelming experience of my life," said Ben Boyd, an account executive at Hill & Knowlton who is moving from Washington, D.C., to the company's New York office. Twice in the last month Mr. Boyd was told he had an apartment -- he had even signed a lease and given over deposit checks in one instance -- only to be told that, sorry, the apartment was gone already after all.
What has happened to the apartment market, real estate professionals, tenants and landlords say, is in many ways a mirror image of the 1980's housing crunch. Then it was a matter of too much demand as businesses expanded and hired; the tale now is of constricted supply, with not enough apartments to go around despite what is still only a shallow economic recovery from the region's deep recession in the early 1990's.
But the root of the supply constriction is also connected to what is perhaps an even more fundamental change, in who owns New York's apartments and how much they can charge in rent.
The co-op- and condo-crazed 1980's created a new class of owned housing in New York, especially in Manhattan. Of the 783,266 housing units in the borough counted by the city in a survey in 1993, just under 231,000, or about 30 percent of the total, were condos or co-ops compared with about 17.7 percent condos or co-ops for the city as a whole.
And during the recession, many of the condo and co-op owners -- institutions as well as individuals -- became members of a new landlord class, as they were forced to rent out apartments that could not be resold.
The economic recovery in the city, beginning in 1993, closed those two forces like a pincer. Some co-op and condo units that had been for rent finally began to sell to new owner-occupants -- thus shrinking the supply. And because a majority of the remaining available rental stock was still composed of co-ops and condos, which are completely beyond the rent regulation laws that cover traditional rental buildings, the shrinkage of supply drove rents as high as the market would bear.
What this means is that the free market is now setting rental rates for much of Manhattan -- a major change in itself for a city that has lived more half a century by the rhythms and rules of the rent laws. At Feathered Nest Inc., one of the city's largest rental brokers, 57 percent of the available rental stock now consists of condos and co-ops.
And all that has brought back almost-forgotten modes of behavior, as well as a cast of familiar characters.
The manipulative apartment broker with ultimate power over one's fate has made a triumphant return, for example. He has been spotted demanding that apartment-seekers spring for cab fare to travel around the city, saying he is short on cash and it will be taken out of his 15 percent broker's fee when the deal is closed. And the imperious co-op board is stirring once again as well, reasserting, in a quickened market, its power to deny admission after years of market-driven obsequiousness.
But there are some 1990's updates as well. The old 1980's ritual of combing The Village Voice classifieds on Tuesday night in preparation for Wednesday morning calls moved this spring into the realm of cyberspace. The paper's classifieds now go on line on the Internet at 1:30 P.M. on Tuesday, giving the electronically aware a crucial five- or six-hour jump on the competition. And for those planning on sharing space, a new company has popped up, supplying temporary rented walls to subdivide small spaces into even smaller ones.
The renters themselves are landing in situations that are far different from their 1980's predecessors. Like many in this new generation of renters, Mr. Boyd and his companion, Eric Fanning, have leased a co-op apartment: $1,600 a month for a one-bedroom on West 15th Street on a two-year lease. Because it's unregulated, except by the market, all bets are off when the lease expires.
"In two years we could just be out, or face some exorbitant rent increase," Mr. Boyd said.
And market-determined rates, at least in this market, only go up. At a new apartment building on Jane Street in Greenwich Village, for example, a one-bedroom that could have been rented in early June for $1,700 a month now goes for $1,850, while studios jumped from $1,200 to $1,400.
"It's the tightest it's ever been, and most of it is in the free market," said Marjorie Ann Otter, the president of Justis Properties Management Corporation, a broker in Greenwich Village. Ms. Otter said that while there are still thousands of rent-stabilized and rent-controlled apartments, fewer and fewer are becoming available. Perhaps, she said, this is because the odds of getting another regulated space are lower than they have been in recent memory, encouraging people with sure bets to become entrenched and thereby furthering the cycle of market control.
But the new rhythms and implications of this apartment crunch also extend beyond simply making life easier for landlords and harder for tenants.
Unlike the 1980's, when neighborhoods throughout much of the city experienced rising rents and real-estate prices, the mid-1990's constriction has had a sharp geographic demarcation: Manhattan only. Although rents in some tonier neighborhoods of the outer boroughs, like Brooklyn Heights and Riverdale in the Bronx, have recently begun to rise, only in Manhattan -- and only south of 96th Street at that -- has the market approached anything remotely resembling its 1980's mania.
That has made the constriction political. In their never-ending battle to convince the State Legislature in Albany that rent regulation laws should be ended, building owners are arguing that, just like the free market overhauled the national health care system despite the failure of Federal Government initiatives, so too has the apartment market in New York rendered rent regulation irrelevant and ready for retirement.
The landlords argue that rents in Manhattan are above what would be allowed by rent regulation -- so the law isn't working there -- while rents in other areas of the city are below what the regulations would allow -- and thus the rules are not working there either.
"Tenants are being protected by the market -- we can't get rents as high as rent stabilization would legally allow," said R. Bonnie Haber, the president of a small-building owner's group called Community Housing Improvement Program that has fought the rent laws, and also the president of RBH Management Corporation, a family-owned company that has 15 buildings outside central Manhattan. "It's a very distorted market."
The disparity -- and the arguments -- could be sharpened further when the biggest concentration of new housing in the region starts coming on line later this year in the Wall Street area as vacant commercial buildings are converted to residential use.
Although the conversions, encouraged by the state and city through tax breaks, would be happening even without the tight market, apartment brokers and developers said that housing pressures will make downtown grow faster and bigger than it would have otherwise. Some say that could siphon away residents from Brooklyn or Staten Island who work downtown and want to live closer to their jobs, and further weaken the outer borough housing markets where new development is just about nonexistent.
Carl Weisbrod, the president of the Alliance for Downtown, a business group that manages the area's business improvement district, said the initial estimates by the city projected that about 2,000 to 3,000 new apartments would be converted in former commercial buildings. Mr. Weisbrod now expects about 7,000 new apartments by early next century.
Higher credit and income restrictions by landlords are also increasing divisions between wealthy and less wealthy residents, and further separating Manhattan from its neighbors. Several years ago, for example, a tenant needed to earn only about three times the annual rent to qualify for a lease in Manhattan, or about $54,000 for a $1,500-a-month apartment. Now, many landlords are demanding -- because they can -- a multiple of four times the rent, or $72,000 for the same apartment.
"Landlords are able to get tenants with virtually perfect credit," said Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest. It's all competition, she said: if one applicant doesn't meet the requirement, "the next one will."
The temporary wall company is also flourishing in this environment of diminished horizons. Scott Webb's two-year-old company, called The Wall (named after the Pink Floyd album, he said, in an attempt to connect with the young renters who are driving the Manhattan market) has rented about 400 to 500 walls so far. But his craft is more than just walls, Mr. Webb said: it's an act of creation and artistic expression, all in miniature. One of his proudest achievements was the creation of a two-bedroom apartment, complete with a living room, in an alcove studio apartment of only 400 square feet.
For some renters who prevail, there is often a sense of modest victory as well: that the apartment they ended up with, however small and expensive, is at least not the worst one they saw. Nearly every searcher has tales of a dead mouse, or a drunkenly sloped floor, or a dark hole that made them depressed even to see it.
Amy Appleton, a pediatrician from New Mexico who is moving to New York next month to take a job at Betances Health Unit, a medical clinic on the Lower East Side, allowed herself a five-day crash course to find an apartment, and came up, she believes, a winner.
"I've been to places that were dark and dirty and renting for more than I ended up paying," Dr. Appleton said. She leased a studio apartment in the new rental building on Jane Street. It's small for $1,445 a month, she conceded. "But it's got a view of New Jersey."

HEADLINE: New Approach Needed to U.S.-Cuba Relations

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Cuba Boomerang" (editorial, July 13) does a fine job of arguing that the punitive Helms-Burton law tightening the United States embargo of Cuba is a step in the wrong direction. We have seen how our families still living in Cuba suffer from a policy based on the premise that by tightening the screws on the Castro regime, that government will fall and Cuba will move toward democracy. 
 I am a Cuban-American who has over the years traveled to Cuba to visit relatives, and the effect of this policy could not be more apparent to me. Children go without milk, an epileptic aunt goes without seizure medicine, a diabetic uncle goes without sufficient insulin.
It is time for a new approach that emphasizes dialogue and negotiation. Let's do this for the vast majority of the Cuban-American community who want to see an end to the artificial separation of families.
 
DELVIS FERNANDEZ LEVY
Exec. Dir., Cuban American
Alliance Education Fund
Fort Lee, N.J., July 14, 1996

HEADLINE: South Korea Democracy Is on a Steady Course

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "At Crossroads of Democracy, South Korea Hesitates" (news article, July 10): Although South Korea has long been a model among developing countries for economic growth, its development toward democracy has been possible only since the 1993 inauguration of President Kim Young Sam as its first civilian leader. 
 South Korea still faces problems, the biggest being the threat from North Korea. So long as that threat remains, a security law must remain in effect for national survival. Yet the Government has instituted new political financing laws, transparency in all financial transactions, ethics requirements for public officials, freely contested elections and local autonomy.
President Kim has played a leading role in advancing democracy and correcting the wrongs of history. He deserves to be commended for his contribution to Korea's democratization, which is on an irreversible course.
 
DJUN KIL KIM
Minister for Public Affairs
Embassy of South Korea
Washington, July 12, 1996

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls vs. Yen and Mark As Stocks Lead Way Down

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar dropped to the lowest level in nearly a month against the mark and fell against most other leading currencies yesterday, dragged down as the United States stock market suffered one of its worst falls this year.
A report in Yomiuri Shimbun predicting that the Bank of Japan was preparing to raise interest rates this month also hurt the dollar. Although the central bank denied the report, traders said it helped incite a selling mood that worsened as stocks took a beating on Wall Street. 
 "I think there's a perception that the dollar has a vested interest in the health of the U.S. stock market," said Wayne Grigull, managing director of foreign exchange sales at Merrill Lynch & Company. "When it sells off as badly as it did today, it weighs on the dollar."
In late trading in New York, the dollar stood at 1.5165 marks, down from 1.5236 marks on Friday and the lowest level since June 18. The dollar fell to 110.36 Japanese yen from 110.80 yen. The British pound rose to $1.5525 from $1.5515.
The main force driving down the dollar was the drop in American stocks, led by technology issues on fears of weaker corporate earnings and higher interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average lost nearly 3 percent, or 161.05 points, its fourth-biggest point loss.
A retreat in bond prices intensified the pressure on the dollar as traders feared foreign investors would sell their dollar-denominated holdings, unleashing dollars onto the foreign exchange market.
"The dollar has behaved poorly," said Richard Alford, an economist with HSBC Midland in New York. "You have the U.S. asset markets selling off. The dollar is moving in sympathy."
The dollar's most notable decline was against the mark, but traders partly attributed that to a growing demand for marks in Europe, where speculation that German interest rates will decline has evaporated and the economy is showing signs of strength. The prospect of lower rates in Germany has weighed on the mark in recent months.
The mark's strength came despite the cancellation by President Boris N. Yeltsin of a meeting in Russia with Vice President Al Gore. Political surprises in Russia can hurt the mark because Germany is Russia's largest trading partner.

HEADLINE: A Missed Chance On Civil Rights

BYLINE: By Faye M. Anderson; Faye M. Anderson is president of the Douglass Policy Institute, an education and research group.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In spurning an invitation to address the N.A.A.C.P.'s annual convention last week, Bob Dole missed an opportunity to deliver an unfiltered message to African-American voters about his lifelong commitment to inclusion, fairness and equal opportunity for all Americans. As a policy adviser to the Dole campaign, I wish Republican strategists would stop running away from African-American voters.
I do not believe that Kweisi Mfume, the president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, was trying to "set up" Mr. Dole, as the Republican Presidential candidate initially thought. Invitations to address the group are routinely sent to candidates in election years. 
 On the contrary, I have no doubt that Mr. Dole could have connected with the delegates of the N.A.A.C.P., which was founded by, among others, W. E. B. DuBois, a Republican. Mr. Dole could have begun with a review of the pivotal role played by many Republicans in the passage of the seminal civil rights and voting rights legislation of the 1960's.
He could have spoken about his own civil rights record, which includes staving off attempts by some in the Reagan Administration to weaken President Nixon's executive order on affirmative action and securing passage of the bill establishing a Martin Luther King Jr. national holiday. Mr. Dole also supported the 1991 Civil Rights Act, which strengthened remedies for past discrimination.
He also could have talked about the meetings he held, starting in 1993, with Republican senators and African-American public policy experts to develop what his staff called a new "paradigm" for civil rights -- one that embraces issues like crime prevention, quality education and repeal of the Davis-Bacon Act, a legacy of the Jim Crow era. (The act requires contractors to pay "prevailing wages" on Federal construction projects, to the detriment of nonunion -- especially minority -- businesses.)
Mr. Dole could have set the record straight on the Equal Opportunity Act of 1995, which he introduced before leaving the Senate. The bill ended racial and sex preferences in Federal programs, but it also mandated vigorous enforcement of nondiscrimination laws and allowed private sector initiatives to recruit more minorities and women. (Congress has since scuttled the bill.)
In addition, at a time when Federal coffers are too depleted to help rebuild crumbling inner-city schools, Mr. Dole could have used the N.A.A.C.P. forum to state his opposition to a new form of corporate welfare: the giveaway of second, "transitional channels" to broadcasters rushing to switch to digital TV transmission. He could have called on his erstwhile Congressional colleagues to rescind their directive to give away these channel frequencies, whose worth at auction could reach $100 billion by some estimates. He could have shared his own notion: that public resources like airwaves should not be at the service of special interests.
That's some of what Mr. Dole could have said. He should now make it clear to the "blue suits" at campaign headquarters who apparently dismissed the N.A.A.C.P. invitation that one does not add to the party's base by subtracting. He should ask what objective was served by a decision that was certain to alienate African-American voters further and generate negative press coverage.
The blue suits, meanwhile, should consider this: The black voting-age population in the 13 must-win Southern states ranges from 11 percent in Florida to 32 percent in Mississippi, with most states in the more than 20 percent range. In Midwestern swing states, the black electorate is about 10 percent, large enough to determine the outcome of a close election.
Finally, Mr. Dole should find another way to speak directly to African-Americans about their concerns -- about economic security, safe streets and whether their children will be able to compete in the global economy. If campaign headquarters needs assistance in identifying an appropriate forum, well, I'm listed.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Bosnia Election Campaign Postponed Over Karadzic Issue

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, July 15

 BODY:
The Western diplomat in charge of overseeing the coming Bosnian elections today postponed the start of the campaign until Friday, to give the Bosnian Serbs a few more days to oust their political leader, Radovan Karadzic.
Robert H. Frowick, a retired American diplomat who is head of the Bosnia operation of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, said "it is my unalterable position" that any political party with officers that have been indicted on war crimes charges cannot participate in the elections. 
 The only party in that category is Dr. Karadzic's Serbian Democratic Party, which is about the only organized Bosnian Serb party with any significant following. Dr. Karadzic, who has been indicted by the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, has said he will not run as a candidate in the national elections scheduled for Sept. 14 -- something that would not be allowed in any case under the Dayton peace accords -- but he was recently re-elected as head of his party and continues to control the police and politics in the Serb-held part of Bosnia.
Mr. Frowick's move is the latest "ratcheting up," as officials here put it, of the diplomatic pressure on Mr. Karadzic to give up his political positions, if not turn himself in to the war crimes tribunal for trial.
On Tuesday, Richard C. Holbrooke, the American diplomat who pushed through the peace agreement last fall, is to arrive in the region and will try to pull off another coup: convincing the President of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic, that he must muscle Dr. Karadzic out, something no one so far has been able to persuade Mr. Milosevic to do. Mr. Holbrooke has left the Government but was specially recalled for the trip.
Beneath the public maneuvering, however, there is widespread pessimism after six months of trying to oust Dr. Karadzic that any political solution is attainable, and a growing belief that only military action will remove him from the scene.
At a news conference here on Sunday, France's Defense Minister, Charles Milion, said France planned to ask the United Nations Security Council to give the NATO forces in Bosnia a clearer mandate to arrest those indicted on charges of war crimes. But any joint action by NATO troops would require the assent of NATO's governing body, which many diplomats say is unlikely.
Under current orders, set by the United States and European powers in NATO, the forces in Bosnia are to arrest indicted war crimes suspects if they encounter them. But they are not supposed to seek them out, and military officers in the country say they fear that any action against Dr. Karadzic or Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb military leader who is also under international indictment, would provoke deadly retaliation.
While France is now the first major power to openly discuss the possibility of a military operation, there is no public indication that the French would be willing to act on their own.
Britain, which has been strongly opposed to a military action, is "rethinking," a senior European diplomat said. And Carl Bildt, the principal international negotiator in Bosnia, has also recently come to the conclusion that a "military snatch" of Mr. Karadzic is necessary, an official close to him said.
The Clinton Administration is divided on the issue. Some officials in the State Department strongly favor a military action, several American officials said in recent days. The Pentagon has said it is against such an operation because it would put American troops at risk.
But a few days ago, the commander of American forces in Bosnia, Gen. William L. Nash, in a meeting with Secretary of Commerce Mickey Kantor, said his troops had the ability to do the job.
"Give us the order, and we'll do it," General Nash said, according to people who were present.
Most important, President Clinton and White House officials, with an American presidential election coming in November, strongly want to avoid American casualties or a wholesale unraveling of the Bosnian peace effort -- clear risks of a military action.
Underscoring the potential risks, the police chief in Pale, the capital of the Bosnian Serb republic, has threatened wide reprisals against NATO troops and the United Nations police if there is an attempt to arrest Dr. Karadzic, a United Nations spokesman, Alex Ivanko, said here today.
Many diplomats are skeptical that the latest diplomatic efforts will succeed in removing Mr. Karadzic, because the weapons that the outside powers have -- or are willing to deploy -- do not match their polemics against Dr. Karadzic. Western countries have not shown the unanimity that would be required to reimpose stiff economic sanctions, for instance.
A senior European diplomat said he thought that Mr. Milosevic was "immune" to any pressure Mr. Holbrooke might bring.
If the West reimposes sanctions, Mr. Milosevic is likely to counter by withdrawing his support for the Dayton peace plan, this diplomat said.
In any event, the Clinton Administration is alone in favoring the reimposition of sanctions.
The so-called contact group on Bosnia is also divided over what to do about the elections. At the London meeting last week, only the United States and Germany backed the proposal of Mr. Frowick to keep the Serbian Democratic Party out of the election if Dr. Karadzic is still around. France had reservations, and the British even stronger ones, but they promised to keep them quiet, American and European diplomats said. The other member of the group, Russia, was largely quiet at the meeting but has previously said no new actions against Dr. Karadzic were necessary.
The British said an election with Dr. Karadzic still in power would be better than disqualifying his party because that would alienate most Serbs.
Asked if he thought the new diplomatic efforts to oust Dr. Karadzic would work, a Western diplomat said: "I don't, and I don't know who does. But Holbrooke has pulled some things out before that nobody ever, ever thought possible."

HEADLINE: Lester Robbins, 90, Who Built Row Houses for Public Housing

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Lester Robbins, a developer of tract housing in the United States after World War II who became a moving force in Brooklyn's highly praised Nehemiah Plan of the 1980's, died on Sunday at his home on Manhattan's Upper East Side. He was 90 and also lived in East Hampton, L.I., and Lantana, Fla.
One of the first builders of tract homes in New Jersey, Mr. Robbins also developed millions of square feet of industrial and commercial property around the country. His organization continues as the Robbins Agency of Union, N.J., which manages far-flung housing projects, shopping centers and office space. 
 In the Old Testament, the King of Persia sent Nehemiah to Jerusalem to rebuild it after the Baylonian Captivity, a tale that fired the imagination of Roman Catholic and Protestant church leaders in East Brooklyn as they contemplated blocks upon blocks of derelict, burned-out housing in Brownsville.
They banded together to raise financing and produce shelter in an area with a large black and Hispanic population and huge tracts of idle city-held land. The idea behind the Nehemiah Plan was that of I. D. Robbins, Lester Robbins's cousin, a civic-minded construction executive who died earlier this month.
He supervised the project and Lester Robbins was the builder. By then, in the 1980's, he had created more than 6,000 single-family homes in New York and New Jersey during 40 years.
The moving force behind the plan was the failure of many large postwar public-housing projects built in the inner cities for urban renewal. Instead, the vision was for affordable, low-density row houses, one to a family. Mr. Robbins finished 1,200 of them in the 1980's.
Born in St. Louis, the son of a dress manufacturer, he was brought to New York City at age 3. He received varsity letters in lacrosse and and football at Cornell, graduating in 1927 as a chemical engineering major.
He worked as a button jobber and helped his father build a sand-lime brick factory, the only experience in construction he brought to his first project. It was a 20-unit four-story walkup in Elmhurst, Queens, in 1936.
Small projects of that sort made for the experience he needed to bid on government housing for workers in war production, just when regular home building ground to a halt because of the draft and a shortage of materials. Mr. Robbins built hundreds of units in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and on Governors Island in New York Harbor.
After the war, he was ready for the building boom caused by returning veterans. He specialized in large-scale production of single-family dwellings and moderately priced garden apartments. He also gradually expanded Robbins Construction into housing for the elderly in New Jersey and commercial and industrial undertakings across the country.
As a philanthropist, he provided college scholarships for dozens of young people. Among his other beneficiaries were the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington and Thanks to Scandinavia, an American-supported organization honoring Scandinavian efforts to save Jews from the Holocaust in World War II.
Mr. Robbins is survived by his wife of 27 years, Sheila Johnson Robbins; two daughters, Marjorie Friedlander of Los Angeles and Ann Aknin of Dana Point, Calif.; two sons, David of Princeton, N.J., and Peter of Manhattan; two stepdaughters, Barbara Morgan of Parlin, N.J., and Meredith Hardy of Mercer Island, Wash.; a stepson, Thomas Hardy of Bethesda, Md., and a sister, Lucille Gruen of Delray Beach, Fla.; 10 grandchildren, 15 stepgrandchildren, 15 great-grandchildren, and 5 stepgreat-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: FINANCE BRIEFS

 BODY:

Capital One Bank, Falls Church, Va., is selling $200 million of senior bank notes due in 1999 through Lehman Brothers. The noncallable notes carry an interest rate of 7.2 percent and are priced at par. The issue is rated Baa3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and BBB- by the Standard & Poor's Corp.

Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $50 million of bonds due in 1999 through Bear, Stearns & Co. The bonds are callable quarterly beginning Oct. 29, 1996, carry an interest rate of 7.045 percent and are priced at par. 

Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $50 million of bonds due in 1999 through First Tennessee Bank. The bonds have a one-time call on July 30, 1997, carry an interest rate of 6.79 percent and are priced at par.

Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $25 million of bonds due in 2000 through Morgan Keegan & Co. Inc. The bonds are callable in six months, carry an interest rate of 7.12 percent and are priced at par.

Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., known as Freddie Mac, is selling $35 million of debentures due in 1999 through Nationsbanc Capital Markets. The noncallable debentures carry an interest rate of 6.54 percent and are priced at par.

Household Finance Corp., Prospect Heights, Ill., is selling $250 million of notes due in 2003 through J. P. Morgan Securities. The notes are priced at 99.985 to yield 7.253 percent. The issue is rated A2 by Moody's, A by S.& P. and A+ by Duff & Phelps.

Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is selling $50 million of medium-term step-up notes due in 2001 through Merrill Lynch & Co. The notes have a one-time call on July 30, 1997, and carry an initial interest rate of 6.4 percent. If the issue is not called, the coupon steps up to 7.75 percent and is priced at par.
