HEADLINE: Business Inventories Drop And Growth in Sales Eases

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
Business inventories fell in May even as companies reported a slowdown in sales growth for the month, Government figures showed today.
Business inventories decreased one-tenth of 1 percent in May to a seasonally adjusted $983.254 billion after rising four-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Commerce Department said. Business sales rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in May after rising a revised 1.1 percent in April. 
 The inventory-to-sales ratio, an indicator of how long it would take to sell the supply of goods available at the current pace, fell to 1.37 months' worth in May, its third consecutive monthly decline and the lowest level since the Government began keeping records in 1982.
While that suggests the economy should get a lift in the third quarter as business managers replenish stocks, many economists doubted that the inventory-buying would be large enough to have much of an effect on growth.
"Any buildup will be slow and cautious," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "They certainly don't want to repeat their 1995 experience, ending up with too much inventories."
A modest inventory accumulation would allay fears at the Federal Reserve that inflation is ready to erupt on the thrust of robust second-quarter growth. Analysts say the economy expanded at a 4 percent annual rate, or faster, in the April-June quarter, or nearly double the pace that the Fed sees as noninflationary.
Most economists, however, including those at the central bank, are forecasting slower growth in this year's second half.
The recent slowing of the growth in sales volume is evidence that the surge in economic growth during the spring "was a short-term phenomenon," said Erin Fossett, an economist with First Chicago NBD. "We're already seeing signs of things starting to slow down again."
Overall retail sales unexpectedly fell last month to their lowest level in almost a year, including a drop in sales in the interest-sensitive auto industry. And auto inventories rose two-tenths of 1 percent in May.
Corporate earnings reports have been disappointing as well, depressing the stock markets recently.
"All these things would indicate finally, finally the economic slowdown we've been all waiting for quite some time is beginning to unfold before us," Mr. Sohn of Norwest said. "In the third quarter we will see consumers spending less, and businesses probably not building much inventory at all."
By industry, inventories at retailers increased less than one-tenth of 1 percent in May. Inventories at wholesalers, which make up about one-fourth of the report, fell two-tenths of 1 percent during the month, and factory inventories, which account for almost half of the report, were down two-tenths of 1 percent.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Inventory-Sales Ratio" tracks total month-end business inventories divided by total monthly business sales, seasonally adjusted, from December 1994 through May 1996. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices for Treasuries Slip, Falling Late in the Session

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell yesterday for the first time in more than a week.
Some traders expected a slumping stock market to add weight to a perception that the economy is running out of steam. Bonds fell late in the day when a rout in stocks temporarily abated, traders said. 
 "If you were in the bond market because stocks were weak, stocks weren't weakening much further and it wasn't benefitting bonds much," said Tony Crescenzi, head of fixed-income trading at the Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company "You had less reason to hang on."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 14/32, to 86 21/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.07 percent, from 7.03 percent on Friday.
Concern that the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, will hint in Congressional testimony this week that there is reason to raise interest rates may have encouraged some bond investors to sell, Todd Speiser, a trader at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company in New York, said.
"Stocks have fallen appreciably in the last week or so, and supposedly some decent-sized investors bought bonds and sold stocks," Mr. Speiser said. "They may not want to ride it through" Mr. Greenspan's remarks, which could suggest the central bank is about to raise interest rates.
Even so, some investors and analysts say a worse threat for bonds would be an indecisive Fed that holds off raising rates to keep stocks from falling further.
"With economic reports continuing to come out on the strong side, they run the risk of being viewed by the markets as doing too little too late," said Anthony Karydakis, chief financial economist at First Chicago Capital Markets.
Traders and investors will gain more insight into the pace of inflation from the Labor Department's report today on June consumer prices. A survey of analysts said that the index probably climbed two-tenths of 1 percent, or three-tenths of 1 percent excluding the volatile food and energy sectors.
In yesterday's regular weekly auction, the Treasury sold $14.2 billion in new three-month bills and $14 billion in new six-month bills.
The average discount rate on the three-month bill was 5.19 percent, down from 5.21 percent last week, while the rate on the six-month bill was 5.36 percent, down from 5.41 percent.
In the corporate bond market, Lucent Technologies Inc. plans to sell $750 million each of 5- and 10-year notes this week to help pay off short-term debt it inherited when it separated from the AT&T Corporation earlier this year. The notes will be rated A2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the municipal bond market, New York postponed the sale of $76 million in bonds after lawmakers ratified the state's $66 billion budget, more than three months beyond its April 1 deadline.
Wall Street's credit-rating companies said the budget process, along with a dependence on about $500 million in one-time revenue measures could hurt New York's rating. Standard & Poor's may revise its outlook on the state's debt to stable from positive, reflecting the delay.
Following are yesterday's results of the Treasury's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Tomorrow, the World Wide Web!;
Microsoft, the PC King, Wants to Reign Over the Internet

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
As a captain of industry and the richest man in America, William H. Gates has often been compared to industrial titans of the past.
And just as the railroad tycoons of the 1800's set the gauge for the nation's railroad tracks, Mr. Gates's Microsoft Corporation seems intent, its critics say, on the modern-day equivalent: controlling many of the basic technical specifications of the global Internet. 
 The result could be a rapid end to the furious pace of entrepreneurial innovation that has marked the Internet in recent years, critics say, just as hegemony of Microsoft's Windows software has often been blamed for limiting technical innovation in personal computing.
Lately, there has been much publicity for Microsoft's new-found focus on the Internet, starting with a celebrated speech last December in which Mr. Gates said his company would cooperatively "embrace and extend" industrywide Internet technical standards. The public spotlight has focused on new software features and product release dates, as the company tries to catch up with Internet leaders -- like the Netscape Communications Corporation, maker of the Navigator browser for the World Wide Web, and Sun Microsystems Inc., whose Java software is designed to move computing power onto the network from the desktop -- that have been seen as the biggest threat in years to Microsoft.
But while these well-chronicled contests continue, far more meaningful skirmishes are occurring among little-known industry groups that set the arcane -- but crucial -- technical specifications that determine whether and how well various makes and models of hardware and software can work together on the Internet.
On this front, Microsoft may be in the best position to use its market power to influence technology's future. And it is a measure of Microsoft's intensity that one of these struggles has even placed the company at odds with its symbiotic hardware partner, the Intel Corporation.
Rather than merely embrace and extend the Internet, the company's critics now fear, Microsoft intends to engulf it.
Microsoft executives insist that the company intends to cooperate with Internet standards groups. But according to industry executives who have observed Microsoft's activities in these standards sessions, there is evidence that the company is attempting to employ the same sort of business practices that helped it rise to dominance in the personal computing industry -- and that have repeatedly drawn the scrutiny of Federal antitrust investigators.
Just as Microsoft did with PC technology, these executives fear, the company intends to subsume more and more of the Internet's basic technology in Windows.
Indeed, even while it works behind the scenes to shape future technical standards to its competitive advantage, Microsoft has begun to absorb into Windows various Internet capabilities -- like the company's Explorer browser for the World Wide Web and Front Page set of tools for creating Web pages. By offering such products as part of Windows, critics contend, Microsoft could wage an Internet war of attrition against rivals large and small -- whether ascendant powers like Netscape or established tool makers like Adobe Systems Inc., producer of Web-page designing software called Pagemill.
"There are societal consequences to Microsoft's strategy," said Gary Reback, a Silicon Valley lawyer who has battled Microsoft in court and before the Justice Department in recent years on behalf of a number of its competitors. "Here is a new technology and a whole new wave of commerce, and Microsoft wants to suck it in to the operating system to maintain its monopoly."
Microsoft insists that using the Windows vacuum cleaner as a way to suck away revenue from competitors is simply good business.
"Yes, that is our business strategy," said Paul Maritz, the executive vice president for the company's Internet business. "But not out of spite. What you're seeing here is competition, which is good and healthy. Now we have Netscape's Navigator and Sun's Javasoft as our new competitors."
Mr. Reback, though, has been trying to raise alarms with the Justice Department, which last year was intensely investigating the potential antitrust implications of Microsoft's placing an icon for its on-line Microsoft Network on the main screen of Windows 95.
Justice officials decline to comment, but as Microsoft has turned its focus from subscriber-based on-line services to the more open Internet and World Wide Web, the antitrust investigation has reportedly become moribund -- though it is not officially closed.
Not all legal experts, however, see an antitrust threat in Microsoft's Internet activities.
"Maybe it's not a polite way of doing business, but it's not Microsoft's responsibility to be polite," said William F. Baxter, a Stanford law professor who headed the Justice Department's antitrust division for three years in the Reagan Administration.
Still, many companies have grown wary of Microsoft's intentions since it set its sites on the Internet.
On Dec. 7, the same day that Mr. Gates was delivering his embrace and extend" speech at Microsoft headquarters in Redmond, Wash., a small group of software developers from Intel was meeting in Silicon Valley with Microsoft counterparts. The group was trying to hammer out details of a new technical standard designed to improve and streamline all aspects of computer security and privacy on the Internet, regardless of the brand of hardware or software used.
For five months, Intel had been quietly orchestrating this effort, which had the preliminary support of a group of influential companies that included Netscape and Sun Microsystems. Apple Computer Inc. was also considering coming aboard. But while Microsoft's commitment looked increasingly likely, it was still not certain.
Intel executives were encouraged by the Dec. 7 meeting, however, and they came away hoping to deliver a finished set of specifications at an industry technical conference the next month.
Only a week before the planned announcement, however, Microsoft shocked Intel: not only did the company abruptly pull out of the consortium -- it also said it planned to work against the group's efforts.
Intel executives decline to discuss the matter. But according to several people familiar with the meetings, Microsoft's rapidly evolving Internet strategy now regarded the specifications backed by Intel as a subset of the computer operating system. And the operating system, came the word from Redmond, was something that Microsoft "owned."
The tentative coalition became undone. Without Microsoft's support, the other members drifted away to try their luck with other Internet standards-setting groups. And while Intel would subsequently publish its security plan, the Common Data Security Architecture, on its corporate Web site (http://www.intel.com/iaweb/security/), today it goes largely unread, like a fading billboard on a side road nobody travels any more.
Significantly, late last month Microsoft posted its own version of a very similar document, called the Microsoft Internet Security Framework, on the company's Web site (http://www.microsoft.com/intdev/security/swpintro.htm), as early notification of the security and privacy specifications the company intends to place in future versions of Windows.
Microsoft executives insist that there was nothing duplicitous in the company's withdrawal from the Intel consortium. The company simply concluded that it would be better to pursue standards-setting within the established Internet committees, rather than ad hoc groups like Intel's, Mr. Maritz said.
"The bottom line on this is we decided to work through the Internet Engineering Task Force and World Wide Web Consortium," he said, referring to established Internet standards organizations.
Microsoft is still getting acculturated to these technical circles, which continue to reflect the Internet's roots in the computer-hacker culture of the 1960's and 70's that was based on an ethic of freely shared work.
"The jury is still out on Microsoft's intentions," said Jeffrey Schiller, a computer security expert at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who is chairman of the Internet Engineering Taskforce's working group on security issues.
But old habits, apparently, die hard. In a separate Internet standards forum, Microsoft earlier this year proposed a proprietary technology the company called Active V.R.M.L., or Virtual Reality Markup Language, to a small Internet group that is setting specifications for virtual reality systems on the Internet.
Mark Pesce, a San Francisco-based computer researcher who was co-inventor of the original version of V.R.M.L. technology, recalled that during the standards meetings Microsoft executives did not appear to be willing to compromise on technology ideas.
"Microsoft was not interested in half and half," Mr. Pesce said. "It was their way or else."
In May, the V.R.M.L. standards committee rejected the Microsoft proposal. But industry executives say the company is now trying to reposition Active V.R.M.L. as a technology for viewing multimedia images on the Web -- an approach that would compete head on with an increasingly popular technology called Shockwave, from Macromedia Inc., a leader in software tools used by multimedia developers.
Microsoft says it is just reacting to a competitive threat. But some legal experts say that if the company's activities have ever warranted Federal antitrust scrutiny, its rapid assault on the Internet would seem to raise many of the same questions.
"The hurdle the Government will have to get over is today they see Netscape with a commanding lead and all the hype around the growth of the Internet," said Garth Saloner, an economist at the Stanford Business School. "What will happen when they see that six or nine months down the road they've been run over, and at that point it is too late?"


GRAPHIC: For years, Microsoft has been able to pressure competitors and control the technical direction of the personal computer world by sucking key technologies into its Windows operating system, the software that runs more than 80 percent of the world's PC's. Now, critics say, Microsoft seems intent on aiming the same strategy at the Internet.

 GROUPWARE -- Net Meeting, which allows people to work collaboratively over a network as with Lotus Notes, will become a Windows feature later this year.
 WEB SERVER -- The new Internet Information Server in Windows NT competes head on with Website from O'Reilly & Associates.

HEADLINE: Despite Solid Profit Reports, Banking Stocks Edge Lower

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Nationsbank Corporation and other large banking companies reported solid gains in second-quarter earnings yesterday, meeting or beating expectations on Wall Street, but their stock prices edged lower on worries that rising interest rates would hurt profits down the road.
Nationsbank, the fifth-largest bank in the United States, said earnings grew 30 percent in the quarter. The First Chicago NBD Corporation said profits rose 9 percent, and the PNC Bank Corporation reported a 28 percent jump in earnings. 
 The companies cited strong loan growth, tight expense controls and acquisitions.
Nationsbank, based in Charlotte, N.C., said earnings grew to $605 million, or $2 a share, in the quarter, which ended on June 30, from $467 million, or $1.71 a share, in the comparable period last year. The earnings exceeded analysts' estimates of $1.96 a share, according to First Call, which tracks earnings forecasts.
The company cited strong growth in consumer loans and higher fees for mortgage servicing and investment banking.
First Chicago NBD said earnings rose to $361 million, or $1.10 a share, in the quarter from $331 million, or 99 cents a share, in the comparable quarter last year.
The company, based in Chicago, said interest income grew 16 percent, bolstered by growth in the credit card and regional banking businesses. Noninterest expense fell nearly 1 percent in the quarter.
First Chicago acquired NBD Bancorp of Detroit for about $5.1 billion in one of many large mergers in the industry last year.
PNC Bank said earnings rose to $248.1 million, or 72 cents a share, in the quarter, from $194 million, or 56 cents a share, last year.
Revenues rose on growth in asset management, brokerage and corporate finance businesses, PNC's chief executive, Thomas H. O'Brien, said in a statement.
The company, based in Pittsburgh, said loan growth and the acquisition of the New Jersey operations of Chemical Bank last year increased interest income. PNC Bank also acquired the Midlantic Corporation of Edison, N.J., late last year.
While the earnings generally met or surpassed expectations, investors have grown nervous because an increase in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve would raise the cost of funds for banks and make borrowers more tight-fisted, hurting bank profits.
A surprisingly strong June employment report early this month convinced some investors the Fed would raise short-term rates by the end of August to keep a lid on inflation.
After the employment report, Merrill Lynch & Company lowered its ratings on several banking companies, sending their stocks sharply lower last week.
Indeed, bank stocks fell yesterday, amid a broad market selloff. Shares of Nationsbank dropped $1, to $79.25; shares of First Chicago slid $1, to $38.125, and PNC shares fell 75 cents, to $28.75.
But not all analysts agree that higher rates will hurt bank earnings. Some said higher rates should not be a concern for many banks and that some regional banks would even prosper, because loan demand was likely to remain brisk.
Among other smaller banking companies reporting earnings, Boatmen's Bancshares Inc. of St. Louis said earnings grew 14 percent, to $146 million, or 92 cents a share, from $128 million, or 80 cents a share, in the comparable 1995 quarter.
"Consistent revenue growth and effective expense control have allowed us to generate attractive year-to-year earnings increases," Andrew Craig 3d, the company's chairman, said in a statement.
Analysts had expected Boatmen's to earn about 91 cents a share in the quarter, according to First Call.
The Norwest Corporation of Minneapolis said earnings rose 22 percent in the quarter, to $285.4 million, or 76 cents a share, from $234.3 million, or 68 cents, last year. The results, which matched Wall Street's expectations, were bolstered by increased fees from its lending business, the company said.

HEADLINE: Pataki Allies To Give Data On Donations

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 15

 BODY:
A State Supreme Court justice today ordered fund-raisers for Gov. George E. Pataki's inauguration and transition to release their financial records, and after 18 months of resisting such demands, the Governor's supporters said they would comply within 40 days.
The Governor, through his aides, initially promised to make the records public when the two funds were established in late 1994 to finance his elaborate inauguration and transition. But the Pataki administration later reversed itself, and the officials who managed the two funds waged a court battle to block efforts by the Democratic-led Assembly to subpoena the records. 
 Today, Justice Joseph Harris in Albany ruled that the Assembly was within its rights to issue the subpoenas and ordered the two funds to release the names of contributors and the amounts of their contributions, as well as information about how the money was spent. Administration officials have said the funds raised $1 million, but the Democrats contend that the total was closer to $1.4 million.
The release of the records is expected to help answer some of the questions Democrats have raised, including these:
Who were the major contributors and did they receive preferential treatment from the administration? How much off-the-books money was taken from the funds and given to senior administration officials for their work on the inauguration and during the transition? Was there any surplus after expenses were paid, and was any of it used for political purposes, like paying off the Governor's campaign debts?
When Mr. Pataki's aides formed the two corporations that managed the transition and inauguration funds shortly after his election, they promised to voluntarily abide by state election laws that limit the size of donations and require detailed public disclosure about contributions and expenses.
But an inquiry by The New York Times in November showed that many lobbyists and corporations that are regulated by the state contributed to the funds, some of them giving more than what would be allowed under state campaign finance laws. When asked for the funds' financial records, Mr. Pataki's aides and the funds' officials refused.
The Assembly Democrats, who began investigating the funds in December, have contended that the corporations may have spent only half of their money on the inauguration and transition and used some of the rest to pay off Mr. Pataki's campaign debts. Mr. Pataki has denied that any money was used for campaign debts, which would violate campaign finance laws.
The Assembly Democrats said they planned to use the financial records as the basis for public hearings into the funds' activities, possibly during the fall elections. The Democrats are developing legislation that would restrict the activities of private corporations that raise money for elected officials' inaugurations and transitions.
The Democrats called Justice Harris's decision a clear victory, saying it had pried open the activities of two corporations that may have conducted secret political work for Republicans.
"The issue has always been who contributes and how was the money spent," said Assemblyman Paul A. Tokasz, a Buffalo-area Democrat who is chairman of the Assembly Election Law Committee. "This will help the Election Law Committee determine whether inaugurals and transitions should be governed by the election law."
But the Governor's aides and lawyers for the inaugural and transition funds also claimed victory, saying that Justice Harris's ruling did not require the funds to release all of their internal documents, including things like contracts, as the Assembly had demanded.
They also noted that the ruling did not allow the Assembly to force the funds' officers to testify at public hearings. One of the people subpoenaed by the Assembly to testify was Charles A. Gargano, who was chairman of Mr. Pataki's inaugural committee and is now state Commissioner of Economic Development.
In his decision, Justice Harris, a Democrat, wrote that it was legitimate for the Assembly to investigate the "political impact" of the two funds. But he said that the demands for records were too broad and would breach the funds' right to privacy. The funds were established as private, for-profit corporations.
The decision, he wrote, provides a balance that "allows the Legislature to fulfill its proper role without permitting an unnecessary political feeding frenzy."
H. Neal Conolly, the lawyer for Mr. Gargano and for Lawrence Kalkstein, who was an official of the corporations and holds their records, said that Mr. Kalkstein did not want to continue a court fight that could further embarrass the Governor.
Mr. Conolly said that Mr. Kalkstein, an accountant who worked on Mr. Pataki's campaign, decided not to appeal the judge's ruling, and that the Governor's office was not involved in the decision.
"It was the decision of our client that we had made our point, and in the end we are hurting the administration by not releasing the information," Mr. Conolly said.
Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's director of communications, said the Governor supported the decision not to appeal. "The judge said what we had said, which is that this is a political witch hunt," she maintained.

HEADLINE: Dole's Sagging Campaign Affects G.O.P. Morale, Poll Finds

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
Former Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign has stumbled so badly that 7 in 10 Americans -- and nearly half of those who say they plan to vote for Mr. Dole in November -- expect him to lose to President Clinton.
That is one of the more intriguing findings of a new New York Times/CBS News Poll, taken last Thursday, Friday and Saturday. It suggests that Mr. Dole's persistent troubles are beginning to affect morale in his party. A total of 979 people, 743 of them registered voters, were interviewed for the survey, which had a sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. 
 If large numbers of Republicans become convinced that Mr. Dole has no chance, many might stay home, hurting the party's chances in contests for the House and Senate.
As it is, the poll showed, 44 percent of all voters would choose a Democratic candidate if the election were held now, compared with 41 percent who would choose a Republican. That indicates a close contest for control of the House, which the Republicans seized in the 1994 off-year elections.
The poll had almost nothing but good news for Mr. Clinton. It showed him running 20 percentage points ahead of Mr. Dole, 54 to 34, in a two-way race, and 22 percentage points ahead of the Republican when Ross Perot was included as the nominee of his Reform Party. The figures in the latter case were 49 percent for the President, 27 percent for Mr. Dole and 16 percent for Mr. Perot.
Mr. Perot took 19 percent of the vote four years ago. He has been relatively inactive lately, until his semiannouncement last week, but it appears that he is within striking distance of his old level of support.
In the same week the poll was being taken, Richard D. Lamm, the former Governor of Colorado, said he would seek the Reform Party nomination. If Mr. Lamm beat Mr. Perot, which is considered highly unlikely, the poll indicated that he would hurt Mr. Clinton more than Mr. Dole. With Mr. Lamm, a Democrat, in the race, the figures were 49 percent for the President, 34 percent for Mr. Dole and 5 percent for Mr. Lamm.
For the first time since he took office, Mr. Clinton's handling of the economy was rated favorably by more than half of the public; 51 percent said they approved of his performance in this area, a crucial element in Presidential elections in the past, and 38 percent said they disapproved, with 11 percent expressing no view.
However, more people said the economy was getting worse (27 percent) than said it was getting better (16 percent). Should the stock market continue to slide, as it has in recent days, that perception could deepen and start to undermine the Clinton campaign.
Hillary Rodham Clinton's standing with the public is another potential danger point for the currently high-flying President. Only 30 percent of the public in the latest Times/CBS Poll holds a favorable impression of the First Lady.
Presumably, Mrs. Clinton's standing has been hurt by recent disclosures in the Whitewater affair and associated matters. But such issues do not appear to be deciding the votes of very many people, even though Mr. Clinton gets very poor ratings for honesty and integrity compared with Mr. Dole and even though more than one-third of all respondents (36 percent) said they believed the Clintons "did something wrong in connection with Whitewater."
Almost two-thirds of those questioned (61 percent) said they thought that Congressional hearings into the Whitewater affair conducted by the Republicans were "mostly a partisan attempt" to damage the Administration.
Asked which former President, living or dead, they would like to have running the country today, most citizens chose not Franklin D. Roosevelt or Abraham Lincoln, as might have been expected, but two more recent Chief Executives. John F. Kennedy was named by 28 percent and Ronald Reagan was the choice of 13 percent.

HEADLINE: THE OTHER DOLE -- A special report.;
Elizabeth Dole Is Eager To Keep Strength Subtle

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
The men and women running Bob Dole's Presidential campaign are happy to tell people what Elizabeth Dole is not. She is not, they say, Hillary Clinton, and she would not be an unelected policy maker as First Lady.
But recent interviews suggest that Mrs. Dole is in fact operating very much like Mrs. Clinton, and that the difference is one of semantics. The same senior advisers who characterize Mrs. Dole as "not Mrs. Clinton" readily admit that Mrs. Dole is her husband's closest adviser, with influence over policy and staff. They also call her the candidate's "chief surrogate," one who campaigns six days a week, mostly without Mr. Dole, to raise money and strengthen his support among groups like women and the Christian right. 
 Indeed, Mrs. Dole's life -- from the debutante cotillions of her Southern girlhood to her rise in Washington to her speeches spreading her evangelical Christian faith -- is the story of a woman whose beguiling charms have overshadowed her drive, discipline and pursuit of power.
Even Mrs. Dole describes herself as a spouse who sounds much like Mrs. Clinton in private, if not in public.
"I'm not in the staff meetings," Mrs. Dole said in a one-hour interview at Dole headquarters in Washington. "But certainly in terms of my relationship with my husband, getting in touch with the road, with Scott Reed, with Don Rumsfeld, with Steve Merrill, saying, 'I think we ought to do this or that,' or 'I'm seeing this or that' -- that's going on quite often." (Mr. Reed is the campaign's manager, Mr. Rumsfeld is a former Secretary of Defense and now a senior campaign adviser, and Mr. Merrill is the Governor of New Hampshire and the campaign's general chairman.)
It was Mrs. Dole, a senior campaign aide says, who insisted that the campaign hire a speech coach for her husband this spring. It was Mrs. Dole, the same aide says, who made sure that Mr. Dole's anti-crime address in Colorado in May included language that treated crime as a women's issue. It is Mrs. Dole whose suggestions on strategy and constant requests for background material irritate campaign aides and, the aides say, sometimes the candidate himself.
Mrs. Dole, who turns 60 on Saturday, dismisses as "crazy" the reports, most recently in the book "The Choice" by Bob Woodward, that Mr. Dole waited two weeks before telling her he wanted to resign from the Senate.
"We were right there together the whole time on this," she said. "And I was raising questions, and I wanted to be certain that he'd thought through every aspect." Mrs. Dole said the couple first talked about Mr. Dole's June 11 resignation during a Florida vacation in early April. Only afterward, she said, did they bring in Mr. Reed and then Haley Barbour, the Republican Party chairman.
Mrs. Dole receives the same written recommendations on strategy from the campaign that her husband does, and, like him, comes back to the staff with thoughts. But some aides to Mr. Dole point out that giving advice is not the same as having it taken, and they say Mrs. Dole is not always listened to. Mr. Dole, whose resistance to being "handled" is already legendary, himself suggested as much in an interview recently when he said that his wife had good political instincts "most of the time," adding, "She may have them all the time, but I don't accept them always."
That dynamic was on display two weeks ago when, in an interview on NBC's "Today" program to promote the re-issue of the Doles' joint autobiography, "Unlimited Partners," Mrs. Dole sat by helplessly while her husband snapped at Katie Couric, the interviewer, over nicotine and liberal bias in the media. "Let's talk about the book," Mrs. Dole cheerily interrupted. Her husband ignored her.
Mrs. Dole has been a Federal Trade Commissioner, Secretary of Transportation under President Ronald Reagan and Secretary of Labor under President George Bush. She is now on leave as president of the American Red Cross, where she oversees a $1.8 billion annual budget, 32,000 employees and 1.4 million volunteers.
While the Dole campaign is eager to remind voters that Mr. Dole is married to an unusually accomplished woman, one who in the words of the Dole pollster Tony Fabrizio puts a "very good face" on the campaign, strategists are fearful of alienating voters who might see Mrs. Dole as some see Mrs. Clinton -- a behind-the-scenes meddler with unchecked powers. But Mrs. Dole, who says she will return to the Red Cross whether or not her husband wins in November -- she dismisses critics who see a conflict of interest -- draws sharp distinctions between herself and Mrs. Clinton.
"I wouldn't have taken on 7 percent of the gross domestic product," she said, referring to Mrs. Clinton's effort to overhaul the nation's health-care system. "You're not elected, you're not confirmed by the Senate, and you've got one of the most volatile, high-visibility issues."
Mr. Dole himself so often says what his wife would not do as First Lady that at times he sounds as if he is belittling her. "When I'm elected, she will not be in charge of health care," he told a crowd in California last month. "Don't worry about it. Or in charge of anything else." When the crowd fell into an awkward silence at that last remark, Mr. Dole tried to recover. "I didn't say that," he said.
Although Mrs. Dole has been mentioned in the past as a possible Republican Vice-Presidential candidate -- even her husband says she is a better campaigner than he is -- she now adamantly denies any political ambitions, and aides say she is not using her current travels to build a network of her own for a future race. Mrs. Dole said that she merely wanted to be a good First Lady and that her project in the White House would be to increase charitable giving in the United States. As the first Presidential spouse to have a paying job, she said, she would leave state dinner menus and other traditional First Lady chores to her staff.
Mrs. Clinton, she said, has not set an example for her.
"I don't think she set a precedent," Mrs. Dole said. "I don't think each First Lady coming after her has to do what she has done. I wouldn't."

Her Character
Perfectionism And Restraint
By 11 on an overcast California morning, the women were already in line for lunch and a look at Mrs. Dole, on day five of a solo six-day swing to let the state know that her husband had not given it up. (Polls show President Clinton is far ahead of Mr. Dole in California.) When Mrs. Dole arrived at the lunch in Montecito two hours later, in a bright-red First Lady-like suit, with lipstick and nails to match, she quickly established herself as a natural campaigner conscious of the delicate balance she must strike as an independent woman and a political spouse.
"This morning I was asked if my husband and I ever have any difference of views on issues," Mrs. Dole began, coyly, in remarks to the 700-plus crowd at the Channel City Club. She went on to relate an often-told story about the time she and Mr. Dole debated each other over the creation of a consumer protection agency -- he against, she in favor -- on a morning news program.
"Now halfway through, my husband said, 'Elizabeth, you know I'd really like to say something if I could get a word in here somewhere,' " Mrs. Dole recounted, laughing. "And I said, 'Bob! I have not made my point yet!' And I kept right on going. I just ignored this guy, you know?"
The line got a big laugh as Mrs. Dole moved into the crowd, Phil Donahue-style, a body microphone clipped to her suit. "You think I can walk right down here?" she asked in her musical North Carolina drawl. Her tone was buttery as she spoke without notes, and her manners those of the old South -- a package the audience seemed to find captivating and unthreatening.
Four times in the last 20 years, Mrs. Dole has either quit or taken leave from powerful jobs to help along her husband's White House ambitions, first in 1976 when Mr. Dole was Gerald Ford's running mate, and then in 1980 and 1988 when he unsuccessfully pursued the Republican Presidential nomination. This year, as the presumed Republican nominee, Mr. Dole is closer than he has ever been to becoming President, although polls still show him well behind Mr. Clinton.
Whatever adjustments Mrs. Dole has had to make in sublimating her career, whatever resentments she may harbor, are not publicly evident in this campaign. In 1987, when she resigned as Secretary of Transportation to campaign for her husband, the press speculated that she was annoyed. This time, Mrs. Dole said that "it's a privilege for me to support him," and when pressed by a reporter about why she herself was not a candidate, lost patience. "Why don't you want to be?" she asked.
Mrs. Dole, her friend Jenna Dorn says, is far more complicated than her press suggests. Childhood friends describe her as intensely loyal, almost saintlike, a deeply religious woman who once treated a high school classmate and her family to an all-expenses-paid weekend in Washington after learning that her friend had cancer. Later, she paid for half of the classmate's chemotherapy. The same friends say Mrs. Dole has a sense of humor and can have fun; Roy Clason, her spokesman at the Red Cross, said she was once ahead of schedule in Minneapolis and insisted they stop for 25 minutes at an amusement park to ride the roller coaster.
But such moments of spontaneity are rare. Mrs. Dole in fact describes herself as a workaholic and a perfectionist who prepares prodigiously for every public moment of her life. "There are very few things that she takes lightly," said John Heubusch, who worked for her at the Labor Department and the Red Cross. Moments before her wedding, Mrs. Dole was still studying her marriage vows, according to a biography for middle-school readers by Carolyn Mulford. Mrs. Dole continues to wake up in the early morning and make lists, as she has done, she said, "on and off, most of my adult life."
In interviews Mrs. Dole is gracious but often stiff, and gets uneasy when she has to veer from her prepared answers. For example, in her speeches, Mrs. Dole calls the Red Cross a "mission field" and says, "It is not what I do that matters, but what a sovereign God chooses to do through me." But when asked if she thinks her Red Cross work is willed by God, she hesitated.
"I'm not sure," she said. "I've never really talked about all of this in great depth. I'm not sure. . . ." She stopped.
She wasn't sure where her interviewer was going with the question?
"Well, I'm not sure where I'm going," she said.
Unlike Mrs. Clinton, who was born only 11 years later but came of age in a feminist era, Mrs. Dole has never been comfortable with confrontation. Indeed, as power changed hands during Mrs. Dole's 30 years in Washington, she quietly switched her allegiance, from registered Democrat in the Lyndon B. Johnson Administration to independent under Richard M. Nixon to Republican when she married Mr. Dole.
And if her silken manners have served her well in a town as traditional as the nation's capital, where she never appeared to want the jobs she worked so hard to get, they have also made some people see her as artificial, or at least caused them to wonder what is really underneath. "I don't think anybody really knows her well," said Mrs. Dole's Harvard Law School roommate, Jean Eberhart Dubofsky, now a lawyer in Colorado.
Mrs. Dole's composure is broken only on rare occasions, as when Lesley Stahl on the CBS news program "60 Minutes" inadvertently called her by her childhood nickname, "Liddy."
"Elizabeth, Lesley," Mrs. Dole corrected on camera, visibly irritated.
Mrs. Dole's family and hometown friends from North Carolina still call her Liddy, but Mrs. Dole has worked hard, with limited success, to shed this bit of her past. When she left North Carolina and went north in the 1960's, the name stayed behind, at least until her husband's Presidential campaigns, when reporters from all over the country descended on her hometown of Salisbury and, to her great annoyance, heard "Liddy" everywhere. Elizabeth, she said ruefully, was gone overnight.
"Elizabeth is my preference," Mrs. Dole said. "I think it's a beautiful name. I love the name. It's just a normal, natural thing. If you like your name, you might like to be called it at some point in your life."

Her Faith
A Shift of Focus To Fill a Void
The most important event of Mrs. Dole's life in the last 15 years -- and one that has become politically crucial to her husband's campaign -- is what she calls her spiritual reawakening. Although she had been raised a devout Methodist, she said that by 1981, when she took a hard look at herself, she saw a woman tyrannized by her own perfectionism. "The career had become so all-consuming," she said. At the time, she was working 12-hour days and seven-day weeks in the Reagan White House. She was 45 years old, married for five years to a busy Senator, and childless.
"It was just a feeling that there's something missing here," she said, although she and her family say the void had nothing to do with not having children. "It would have been wonderful if it had happened," Mrs. Dole said. "We did marry later in life, and I think that's just clearly the answer. We just weren't, you know, 22. I was almost 40, and Bob was 53. So you're realistic."
Whatever the roots of her crisis, Mrs. Dole reached out to the Rev. Edward Bauman, then her minister at Foundry Methodist Church in Washington, who helped her join a prayer group. Mrs. Dole also called an old friend, Charles W. Colson, the former White House special counsel convicted for his role in the Watergate cover-up, now chairman of Prison Fellowship Ministries. Mr. Colson put Mrs. Dole in touch with Arthur Lindsley, a scholar at the C. S. Lewis Institute, a lay theological training center in Reston, Va. "The idea there was to focus on the intellectual underpinnings of your faith," Mrs. Dole said. She began to read the Bible for at least 30 minutes each day, and for the first time in years took Sundays off.
Mrs. Dole attended the prayer group until 1984 and, according to the biography by Ms. Mulford, went so far as to discuss with the members her offer from the White House to become Secretary of Transportation. "I have never met anyone who is quite so disciplined and focused in trying to live her faith," said Ms. Dorn, who met Mrs. Dole in the prayer group and is now a senior vice president at the Red Cross.
Although Mrs. Dole kept her religion private, a turning point came in 1987 when, in evangelical parlance, she "gave witness" at the National Prayer Breakfast in Washington. Or, as she defines the term, "you explain what Christ has meant in your life." In that speech Mrs. Dole told the story of Esther, the Old Testament heroine who in risking her life to save the Jews chose faith and commitment over privilege and power. Esther, Mrs. Dole said in her speech, "has taken on great significance for me."
Mrs. Dole went on to tell the 3,000 prayer breakfast guests, including President Reagan, that she once "had God neatly compartmentalized, crammed into a crowded file drawer of my life, somewhere between 'gardening' and 'government.' " But she realized, she said, that it was "time to submit my resignation as master of my own little universe, and God accepted my resignation."
Although evangelicals would recognize Mrs. Dole's language as a description of a born-again experience, in the interview she shied away from the terminology. "Labels I think don't help," she said. "I'm a follower of Christ."
She added: "As you read the Bible, you see God's will in many places. It's a great guide for your life when you really get into it. I guess the bottom line for me is that I don't think I'm in this alone. I feel there is a source of strength beyond myself. I can call on God for wisdom. I try to think before something major is coming up to ask for His help."
In her speeches, Mrs. Dole speaks of the horrors she has seen in her travels for the Red Cross, particularly in Goma, Zaire, where in 1994 one million refugees from the ethnic war in neighboring Rwanda crossed over the border. She was, she says, "stepping over dead bodies." In "Unlimited Partners" Mrs. Dole tells of the time she gave camel's milk to a starving Somalian boy, and put her arm around his back. "The feeling of the little bones almost piercing through his flesh is something I will never forget," she recounts. Mrs. Dole says she cannot explain why God has allowed such things to happen.
"I just know my personal faith," she said. "Some questions really are a matter of mystery."
Since 1987, Mrs. Dole has spoken regularly to religious groups. She is a favorite of the Christian conservatives who do not trust her husband, particularly since he has distanced himself from the most vocal opponents of abortion. Religious conservatives are a vital part of Mr. Dole's support, and he cannot win the election without them.
Last October, Mrs. Dole appeared on the "Hour of Power" religious program of the television evangelist Robert Schuller, broadcast from the Crystal Cathedral in Anaheim, Calif. Mrs. Dole appealed for both money and blood donations to the Red Cross, then read a Psalm from the Bible.

Her Background
A Mix of Gentility And Achievement
Mrs. Dole grew up in a small Southern world of white gloves and petit fours, a princess of the landed gentry in Salisbury. Her father, John Van Hanford, was a successful flower wholesaler in the city of 25,000 deep within the Bible Belt. Her mother, Mary Hanford, belonged to the Daughters of the American Revolution. Elizabeth, born 13 years after her brother, John, was raised in a spacious tudor house on South Fulton Street. There was a spiral staircase in the front hall, an overgrown magnolia in the yard, and nursemaids to help with the children.
Mrs. Dole describes her childhood as idyllic. At the very least, it was well documented, as a visit to Mrs. Dole's 95-year-old mother in Salisbury proves. "Elizabeth began omitting her 2 A.M. bottle at 3 months of age," Mrs. Hanford wrote in the first of some 20 scrapbooks detailing every piano recital and Cabinet appointment of her daughter's six decades.
"I don't think I had much to do," said Mrs. Hanford, amused.
By 1945, the society page of The Salisbury Post was chronicling Liddy Hanford's ninth birthday party, with its 40 guests. "She wore a crisp frock of yellow dotted Swiss," the paper reported. "The birthday cake was arranged on a glass and wrought-iron table on the screened porch. About it were gardenias and yellow rosebuds."
At the time of her high school graduation, "Likable Liddy" was voted "Most Likely to Succeed," which surprised no one. "She was very, very bright, and she was very, very focused," said Betty Dan Spencer, a childhood friend. "We used to tease that she would be the first woman President."
Mrs. Dole went on to Duke University, was a debutante in Raleigh and in her senior year was elected both May Queen and Leader of the Year. Her scrapbooks -- which she was by now keeping herself -- also reveal a woman, however absorbed by her own paper trail, who was vulnerable to everyday anxieties. "Fred Sheheen called," says one note in the scrapbook, apparently scrawled in haste by a roommate. "Will call back, but if he doesn't, don't get in a panic."
But Mrs. Dole, unlike most of her friends, was not ready to settle down after graduation. "The young man I was pinned to started talking about getting married, and my reaction was, 'I'm too young, I've got all these things to do,' " she said. It was 1958, and she knew her choice was either a husband or a career, not both.
Mrs. Dole eventually went on to Harvard Law School, one of two dozen women in a class of 550. She graduated in 1965, headed for Washington -- a city, she has said, that attracted her "like a magnet" -- and by 1968 had a job in the office of Betty Furness, President Johnson's crusading consumer advocate.
When Mr. Nixon became President, he replaced Mrs. Furness with Virginia Knauer. Mrs. Dole not only survived the transition, but she also quickly became a favorite of her new boss. "I could count on her implicitly," Mrs. Knauer said. By 1973, Mrs. Knauer saw to it that Mrs. Dole was nominated for a spot on the Federal Trade Commission. A year earlier she had taken her protegee to a Pennsylvania Avenue sidewalk and introduced her to the newly divorced Senator from Kansas, Bob Dole, who as chairman of the Republican Party was opening a local headquarters.
"They sort of looked each other over," Mrs. Knauer said. Later, a piece of legislation gave Mrs. Knauer's protegee an excuse to reacquaint herself. "She said, 'Virginia, I think you should brief the Senator on this,' " Mrs. Knauer recalled. "Well, I knew Elizabeth pretty well -- and I could tell she wanted to get a second look."
The two were married in 1975 at Washington's National Cathedral. "I waited for the man I loved," Mrs. Dole said. By 1981, Mrs. Dole was running the White House Office of Public Liaison, where she fielded the complaints of interest groups -- women, blacks, veterans, farmers -- but found few men in the White House willing to listen to their concerns, or to her.
"She just had difficulty breaking into the inner circle," said her deputy at the time, Red Cavaney. Feminists were angry that Mrs. Dole did not support the Equal Rights Amendment, as she once had, but instead promoted Reagan alternatives. By 1983, when the Administration was worried about Mr. Reagan's weak support among women, the White House decided to promote Mrs. Dole to a far more visible job, Secretary of Transportation.
Over the next five years, Mrs. Dole oversaw the privatization of Conrail, made rear-window brake lights standard equipment in automobiles, and through a scheme that pitted the insurance industry against automobile manufacturers -- both praised and criticized for its political maneuverings -- eventually got credit for requiring airbags in cars.
Mrs. Dole became Secretary of Labor in 1989, and she was widely praised for intervening to settle the United Mine Workers strike against the Pittson Coal Company.
Mrs. Dole always mentions her work at the Red Cross in her campaign speeches, as she did in Montecito. Afterward, she invited the crowd to come up and "visit" a little with her at the dais.
"You should be Vice President," one woman said to her, echoing the others. "They're looking too hard."

HEADLINE: Dole Names Keynote Speaker And Sends Message to Women

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
Bob Dole said tonight that Representative Susan Molinari, a Staten Island Republican who supports abortion rights, would be the keynote speaker at the Republican National Convention in August.
The Dole campaign had worked out in advance that Mr. Dole, the likely Republican Presidential nominee, would announce his choice of Ms. Molinari, the mother of a 2-month-old daughter and wife of Representative Bill Paxon of Buffalo, on CNN's "Larry King Live." But apparently no one had informed Ms. Molinari, and she gushed breathlessly from a restaurant in Buffalo when CNN tracked her down. 
 "She's dynamic, she's young, she's bright, she's articulate, she'll bring the Republican message all across the nation," Mr. Dole said, noting that the Republicans were not a "one-issue party."
Mr. Dole said the selection made a "big statement," both about abortion, an issue that has been bedeviling his campaign, and about women. Polls have shown his candidacy to be suffering from a gender gap, in which the vast majority of women have indicated a preference for President Clinton over Mr. Dole.
The candidate's wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole, sat at his side and helped make that case, demonstrating that Mr. Dole can be comfortable with strong and independent women. Mr. King seemed to treat her as a spokesman for her husband, and Mrs. Dole frequently answered questions that are usually directed to a candidate, such as when Mr. King asked whether the campaign had communicated its messages.
"Oh, my goodness," she replied, going on to list tax cuts and letting families keep more of their income instead of "sending it off to the Government."
Mr. Dole appeared on the program as his poll ratings remain weak, although he insisted that the race was much closer than the 20 points that most national surveys suggest.
He also said that he had contacted Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania about possibly being his running mate, but averred that he had no real list from which he was working. Asked if he had any women under consideration, he hesitated, then said: "Yes, obviously," and joked later that he might ask his wife.
He said he expected to deliver his economic package by the end of this month. He told Mr. King that it would have "10 facets," one of which would involve tax cuts.
He also indicated that he regretted not having accepted an invitation earlier this month to speak at the N.A.A.C.P. convention. But he said he might meet with the group's board of directors and was arranging to speak with a group of black journalists.
A string of verbal stumbles has put Mr. Dole on the political defensive lately, and Mr. King asked if he would admit to any mistakes.
"I made enough of them during the last few weeks to last through a month or two," he said, adding: "But I like to get them out of the way -- you got any other mistakes I can make?"
Despite his political woes, Mr. Dole appeared relaxed and good-humored.
Mr. Dole made the announcement about Ms. Molinari without first informing her. "Maybe I should call her during the break," Mr. Dole mused on the air. CNN workers then tracked down Ms. Molinari at a Buffalo restaurant, and before the program was over, Ms. Molinari was on the line effusively thanking Mr. Dole and promising that she would "check and double-check" her speech in advance "with Mrs. Dole and Bob Dole."
Mr. Dole used the Molinari announcement as a stepping-off point to talk about his record of appointing women. "Keep in mind," he said, "I appointed the first woman secretary of the senate in the history of the Senate, the first chief of staff was a woman in my organization. I've been living with a Cabinet member."
When Mr. King asked the candidate if he were a "feminist," Mrs. Dole replied, "He is a strong supporter of women."
Another moment illustrated the dynamic between the Doles. When Mr. King was talking about trust and Mr. Dole said, "I just have to lay out my case," there was chatter all around before he concluded, "And she can do it better than I can." Mrs. Dole was holding up a finger, indicating she wanted to speak, and Mr. King said, "Go ahead, Elizabeth."
"I've got one more thing I want to say," she began, "and that is that I think that, clearly, trust is so key."
Mr. King asked her about her previously announced plans to go back to work as President of the American Red Cross even if Mr. Dole is elected. She confirmed that plan.
"I'll be a supportive spouse," she added, "a supportive spouse, because this is the most difficult, challenging job in the world, and that's when Bob will need my love and support more than ever. So as with spouses all across America, I'm going to be a supportive helpmate."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Rout in Stocks Continues, With Every Sector Hit
Few investors or companies avoided the carnage on Wall Street as shares of every sort of company, big and small, high technology and low, fell sharply. Technology stocks suffered the most, with the Nasdaq composite index falling 3.92 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 161.05 points, or 2.9 percent, to 5,349.51. [Page A1.]
 
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell slightly to 86 21/32, and its yield rose to 7.07 percent, from 7.03 percent on Friday. [D18.]
 
New World of News, Same Glitches
Even as NBC and Microsoft heralded their MSNBC cable-television and Internet service as a new world of news delivery, MSNBC fell victim to old-world glitches. [D6.]
 
Tight Money Slows Chinese Inflation
After three years of tight monetary policy, China has sharply cut inflation without slowing the robust growth rate of its economy. [D7.]
 
Coca-Cola Profits Rise 17%
Coca-Cola profits rose 17 percent in the second quarter, as sales increased abroad. [D2.]
 
Earnings Up for 3 Bank Companies
Nationsbank, First Chicago and PNC Bank reported solid earnings gains. [D4.]
 
Archer Critics Set Back in Court
Under a ruling by a Federal judge, critics of a proposed settlement of a suit against Archer Daniels Midland and two rivals may be unable to question an A.D.M. executive they contend was involved in price-fixing. [D4.]
 
G.E. on Aircraft Spending Spree
General Electric will buy more than $2.5 billion worth of planes from Airbus Industrie, continuing a spending spree for aircraft. [D2.]
 
If the Ambush Won Olympic Gold
With advertisers planning to spend an estimated $5 billion on Olympic-related campaigns, this Olympics will be the most lavishly sponsored ever. But if commercialization and ambushing were Olympic sports, the Games could be called off before they began because the United States would have already won most gold medals. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]
 
Turmoil Increases at Sony Pictures
Marc Platt, the chairman of Tristar Pictures, a division of Sony Pictures, was pushed out, adding to the turmoil at the studio known as the most troubled in Hollywood. [D7.]
 
Business Inventories Fall Slightly
Business inventories fell one-tenth of 1 percent in May, the Government said. [D18.]
 
U.S. Chief For Sega Quits
Thomas J. Kalinske, the president and chief executive of Sega of America, home of Sonic the Hedgehog, resigned amid disappointing sales of the next-generation video-game player. He will join a new company founded by Michael Milken and Lawrence Ellison, the chairman of Oracle. [D18.]
 
Higher Profits for Brokerage Firms
Paine Webber, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and Smith Barney all reported higher quarterly earnings. [D4.]
 
F.C.C. Denies TCI Satellite Request
The F.C.C. denied an application by Tele-Communications and Telquest Ventures to use Canadian satellites to beam television programming to American viewers. [D6.]

HEADLINE: A POWER STRUGGLE IS SEEN AS YELTSIN ENTERS SANITARIUM

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 15

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin today heightened alarm about his health and gave new impetus to a power struggle in the Kremlin when he abruptly left Moscow for a sanitarium.
His sudden departure for what an aide described as a two-week vacation stunned an American delegation headed by Vice President Al Gore, whose meeting with Mr. Yeltsin was canceled at the last minute. The Americans had hoped to use the meeting to underscore support for the Russian President and assess his physical stamina following a grueling re-election campaign. 
 Mr. Yeltsin, who is 65 and has a history of heart disease, has not appeared in public for nearly three weeks, except in taped television addresses and brief, carefully staged photo opportunities.
Before leaving the Kremlin, Mr. Yeltsin injected a new element into the power struggle there by naming Anatoly B. Chubais, a free-market advocate, as his new chief of staff. Just six months ago, Mr. Chubais was forced out of office by an embattled President Yeltsin, who sought to turn the reformer into a scapegoat for alleged favoritism and insider dealing that grew out of the program to privatize state-owned industries. But throwing his support behind Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Chubais helped mastermind the President's successful election campaign.
Mr. Chubais's appointment as a replacement for the hawkish Nikolai Yegorov will strengthen the role of economic reformers in the Government at the expense of hard-liners.
It appeared to leave three strong, ambitious men jockeying for position as Mr. Yeltsin's energy is in doubt: Mr. Chubais, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, the resilient and cautious Prime Minister, and Aleksandr I. Lebed, the erstwhile general and presidential candidate enlisted as Mr. Yeltsin's national security adviser.
Mr. Gore was preparing to leave for the Kremlin when he received the news that Mr. Yeltsin was leaving for the Barvikha sanitarium outside Moscow, the same sanitarium the President has gone to twice before to recover from heart ailments.
The American Embassy frantically notified reporters that Mr. Gore's midday press conference had been postponed due to "scheduling problems," while American officials insisted that the two leaders would meet on Tuesday at Mr. Yeltsin's retreat.
But even as Mr. Yeltsin's most loyal lieutenants sought to put the best face on the situation, they acknowledged that the campaign had taken a heavy toll on the President.
"He is really very tired, and he just needs a good, proper holiday," said Sergei K. Medvedev, Mr. Yeltsin's spokesman.
Mr. Yeltsin has a long history of recurring illness, evidently aggravated by an appetite for vodka, that has sometimes led to periods of strange behavior or disappearance from public view.
In September 1994, he created a stir when he failed to emerge from his plane during for a scheduled meeting at Shannon Airport with Ireland's Prime Minister.
More recently, Mr. Yeltsin dropped out of sight during the final days leading up to the July 3 presidential runoff election and has barely been visible since, his major appearances being recorded televised addresses.
Mr. Yeltsin was hospitalized twice last year for acute ischemia, a heart problem. He also has suffered from back trouble and other ailments in recent years.
Two days after Mr. Yeltsin's election victory, President Clinton said he talked to him by telephone for about 25 minutes and "I didn't have to ask him about his health because he sounded so good."
Clinton Administration officials say Mr. Yeltsin needs a heart operation. But the President stubbornly refused to take a break in recent months, campaigning at a breakneck pace.
Mr. Gore, for his part, had little to say today about Mr. Yeltsin's health problems and the canceled meeting. "I learned this morning that it would be postponed until tomorrow," Mr. Gore said.
The appointment of Mr. Chubais seemed likely to curb Mr. Lebed's bid for influence within the newly elected Yeltsin Government. Since he was named to his post as the top national security official, Mr. Lebed has talked openly about his presidential ambitions and his desire to extend his current authority into other spheres, including economics.
He has suggested that an economist be appointed to the Security Council, a policymaking body he heads, and, to the consternation of Prime Minister Chernomyrdin, has predicted a downturn in the economy in the fall.
Mr. Chernomyrdin has made it clear that he has no desire to cede authority over economic policy to Mr. Lebed.
And Mr. Chubais, a trained economist who played a pivotal role in recent years in helping Russia move toward capitalism, also indicated that he intended to play a central role in enforcing Mr. Yeltsin's decisions, strengthening pro-reform local authorities and mobilizing popular support for continued reforms.
Sergei A. Filatov, Mr. Yeltsin's former chief of staff, said that he expected Mr. Chubais to recruit more "people with a liberal, democratic orientation."
Today's meetings between American and Russian specialists were overseen by Mr. Gore and Mr. Chernomyrdin as part of a regular forum on broad range of economic, political and military issues. Exhausted by the long campaign and with many key appointments yet to be made, Mr. Yeltsin and his top aides were not poised to make major breakthroughs in the talks.
Still, some progress was made. The Russians agreed to roll back new excise taxes on six American-Russian joint oil ventures, which account for the bulk of American foreign investment in Russia.
The Russian Government had ordered that the excise taxes be raised from 16,000 rubles a ton to 70,000 a ton. But in meetings today with Mr. Gore and Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor, the Russian side agreed that the tax would be reduced to 20,000 rubles a ton for at least another year.
American officials said the change would make the difference between profit and loss for the companies involved.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls in Panicky Selloff Wrenched by Volatile Stocks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Violent swings in the United States stock market wrenched the dollar's value down yesterday in a panicky selloff that left the currency at the weakest level against the German mark in more than three months.
Currency traders called it the worst one-day slide of the dollar this year and said Wall Street's spasms had become the main driving force behind the currency's behavior. 
 "With the stock market environment, people just dumped the dollar," said Nathaniel Litwak, manager of foreign exchange trading at the New York branch of Banque Indosuez. "We saw selling that we haven't seen in months."
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar stood at 1.4806 marks, down from 1.5165 on Monday, a drop of 2.4 percent. It was the lowest level against the mark since April 4. The dollar also fell to 109.25 Japanese yen, down from 110.36 and its lowest level since June 27. The British pound rose to $1.5595 from $1.5525.
For the second consecutive day, the currency market hung on the American stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average, which tumbled 161.05 points on Monday, fell more than 167 points before recovering to end the day up 9.25 points.
Currency traders focused on Wall Street's drop because it raised fear that foreign investors might liquidate their holdings in the United States and move their money elsewhere, creating a surge of dollars on the market. As the dollar fell through important technical support levels it incited more selling.
"We had a panic selling of the dollar," said Elena Shperling, head of foreign-exchange trading at the New York branch of Banco di Sicilia. "When we come up with something like this, everyone's getting out of the way."
In what appeared to be a move to help talk up the dollar, the president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, said the German central bank was not considering an interest rate increase in the foreseeable future. He also held out the possibility of lower rates, which could weaken the mark against the dollar.
But Mr. Tietmeyer's statement had no discernible effect in foreign-exchange trading.
"The overriding fact was the U.S. equity markets drove the dollar today," said Thomas Benfer, foreign exchange director at the New York branch of the Bank of Montreal.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Turkey Wings It

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Turkey

 BODY:
While traveling, you are often asked what you do for a living. Lately I answer that I'm a foreign affairs columnist and that means I cover wars -- occasionally wars between countries but more often the wars between economic winners and losers within countries. Because it is these domestic wars that increasingly shape international affairs, from Russia to Mexico to Turkey.
Why have such internal wars become so sharp? The short answer is "globalization" -- the integration of free markets, financial flows, trade and information -- which has established a very powerful set of rules and standards for how countries have to behave if they are going to attract investment capital to grow. You can call those rules "The Paradigm." Once a country opens itself up to the global market and accepts The Paradigm, those of its citizens with the skills to take advantage of it become the winners and those without become losers or left-behinds. 
 In those countries where all political parties have basically accepted The Paradigm, there really isn't much difference anymore between ruling and opposition parties. In most countries, though, there is usually one party that runs against The Paradigm, offering populist solutions that claim to be able to defy globalization or ease its pain. That's Pat Buchanan in America, the Communists in Russia and now the Islamic Welfare Party here in Turkey.
In other words, the coming to power last week by the Islamic Welfare Party is part of a trend, but it's not the trend of Islamic fundamentalism. It's the trend of the backlash against globalization.
In the 1980's Turkey went from being a relatively closed, Socialist economy to opening itself to the global market. But it did so without many of the institutions to prevent huge disparities of income when its economy started to be privatized and without effective social safety nets to cushion the impact of globalization on traditional society. As a result, those who understood the new game flourished; those who didn't got left behind or flocked from farms to cities in search of work in the new industries of the global economy, creating a huge urban underclass.
The reason the Islamic Welfare Party was finally able to take power last week was a fluke: former Prime Minister Tansu Ciller, in a venal bid to avoid prosecution for corruption, agreed to join a coalition Government under the Welfare Party leader, Necmettin Erbakan, if he blocked her indictment. But it was also part of a trend in which the Welfare Party has steadily built support among Turkey's new urban underclass. As one wealthy Turkish businessman remarked to me, the Welfare Party "is the loser's way of punishing us." Mr. Erbakan's first decision was not to pass out Korans, but to raise civil service wages by 50 percent. Even many secular Turks, fed up with their own parties, are ready to give Welfare a chance.
So the Welfare Party's mandate is not to bring more God into Turkish life but to bring more good -- good services and good government. Welfare cannot do what the majority of Turks want without in some way adapting itself to the rules and limits of The Paradigm. Turkey is not like other Islamic states. Iran's mullah's can live outside The Paradigm because they have oil. Sudan's mullahs can live outside The Paradigm because they have nothing. Turkey has no oil, but it has a huge industrial base. To survive economically it must sell a thousand different products globally. Turkey cannot live outside The Paradigm, and Mr. Erbakan will learn that.
So what's happening in Turkey is much more complicated than just a Muslim fundamentalist takeover. It is what happens when widening globalization spins off more and more losers, while widening democratization gives them all a vote, while religious parties effectively exploit this coincidence to take power. Whether these religious parties can actually rule more effectively, and deal with the demands of The Paradigm, remains to be seen. So watch Turkey, but don't panic. Its quandary applies to many U.S. allies: how to make the transition from a closed society to the global market while maintaining political stability. Helping allies manage this transition could become the most important issue of U.S. foreign policy.

HEADLINE: Myron Goldsmith, Architect And Engineer, Is Dead at 77

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
Myron Goldsmith, an architect and engineer whose work merged the jewel-like precision of Mies van der Rohe with the greyhound-sleek forms of Pier Luigi Nervi, died on Monday at his home in Wilmette, Ill. He was 77.
The cause was heart failure, said his wife, Robin. 
 A student both of Mies and of Nervi, two of the century's most important architects, Mr. Goldsmith brought their influence to bear on more than 40 projects he designed around the nation for the firm of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, where he worked from 1955 to 1983, the last 16 years as a general partner in its Chicago office.
Like Mies, Mr. Goldsmith sought to express the structural essence of his buildings in their exteriors, unmasked by ornament. Like Nervi, he designed with the sweeping arcs and long spans made possible by new technologies. The results were almost sculptural: cool, spare, gleaming and hard-edged.
Mr. Goldsmith's best-known work was the McMath-Pierce Solar Telescope Facility of 1962, at the Kitt Peak National Observatory in Arizona, which draws some 100,000 visitors a year.
Crowning a mountaintop near Tucson, the structure looks like the bottom half of the letter K, with a 110-foot tower joined to a shaft that runs 500 feet above and below ground. Both tower and shaft are diamond-shaped, clad in copper panels that are painted white.
Although it appears abstract, the shape is actually a reflection of pure function, since the 32-degree angle of the shaft parallels the axis of the earth's rotation, allowing the viewing angle of the sun to remain constant. And the diamond shape helps reduce wind turbulence on the surface.
Mr. Goldsmith distilled his philosophy in a 1987 monograph: "A building should be built with economy, efficiency, discipline and order."
The work of Miesian architects was widely dismissed in the 1970's and 80's as cold, sterile, repetitive and inhumanly scaled. But Mr. Goldsmith was not singled out for criticism.
Moreover, he was disarming in person, almost an antithesis of his architecture; perpetually rumpled, with a bird's-nest tangle of hair and a shy, soft-spoken demeanor. "He managed with gentleness to exist and prosper in a field that is otherwise eaten up by tigerish egos," said Franz Schulze, an art historian and Mies biographer.
Mr. Goldsmith was born in Chicago and graduated in 1939 from the Illinois Institute of Technology, where he studied under Mies, whose Chicago office he joined in 1946. He worked there until 1953, when he received a Fulbright Grant to study under Nervi at the University of Rome.
His first major projects at Skidmore were two United Air Lines hangars at San Francisco International Airport, one of which used cantilevered steel girders to form a structure large enough to house four DC-8 jetliners.
Other significant projects were the Oakland Alameda County Coliseum of 1966, in California, which includes a circular arena 420 feet in diameter, ringed by a 70-foot-high glass wall behind enormous concrete X-braces; and The Republic newspaper plant in Columbus, Ind., completed in 1971, whose delicate aluminum and glass skin allowed passers-by to view the newsroom and pressroom.
Left unbuilt was the Ruck-a-Chucky Bridge, which was to have spanned the American River in Auburn, Calif., northeast of Sacramento. Recalling somewhat a cat's-cradle on a giant scale, the curving bridge deck would have been suspended from a network of steel cables anchored in the surrounding mountainsides.
Mr. Goldsmith had been a professor of architecture at the Illinois Institute of Technology since 1961. His students' theses in long-span structures and high-rise buildings were frequently prototypes for new engineering systems used in actual projects, like the John Hancock Center in Chicago.
At the time of his death, he was a member of a team organized by the institute to design a 115- to 120-story office, hotel and commercial structure in Seoul for the Hyundai Engineering and Construction Company. The project, known as "Hankang City," may end up as the world's tallest building.
Besides his wife, Mr. Goldsmith is survived by a son, Marc, of Tempe, Ariz.; a daughter, Chandra, of Boston, and a sister, Bernice Colner of Pacific Palisades, Calif.
