HEADLINE: U.S. to Tell Serbs They Face New Sanctions

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, July 16

 BODY:
Richard C. Holbrooke, the special American envoy to the Balkans, plans to tell President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia on Wednesday that economic sanctions will be reimposed on Serbia unless the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, is both removed from power and leaves Bosnia, two senior Western officials said.
Mr. Holbrooke made this stance clear today in meetings with top Bosnian Government officials and senior international civilian and military officials, said two officials familiar with the meetings. 
 Mr. Holbrooke, who arrived here today and will go on to Belgrade on Wednesday, told officials here that he would demand Dr. Karadzic's "immediate" departure from Bosnia, but did not specify a date. Nor did he say where Dr. Karadzic -- who is under international indictment for war crimes and subject to arrest -- should go.
Mr. Holbrooke acknowledged that he did not know if Mr. Milosevic could be persuaded, an official with knowledge of his plans said.
Out of office and out of Bosnia are Mr. Holbrooke's "minimum" conditions for Dr. Karadzic's removal, said one official, who declined to say what else the American envoy would tell Mr. Milosevic. The Bosnian Serbs have already been threatened with exclusion from the Bosnian elections later this year if Dr. Karadzic remains as chairman of the Serb Democratic Party.
Mr. Holbrooke, who negotiated the Dayton peace agreement last fall and then left Government service, was called back by President Clinton this week, after the allies had been repeatedly outmaneuvered by Dr. Karadzic.
"We're here because we're not satisfied with the degree of compliance on the part of the parties in the region with the Dayton agreement, above all with attitudes of noncompliance by the Bosnian Serbs," Mr. Holbrooke said when he arrived at the Sarajevo airport.
And Mr. Holbrooke delivered a message to the Bosnian Serbs, who have been threatening to harm NATO forces if any attempt is made to seize Dr. Karadzic. If they take any action against Western forces, he said, "They'll be met with swift military action."
Just how much leverage Mr. Holbrooke can bring to bear on Mr. Milosevic to achieve compliance with the demands is unclear. Although under the Dayton accord the senior military and civilian overseers in Bosnia can reimpose economic sanctions, many countries would have to take quick action for them to be effective. But major Western powers have shown little unity on the subject.
Only Germany fully endorses the ultimatum Mr. Holbrooke will deliver. Russia, which feels that Dr. Karadzic has already surrendered enough of his power, is adamantly opposed to reimposing sanctions, Britain has strong objections, and France is lukewarm, diplomats say, but the British and French will keep their reservations quiet.
One looming question over Mr. Holbrooke's mission is whether the threat of sanctions would, in any case, be enough to impel Mr. Milosevic to take action. The international economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations in the summer of 1992 were never fully effective, because of wide-spread leakage. But they hurt Serbia economically and Mr. Milosevic fought hard to have them lifted. They were suspended only after Mr. Milosevic signed the peace agreement.
A decision of the United Nations Security Council is not needed to reimpose sanctions, according to international diplomats here. They said they can be reimposed by the commander of the NATO-led forces in Bosnia, Adm. Leighton Smith, or the chief civilian in charge of putting the accords into effect, Carl Bildt.
And Admiral Smith is prepared to do so, said an official, in part because such a step would relieve the mounting pressure on the NATO forces to launch a military operation to seize Dr. Karadzic.
En route to Sarajevo, Mr. Holbrooke stopped in Brussels, where the senior political and military leaders of NATO gave full support to his negotiating position, an official said.
Robert H. Frowick, a former United States diplomat who is overseeing the elections as head of the Bosnia mission of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, has said that if Dr. Karadzic remains as chairman of the Serb Democratic Party, the party -- by far the major political force in the Serb-held portion of Bosnia -- will not be allowed to take part in the national elections scheduled for Sept. 14. On Monday he delayed the official start of campaigning until Friday, to give Dr. Karadzic time to step down.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;
White House Report Foresees A Sharp Decline in the Deficit

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
The Clinton White House issued its midsummer revised economic forecast today, predicting that the Federal budget deficit this fiscal year would be $116.8 billion -- $29 billion less than the Administration forecast just this spring and only a third of its level when Mr. Clinton took office.
The White House used the good news to make good politics, sending out a bevy of senior officials to brag about it at a morning briefing where they attributed it to Mr. Clinton's 1993 deficit reduction package. 
 The White House also said that it expected the domestic economy to grow by 2.6 percent this year, up from its previous forecast of 2.2 percent growth and the 1.5 percent rise of 1995.
"The fact is, our economy is now the soundest it's been in a generation," Mr. Clinton said today in a speech to the National Governors' Association.
The President added that as a percentage of the economy, the deficit was at its lowest level since 1974: 1.6 percent of gross domestic product, by far the lowest current level for any of the world's leading industrialized nations.
The news was a sort of vindication for Mr. Clinton, who has tried to make cutting the deficit a centerpiece of his first term but has seldom received the credit he seeks.
Congressional Republicans were quick to acknowledge the political potency of the deficit's decline, but just as quick to take credit for it.
The chairman of the House Budget Committee, Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, said that "the deficit is this low because of Republican reform efforts, not any new action on the President's part."
Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said that much of the decline was a result of nothing more than revisions in technical assumptions and economic forecasts.
"The Administration taking credit for it," Mr. Domenici said, "is like the rooster taking credit for the sunrise."
In fact, last summer Mr. Clinton decided to match the Republicans' goal of balancing the budget by just after the turn of the century, having previously resisted a specific deadline. Today the White House said the improved forecasts would actually produce a budget surplus of $25.8 billion in 2001 and $60.9 billion in 2002.
Indeed, the one potential dark lining for Mr. Clinton in this silver cloud is that the deficit has now shrunk so much that Republicans may be tempted to propose a larger tax cut than can be easily financed, and thus put him on the defensive as a dour-faced deficit hawk. But Republicans, too, are heavily invested in balancing the budget, and, compared with the alternatives, stolidity is a risk the Administration seems happy enough to take.
The new estimate, if realized, would mean a decline from an actual deficit of $164 billion for the 1995 budget year and would mark the fourth consecutive year of declining deficits.
The midsession review does forecast a slight increase in the deficit next year, to $125.7 billion. But the Administration projects steady declines after that, and a budget surplus five years from now. That would be the first time since 1969 that the Government had not run a deficit.
Residents of the Okimaw Ohci Healing Lodge in Maple Creek, Saskatchewan, the first Canadian penal institution designed specifically for Indian offenders, embrace after holding a "talking circle," at which they freely discuss what is on their minds.

HEADLINE: Mr. Yeltsin's Health Problems

 BODY:
President Clinton and Vice President Gore may find it politic to downplay Boris Yeltsin's latest physical setback, but that is no reason for the rest of us to ignore what is happening. The freshly re-elected President of Russia is once again in precarious health. Should he become incapacitated, the ability of Russia's fledgling democracy to effect an orderly transfer of power will be put to a severe test.
Mr. Yeltsin's withdrawal to a sanitarium outside Moscow may indeed merely be prompted by extreme fatigue after an exhausting electoral campaign, as Mr. Clinton, Mr. Gore and Kremlin aides hopefully suggest. But it could also signal a recurrence of the serious heart problems that sent him to the same place twice before or the drinking bouts that have periodically immobilized him. 
 Mr. Yeltsin's sudden disappearance from public view in the midst of the presidential runoff campaign, his last-minute rescheduling of a key meeting with Mr. Gore and his abrupt departure from Moscow this week have unleashed a flood of Kremlin speculation and brought worried concern in foreign capitals. The happiest outcome for Russian democracy and American interests would be for Mr. Yeltsin to return speedily to full strength and serve out his new four-year term. Should he falter, now or later, the next best alternative would be an orderly transition to his constitutional successor, Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin. Whatever one thinks of Mr. Chernomyrdin, it is critical to reinforce the validity of constitutional processes and avoid a free-for-all scramble for power.
Mr. Yeltsin's latest health crisis has quickened the jockeying for position among his top deputies -- Mr. Chernomyrdin, Aleksandr Lebed, the national security adviser, and Anatoly Chubais, the newly appointed presidential chief of staff.
Mr. Chubais, whose appointment on Monday suggests that Mr. Yeltsin is still cogent and making important decisions about his administration, is an architect of the radical economic reform that marked Mr. Yeltsin's first years in office. Earlier this year Mr. Yeltsin cast him aside as a sop to populist anger over the rise of a rich, and unpopular, Russian business class. His return marks an acknowledgment that the newly privatized businesses he helped bring into being are now an important new political constituency. It is also a reward for the political skills he displayed in Mr. Yeltsin's successful electoral campaign.
Mr. Lebed is a retired general who ran a surprisingly strong third in the first round of the presidential contest before joining forces with Mr. Yeltsin for the runoff. He is a strong nationalist who is transparently ambitious for the presidency. But he is also politically inexperienced and has an alarming penchant for disparaging remarks about ethnic and religious minorities.
Mr. Chernomyrdin comes from the ranks of the elite industrial managers under Communism. He represents a centrist, steady hand on the Government and economy but shares responsibility for the Government's reckless spending spree to bolster Mr. Yeltsin's election campaign. He has also been criticized for extending favors to his former company, Gazprom, and other large state enterprises jockeying for position in the new Russian economy. But as Prime Minister he has proved a successful crisis manager and has acted as a sober counterweight to the often impulsive Mr. Yeltsin.
What most entitles Mr. Chernomyrdin to Washington's recognition as Mr. Yeltsin's heir apparent is his constitutional position. America's relations with a country as geopolitically important as Russia must go beyond personalities. They should focus on the orderly development of Russia's new political institutions, including respect for election results and constitutional succession provisions.

HEADLINE: Those Slam-Dunk Salaries

 BODY:
Free-agent season opened for National Basketball Association players last week, with dazzling financial rewards for a handful of superstars. Michael Jordan, the world's best player, won the sport's best salary -- a reported $25 million for one year. Shaquille O'Neal, the gargantuan center for the Orlando Magic, was reportedly offered over $95 million for seven years by the Los Angeles Lakers -- a contract the Lakers expect Mr. O'Neal to rip up after three years to collect much more. But Shaq will have to balance that against a $115 million seven-year offer to stay with the Magic. Juwan Howard, a 23-year-old player for the Washington Bullets, jumped to the Miami Heat for $98 million over seven years. That would make him only the second-best-paid player on the Heat, which reportedly offered its center, Alonzo Mourning, about $10 million more.
But there is another, less eye-catching side to the N.B.A. salary follies. The combination of free agency, which allows players to switch teams, and salary caps, which limit the total payroll that teams can pay players, is producing a high-rent replica of the American economy at large. Superstar incomes are soaring, leaving everyone else behind. 
 The league caps the total amount that owners can pay players, currently at $24.3 million a year, though salaries of longtime team members are in effect exempt when their contracts expire. That loophole allowed Chicago to pay Michael Jordan, whose contract expired this year, more than its entire team salary cap. The system compels owners to pay fabulous amounts to woo or keep superstars. But such payouts push down the salaries of unspectacular players. Having lost Mr. Howard to Miami, the Bullets now must go out and wave big bucks at another superstar. That superstar's salary must fit under the team's cap, since he will be a newcomer to the team. Thus the team will virtually have to turn around and offer secondary players of only slightly less spectacular ability that much less.
No one will cry over players who earn a mere quarter-million dollars. But the ballooning inequality mirrors the trend taking place in the economy outside the sports pavilion. Cable television and other modern telecommunications bring Mr. Jordan's talents before worldwide audiences and, therefore, advertisers. He earns $25 million because he generates enormous revenue. That is precisely why the head of Disney, Michael Eisner, takes home as much as hundreds of millions in a year. He may not be able to dunk a basketball, but his decisions have worldwide reverberations, adding billions to Disney's coffers -- or subtracting them.
There is one big difference, however. Mr. Eisner's pay takes nothing out of the pockets of other Disney employees. But because of the salary cap imposed by the owners of professional basketball teams, what goes into the pocket of one superstar may come out of the pockets of lesser players.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Show Gain for Day

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended higher, jostled by a rocky stock market but supported by benign consumer inflation data for June.
"The bond market had a fairly volatile session caused by the movements in the equity market," said Michael Strauss, chief economist at Yamaichi International (America) Inc. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 19/32, to 87 11/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 7.02 percent, from 7.07 percent on Monday. The gains came as the Dow Jones industrial average seesawed throughout the session. After dropping more than 150 points, the Dow closed up 9.25 points.
" We had flight-to-quality buying and then sold again when stocks started to stabilize," a trader said.
Despite recent price movement, pundits said the Treasury market remained in a trading range as no fundamental change in the economic scenario appears to have taken place. "The range is centered on 7 percent," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, referring to the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond.
Bonds were also bolstered by a report showing that consumer prices rose one-tenth of 1 percent in June, slightly below the expectations of most economists. Excluding food and energy, the index was two-tenths of 1 percent.
The report helped ease fears that the Federal Reserve would need to raise short-term interest rates soon to prevent inflation from accelerating. Such fears had escalated after an employment report on July 5 showed unexpected strength in the economy. While many in the market still look for the Fed to push up rates in the coming months, the report on consumer prices suggested that a rate increase might not be sooner or sharper than expected.
Still, there remains uncertainty over the direction of the economy following a robust second quarter and over what course of action the Fed will take.
"There is a degree of uncertainty about the outlook for the economy," Mr. Jones of Lanston said, adding that his own view calls for "reasonably good" momentum going into the second half.
Traders reported heavy selling in intermediate maturities -- mainly 10-year notes --- in late morning trade related to weakness, which was pulled down by the drop in stocks.
In addition, market strategists said they saw some sporadic flows from the stock market into Treasuries.
They said, however, most of the purchasing power was concentrated in the short end of the curve as players moved out of stocks and increased their holdings of cash or cash equivalent securities.
"Most of the activity has been going on in the short end of the market," said Josh Stiles, senior bond strategist at consulting firm I.D.E.A. Inc. "You get the dollar and the Dow together propping up the short end relative to the long end."
The bill sector of the curve -- with maturities ranging from three months to one year -- ended higher. The two-year note was up 5/32 at 100 3/32, to yield 6.20 percent.
In the corporate bond market, prices of junk bonds were weighed down by a wildly swinging stock market and closed mostly unchanged despite gains in Treasury securitities, traders said.
But investment-grade corporate bonds moved lockstep with government securities in thin trading.
In the municipal market, First Chicago Capital Markets Inc. said yesterday that it hadrepriced $487 million Cook County, Ill., general obligation bonds, adding several maturities and raising the top yield in 2022 to 6.13 percent from 6.10 percent. The offering contained both capital improvement and refunding bonds.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Caterpillar Posts a 16% Rise In Profit Despite Lower Sales

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 16

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc. said today that earnings rose 16 percent in the second quarter despite a decline in equipment sales.
The company, a leading maker of earth-moving, construction and farming equipment as well as diesel engines, earned $374 million, or $1.94 a share, in the quarter ended June 30, up from $323 million, or $1.62 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. The results exceeded Wall Street estimates of $1.64 a share. 
 Shares of Caterpillar rose $2.625 today, to $66.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 Caterpillar, which is based in Peoria, Ill., said revenues for the quarter slipped to $4.18 billion from $4.21 billion, primarily because of lower sales of diesel engines. It said equipment sales fell to $4.01 billion from $4.06 billion.
 The company also said it expected sales and profits for all of 1996 to be above 1995 levels. The company posted sales of $16.07 billion and profits of $1.14 billion last year.
 Improved prices helped offset lower machinery and engine sales volume, Caterpillar said, adding that a favorable change in the geographic sales mix helped profits.
 These factors were partly offset by higher sales discounts and the negative effect of the stronger dollar on sales in European currencies, the company said.
 "This was really a gross margin story as the result of the cumulative benefits of restructuring," said Barry Bannister, an analyst with S. G. Warburg & Company. "I think they'll be slightly up this year in earnings over last year."
 Other analysts warned that the earnings gain might have been inflated by currency factors.
 "In terms of the business fundamentals, it's not as much as you'd like to shout about, being that they beat consensus by 30 cents," said Lisa Shalett of Sanford C. Bernstein.
 As a result of economic growth in the United States that was stronger than expected, worldwide machine sales for the industry are close to 1995 levels, Caterpillar said, despite demand from Europe that was weaker than expected.
American industry demand for machines is expected to be just slightly below 1995 levels, an improvement over Caterpillar's earlier forecast, the company said.
 Worldwide demand for engines, however, is still expected to be lower than last year, Caterpillar said, while domestic demand is expected to decline, but less than thought earlier.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Sprint and Ameritech Post A Rise in Their Earnings

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Two of the nation's largest telephone companies posted higher second-quarter earnings yesterday, reflecting increases in phone traffic and in demand for more phone lines.
The Sprint Corporation, the nation's No. 3 long-distance company after the AT&T Corporation and MCI Communications, reported a 30 percent profit rise on its highest long-distance volume and revenue growth in six years; it also posted a 5.3 percent increase in local phone lines. 
 Earnings of the Ameritech Corporation, a regional Bell operating company based in Chicago, rose 12.5 percent, as the number of phone lines increased by 4.2 percent and the number of cellular customers rose 40 percent.
Results are driven by "people who are putting in second lines for telecommuting and Internet access," said Michael Balhoff, an analyst at Legg Mason Wood Walker. "And the economy has been very good."
Sprint, based in Westwood, Kan., said profit from continuing operations rose to $316.8 million, or 73 cents a share, from $245.7 million, or 70 cents, a year earlier, matching the average estimate of 15 analysts surveyed by IBES International Inc.
"Sprint is hitting on all cylinders," said Frank Governali, an analyst at CS First Boston. "There appear to be no areas of weakness."
Shares rose 62.5 cents, to $37.875 in late afternoon trading.
Revenue rose 12 percent, to $3.51 billion from $3.14 billion.
"Revenues, operating income and margins in our long-distance operations hit record levels," said William T. Esrey, chairman and chief executive. That offset losses from Sprint's new international venture, Global One, and its new United States wireless operations, Sprint Spectrum.
Volume, or the minutes of use on Sprint's long-distance network, rose 19 percent. Analysts said that would be about double AT&T's volume growth and above MCI Communications'.
"Their 10-cents-a-minute rate anytime, anywhere in the U.S. is getting them residential long-distance left and right," said Ellen Clifford, an analyst at Telechoice Inc., a Verona, N.J., consulting firm.
Sprint said its second-quarter loss from its start-up operations widened to $44 million, or 10 cents a share, from $6 million, or 2 cents. The start up operations include its Global One joint venture with France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom as well as Sprint Spectrum, its wireless alliance with Tele-Communications Inc., the Comcast Corporation and Cox Communications.
In the latest period, income of $300,000 from discontinued operations from the spinoff of its cellular business in March resulted in net income of $316.8 million, or 73 cents a share. In the 1995 period, income of $2.5 million, or 1 cent a share, from discontinued operations, resulted in net income of $245.7 million, or 70 cents.
Per-share results in the second quarter also reflect a 24 percent increase in the number of shares outstanding to 434.1 million from 350.2 million because of France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom's purchase of 20 percent of Sprint for $4.2 billion last year.
Ameritech said earnings rose 12.5 percent, to $567 million, or $1.02 a share, from $504 million, or 91 cents, a year ago, beating the average estimate of $1.00 a share, based on a survey of 19 analysts by IBES International.
Revenue rose 11 percent, to $3.74 billion from $3.37 billion. Ameritech shares rose 75 cents, to $57.75, in Big Board trading yesterday.
The results were aided by a 4.2 percent increase in phone lines to 19.4 million from 18.6 million. The company also posted a 9.3 percent increase in volume on its local phone network.
Meanwhile, Ameritech kept a lid on costs. Total expenses rose 10 percent, to $2.85 billion from $2.59 billion, below the 17.3 percent increase for the first half of 1996 to $5.67 billion.
Ameritech also maintained its lead among the Bells in the number of phone lines per employee, a key measure of efficiency in the industry, with 372, up from 359 a year ago. Further, cellular customers increased to 2.2 million from 1.6 million a year earlier.

HEADLINE: A WILD DAY ON WALL STREET: THE FOREIGN STOCKS;
A Tremor On Wall St. Reverberates Overseas

 BODY:
The rest of the world didn't stand a chance.
Monday's bloodbath on Wall Street spread around the globe yesterday, overwhelming stock exchanges on a westward-bound rampage: Sydney, Tokyo, Hong Kong, Bangkok, Bombay, Tel Aviv, Johannesburg, Vienna, Oslo, Frankfurt, Milan, Amsterdam, Brussels, Paris, London, Madrid. 
 Though the declines were generally less severe than in the United States -- and while there were pockets of resistance to the downdraft -- the selloff was unmistakably a panicky reaction to the Wall Street carnage. "It's impossible for European markets to avoid following on the coattails of the U.S. market," Roger Mondon, chief equity strategist at Daiwa Europe Ltd. in London, told Bloomberg Business News.
Western Europe, at least, experienced a flicker of hope when, at the start of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average spurted up more than 40 points in the first few minutes of trading -- even while Europe's markets were still open.
But then the Dow turned south, and European stocks also got hammered by a weakening dollar that cast a cloud over the earnings prospects of export-oriented companies.
An early sign yesterday that Wall Street's Monday swoon would take other stock markets with it came when Australia's All Ordinaries index slumped 2.17 percent. Though less than either the Dow's 2.9 percent dip or the Nasdaq composite index's 3.9 percent plunge on Monday, the decline dragged the Australian index to its lowest point in more than seven months. "Mums and dads are hitting the panic button," David England, a trader with BT Securities, told Bloomberg.
Then it was Tokyo's turn, and the world's second-biggest exchange didn't even put up a fight. Today, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks rose 6.53 points, or 0.03 percent, to close at 21,412.88. Yesterday the index dropped 347.07 points to 21,406.35, mostly in the first few minutes of trading. Aside from the fall in American stocks, analysts said, Japanese investors feared a further retreat by Americans from mutual funds that have been pouring money into Japanese stocks, and worried that the Federal Reserve Board would raise interest rates in the United States, putting pressure on the Bank of Japan to follow suit. Even so, some analysts remained upbeat, noting that Japanese stocks tend to move independently of the American market over the long term and suggesting they might get a lift later this year as the Japanese economy continues to recover from a slump.
Technology stocks -- the same sector that led the American market down -- were some of the hardest hit in Japan. The electronics industries of the two nations are highly interdependent, and announcements in the United States of poorer-than-expected earnings by Motorola, Hewlett-Packard, Applied Materials and other companies heralded bleaker prospects for their rivals and suppliers in Japan, analysts said.
Elsewhere in Asia, Hong Kong stocks hit a two-month low, with the Hang Seng index off by 1.59 percent. Benchmark indexes were down 1.8 percent in India, 0.98 percent in Indonesia, 0.94 percent in Malaysia and 0.58 percent in Thailand.
Two Asian exchanges bucked the trend: the Korea Composite Index declined by an insignificant two-tenths of 1 percent, albeit to a 30-month low, and Singapore's Straits Times Industrials Index, which has fallen more than 6 percent since June 1, slipped by a minuscule six-hundredths of 1 percent.
In a preview of the action ahead in the main trading centers of Europe, stocks fell by about 5 percent in Israel, 3.3 percent in Hungary, 2.2 percent in Poland, 2.6 percent in South Africa and 1.8 percent in Austria. "It's a pure knee-jerk reaction," Robin Gardy, a trader at Frankel Pollak in Johannesburg, told Bloomberg. "There's no reason our market should fall like this."
In Western Europe, the selloff continued with benchmark indexes sinking more than 2 percent in Italy, Germany, Switzerland and the Netherlands, and more than 1.5 percent elsewhere. Shares in export-oriented stocks sank as the dollar fell to a three-month low against the German mark, crashing through the psychologically important 1.50-mark barrier, from 1.52 marks late Monday in Europe to less than 1.49 marks by midday Tuesday in New York.
Leading their respective markets lower, SAP A.G., a German software maker, plunged 5.93 percent, the French aerospace and electronics company Thomson CSF slumped 5.40 percent, and Ericsson A.B., a Swedish telecommunications company, declined 4.06 percent.
While a bad day for stocks, yesterday was a good day for British understatement, and Tim O'Dell, a stock strategist at UBS Ltd. in London, provided some. "Today's been a bit of a disappointment," he told The Associated Press.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Wall Street's Big Tumble Echoes Around the Globe
As Wall Street rode a record-breaking roller coaster, stock exchanges across the globe took their cues from Monday's bloodbath. Though the declines were less severe than in the United States, the global selloff was a panicky reaction to the carnage. [Pages A1 and D7.]
 
Treasury prices ended higher, jostled by a rocky stock market. The yield of the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 7.02 percent. [D4.]
 
G.M. Profits Fall on Charge
General Motors reported a 16.7 percent decline in second-quarter net income because of a charge, but profits from continuing operations were better than expected. [D2.]

Clinton Acts on Cuban Plants
Faced with conflicting domestic and foreign pressures in an election year, President Clinton announced a compromise measure intended to tighten the economic noose around Cuba and avert European retaliation. [A1.]
 
Upbeat Forecast on Economy
The White House predicted that the economy would grow by 2.6 percent this year, up from its previous forecast of 2.2 percent. [D21.].

Kerkorian Group to Buy MGM Again
Kirk Kerkorian, who twice bought and sold Metro Goldwyn Mayer, is buying the ailing film company again. Credit Lyonnais, the French bank that owns the studio, accepted a $1.3 billion bid from a group led by Tracinda, Mr. Kerkorian's holding company. The Kerkorian group includes MGM's chairman, Frank Mancuso. [D18.]
 
An Inquiry Finds for Mattel
An investigation of Mattel has concluded that there were no irregularities in the toy maker's accounting practices. [D3.]
 
Philip Morris Profit Up 15 Percent
Philip Morris earnings rose 15 percent as the company's food business turned around and its overseas tobacco business grew. [D2.]
 
Results Vary for Two Bank Mergers
Chase Manhattan posted better-than-expected earnings, but Wells Fargo came in well short of forecasts as the two big bank mergers showed different results. [D3.]

Earnings Rise at Eli Lilly and J.& J.
Johnson & Johnson reported a 19.7 percent gain in earnings for the quarter and Eli Lilly & Company reported a 12 percent advance. [D6.]
 
Time Warner Cash Flow Up Sharply
Time Warner reported that operating cash flow for the second quarter jumped 20 percent to $1.031 billion. [D5.]

Merrill Lynch Tops Forecasts
Merrill Lynch reported a 53 percent surge in second-quarter earnings that exceeded analyst expectations. [D4.]
 
A New, Old Name For an Ad Agency
The name of Theodore F. MacManus, one of the most famous individuals in advertising, whose 1915 slogan for the Cadillac, "The Penalty of Leadership" is still quoted, will soon adorn the ad agency D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles. The board of the agency voted to adopt a new name, the MacManus Group. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Industrial Output Gains, And Inflation Stays Low

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
The economy remained healthy and balanced last month, displaying solid gains in industrial production and no signs of surging inflation, the Government reported today.
The benign data -- contained in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index and the Federal Reserve's industrial output survey -- provided a calming counterpoint on Wall Street to the rash of lower-than-expected corporate earnings announcements that helped to send stock prices gyrating. 
 The reports were characterized by the Clinton Administration as further evidence that the economy was performing as well as it had in decades, with steady growth and low inflation. And while economists predicted that the pace of growth would slow as the year progressed, they said the economy remained nearly free of the kinds of bottlenecks that could derail the expansion.
"What could be better than an economy that is growing at a relatively fast clip, with lots of jobs being created, yet with very little in the way of inflationary consequences?" said Edward Yardeni, an economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell/C.J. Lawrence Inc.
Today's news did not totally dampen speculation that the Federal Reserve would push interest rates up later this summer to forestall the possibility of a wage and price spiral farther down the road. The Fed is expected to scrutinize a number of economic indicators at the end of this month and early next month, including employment costs and job growth, before deciding whether a rate increase is warranted.
Today's reports, said Joel L. Naroff, an economist at the First Union Bank in Philadelphia, provided "not a whiff of rising inflation."
The Labor Department reported that the Consumer Price Index inched up one-tenth of 1 percent in June, slightly below the expectations of most economists and down from its increase of three-tenths of a percent in May. For the last 12 months, inflation at the consumer level rose 2.8 percent, roughly consistent with its trend of the last several years.
Excluding its most volatile components, food and energy, the inflation index was up two-tenths of a percent last month and at a 2.7 percent annual pace for the last 12 months.
The report showed that energy prices, which had shot up this spring, fell 2.2 percent in June. Included in the energy price drop was a 3.2 percent decline in gasoline prices, whose rise earlier this year prompted a frenzied election-year political response, including a Republican proposal to rescind the 4.3-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax and an effort by the Clinton Administration to nudge down oil prices by selling some of the nation's petroleum reserves. At the same time, food prices shot up seven-tenths of a percent during the month, with meat, poultry, dairy and produce prices all sharply higher.
Inflation would normally be expected to increase when the economy is growing at a strong rate and the unemployment rate is low, since companies would normally try to pass on the resultant rise in wage rates to consumers in the form of higher prices. But the June inflation numbers were muted despite a strong rise in industrial production at a time when the unemployment, at 5.3 percent, was at a six-year low.
The Federal Reserve said industrial production increased five-tenths of a percent in June, somewhat higher than most projections. At the same time, however, the Fed revised its estimate of industrial production in May down to five-tenths of a percent from seven-tenths.
While industrial production continued to grow at a strong clip in June, it did not appear to strain the ability of factories, mines and utilities to keep up with demand. The Fed reported that the capacity utilization for the month stood at 83.2 percent of potential output, still below the 85 percent that most economists believe signals potential inflationary bottlenecks.
The Labor Department reported that real average weekly earnings rose 2.2 percent from May to June. The increase was caused by what the Bureau of Labor Statistics said was an "unusual combination" of a 1.5 percent increase in hours worked and an increase of eight-tenths of a percent in average hourly earnings.
Economists and traders are now turning their attention to testimony by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, on Thursday before the Senate Banking Committee.
In particular, they will be looking for clues as to how the Fed is resolving the debate over whether the economy is more capable of sustaining noninflationary growth than previous rules of thumb suggested. Not only have economists been forced to rethink their assumptions about the relationship between unemployment and inflation, they have also had to question whether rapid changes in technology and business practices have left them unable to measure improvements in such key gauges as productivity and capacity.
Wall Street will also be looking for signals that the Fed, after the volatility of the last few days on Wall Street, may be concerned about a sharp downturn in the stock market and its effect on the broader economy and on monetary policy. A steep downturn in the market could leave individual investors feeling poorer and cause them to rein in their spending. A crash in prices could force the Fed to keep monetary policy looser than it might otherwise, as it did during and after the market tailspin in October 1987, to insure adequate liquidity.
At the same time, analysts will be watching for any indication that the Fed is willing to hold its fire on inflation this year, at a time when the economy seems to be humming along, and save its ammunition for the next cyclical downturn or upward spike in inflation.
Since The Wall Street Journal reported earlier this month that two Fed economists conducted a mathematical review of that approach, known as "opportunistic disinflation," some analysts concluded that the Fed was sending a signal that it would not raise rates this summer.
But other economists said the "opportunistic disinflation" approach was by no means new, and indeed was the signature of Mr. Greenspan's nine-year tenure at the central bank. In Congressional testimony in February, Mr. Greenspan said "keeping inflation from rising significantly during economic expansions will permit a gradual ratcheting down of inflation over the course of successive business cycles" -- a formulation that implied that progress on inflation during downturns.

HEADLINE: In Shift, U.S. Will Seek Binding World Pact to Combat Global Warming

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
For the first time, the United States will seek a binding international agreement to reduce the kinds of air pollution, chiefly from burning fossil fuels, that threaten to warm the global climate, Administration officials said today.
Endorsing the view that the buildup of so-called greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, mainly carbon dioxide, is probably already beginning to warm the planet, the Administration will urge the world's nations to adopt, by the end of next year, "realistic, verifiable and binding" targets for reversing the trend. 
 Although the Administration has devised no specific target or timetable, its position signals a more aggressive campaign against climate change than the voluntary measures it endorsed in the past, and puts it on a course that promises to be politically difficult.
Environmentalists praised the new approach, but officials of the energy industry reacted skeptically, although they said the impact of the plan would depend on the specific goals, which have not been spelled out.
The United States, with its huge appetite for energy, burns more fossil fuels than any other country in the world and its output of greenhouse gases has continued to rise despite conservation measures. Proposals for the stringent measures that would be required to reduce emissions have been politically explosive.
"This is a big deal," said Timothy E. Wirth, the Under Secretary of State for Global Affairs, in a telephone interview from Geneva. On Wednesday he is scheduled to present the American position at a negotiating session among some 150 nations who signed the 1992 treaty on climate change.
"Saying that we want to have a target that is binding is a clear indication that the United States is very serious about taking steps and leading the rest of the world," he said. "We will be getting more and more specific as the next year and a half rolls through."
The Geneva talks are a prelude to a conference in Tokyo late next year where the signers of the treaty plan to set forth the next steps in heading off worldwide climate change.
The Administration would have preferred to wait until after the election before introducing tougher measures, but the diplomatic timetable would not allow that.
In the treaty, negotiated in Rio de Janeiro during the Bush Administration, industrial countries set a non-binding goal of limiting emissions of greenhouse gases by 2000 to the levels that prevailed in 1990. But the United States and most other countries are unlikely to meet that goal, and have since conceded that even deeper cuts in pollution are needed.
In remarks prepared for delivery by Mr. Wirth on Wednesday, the United States rejects some proposals for steep and immediate cuts in pollution, such as the 20 percent cut within a decade that is being sought by small island nations fearful of being swamped by rising oceans as the planet warms.
Mr. Wirth will call that goal unrealistic, given the economic disruption that would occur if energy consumption were restricted so sharply. A copy of his prepared text was obtained by The New York Times today.
He will also say that the United States wants flexibility to allow every country to meet the new targets in whatever way seems best to each government, and he signaled that the Administration intends to use market-based approaches, like the trading of pollution permits, to help its industries do so in whatever fashion they deem most efficient.
Those positions seemed intended to deflect some of the political fallout from industry groups that have strongly opposed strict new measures to combat global warming. The Administration in the past has adopted purely voluntary approaches, which have cut the growth in pollution but have failed to actually reduce emissions.
John Schlaes, executive director of an industry group that opposes quick action to head off global warming, said that the key to the Administration's proposals would lie in details of the timing and extent of any emission reductions that are to be sought. His group, the Global Climate Coalition, is made up of oil, coal and electric companies and industries that use large amounts of energy.
"Any kind of binding target, without doing the appropriate analysis and assessment, and then having a dialogue with the American public, doesn't make sense," he said in a telephone interview from Geneva, where he is observing the negotiations.
Environmental groups generally reacted positively to the Administration's position, although not all of them favor the market-based approach that Mr. Wirth mentioned.
"It shows that the Administration is serious about this issue," said Michael Oppenheimer, an atmospheric physicist who is a senior scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund in New York. "It shows that they have accepted the judgment of the scientific community that climate change is happening and that something has to be done about it."
In his prepared remarks, Mr. Wirth calls for quick action, not decades of delay, and for concrete measures, not vague promises, in the binding measures that would be negotiated in time for the meeting scheduled in Tokyo at the end of next year.
"We are not interested in grand rhetorical goals that are impossible to realize," he says in his speech. "We want the negotiations to focus on outcomes that are real and achievable."
Mr. Wirth and other senior leaders are expected to issue a joint statement of policy on Thursday, joined by many nations, and a key test for the Administration is the extent to which its views are incorporated into that statement.
Although his statement is cautious about what steps to take next, it is unequivocal in calling the efforts to date a failure. "We have to do better," it says bluntly.
The Administration had held its negotiating stance close to the vest in recent weeks, officials said, partly to avoid heavy criticism from industries that contend that acting precipitously will do economic damage.
Mr. Wirth said today that those critics, who have also attacked the scientific work supporting the theory of global warming, are "bent upon destroying" the climate treaty.

HEADLINE: Clinton Grants, Then Suspends, Right to Sue Foreigners on Cuba

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
Seeking to weave his way between conflicting domestic and foreign pressures, President Clinton today granted American citizens the right to sue foreign companies that are using American plants seized by Cuba over 35 years ago, but he immediately suspended those suits for at least six months.
Mr. Clinton's election-year compromise, his aides said, was an effort to demonstrate that he is eager to tighten the economic noose around Fidel Castro while defusing the criticism at home and the threats of retaliation from the European Union, Canada and Mexico. 
 Those countries have accused the United States of using threats of legal judgments against foreign companies to force other governments into helping to isolate Mr. Castro. Those countries have vowed to impose equal penalties against American companies, especially after Mr. Clinton moved last week to deny visas to executives and major shareholders of the foreign companies.
By delaying the legal actions, Mr. Clinton puts off that conflict until after the elections in November. Meanwhile, he can argue in Florida and New Jersey, two key electoral states with large Cuban-American populations, that he is working to speed the collapse of Mr. Castro's Communist Government.
Administration officials conceded that Mr. Clinton's action today, taken hours before a midnight deadline set by the Helms-Burton law, was a muddled outcome to a highly charged issue.
"This was classic Clinton," one of his top aides said after the President sought recommendations from his Cabinet in a late-night meeting Monday at the White House. "It's creative, but it runs the risk of looking like a waffle."
The move was immediately criticized as such by Bob Dole, the President's likely Republican opponent in November. "President Clinton's continued indecision until the last possible moment demonstrates, once again, that this President is rudderless when it comes to standing up for American principles around the world," Mr. Dole said.
Even with delayed enforcement, the measure could still have a real impact, Clinton aides said. The prospect of litigation is likely to discourage foreign companies from risking investment in Cuba, cutting off one of Mr. Castro's few sources of new capital -- selling Cuba's decrepit infrastructure.
Mr. Clinton's aides insisted today that by delaying the suits, they have six months to convince the Europeans to act to isolate Mr. Castro, or risk a decision by the White House to let the lawsuits go forward.
"If we had allowed the suits today, it would begin a cycle of retaliation and counter-retaliation with our allies that would divert attention from the primary issue: Fidel Castro," said Sandy Berger, the deputy national security adviser, who pressed Mr. Clinton on Monday night to take this course. "Now, we have the means to focus their minds."
But if the action was intended to end the criticism from abroad that Washington was being an economic bully, it was not immediately successful.
Britain said today that it would consider restrictions on visas for American citizens. This was a direct response to the decision a week ago to ban several Britons from entering the United States because they are major shareholders in companies that "traffic" in American properties that were nationalized by Cuba after Castro and the Communists came to power in 1959.
The Helms-Burton law, passed by Congress and signed by the President last March after Cuba shot down two small planes piloted by anti-Castro demonstrators, defines "trafficking" so broadly that it even covers Mexican and Italian companies that have taken over Cuba's crumbling telephone system, parts of which were built by the ITT Corporation in the 1950's.
Canada said today that it would go ahead with legislation giving Canadian companies the right to retaliate if American courts penalize them for using equipment in Cuba that once belonged to ITT and to American mining companies.
"The situation remains exactly as it did yesterday," Reuters quoted a spokesman for the European Commission as saying. "European companies still have the threat of legal action against them."
Mr. Dole, however, was critical from the opposite point of view. "Allowing American citizens whose property was illegally stolen by the Castro regime to use American courts to seek justice is the right thing to do," he said.
Several of Mr. Clinton's economic advisers argued in the Oval Office on Monday night that the President should use his powers to waive entirely the section of the Helms-Burton law that gives American citizens the right to sue.
They were concerned, they said, that the law itself sets a precedent that could boomerang on American companies: It establishes an "extraterritorial" law, punishing, for example, Canadian companies for their activities in a third country. Washington condemned such actions during the Arab boycott of American companies that did business with Israel, arguing that such actions amount to blackmail.
For that reason, Mr. Clinton initially opposed the Helms-Burton bill. But when the Cuban-Americans' aircraft were shot down in February, he signed the legislation over the objections of some foreign-policy advisers.
In recent months, carrying out the bill has become an issue of enormous political sensitivity. Cuban-Americans are a relatively small constituency, but they are highly influential in two hotly contested states.
"They are very disappointed, and so am I," said Representative Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, the Democratic candidate for the Senate seat being vacated by Bill Bradley. "The Castro Government is weaker than it is perceived, and this was a chance to bring an end to that Government."
Mr. Clinton has also been seeking a way to deflect Mr. Dole's criticism that he is coddling a Communist neighbor, even if Cuba represents little threat to American security.
The problem has been that the United States is alone in its strategy of economically isolating Cuba, in hopes of speeding the collapse of the Castro Government. Europe and Canada argue that Cuba should be treated much as Washington treats China -- with economic engagement intended to slowly bring about reform. Years of arguments between Washington and its allies over this strategy with Cuba have failed to narrow their differences.
"I think that the U.S. is totally isolated on this one," Lloyd Axworthy, Canada's Foreign Minister, said last week. "Cuba has actually changed a great deal, though Washington will not easily acknowledge that."
In the days before Mr. Clinton made the decision, pressure mounted from overseas to delay the suits or prevent them altogether. The European Union threatened retaliatory steps that it knew would alarm large multinational corporations that have little interest in Cuba or its market, but that have much at stake in Europe and Canada.
The allies threatened to bring the United States before the World Trade Organization, and to order their own courts not to enforce judgments against companies that emanated from the United States.
Mr. Clinton decided today to appoint a special envoy, who has yet to be named, to try to convince America's European allies to change their view. The envoy, Mr. Berger said, would try to get cooperation in providing assistance to human rights groups, dissidents and journalists in Cuba, as the Administration did recently when it granted $500,000 to Free House, a human rights group.
The allies will also be urged to withhold economic assistance and to promote a code of business practices similar to the Sullivan principles, which companies operating in South Africa in the era of apartheid were asked to subscribe to in an effort to assure nondiscriminatory hiring.

HEADLINE: A WILD DAY ON WALL STREET: STORM CLOUDS GATHER OVER WALL STREET -- THE LAST WILD TIME;
How 1996 Is Like 1987, and How It Isn't

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
If investors were holding their breath yesterday, it was with good reason.
As the historically minded -- or superstitious -- might recall, in 1929 the stock market peaked and then, 55 days later, crashed. In 1987, the stock market peaked and then, 55 days later, crashed. And in 1996, the stock market peaked and then, 55 days later . . . 
 Ended almost unchanged. Yes, yesterday was another Day 55 for the Dow Jones industrial average, which topped out on May 22 at 5,778 points. And after Monday's 161-point plunge in the Dow, a decline that the index matched early yesterday, investors could be forgiven for thinking that history might just be repeating itself. In the end, though, the Dow gained 9.25 points, to 5,358.76, a rise of less than two-tenths of 1 percent.
Faced with wild days like yesterday, investors and analysts naturally look to the past for clues about what is happening today, and will happen tomorrow. In particular, the last big debacle in the stock market -- the crash of 1987 -- looms large in the minds of everyone who lived through it.
To be sure, there are significant differences between the summer of 1987 and this one, in both the economy and the stock market. But, according to some market gurus, some parallels exist:
*Skyrocketing stock prices, coming atop several strong years. By the time of the crash of 1987, the market had gone more than three years without falling by 10 percent -- a record at the time. This time around, stocks have climbed steadily for more than five years. In both cases, the Dow zoomed about 150 percent.
*Sky-high valuations, especially when the stock prices of companies are compared with their earnings. At the peak in 1987, stocks in the Dow traded for about 24 times their average earnings over five years, according to data from the Leuthold Group, a research firm in Minneapolis. At the end of June of this year, the ratio of prices to earnings was 23.1. To put that in perspective: since 1926, the ratio has tended to average about 15.
*A torrent of companies clamoring to sell shares to the public, resulting in a heavy calendar of initial public offerings. In the last 12 months, about 800 companies have raised $47.6 billion, more than double the previous year's activity. For the year ending Oct. 31, 1987, more than 700 companies raised in excess of $24.2 billion, almost double the level of the prior year.
*Heavy participation by small investors, especially those investing in mutual funds. The current fund boom has been building since 1992. And investors in 1987 had a boomlet of their own, pouring record sums into mutual funds.
Indeed, the numbers in 1987 form a pattern a lot like this year's: In January 1987, $5.9 billion flooded into stock funds -- at the time, the biggest month ever for funds. Fund purchases slowed a bit later in the year, totaling about $2.8 billion in August, when the market peaked.
Today, the inflow from individual investors, especially those saving for retirement, "dwarfs every other consideration" in market performance, said Steven C. Leuthold, who runs the research and money management firm. "The most important factors by far are mutual-fund flows and public confidence."
The latest numbers? Americans put more money into stock funds in the first six months of 1996 than in any previous full year, but they cut back their net buys substantially in June. Some big fund companies reported more redemptions from stock funds than purchases over the last two days.
*A sudden change in investor sentiment after the peak. This is the hardest to document, but some analysts say they are starting to see it. "There has been a shift, though it is almost invisible, from fear of being left behind to fear of losing one's behind," said James B. Stack, editor of Investech Market Analyst, a newsletter based in Whitefish, Mont. Mr. Stack, who has been bearish for some time, said he thinks investors are moving "from buying on dips to the desire to sell into rallies."
*Sudden poor performance after a market peak by stocks that trade over the counter. Recently, the number of over-the-counter stocks hitting new lows has far outpaced those hitting new highs, Mr. Stack said, a measure of the depth of the market's problems. The plunge in the ratio of advancing stocks versus declining stocks, which Wall Steet often calls breadth, is the steepest since right before the '87 crash, he said.
But the action in smaller stocks is also among the salient differences between then and now, analysts said:
*In 1987, big stocks were far more in favor than their smaller brethren, the reverse of conditions this year. Then, the blue-chip issues that make up the Dow outperformed both the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Nasdaq composite index.
Yet when the crash came, it was the Nasdaq that really got clobbered. This year, the Nasdaq moved far ahead of the indexes of bigger stocks before falling back to earth. Early last month, the Nasdaq was up 18.7 percent, versus 11.3 percent for the Dow; as of yesterday, the Nasdaq had eked out a gain of just one tenth of 1 percent this year, while the Dow is still up 4.7 percent.
Some analysts suggest that the recent declines may amount to a wringing out of excess in high-technology issues, which make up a large part of the Nasdaq and which have been the magnet attracting speculators this year. If so, the broader stock market may not fare so badly going forward.
*Conditions in the bond market are much more favorable for stocks. In 1987, the stock market rose even while the bond market plunged; yields, which move in the opposite direction from bond prices, soared by three percentage points. "It was absolutely, categorically impossible for both markets to be correct," said Robert J. Barbera, co-chairman of Capital Investments International Inc. This time, bond yields have risen by only one percentage point, and the recent decline in the stock market, he said, "is a more traditional and orderly repricing as a consequence of higher interest rates and lower" price-to-earnings ratios.
*The dollar is now relatively strong, while in 1987 it was in freefall. Today's stronger dollar carries its own worries -- mainly, that it will damage the sales and profits of American exporters, notably those of big durable-goods makers represented in the Dow.
*The economy in general is much stronger now than it was back then, at least in the view of Byron R. Wien, director of U.S. portfolio strategy at Morgan Stanley. Though Mr. Wien is a market bear, he said that "the fundamental background is very different. The American economy is fine, and the U.S. is in a much better competitive position than it was."
*It is a Presidential election year. And that may be the most important difference of all. While no one knows exactly why, there seems to be a four-year cycle in the economy and the stock market, according to Marc M. Groz, president of the Quaternion Group, a research firm in New York. And since 1941, the stock market has risen in the third and fourth years of every president's administration.
Of course, history is no sure guide, as the failure of the 55-day pattern proves. But sometimes it bears review.

INTEREST RATES -- In 1987, the yield on 30-year bonds rose 272 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 10.17% from Jan. 1 to the October market crash, offering stock investors a rewarding alternative. This year, yields have moved up ust 108 basis points, to 7.02%
 
THE DOLLAR -- In 1987, the dollar was weakening against key currencies, raising fears about inflation and a breakdown in the global trading system. This year, the dollar is strengthening, raising worries about the profitablility of U.S. exports.
 
VOLATILITY -- In 1987, there was no system in place to limit huge market swings, and computerized trading programs accelerated selloffs. Now, "circuit breakers" on both the stock and futures exchanges prevent freefalls, giving opportunistic investors time to buy on midday dips.

WASHINGTON -- Alan Greenspan, who had just taken over as Federal Reserve chairman in the summer of 1987, immediately raised interest rates to slow the economy and demonstrate his inflation-fighting resolve. Now, after winning a third four-year term, Mr. Greenspan may be more circumspect -- particularly since 1996 is an election year. (pg. D1)

HEADLINE: Netanyahu, Home, Finds Honeymoon Is Waning

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 16

 BODY:
Fresh from an American tour and boasting that Washington did not try to "twist my arm," Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has returned to new pressures at home, and is bracing for some arm-twisting by his Arab neighbors.
Upon his return, Mr. Netanyahu was greeted by withering criticism from his predecessor, Shimon Peres, and a call by Israel's umbrella labor federation for a general strike on Wednesday. And as Mr. Netanyahu heads to Cairo on Thursday for his first face-to-face encounter with an Arab head of state since he became Prime Minister, even his supporters have warned that he has a difficult mission ahead. 
 In a gesture that might appease some of his critics, Mr. Netanyahu's Government said today that it had decided in principle to ease a 19-week blockade of Gaza and the West Bank that has kept tens of thousands of Palestinians from their jobs.
But the Cabinet announcement did not spell out what steps the Government would take, and it did not say whether those steps would be contingent on further action by the Palestinians. And a bleaker measure of that relationship became evident tonight when Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, refused to meet with an envoy of Mr. Netanyahu, Dore Gold.
Mr. Peres, whom Mr. Netanyahu defeated in the May election, broke a public silence on Monday night when he told fellow Labor Party members that the new Prime Minister's first official trip had "been in the wrong direction in every sense of the word."
Maariv, a newspaper generally sympathetic to Mr. Netanyahu, has warned that the new Prime Minister cannot "rest on the laurels" of his trip to the United States and must address problems at home, including a controversy over his plans to reduce Government spending by more than 3 percent in the year ahead.
It is to protest that proposal that Histadrut, the labor federation that strongly supported the previous Labor Government, has called a general strike for Wednesday, the first in several years. And broader uncertainty over the new Government's course, even among Mr. Netanyahu's supporters, has contributed to a plunge on the Tel Aviv stock exchange, where the average share price has fallen more than 20 percent since he took office.
More than a month after he took office, Mr. Netanyahu has still not said even whether he intends to withdraw Israeli soldiers from the West Bank town of Hebron, a step required under the 1993 accord between Israel and the Palestinians and one on which he is certain to be pressed on Thursday when he meets with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt.
Mr. Netanyahu's visit to Cairo comes after weeks of warnings, in increasingly sharp language, from Arab leaders who want him to stay on the road toward peace that Mr. Peres was pursuing.
Over the weekend, eight Arab foreign ministers meeting in Oman issued a statement expressing "deep concern" at remarks made by Mr. Netanyahu that underscored his opposition to trading land for peace with Syria, to the establishment of a Palestinian state and to negotiations about the future of Jerusalem. In addition, Qatar announced that it was postponing a plan to open a trade office in Tel Aviv.
Mr. Mubarak, whose country made peace with Israel 17 years ago, has never met Mr. Netanyahu, but has so far been mostly muted in his criticism of Israel's new Prime Minister. He has said that he intends to devote Thursday's meeting to a "heart-to-heart talk" in an attempt to learn more about Mr. Netanyahu's intentions.
But both Israeli and Egyptian officials have signaled that they expect the session to be anything but gentle, and Mr. Netanyahu has taken an uncompromising line in accusing the Arab leaders of being disappointed over what he described as American "understanding" of his position.
"There's rhetoric and there's reality," Mr. Netanyahu said as he returned to Jerusalem on Sunday night. "I call on Arab leaders to drop the rhetoric, to return to the solid ground of reality."
In a diplomatic crunch leading up to the Cairo meeting, the Jordanian Prime Minister, Abdul Karim al-Kabariti, on his way home from Egypt, made an unscheduled stop in Tel Aviv tonight to meet with Mr. Netanyahu. "I sense that there is a sincere commitment from Prime Minister Netanyahu when it comes to making peace," Mr. Kabariti said after talks with the Israeli leader.
Not all of the attention that Mr. Netanyahu's five-day trip to the United States received in Israel was favorable.
Even some who support Mr. Netanyahu's hard-line stance on the terms for a broader peace have questioned his judgment in telling Congress that he would ultimately go along with a reduction in the package of $3 billion in economic assistance that the United States provides each year to Israel.

HEADLINE: Bipartisan Agreement Reached Regarding Chemicals in Foods

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
A bipartisan group of House members said today that they had reached agreement on a compromise pesticide bill that would guard consumers against dangerous chemicals in food while ending what they described as an outdated law that threatened to keep many useful substances away from growers.
The bill would repeal 1958 legislation known as the Delaney clause, which bans any cancer-causing residues in processed foods, like raisins or ketchup, if the residues concentrate higher than in raw foods. Some levels of cancer-causing ingredients are allowed in raw foods like apples and tomatoes. 
 Under the agreement, the legislation would allow only pesticide residues that pose a "reasonable certainty of no harm." That is understood to mean creating a lifetime risk of developing cancer of no more than one in one million -- tougher than the current standard for raw commodities.
The bill would create a single standard for regulating all pesticides in foods, replacing the current system that has different standards for raw and processed foods. The legislation would also let the standard be loosened in rare cases where a crop might be threatened.
Moreover, the bill forces regulators to weigh the special risks of cancer, damage to the nervous system and other harm caused by exposure of children and infants to pesticides, incorporating recommendations made in 1993 by the National Academy of Sciences. It also requires the Government to weigh the risk of breast cancer and reproductive harm in women.
The Environmental Protection Agency had been faced with banning pesticide uses on raw produce so that it could carry out bans on processed foods. Environmentalists and others sued and won in 1988, when the E.P.A. tried to work around the standard, which was created when the ability to detect cancer-causing ingredients was limited.
Scientists can now detect residues in amounts far lower than what is permitted.
As a result of the law, the environmental agency has begun singling out pesticide uses for cancellation. Chemical companies were not seeking approval for newer, possibly safer pesticides that still carried a small cancer risk.
After the agreement, Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., the Virginia Republican who is chairman of the House Commerce Committee, said, "For the first time, we will be able to address the issue of food safety comprehensively, taking into account the safety of the consuming public, preservation of the food supply and economic benefits as well."

HEADLINE: Aquatic Aerobics

 BODY:
To The Living Section:
The exercise Judith Zimmer described in "Low-Impact Workout, No Sneakers Required" (July 10) is more than a leisure activity. It may hold the secret of life. 
 Since 1979, my mother, now 86 years old, has been leading a daily aerobics class in the swimming pool at her condo in West Palm Beach, Fla. Up to sixteen glorious women -- defying hurricanes, plagues, royal divorces and vacillating interest rates -- have been stirring the waters, punching at the sky and keeping the universe in order.
 
MARILYN GAULL HOWARD
New York

HEADLINE: A WILD DAY ON WALL STREET: THE MARKET;
Stocks on Roller Coaster, But Finish Little Changed

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
The stock market rode out the busiest day in its 204-year history yesterday, and the wildest day since the 1987 market plunge, to end basically unchanged.
As the closing bell sounded at 4 P.M., the Dow Jones industrial average reported a gain of 9.25 points -- that is less than two-tenths of 1 percent -- to close at 5,358.76. This came after stocks dropped sharply on Monday, scaring investors and causing the market to open uneasily yesterday on fears that the plunge would snowball. 
 But it did not. Still, investors were treated to a roller coaster ride in which the Dow, after rising briefly, plunged by 212 points and then climbed 219 before stabilizing in the heaviest trading day ever. These swings occurred for no clear reason -- the wrenching midday plunge was followed by an equally stunning rise as bargain-hunters stepped in to push prices up again.
And technology stocks, which had soared in the first half of the year, continued to face heavy battering, although many began to rise at day's end as news leaked out that the Intel Corporation, a bellwether semiconductor company, would report strong earnings after the market's close. The technology-heavy Nasdaq market, as measured by its composite index, fell by 6.72 points, or about six-tenths of 1 percent, to close at 1,053.47 -- about where it opened for the year.
Mutual fund companies began to report a modest level of redemptions as small investors began to leave the market. [Page D1.] As buyers and sellers flooded the markets with orders, volume records were broken on the New York Stock Exchange, where a historic 683 million shares changed hands, and on the Nasdaq market, where a record 877 million shares were traded. This frenzy was a reflection of genuine confusion in the marketplace as investors wondered where stocks would head next.
Even the experts were baffled. "The reason is . . . who knows?" said Byron Wien, an investment strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "Some people say the economy is too strong, and others say it is slowing."
Prices in New York stood in sharp contrast to the dismal performance of shares on other world exchanges yesterday. Taking their cue from the Monday plunge in New York, stocks in Tokyo, London and everywhere in between suffered declines.
If Monday's market was dominated by concerns about falling corporate profits, yesterday's market had no clear force behind it. This, analysts say, reflects a belief that worries about falling corporate profits may be overblown and that investors are still uncertain about whether the market has switched to bearish.
"It has begun to sink in to investors that corporate earnings are really no worse now than at this stage in the last quarter," said Christine Callief, an equity strategist at the CS First Boston Corporation. "The heavy volume is a ray of sunshine. It suggests that when investors sell stocks, they are finding buyers. There's a lot of traffic on both sides."
Yesterday actually opened with good economic news. The Government reported that consumer prices edged up just a tenth of a percent in June, the best inflation performance since November. And industrial production rose five-tenths of a percent last month, a healthy gain. Some of the market's recent drop has been caused by concerns that the Federal Reserve, amid fears of an overheating economy, would begin to push up interest rates to stave off inflation, which would cause investors to shift from buying stocks to buying bonds.
Also on the bright side, two large industrial companies, Caterpillar and Eastman Kodak, reported better-than-expected earnings yesterday, and operating profits were also up at General Motors and Merrill Lynch. I.B.M. and Microsoft began to trade up at day's end on word of the strong Intel earnings.
Yesterday's wild ride started after the Government's positive economic report quickly sent the Dow up 45 points. But then it plunged, with the index off 166.73 at its lowest. From there it soared by 219 points before falling back to close ahead of Monday's final price by 9.25 points. Both the downward plunge and the upward ride set off "circuit breakers" which temporarily halted trading both on Wall Street and in the futures market in Chicago to limit computer-guided programs and give the market breathing room.
Jeffrey Applegate, chief investment strategist at Lehman Brothers Inc., said the volatility reflected "an immense amount of uncertainty."
"Either we are working through a modest correction in a bull cycle, or we've got a lot more correction ahead," Mr. Applegate said. "I still think there is life in this market."
Richard Bernstein, director of quantitative research at Merrill Lynch, added: "People seem to have no firm convictions positive or negative. They can't figure it out. When you have big moves in the market, you have that."
Life was eerily normal on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, where technological advances have allowed for the faster spread of information and made it easier for traders to move more shares. This is in sharp contrast to the 1987 one-day market plunge, when prices ran up to three hours late. "Everything remained orderly, even though there was more volume than 1987," said Willis P. Benedict 3d, a floor trader. "There was never a sense of panic."
The shadow of an uncertain market hung over all of Wall Street yesterday, especially at investment firms that specialize in raising money for technology companies. A robust stock market has lead to a frantic market for initial public offerings. Now, as the market gyrates daily and wobbles downward, many of those plans are being postponed.
"We're in a period of watchful waiting," said Terrence Connelly, head of investment banking at Cowen & Company. "The market seems to have caught a virus here, and the question is we don't know how serious it is. It's time for cautiousness and prudence and a number of issues we had going to the market are now delayed."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 18, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about stock trading on Tuesday misstated the change in the Nasdaq market's composite index in some editions. It fell 6.72 points, or about six-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,053.47.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Crude Oil Prices Fall as U.S. Hints Iraq Has Met Conditions

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday on signs that the United States would not object to Iraq's revised plan for distributing humanitarian aid bought with the proceeds of a limited oil sale. Comments from a United States official led traders to speculate that Iraqi oil was nearer to coming to market.
On other markets, corn prices tumbled. 
 While United States officials had called earlier versions of Iraq's distribution plan unacceptable, comments yesterday from Edward W. Gnehm Jr., deputy representative to the United Nations, suggested to traders that Iraq had largely met the United States' objections.
Approval of the plan is one of the last steps remaining before Iraq can begin selling as much as $2 billion of oil during a six-month period under an agreement reached with the United Nations in May.
"The U.S. is apparently getting closer to approving the Iraqi distribution plan," said Hugo Zagaria, a trader at Cargill Northeast Petroleum in Beverly, Mass. "That may mean the oil is getting closer, and that's why the market is down."
The United Nations sanctions committee must still approve guidelines for exporting the oil, though the group appears close to an agreement, a United Nations spokesman said. And the United Nations must set up a variety of monitors to oversee the actual oil production and exports and the distribution of aid.
Crude oil for August delivery tumbled 58 cents, to $21.80 a barrel.
Corn and soybean prices plunged for a second day as plentiful rains across western crop regions eased the stress of dry soil conditions.
As much as an inch of rain fell across at least half the nation's corn fields last night, traders said. The rains come after dry weather threatened the crop's condition. The size of the crop is particularly important since the Agriculture Department predicts only 322 million bushels of corn will be left in storage as of Aug. 31, the lowest in almost 50 years.
Corn for December delivery fell 12.25 cents, to $3.55 a bushel, at the Chicago Board of Trade while November soybeans dropped 15.5 cents, to $7.78 a bushel.
