HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains a Bit in Europe But Loses Ground Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar failed to regain much ground yesterday, despite a relatively stable day on Wall Street, rising a bit in Europe but eroding further against the yen on talk of higher interest rates in Japan.
Many currency traders were reluctant to buy or sell the dollar until they could get a better sense of the American stock market. 
 The dollar fell sharply on Tuesday in a day of wild price swings in the stock market. Stocks strengthened yesterday, but the improvement did not rejuvenate demand for dollars.
"Everyone is just sort of sitting back and licking their wounds," said Roger Chapin, foreign exchange manager at Bank One Columbus, a regional bank in Columbus, Ohio.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar stood at 1.4857 German marks, up from its three-and-a-half-month low of 1.4806 marks on Tuesday. The dollar fell to 108.68 Japanese yen from 109.25 yen. The British pound declined to $1.5455 from $1.5595.
Traders partly attributed the dollar's strength in Europe to remarks by Ernst Welteke, a member of the policy-making council of the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank. Mr. Welteke told the VWD news service that a higher dollar would help Germany's competitiveness. A more expensive dollar benefits German exporters by making goods denominated in marks more affordable.
The dollar also drew strength from weakness in the British pound, which sold off in Europe after the British Government released minutes of the June monetary meeting between Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke and the governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George. It showed Mr. George had opposed the move to cut interest rates by a quarter-point, to 5.75 percent.
Peter Wadkins, a vice president at the New York branch of Britain's Standard Chartered bank, said traders sold the pound on the news because "it gives them the feeling that the central bank and Government can't coordinate policy."
The dollar weakened against the yen after a Japanese business executive, discussing his meeting with Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, hinted that higher interest rates loomed in Japan. Jiro Ushio, chairman of the Japan Association of Corporate Executives, said Japan might raise rates before the Federal Reserve's Aug. 20 meeting. Higher rates would make yen-denominated investments worth more.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Another Government bailout, a mere $18 billion at risk.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
READY to ante up for another financial fiasco generated by regulatory myopia? Just when you thought the cost of the savings and loan debacle was pretty much past, the next Government bailout is about to hit, revolving around federally insured mortgages on subsidized housing for the poor.
This time, the cost will be much smaller: A mere $18 billion is at risk compared with more than $130 billion that taxpayers shelled out to pay off depositors at failed savings institutions. But the real question, argues Robert Litan, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution, is whether Washington will end up paying a little now or a lot more later to clean up the mess. 
 While 1.4 million poor families live in Government-owned housing, 700,000 more rent private apartments that would not have been built -- and could not be maintained -- without Federal subsidies. Owners of this Section 8 housing, named for a part of the law administered by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, negotiated "fair market rents" with the Government when the units were built in the 1970's and early 80's. Tenants pay 30 percent of their incomes to the landlords, with the difference paid by Washington.
Economists do not like this "Soviet style" system, as Mr. Litan, who was a top budget official in the Clinton Administration for a while, terms it, because the negotiated rents are no more determined by competitive market forces than the price the Pentagon pays for B-1 bombers. Mr. Litan and James Barth of Auburn University, estimate that two-thirds of the apartments rent for premiums over the local competition.
Tenants are not wild about the system, either. Since their subsidies are tied to the building, they are effectively prisoners of their landlords.
The real estate industry loved the system, but politicians are finally tiring of playing Uncle Sucker. "In an era of budget scarcity how can you defend a system in which the Government pays more than everybody else?" asks Nicolas P. Retsinas, Assistant Secretary of H.U.D.
But, in this highly partisan era where the Republicans rule in Congress and President Clinton runs the White House, reaching a consensus is never easy. And this problem is tough, because the renegotiation of overpriced subsidy contracts and the conversion of building-specific subsidies to housing vouchers useful anywhere won't get the Government off the financial hook. Mortgages on the subsidized buildings are all federally insured. And while no one knows the exact numbers, it is widely agreed that landlords would default on the great majority if H.U.D. allowed their rental income to fall to competitive levels. Hence from Washington's perspective, Mr. Litan notes, "it's pay now or pay later."
Make that "pay more later," much more. Unless Congress extends building-specific subsidies indefinitely -- an implausible outcome in light of the Federal budget crunch -- the Government will have to foreclose on hundreds of thousands of occupied units. H.U.D. estimates the foreclosure route would add $5 billion to the cleanup cost.
A tidier, cheaper fix, proposed by the Clinton Administration in 1995, would eliminate building-linked subsidies as the current contracts expire. The Government would voluntarily take a one-time hit by relieving building owners of a portion of their mortgage liability. Meanwhile, tenants in previously subsidized units would get housing vouchers that would give them the option of staying put or shopping for something better.
The Republican Congress took a rain check on serious consideration of the proposal. Instead, it extended expiring subsidy contracts for one year -- no big deal since fewer than 1 percent expired in 1996. And it gave H.U.D. authority to restructure the mortgages on a token 15,000 units. But subsidy contracts for 236,000 units expire next year.
Now the Clinton Administration is back with a revised proposal. The plan would pay third parties -- including state and local housing agencies -- to take over the Federal mortgage liabilities and make the best deals they could with landlords losing their above-market subsidized rents. Uncle Sam would share in any profits associated with hard bargaining. To win over the real estate lobby, the Administration has also signaled that it would not oppose tax breaks for landlords who would otherwise be forced to pay capital gains levies on any savings on their mortgage.
A bipartisan settlement of so complex and potentially embarrassing a problem along these lines may seem out of reach in a Presidential campaign. But Mr. Retsinas is cautiously optimistic. There is quiet agreement in Congress that future subsidies for affordable housing must be untangled from past errors in housing finance -- and at minimal taxpayer cost. "This," Mr. Retsinas says hopefully, "is no longer about ideology."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Show Little Change

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were nearly unchanged yesterday, while in the corporate bond market, Lucent Technologies Inc. sold $1.5 billion of notes in its first public debt offering.
Trading in the Treasury market was subdued as investors awaited today's appearance before Congress by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan. 
 "People are certainly nervous about what Greenspan will say and what the Fed's going to do," said William Schultz, who manages $1.4 billion of bonds at W. R. Lazard & Company in New York.
Earlier in the week, bonds had been roiled by sharp swings in the stock market and by concerns over rising interest rates. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 1/32, to 87 10/32, leaving the yield on the bond unchanged at 7.02 percent.
The calm in the bond market enabled Lucent, a former unit of the AT&T Corporation, to go ahead with its offering. Lucent sold $750 million each of five- and 10-year notes yesterday in the third-largest sale of new corporate debt this year. It will use the proceeds to help repay short-term AT&T debt it inherited.
"It's one of those hallmark deals that comes along once in a while, like Disney or Lockheed," said Robert Cessine, who manages $4 billion of corporate bonds at Kemper Funds in Chicago. The five-year notes were priced to yield 6.948 percent, or 35 basis points more than the five-year Treasury note, while the 10-year notes were priced to yield 7.28 percent, or 45 basis points more than the 10-year Treasury note, within the expected range.
Demand for the bonds may have been buttressed by recent declines in the stock market, investors said.
"The stock market is telling you the economy is slowing," said Geoffrey Kurinsky, who helps manage $18 billion of bonds at MFS Asset Management in Boston. "If you believe that, this isn't one of those companies that's going to be affected as much as a cyclical company like a steel or paper firm."
The sale followed a surge of almost 1.5 percentage points in 10-year Treasury yields this year, a rise that made some corporate treasurers reluctant borrowers.
With its sale, Lucent joins the Lockheed Martin Corporation and the Walt Disney Company, which raised some $8.1 billion in jumbo bond sales earlier in the year.
Investment grade bond issues -- those carrying a Baa3 or higher rating by Moody's Investors Service and BBB- or higher rating by the Standard & Poor's Corporation -- accounted for 60 percent of the total of the $52.8 billion corporate bond sales in the United States in the second quarter, down from nearly 75 percent of the $57.6 billion in the first quarter, according to Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: Bully-Boy Foreign Policy

BYLINE: By Gideon Rose; Gideon Rose is a fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations.

 BODY:
Recently, I asked an editor of a foreign policy journal why he wasn't publishing any criticism of legislation like the Helms-Burton Act, which penalizes foreign companies dealing with Cuban properties formerly owned by American businesses. Everyone knows that such extraterritorial sanctions don't work, he replied, so what would be the point?
There is indeed much agreement that these kinds of sanctions are misguided attempts to coerce allies into following Washington's lead on regional issues. Nevertheless, they are now official policy. Congress approved the Cuba legislation, named for its Republican co-sponsors, Senator Jesse Helms and Representative Dan Burton, by an overwhelming margin. President Clinton signed it in March. 
 Last week, the Administration invoked the law in moving to deny entry visas to executives of a Canadian mining company doing business with Cuba. This week, the Administration chose not to waive -- as it could have -- a provision of the act allowing American lawsuits against many foreign companies doing business in Cuba, although under pressure from allies it blocked such suits for six months. The trend does not stop with Cuba: Legislation now in Congress would penalize foreign businesses involved in big oil deals with Iran and Libya; the President has said he will sign that, too.
Basically, these punitive actions are fits of pique; the aim is to try to bully allies who cannot be persuaded into supporting American policy. But they are counterproductive. In the pursuit of minor foreign policy objectives, such penalties can lead to major disputes between the United States and its allies.
In the early 1980's, for example, the Reagan Administration worried that a pipeline carrying natural gas from the Soviet Union to Western Europe would help the Soviet economy and make Europe dependent. So it prohibited foreign subsidiaries of American businesses from participating. When the ban threatened relations with allies, the Reagan Administration was forced to back down.
Heavy-handed attempts to dictate the foreign policy of Washington's allies are not worth it even in the case of Iran, whose quest for nuclear weapons and support of terrorist groups are worrisome. Playing such games over the backwater that is Cuba today is risible, especially when it outrages American allies: Canada, the European Union and Latin American countries have threatened retaliation.
The current vogue for these kinds of sanctions has everything to do with domestic politics, of course. Republicans raised the Cuba issue to court Cuban-Americans and paint the Democrats as soft on tyrants. The Clinton team is trying to beat the Republicans by joining them.
This would merely be politics as usual if it did not symbolize a dangerous impulse in both parties to treat foreign affairs as a second-class arena. Damage relations with our chief allies over Cuba? Who cares? Some votes in Florida and New Jersey may depend on the issue. Expand NATO? That could undermine Washington's Russia policy, but it sounds tough and might please Americans of Eastern European descent.
These days, one of the few ways the United States could undermine its status as the world's dominant power would be to act so erratically that other nations question whether it is wise to continue their deference. This is why Helms-Burton and measures like it are more consequential than they might appear. They may erode the trust that others place in America -- a trust that makes for a safer world.

HEADLINE: The Better Welfare Bill

 BODY:
The House plans to vote today on two welfare bills. The Republican version could push a million children into poverty, victimize legal immigrants and leave no ironclad Federal safety net underneath families that search for but cannot find work. The bipartisan alternative, sponsored by Mike Castle, Republican of Delaware, and John Tanner, a Tennessee Democrat, is also needlessly punitive but at least removes the cruelest fangs of the G.O.P. measure.
The Republican bill would end the entitlement of states to increasing Federal help when their welfare rolls swell during recessions. The bill calls for penalizing recipients who fail to find work within two years, but provides too little money to prepare them to find jobs. It would cut off benefits entirely after five years even for families that looked earnestly, but unsuccessfully, for work. 
 The Republicans are threatening to allow states to knock some children covered by Medicaid off the program and prohibit legal immigrants -- who pay taxes like everyone else -- from collecting food stamps and disability payments. Besides cutting food stamps by tens of billions of dollars -- over $600 a year for the poorest families -- the measure would also allow states to cut their own welfare spending by 20 percent, hitting the poor with a double blow.
The preferable Castle-Tanner bill eliminates many of these excesses. It would provide uncapped Federal help to states during steep recessions. It would require states to provide Medicaid to children it currently covers. Children of some of the parents thrown off welfare would temporarily receive vouchers for vital services. Castle-Tanner preserves a federally guaranteed food stamp program and preserves health coverage for poor immigrant children and pregnant women. It permits states to cut back welfare spending by only 15 percent and spends $3 billion more than the G.O.P. plan on welfare-to-work programs.
President Clinton tried this week to take some steam out of Congress's rush to slash welfare by pledging new rules to require welfare recipients to sign plans to work within two years, and to sanction those who refuse available work. But that does not do much more than exhort states to enforce current law.
Even the Castle-Tanner bill, despite its compassionate virtues, cuts welfare programs too far. It would make huge reductions in food stamp spending. It would eliminate federally guaranteed cash assistance for those who cannot find work. It would rob legal immigrants of the existing safety net. But it is the best option the Republicans will allow on the House floor anytime soon.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Bulls, Bears and the White House

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN 

 BODY:
For sheer drama, the stock market has certainly surpassed the sluggish race between Bob Dole and President Clinton this summer. More striking, however, is what the two phenomena have in common. Both politics and the markets can be moved by mysterious, irrational forces. While Mr. Dole is trying to figure out why he cannot do better against a President with low poll ratings on character and integrity, Mr. Clinton may be wondering why the strong economy has not led to more stable markets.
Economists and political experts are also confused. When the markets started dropping, most analysts said it was because the economy was overheating, and that the resulting inflation would lead to higher interest rates. Higher bond rates, in turn, draw investors away from equities. Now economists say the troubles occurred because the economy is cooling off, particularly in the technology sector. 
 The complaint about good news being bad news on Wall Street is hardly new, but the latest version is truly disheartening. Everyone agrees that one of the major unsolved problems facing the United States is wage stagnation, particularly among low earners. Recently there have been signs that wages are picking up. Then, wham! Wall Street gets spooked about "wage inflation," and stock prices tumble. Did you think the conflict between labor and capital died with the cold war?
The overriding political fact of life is that Mr. Clinton's standing in the polls is due more to economics than anything else. Americans who denied the Democrats credit for the improving economy in 1994 now seem to be giving them credit, whether or not that is fair or logical. Even Mr. Dole says the President deserves some credit. History shows that Presidents with a good record on job growth, low unemployment and low inflation get re-elected.
Still, if anything could shake up the Presidential race, it would be a stock market collapse. Until recently the market has been a gravity-defying plus for the President, soaring more than 60 percent since he took office and creating trillions of dollars in new wealth. Small wonder some Democrats fear that a decline could presage economic contraction.
The Administration argues that both the stock market and the economy generally have been helped by cuts in the deficit. (This week the White House announced that the current year's deficit will be $117 billion, 60 percent lower than it was when Mr. Clinton took office.) While some economists argue that reduced Federal spending slows economic growth, Clinton aides and many on Wall Street say deficit reduction helped persuade the markets and the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates low, encouraging investment and growth.
In any case, the Republican counter-argument has not been to dispute the value of reduced deficits. Mr. Dole argues instead that the deficit was reduced in part by "the largest tax increase in history." (It was the biggest in history, but only in the sense that "Independence Day" is the biggest-grossing movie in history. Adjusted for inflation, the 1993 tax increase was comparable to other tax increases that Mr. Dole himself voted for in the past.) The Clinton tax increase has accounted for about half the deficit reduction that has occurred on his watch. In political terms, raising taxes was a "riverboat gamble" as much as President Reagan's 1981 tax cuts were. But it has certainly not killed job growth and widened the deficit, as Republicans predicted.
If most economists agree that, Wall Street notwithstanding, deficit reduction has been a plus for the economy, it sharpens the dilemma faced by Mr. Dole. He has been under fire for years from conservatives for supporting tax hikes. The political world is waiting for his economic program, to be unveiled soon. It would be a supreme irony if the strong economy under Mr. Clinton reinforced Mr. Dole's instincts, making him oppose the tax cuts conservatives are pushing to energize his campaign. Mr. Dole's performance may be more intriguing than the stock market's. STEVEN R. WEISMAN

HEADLINE: Convention Underscores Hispanic Consumer Market, and Complaints of Bias

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: DENVER, July 17

 BODY:
At the National Council of La Raza convention here, a recruiter from Wal-Mart was busy today handing out glossy brochures that boasted of the career opportunities that the discount retailer could offer Hispanic employees.
No more than 20 feet from the Wal-Mart booth in the exhibitors' hall, on tables occupied by local affiliates of the National Council, were stacks of flyers accusing Wal-Mart of barring 11 Hispanic men from shopping in its store in Amory, Miss., two years ago. In a sworn statement attached to the flyers, the men's employer recounted his protest to the store manager: 
 "And I said, 'Son, you can't do that. That's against the law. You know, you're discriminating against these men.' He was very apologetic. He said, 'I'm sorry. I'm just doing what I was told to do.' "
Betsy Reithemeyer, a spokeswoman for Wal-Mart, said in a telephone interview from company headquarters in Bentonville, Ark., that "if there was any discrimination, it definitely was a violation of our policy."
The juxtaposition of the Wal-Mart booth and the flyers condemning the chain captured in microcosm the twin themes at this annual gathering of the National Council of La Raza, the country's largest Hispanic service organization.
On one hand, the 3,500 conference participants are being courted Fortune 500 companies that are seeking to tap into the burgeoning economic power of the country's Hispanic population of more than 22 million.
Over 70 of the country's largest corporations paid as much as $50,000 each to sponsor a luncheon or dinner and maintain a booth during the organization's four-day conference, which ended today.
Latinas lined up at the Nordstrom booth to win a basket of cosmetics. Representatives of Rockwell International handed out rubber erasers in the shape of the space shuttle. Anheuser-Busch gave away 6-ounce cups of Budweiser, Allstate handed out material soliciting insurance business.
Edwina Anderson, representing Reebok, explained her company's presence this way: "Of course the ultimate goal is to sell products. But also by supporting groups like La Raza, we send a message that we believe in corporate responsibility."
But even as they were being pursued by corporate America, conference participants and their leaders expressed anger and impatience at what they say is an increasing anti-Hispanic tenor in the political debate.
Citing proposals in Congress to bar the children of illegal immigrants from public schools, to declare English the country's official language and to deny Federal benefits to legal immigrants who are not yet citizens, Hispanic leaders here complain that their people are being exploited by the political system.
"We feel that we are being used as scapegoats, that we're being stigmatized, that we are indeed the Willie Hortons of 1996," said Raul Yzaguirre, the president of the National Council of La Raza. "But, instead of it being one individual, it's an entire community that's being scapegoated and used as a symbol to divide the American people."
Mr. Yzaguirre noted in a keynote speech on Monday that none of the major Presidential contenders chose to attend the La Raza convention or any other meeting of a national Hispanic organization.
"Intended or not, the Presidential candidates are sending us a message about the status of the Hispanic community," he said. "They're telling us that we don't count, that our support is not worth soliciting and that we can be taken for granted."
The group is officially non-partisan and its leaders criticized the major parties in equal measure. But Republicans came in for particularly harsh judgments. At a debate between representatives of the Democratic National Committee and the Republican National Committee, questioners peppered the Republican official with hostile questions, ignoring his please to focus on questions of President Clinton's character.
"I really don't care about Whitewater, or the F.B.I. files," J. Homar Perez, a delegate from Washington, shouted at the Republican official, Antonio Monroig. "I care about what affects my life."
Officials of the organization say that since the passage of in 1994 of Proposition 187, a California ballot initiative that cuts state benefits, including education, to the children of illegal immigrants, the La Raza conventions have become much more infused with political activism.
This year, for the second year in a row, officials provided an update to participants on the status of pending legislation in Washington. The workshop drew an overflow crowd, with people who could not squeeze into the room standing in the hall outside, straining to hear.
Amid the corporate booths in the exhibition hall, the organization maintained a table where participants could sign and send as many as four form letters to their Congressional representatives. The letters protested pending legislation on budget cuts, affirmative action, immigration and English as the official language. By the end of the conference today, nearly 5,000 letters had been sent.
"Ever since they passed the 187 bill, the one in California, I think there has been more discrimination," Mary Lou Olivas, a delegate from Twin Falls, Idaho, said as she signed all four of the letters.

 BODY:

Charming Shoppes Inc., Bensalem, Pa., is selling $120 million of convertible subordinated notes due in 2006 through Lazard Freres & Co. The notes which are callable in three years, carry an interest rate of 7.5 percent and are priced at par. The issue is rated B2 by Moody's and B- by S.& P.

Cook County, Ill., is selling $482 million of tax-exempt general obligation capital-improvement bonds and refunding bonds through First Chicago Capital Markets Inc. The bonds are priced to yield a maximum of 6.10 percent for an issue due in 2022 and 6.05 percent for an issue due in 2016. For short-maturity serial bonds, the yields range from 4.65 percent in 1999 to 5.70 percent in 2011. The bonds are rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's Corp. because they are insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company. 

Federal Farm Credit Banks is selling $120 million in medium-term notes due in 1999 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The notes are callable in one year, carry an interest rate of 6.860 percent and are priced at par.

Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is selling $50 million of medium-term notes due in 2006 through Bear, Stearns. The notes are callable in three years, carry an interest rate of 7.830 percent and are priced at par.

First Union Corp., Charlotte, N.C., is selling $300 million of subordinated notes due in 2006 through Goldman, Sachs. The notes are priced at 99.762 to yield 7.534 percent. The issue is rated A2 by Moody's and A- by S.& P.

Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is selling $50 million of debentures due in 1999 through Morgan Stanley. The debentures are callable in one year, carry an interest rate of 6.855 percent and are priced at par.

Student Loan Marketing Association is selling $30 million of medium-term notes due in 1997 through Sanwa Securities. The notes are callable quarterly beginning Nov. 1, 1996, carry an interest rate of 6.1 percent, payable at maturity, and are priced at par.

HEADLINE: 500,000 Strike in Israel to Protest Netanyahu's Economic Plans

BYLINE: By JOEL GREENBERG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 17

 BODY:
Opponents of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's plans for Israel's economy today closed factories, banks and Government offices across the country with a general strike, which also crippled hospitals, public utilities and the national airport.
The strike was called by the umbrella labor federation, the Histadrut, which accuses the Government of approving budget cuts that will hurt middle-class wage-earners and the poor. About half a million workers took part. 
 The 10-hour shutdown and a plunge in Israeli stock prices in the last two weeks were two major indicators of public unease over the new economic measures Mr. Netanyahu pushed through this month.
But even as he was buffeted by economic troubles at home, Mr. Netanyahu prepared to travel to Cairo on Thursday to meet the Egyptian President, Hosni Mubarak. Striking a tone of urgency, Palestinian officials and Egypt's Ambassador to Israel pressed Mr. Netanyahu to move swiftly to restart Arab-Israeli peace talks and to carry out agreements with the Palestine Liberation Organization.
Mr. Netanyhau has taken a cautious line on negotiations with the Arabs, but he has acted quickly on the economic front, provoking resistance.
The Government approved a $1.6 billion budget cut last week before Mr. Netanyahu left for the United States, where, in addition to conferring with President Clinton and other Government leaders, he met business leaders in an effort to drum up investment. Mr. Netanyahu vowed to free the Israeli economy of Government controls and promised "sweeping liberalization" of the economy, including the breakup of monopolies and the sale of Government-owned enterprises.
But the budget cuts have drawn criticism from many Israelis who feel unfairly burdened by reductions in state support. These include cuts in childbirth allowances and benefits for the elderly, as well as increases in bus fares and medical fees.
The Histadrut, which is dominated by the opposition Labor Party, complains that workers are feeling the effects of the Government's belt-tightening, and the labor organization is demanding a role in setting economic policy. It said that today's strike was a first warning.
"We are striking to tell the Government that this nation is united, that its rumblings are real," said Amir Peretz, the head of the Histadrut, at a rally of thousands of protesters outside Parliament. "If they do not come and talk to us, we will not be able to stop the rumblings."
"We want to tell the Government that its 100 days of grace do not mean 100 days of quiet," Mr. Peretz said. "These are 100 days in which we expect you to speak with us."
Mr. Netanyahu was also prodded today to restart talks with the Palestinians and to carry out Israel's agreements with the P.L.O.
"We don't want to put Mr. Netanyahu in a corner, but we would like to encourage him to move quickly because the time factor is crucial," the Egyptian Ambassador, Mohammed Bassiouny, said at a symposium at Tel Aviv University. "You can perhaps convince the leaders to wait, but you can't convince the people."
Mr. Bassiouny said that Mr. Mubarak would urge Mr. Netanyahu to carry out clauses of the Israeli-Palestinian accords, including those that call for withdrawing Israeli troops from Hebron and other areas of the West Bank, and to ease a border closing of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. He also said it was time for Israel to carry out its commitment to start negotiating a final peace settlement with the Palestinians.

HEADLINE: Europe Gives Cold Shoulder To Clinton On Cuba Law

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, July 17

 BODY:
President Clinton's decision to suspend for six months that part of a law allowing lawsuits against foreign companies that use confiscated United States property in Cuba got only a lukewarm welcome today from the 15-nation European Union.
European officials warned of a new dispute with the United States over similar proposed legislation that would affect European investments in Libya and Iran. 
 European Union countries would vigorously oppose attempts to impose American law on foreign companies' operations overseas, officials said, and would go on doing business in Cuba whether the United States liked it or not.
Peter Guilford, a spokesman for the European Union's Executive Commission in Brussels, said that despite Mr. Clinton's attempt to be conciliatory, officials there were still working on plans for member countries to retaliate by denying visas to officers of selected American corporations, and on other measures.
The American law also denies entry into the United States to executives of foreign companies that "traffic" in Cuban concerns that use American property seized by the Communist Government in Havana over the past 37 years.
Though the Europeans are unlikely to proceed with retaliatory steps for days or even weeks, Mr. Guilford said, "we are preparing the legal work to go ahead with the countermeasures decided by European Union foreign ministers on Monday."
The foreign ministers gave the green light for retaliatory actions that would include taking the dispute to the World Trade Organization, establishing a list of American companies that file suit against European companies under the new law, and requiring visas for some American business travelers.
President Clinton suspended the part of the law, the Helms-Burton Act, that would allow Americans to sue foreign companies that use American property seized by the Cuban Government of Fidel Castro, which means no lawsuits can be filed for the next six months.
The German Foreign Minister, Klaus Kinkel, welcomed Mr. Clinton's decision to delay the lawsuits as "a step in the right direction," according to the Foreign Ministry in Bonn, and there were similar statements by his colleagues in Ireland, France and Spain, a strong opponent of the new law.
Mr. Clinton does not have the statutory authority to suspend the part of the law that its opponents abroad hate most, allowing the United States to bar entry to executives of certain companies.
Under Title IV of the new law, American officials announced this month that nine executives and directors of Sherritt International, a Canadian mining group, and members of their families would be barred from entering the United States starting in late August.
"We are still bothered by the extraterritorial aspects of the law," another European Union official said. Representatives of the 15 member countries are to meet in Brussels on Thursday to discuss Mr. Clinton's actions, but Mr. Guilford said further steps would depend on how upset member governments were.
After the United States Senate voted on Tuesday night to punish non-United States companies that invest in the oil and gas industries of Libya and Iran, France said it was opposed to extraterritorial legislation in principle, and said it violated World Trade Organization rules.
Britain's Trade Secretary, Ian Lang, told BBC Radio this morning, "We must bring home to the Americans the unacceptable nature of what they are doing." He said there was little likelihood that European countries would join the United States in trying to isolate Cuba economically and diplomatically.
"We believe democracy should be encouraged in Cuba," he said. "We share the Americans' objective there. But we don't see the way of doing that as being to attack trading partners in other parts of the world who are carrying on legitimate business with Cuba."
A Spanish hotel management company, Sol Melia S.A., which owns six hotels in Cuba, said on Tuesday that it had not received notification that its executives would be barred from the United States, but shares in its stock fell by more than 1.8 percent anyway.
Canada and Mexico also oppose the Helms-Burton law, and Lloyd Axworthy, the Canadian Foreign Minister, said of the President's suspension of part of it that "under the circumstances, with the pressure domestically, it was about as good as we could get."
"It's an election year," a French official said.
Mr. Clinton opposed the legislation until February, and then approved it after Cuban fighter planes shot down two small planes flown by anti-Castro Cuban exiles with the proviso that he had until July 16 to waive part of the bill.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
While Albany Fiddled, Many Got Burned

BYLINE: By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
THE Legislature and Governor relaxed last week after finally reaching agreement on the latest state budget ever. Lawmakers got their pork -- money for pet projects back home. And Gov. George E. Pataki, though an abject failure in meeting his goal of bringing in a conservative budget on time, nonetheless pronounced himself deeply satisfied because, he said, he and his administration "stuck to our principles."
Stuart Weinberg is not satisfied. He is a college administrator who was laid off because his college did not know whether the state would again finance his program. 
 Jane Velez is not satisfied, either. She runs a human services agency that had to "downsize" in anticipation of a state budget cut.
Monifa Famad is unhappy, too. She was looking forward to a summer studies program at Barnard College, but Barnard had to cancel it because of the budgetary uncertainties.
Mr. Weinberg, Ms. Velez and Ms. Famad are far from alone. The public tends to think of the delayed budget approval -- on July 13 instead of April 1 -- as an abstraction, an accounting matter. In fact, the shenanigans in Albany have had flesh-and-blood consequences. They are hurting ordinary New Yorkers -- hundreds, perhaps thousands, of people who depend on the state's largess.
There's got to be a better way to do this," said Ms. Velez, president of the Project Return Foundation, which serves the homeless, AIDS patients, battered women and drug abusers. "Nobody expects the budget to come in on time anymore. Nobody even gets mad. The only people who get upset are people like me, who have to make a payroll."
Project Return gave notice to some drug counselors in March, and cut back medical hours because of deep cuts in the Governor's original budget proposal. Some of the cuts have been restored, but Ms. Velez wanted to avoid an even more damaging scramble when the budget finally passed.
Project Return still does not know its state allocation.
Neither does Luis Garden-Acosta, president of El Puente, a community organization in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It deliberately went into debt to keep its staff members employed.
"We have not paid rent," said Mr. Garden-Acosta, who has been plowing his salary into the agency and living on savings since April 1. "We have not dealt with most of our vendors, which puts us in a real difficult situation. I don't think the public realizes that so many people in the state are going without meeting basic needs, going on I.O.U.'s to be able to survive."
MR. WEINBERG, director of the Collegiate Science and Technology Entry Program at Onondaga Community College in Syracuse, has been unemployed since July 1 because his school could not get a guarantee of new state financing. The Legislature has decided to continue the program, widely known as C-STEP, which provides courses for minority and economically disadvantaged students. But the participating colleges do not yet know their budgets. So Mr. Weinberg, father of two, expects he will be off the payroll most of the summer. "I can collect some unemployment," he said. "I can teach. We'll get by."
Barbara Deming, a secretary for the program at the State University at Brockport, is out of a job, which pays a modest $21,200 a year, for a while, too. The program director reluctantly had to take her off the payroll July 1, and she does not know when she will go back to work. "So you're doing an interview on how it feels to be a yo-yo?" she asked the other day. "Not good. It's extremely difficult to plan."
The state upset Monifa Famad's plans, too. The 17-year-old student was headed for a summer of study at Barnard College in the STEP program, which is for high school students. But because some Federal money was no longer available, and the state could not commit itself to making up the difference, Barnard had to cancel. The last week in June, the program's director, Saul Davis, notified 40 students that the program was off. They had expected to take courses in math, science, writing and public speaking. Instead, some will piggyback on another program and enroll in only one physics course.
Michael A. Molina, director of the STEP and C-STEP programs at Fordham, said he had to cancel a similar summer session for about 20 incoming freshmen.
The students will find something else to do. It is not life and death, any of this. It is simply an injustice, brought to you by the Governor and Legislature of New York.

HEADLINE: Serb Stands Firm in Face of U.S. Effort to Oust Karadzic

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, July 17

 BODY:
A round of high-profile American talks to persuade President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia to remove the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, from power in Bosnia ended without progress today, the special United States envoy to the Balkans, Richard C. Holbrooke, said.
After four hours of talks with Mr. Milosevic, the man whom Mr. Holbrooke persuaded to sign the Dayton peace accords last fall, the envoy left for Zagreb to meet with the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, and said he would return here on Thursday. 
 Diplomats said Mr. Holbrooke had threatened to reimpose sanctions on the battered Serbian economy if Mr. Milosevic did not bring about the removal of Dr. Karadzic as head of the biggest political party in the Serbian portion of Bosnia, and his immediate departure from Bosnia.
Under the Dayton accord, Dr. Karadzic, who is under international indictment for war crimes, is supposed to be arrested and handed to the tribunal in the Hague. But American officials are now eager, at a minimum, to remove Dr. Karadzic from power in Bosnia well before the national elections are held there on Sept. 14.
Mr. Holbrooke appears to be facing an informal Friday deadline for Dr. Karadzic's resignation from his post as party chief, at least. On Monday, Western officials delayed the official start of campaigning for the Bosnian elections until Friday to allow time for his removal, and said they would not allow Dr. Karadzic's powerful party to take part if he remains in office.
Unwilling to risk provoking retaliation by using NATO troops to arrest Dr. Karadzic, Western countries have threatened renewed economic sanctions against Belgrade, which is believed to have the ability to force Dr. Karadzic out. This threat may be Mr. Holbrooke's strongest lever as he negotiates with Mr. Milosevic here.
But diplomats and economic analysts wondered how seriously Mr. Milosevic would take the threat.
A Western diplomat here said Mr. Milosevic held a "healthy skepticism" about whether the major powers, who are divided over the question, would quickly organize effective sanctions like a ban on trade.
Economists also questioned whether Mr. Milosevic, a skilled political poker player, would be influenced by the economic threats or rewards Mr. Holbrooke can offer.
United Nations sanctions against Serbia were suspended after the Dayton accord but can be reimposed for noncompliance with the treaty. On the positive side, Mr. Holbrooke can offer to formally end the sanctions, lifting the cloud of uncertainty that might deter international investors.
Since the suspension of sanctions last December, there has been little improvement in the Serbian economy, largely because of the determination of Mr. Milosevic, a former Communist, to keep state controls and his refusal to allow privatization.
But daily life has regained a modicum of normality. Families no longer hoard oil, sugar and other foodstuffs and gasoline, previously sold on the roadside by black marketeers, is more easily available.
Thus, initially, the reimposition of sanctions would mainly have a negative psychological impact on the country, economists said.
"If we have sanctions again, we will have a really bad situation," said Tomislav Popovic, director of the Institute of Economic Sciences in Belgrade, and a critic of the government's policies. "But we have developed survival mechanisms and the possibility to live under many limitations."
In the longer term, however, new sanctions would be "catastrophic," Mr. Popovic said. The once healthy but now decrepit industrial base -- 70 percent of factory machinery is useless because of the effect of three years of sanctions -- would decay further, he said.
Western diplomats said that one of Mr. Holbrooke's strongest positive incentives would be allowing Serbia to re-enter international organizations, including the International Monetary Fund, the World Trade Organization and the United Nations. But a Serbian economist at the Vienna Institute for Comparative Economic Studies, Vladimir Gligorov, said that because state monopolies were enriching Mr. Milosevic's political cronies, membership in the I.M.F. and the World Bank would not be that attractive at the moment.
"They are not in a great hurry about that because they are not ready to accept the conditions the I.M.F. would put on Serbia," Mr. Gligorov said.
To gain I.M.F. support Mr. Milosevic would have to agree to politically unpalatable policies, like reducing the deficit, now estimated at between 10 and 20 percent of gross domestic product, and slashing subsidies to industry.
Politically, Mr. Milosevic seems to have little to lose by ousting Dr. Karadzic and may even gain. With Dr. Karadzic out of the way, for example, Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party would have a better chance of winning seats in the Bosnian elections.
"We are actually asking Milosevic to do something that will help him in the election but Milosevic has set it up so cleverly we have to grease his palm to get him to do it," one diplomat said.
Should he choose to act, Mr. Milosevic has plenty of economic and political leverage over Dr. Karadzic, said Serbian economists who described the Serbian-held region of Bosnia as a virtual colony of Belgrade.
The Bosnian Serb police are heavily infiltrated by people loyal to the Serbian leader, they said. Almost all of Serbian-held Bosnia's food and industrial products come from Serbia and the Bosnian Serb military is completely dependant on the Yugoslav national army, run by Mr. Milosevic.
Further, Mr. Milosevic could, if he wanted to, choke off the profitable smuggling businesses that many Bosnian Serb leaders run through Serbia.
White House officials in Washington, mindful that President Clinton faces election in November, sent Mr. Holbrooke on his mission in the hope that the Bosnian elections can proceed smoothly, avoiding a collapse of the Dayton peace effort. However, they say they feel little domestic political pressure to take military risks to arrest Dr. Karadzic.
The expected Republican nominee, Bob Dole, attacked the President's approach this week in response to questions.
Referring to the continued power of Dr. Karadzic and the Bosnian Serb military leader General Ratko Mladic, who is also under indictment for war crimes, Mr. Dole said:
"All we've heard from the Administration are empty threats, not even the minimal action of reimposing sanctions."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard C. Holbrooke, an American envoy, tried unsuccessfully yesterday to persuade President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, right, to unseat Radovan Karadzic, a Bosnian Serb leader indicted on war crimes charges. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Olympics Are a Mixed Blessing for Atlantans

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 17

 BODY:
They are stocking up on medicine, canceling trips to the mall and digging in for the long haul at Judith Barash's senior citizens high rise.
"I see people carrying in all this bottled water, and I tell them, 'What? You're running in the Olympics? What do you need all that water for?' " said Mrs. Barash, a 75-year-old retiree and one of 240 elderly residents of her building. "But people don't know what to expect. They hear things on television about running out of water, and they don't want to take any chances." 
 Indeed, two days before the official opening of the Olympics on Friday, Atlanta remains a place where no one is quite certain what to expect in terms of commuting, commerce, crowds and chaos. What is clear is that after six years of almost hysterical buildup, the Olympics are having myriad effects on virtually everyone living here, but many of those effects bear little relation to the grandiose expectations engendered when Atlanta was awarded the Games.
Despite predictions that visitors would have to go almost to Chattanooga to get a hotel room, rooms are still available in Atlanta. Despite expectations that the Olympics would be a windfall for tens of thousands of homeowners, Olympic housing rentals have turned into a buyer's market, leaving most owners disappointed. The overall Olympic economic impact seems certain to be smaller than originally expected.
Still, after six years of doubts about its ability to be host of the Games, Atlanta has apparently made it to the starting line with its stadiums built, its malls full of Russian power lifters and Dutch archers, its transportation plans in place, more or less prepared to be host to the 100th Anniversary Olympic Games.
"We'll be ready, but we won't be finished," said former Mayor Andrew Young, co-chairman of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, the host of the Games. "Every night during the Games, we'll probably have crews on the streets doing things. But the spirit of the people will more than make up for the physical things that were not completed."
Visitors will find an odd mix of corporate extravaganza and tent city. Atlanta's downtown is at once gussied up with new streets, sidewalks, signs and art and at the same time has turned into a temporary tent city looking like an insanely overblown county fair.
Locals are finding a place transformed, in small ways like the international flags sprouting incongruously in local supermarkets or outside laundromats; in odd ways like the army of people with arms like tree trunks barking into cellular phones in French or German, and in ways whose long-term impact remain uncertain.
Some Atlantans are getting the economic bonanza they expected.
Rick Patton's hotel development company has had two projects, one downtown in what had been an old bus station, the other just outside Atlanta in suburban Vinings. The new hotel in Vinings was immediately filled with the delegation from the Russian Olympic Committee and the downtown building has been turned into the Centennial Gateway Pavilion, a marketplace and eatery with a staff of about 220 people at a prime location just down the street from Centennial Olympic Park.
"We did our projections without planning on the Olympics, so these are windfalls, but they're nice windfalls to have," Mr. Patton said.
Others are benefiting in smaller ways.
John Bradford got out of the Army on June 30 and is now general manager of the Tower, a 12-story, 123-foot-high tower shaped like the Olympic torch with a 16-foot Olympic flame, which has infuriated Olympic officials by opening across the highway from the Olympic Village. In addition to his other duties with the company that built the Tower, he heads a crew of six that sells souvenirs and leads visitors up the 156 steps to the top for $3.
Workers are so hard to come by that virtually every grocery store or fast-food outlet near Atlanta has a help-wanted sign up and some local Waffle Houses are trying to lure customers into becoming employees during the Games. Those who do get green T-shirts reading, "Waffle House: Eaten There, Worked There, Got the T-Shirt!"
But there are plenty of disappointed people as well.
Donald Ratajczak, an economist at Georgia State University, said that instead of the $5.1 billion economic impact projected for the Games, the impact would be closer to $4 billion, largely because about twice as many tickets went to locals as organizers had projected and because visitors turned out to be more likely to stay with friends than in hotels. Olympic officials are quick to say that whether $5.1 billion or $4 billion, that is still an enormous economic boost.
Still, an anticipated bonanza in home rentals never materialized. Private Housing 1996, the organization set up by the Olympics to help visitors rent homes, has about 30,000 homeowners in its database. The organization expects now to rent about 1,000 private homes and about 1,500 apartments. Private rental firms and homeowners trying to rent on their own have also had much less success than anticipated.
And the Games are having a negative impact on other business. Amusement parks, museums and zoos are all struggling, partly because people are so terrified of Olympic traffic, they will not venture out. Bookings are terrible throughout the North Georgia mountains. Wedding planners and tuxedo dealers had their worst June and July ever because no one is getting married.
What's good for some people is bad for others. Carpenters, construction crews and remodeling firms have been in such demand that homeowners with modest jobs have found it almost impossible even to get calls returned. Randy Terrell tried for months to get workers for a modest 15-by-12-foot wading pool for toddlers at his community swimming club, but bids were so high and workers so hard to find he had to do most of the work himself and still does not have it done.
Dan Neilson, who delivers pizzas for Papa John's Pizza at what should be a prime location across from the Olympic Village, is distraught because the roads will be closed or gridlocked, preventing deliveries.
Sandy Walters, who cuts hair a few blocks away, is closing down because the Olympic athletes have supplanted her customers from Georgia Tech.
"They get their hair cut free," she said. "I can't compete with free."
Almost everyone is adjusting plans for the next few weeks, with many employees working from home or working odd hours, restaurants and contractors making deliveries between midnight and 6 A.M. and many businesses closing down. Some government bodies, like courts, will be closed, and Piedmont Hospital has rented a helicopter to airlift doctors in case of emergencies.
Despite widespread expectations of gridlock near downtown, no one knows for sure what will happen with traffic. Despite fears of water shortages, officials say the city is prepared for the two million to three million visitors.
While the uncertainty is nerveracking for many, particularly the elderly or those needing to get to hospitals or doctors, others are trying to make the best of it.
A. J. Robinson, head of Portman International, an Atlanta development firm, said his wife is due to give birth July 30, right in the middle of the expected Olympic gridlock.
"I've worked it out with my wife that if she plans it right, the marathon goes around our neighborhood on Aug. 4, so people can watch the beginning of it, then come by for brunch and then run to the other side of the neighborhood for the finish."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Ford Posts A Big Profit For Quarter

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., July 17

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company posted stronger second-quarter earnings today than analysts had expected, including solid profits from financial services and an improvement from its North American car-making operations. The results spurred a rally in auto issues and helped steady the stock market.
Ford said that earnings rose 21 percent, to $1.90 billion in the second quarter, or $1.56 a share, on sales of $37.94 billion, from $1.57 billion, or $1.30 a share, on sales of $36.39 billion in the period a year earlier. 
 This quarter's results were inflated slightly by a one-time net gain of $213 million, or 18 cents a share. But analysts said that the company's results over all showed Ford was beginning to rebound after nearly a year of heavy spending on the introduction of new models like the Taurus sedan and F-150 pickup truck.
Ford cut back on sales of heavily discounted vehicles to rental fleets in the second quarter, while gaining from strong demand for the highly profitable F-150 and Explorer sport utility vehicle. "We are at the inception of a period where we can expect to see improved results from the North American automotive operations," said Maryann N. Keller, an analyst at Furman Selz in New York.
David N. McCammon, Ford's vice president for finance, forecast that strong sales and profits would continue through the rest of the year, even if the stock market tumbles and the Federal Reserve raises short-term interest rates as much as half a percentage point. The 1987 market crash had little effect on car sales that year or in 1988 or 1989, he noted.
Ford's stock rose $1.75 to close at $32.25 today in fairly heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of the General Motors Corporation climbed $2, to $49. The Chrysler Corporation's shares, which split 2 for 1 after the close of trading on Monday, jumped $1.125, to $29.375.
Ford's one-time gain of $213 million was the net from two moves that had been previously announced. Ford posted a $650 million gain after taxes from the initial public offering of 19.3 percent of the common stock in the Associates First Capital Corporation, a commercial finance and leasing company.
Ford also took a $437 million charge to write down its investment in Budget Rent a Car, and now plans to take control of the rental car company, provided Federal antitrust regulators do not object because Ford also owns Hertz, the largest rental car company.
Excluding the one-time gain, Ford earned $1.38 a share, or 8 cents more than a year earlier. The consensus of analysts had been that Ford would only earn $1.21 in the second quarter, excluding one-time gains, according to a survey by the First Call Corporation.
But today's results also contained a few signs of lingering trouble. Ford spent an average of $945 in cash rebates, lease subsidies and other incentives for each vehicle sold to retail buyers in the second quarter, up from $760 a year ago; Ford has found it necessary to give a lot of money back to buyers of its Taurus sedan and Windstar mini-van.
Mr. McCammon said that Ford would offer similar retail incentives in the third quarter. But because the company is offering fewer discounts to fleet purchasers, overall marketing costs in North America fell to 8.4 percent of gross revenue, from 8.7 percent a year earlier, he said.
Net income from automotive operations in the United States was $697 million, up from $663 million the corresponding period a year ago. But the company's net income from international operations dipped to $411 million, from $427 million a year earlier, as brisk competition in Europe and Brazil eroded margins.
Excluding the one-time gain from the sale of the Associates stake, Ford earned $582 million in the second quarter from financial services, up from $472 million a year earlier.
Mr. McCammon was mildly critical of the Clinton Administration's "strong dollar" policy, echoing concerns expressed by Chrysler officials last week. The dollar's recent strength against the Japanese yen has eroded Ford's profits in Japan while making Japanese auto makers more competitive in the United States, he said.
"They're certainly making it difficult for those of us who would like to export more," Mr. McCammon said. "We have gone a little overboard" in allowing the dollar to strengthen against the yen, he contended.

HEADLINE: Building Starts on Homes Took Strong Jump in June

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
Construction starts on new homes rose unexpectedly in June, the Commerce Department said today, in the latest evidence of the resiliency of the housing market.
"So far, the strong job market and strong consumer confidence have been winning the tug-of-war against higher interest rates," said Eileen Neely, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae. 
 Housing starts rose 1.3 percent, to 1.48 million units at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, in June after retreating a revised 3.3 percent in May. The May rate was up from a previously reported drop of 4.7 percent. Many economists had been expecting a small decline in housing starts for June.
In addition, single-family construction -- 80 percent of total starts -- reached a two-year high.
The department also said that starts in April and May were even stronger than originally estimated. They totaled 1.51 million in April, rather than 1.50 million, and 1.46 million in May, rather than 1.43 million.
The national picture in June was mixed, however. While overall starts were up in the South and West, they slipped in the Northeast and Midwest. And the volatile multifamily sector posted a double-digit decline.
And many analysts expect housing starts to begin to slow this summer as mortgage rates continue to rise.
"It won't be a slump, but we won't have the breakneck pace we saw during the first half of the year," Ms. Neely of Fannie Mae said. "One indication of a slowdown already is showing up" in building permits, she said.
Applications for building permits, a gauge of builder confidence and future activity, slipped 2.5 percent in June to a 1.42 million rate.
It was the second consecutive decline.
A survey by the National Association of Home Builders also suggested that the market might be leveling off.
"The gradual decline occurs as pent-up demand from the unusually severe winter months runs its course and home buyers begin to slow the pace of purchases as a result of rising interest rates," the association said.
During June, 30-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 8.32 percent, up from 8.09 percent in May and matching the average in April 1995.
By last week, they had risen to 8.42 percent, meaning the monthly payments on a $100,000 mortgage would be about $100 more than they would last January, when rates averaged 7.03 percent.
Still, Paul Taylor, economist with America's Community Bankers, said that even at 8 percent, mortgage rates were still "at a generational low for a lot of people."
Single-family starts shot up 7.4 percent, to a 1.225 million rate, wiping out a 5.6 percent loss a month earlier.

HEADLINE: Hondurans in 'Sweatshops' See Opportunity

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras, July 13

 BODY:
Each morning, the workers spill off the buses and past the guards at the front gates of the industrial parks here, rushing to punch the clock before the 7:30 start of their workday.
Outside, anxious onlookers are always waiting, hoping for a chance at least to fill out a job application that will allow them to become part of that throng. 
 With wages that start at less than 40 cents an hour, the apparel plants here offer little by American standards. But many of the people who work in them, having come from jobs that pay even less and offer no benefits or security, see employment here as the surest road to a better life.
"In the countryside, a peon is a peon for all of his life," said Yensy Melendez, 29, a father of two and former farm worker who migrated seven years ago to this bustling city of 350,000 near Honduras's Caribbean coast and now has a factory job. "Here, it's not perfect, but at least you have a chance to improve your situation."
What residents of a rich country like the United States see as exploitation can seem a rare opportunity to residents of a poor country like Honduras, where the per capita income is $600 a year and unemployment is 40 percent. Such conflicts of standards and perceptions have become increasingly common as the global economy grows more intertwined, and have set off a heated debate about international norms of conduct and responsibility.
The recent controversy involving the television personality Kathie Lee Gifford and a line of clothing made here that bears her name provides a widely publicized case in point.
To critics in the United States, the apparel assembly plants here, known in Spanish as maquiladoras, are merely "monstrous sweatshops of the New World Order," to use the phrase of the National Labor Committee, the New York-based group that originally accused Mrs. Gifford of turning a blind eye to Hondurans working for "slave wages."
The National Labor Committee, a nonprofit group, is largely financed by foundations but also receives money from labor unions in the United States.
After the attacks on her, Mrs. Gifford has now endorsed efforts to monitor and improve conditions in apparel plants around the world. But the debate over what constitutes adequate wages, what minimum working conditions should be required and at what age it becomes permissible for minors to work continues here and in other developing countries that have eagerly welcomed assembly plants as a source of employment for their poor.
Whether workers think they are better off in the assembly plants than elsewhere is not the real issue, argues Charles Kernaghan, executive director of the National Labor Committee. Employers, he said, have a moral obligation to pay not merely what the market will bear, but a wage they know to be just.
 
Low Wage Rates Draw Criticism
 "The salaries being paid in a place like Honduras amount to less than 1 percent of the price of the garment in the United States," he said. "That's a crime." Companies could easily double their employees' wages, he added, and "it would be nothing."
But many of the people who work here and are most familiar with conditions in the plants argue that the situation in Honduras, at least, where about one-fifth of the clothing workers are unionized, is far more complicated than portrayed in the American debate over "sweatshops."
To make any kind of sweeping generalization is dangerous and misleading, many said during interviews here with more than 75 apparel workers and union leaders and visits to half a dozen plants, including the one that made clothes for the Gifford line.
Many here say critics from the north are more interested in protecting jobs in the United States than in improving the lot of Honduran workers.
Yes, workers and employers here say, some companies verbally abuse their workers on a regular basis, insist on compulsory overtime, impose unreachable production quotas or dismiss employees who become pregnant in order not to have to pay maternity benefits.
But other plants supply a subsidized lunch and free medical care to employees, are modern and air-conditioned, have agreed to union shops and generally respect workers' rights.
"You will find varying conditions and outlooks here," said Israel Salinas, president of the Federation of Independent Workers of Honduras, one of three rival labor groups seeking to organize the approximately 75,000 employees who work in the estimated 160 assembly plants in this country. "It all depends on whom you talk to and where you go."
 
A Worker's Escape From Rural Poverty
The story told by one apparel worker, Eber Orellana Vasquez, is not unusual. He is one of some 450 employees at the King Star Garment assembly plant just south of here, a Taiwanese-owned company that produces beach shirts, shorts and other sportswear for the United States market.
At 26 he is a veteran of three years as an apparel worker and a strong supporter of the union that represents the employees in their dealings with the company.
"This has been an enormous advance for me," Mr. Orellana said, "and I give thanks to the maquila for it. My monthly income is seven times what I made in the countryside, and I've gained 30 pounds since I started working here."
Before he became an apparel worker here, Mr. Orellana explained, he worked for a decade on a dairy ranch, milking and herding cows and living in a rented shack. "My only possession there was a bicycle," he said, so small was his salary.
Now, thanks to his job as a quality control checker, he owns a house of his own, "made of brick with a zinc roof," he noted proudly, in contrast to the flimsy wood and thatch roof dwellings that are the norm in the countryside, and has access to electricity and water.
He has been able to bring his wife and a younger brother, now 17, from the ranch and find them jobs in the plant.
"Every time I go to visit the ranch, everyone wants to come back with me," Mr. Orellana said. "The work there is very hard, exhausting. You get up at 1 o'clock in the morning to start your chores, and the bosses are always mean. If you drink too much milk, they will fire you."
 
Company Accused Of Rights Abuses
The clothes for the Kathie Lee Gifford line were produced by the Global Fashion plant at the South Korean-run Galaxy Industrial Park just north of town, which has been singled out by human rights advocates here and abroad as being especially harsh and abusive to workers.
In recent testimony to Congress, a former employee at the factory, Wendy Diaz, 15, said she had been forced to work up to 74 hours a week by supervisors who regularly screamed at, hit and sexually harassed employees.
"We knew that factory wasn't the greatest," Mr. Kernaghan said in a telephone interview from New York. "We knew that conditions were pretty rough there, that people were being fired for trying to organize, that it was not a good place, not near to being among the better factories in Honduras."
Wal-Mart, which markets Mrs. Gifford's line of clothes, has no production contracts at the moment with Global Fashion. But it continues to have clothing made under contract at numerous other apparel plants in Honduras, and is being pressed by the National Labor Committee to consent to an independent monitoring program.
In an interview at the plant, Paul Kim, president of Global Fashion, acknowledged that his company required compulsory overtime of its employees, had a high employee turnover rate and might demand more effort of workers than some other companies here.
But he denied Miss Diaz's charge of systematic abuse, and described the regimen here as a form of tough love that works for the good of all concerned.
"Korea used to be a poor country, like Honduras," Mr. Kim said, speaking in Korean through a Spanish-language interpreter, "but we have had a lot of development because we worked very hard. The more you work, the more you earn. That's what Central America needs if it is going to become prosperous."
 
An Industrial Boom Brings Labor Shortage
A decade ago, Honduras had virtually no assembly plants, and poor people had few options. Now, the factories have absorbed so many workers that they are creating labor shortages that have helped drive up wages for workers in other sectors, including agriculture, forestry, mining, fishing and even domestic work, traditionally the worst paid and most abusive.
"It used to be easy to get a nanny or a maid, but not now," said Jesus Canahuati, whose family owns an industrial park and several assembly plants here. "Everybody wants to work in the maquilas, because they represent an opportunity for a better life."
Within the apparel assembly industry itself, workers and employers agree, explosive growth has also encouraged the labor force to be on the move, always looking for the best offer. When workers do not like conditions where they are, both sides say, they often move to other jobs offering production incentives and increased benefits that in some cases double their base wage.
"If you don't pay more than the legal minimum, you don't get any employees," said Perry Keene, acting manager of Certified Apparel Services of Honduras, a plant here that makes infants' wear for department stores in the United States. "They will all go to other people, because it's a competitive labor market."
Another sharp difference of perspective surrounds the issue of teen-agers working in the assembly plants. The National Labor Committee and other critics in the United States contend that the practice, widespread here, is "destroying a whole generation of young women" and have called for American apparel concerns to stop doing business with all suppliers who hire children.
 
Honduran Unions Defend Child Labor
But all three of the leading labor federations here, including unions that have worked closely with the National Labor Committee in denouncing abuses of workers, disagree with that position.
Instead, acting in accordance with the demands of members whose own children are already working, they want the Honduran Government to enforce regulations that are already on the books.
Under Honduran law, adolescents between the ages of 14 and 16 can be employed for up to six hours a day. To do so, they must first obtain the permission of their parents, which is usually readily granted, and of the Labor Ministry, also easily obtained in a country in which education for the majority of the population ends at sixth grade.
"This country is not the United States," said Evangelina Argueta, a labor organizer in Choloma, a suburb just north of here with a large concentration of industrial parks. "Very few Honduran mothers can afford the luxury of feeding children until they are 18 years old without putting them to work."
Nevertheless, responding to complaints from the United States and to the fears of blacklisting that have arisen as a result, the Honduran Maquiladora Association says its members have now stopped hiring any workers under 16. Union leaders and workers say factory owners have also been reviewing their personnel records and dismissing all employees who are minors.
But that does not mean the dismissed youngsters are returning to school. On the contrary, management and labor agree that most of the children have instead sought new jobs outside the assembly sector that are lower paying and more physically demanding or are buying fake documents in an effort to sneak their way back into the apparel plants.
 
Campaign Brings Unintended Result
Mr. Kernaghan acknowledged that his group's effort to end child labor had produced unanticipated consequences. "Obviously this is not what we wanted to happen," he said.
He added that his group had discussed with Honduran factory owners an arrangement that would permit the 14- to 16-year-olds already employed to keep their jobs but shift future hiring toward adults.
"It's a tragic situation that needs to be resolved," he added. When asked how that should be done, he replied, "I may not be the right person to answer that kind of question, since I'm not an economist."
Many older workers who themselves began working at a young age assert that the American campaign may actually be hurting the very people it is intended to help.
Rene Javier Robertson, for example, left school at 13 to work as a fare collector on a bus "because with four kids besides me, my family needed me to work" and opportunities for teen-agers were limited.
"In 11 years on that job, I worked 14 hours a day, seven days a week, never got a day's vacation, didn't get paid when I was sick, and had to content myself with whatever wage the bus driver felt like paying me at the end of the day," said Mr. Robertson, who got a job on the assembly line three years ago and is now 27. "I was a slave, with no rights."
Teen-agers working at assembly plants "are a million times better off in here than out there on the street, because the maquila represents progress," Mr. Robertson added. "The work here isn't heavy, there are many benefits, and they have to respect your rights. I wish the maquila had existed when I started to work, because I could have avoided a lot of suffering."
