HEADLINE: Pesticide Measure Advances In House, Without Rancor

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
With a remarkable absence of rancor, long-divided factions on the House Commerce Committee voted unanimously today for fundamental changes in the regulation of pesticides in food.
The bill's authors said it would strengthen Federal restrictions on chemical residues in the food that people buy. 
 In approving the compromise legislation, the committee members swept aside much of a proposal backed by the food, agricultural and pesticide industries and endorsed by most members of the House. Instead, they accepted provisions long sought by the Clinton Administration and environmental groups.
New standards for pesticides, calling for "reasonable certainty" that nobody would be harmed by consuming them, would apply to all food, whether it is bought in raw or processed form. Also, the exposure limits would be established at levels intended to protect infants and children.
The bill would eliminate the current absolute prohibition against potentially cancer-causing residues, no matter how slight, in certain processed foods. The decades-old requirement, known as the Delaney Clause, has been widely criticized for years as being scientifically unsupportable.
Under the measure, industry and Government officials predicted that public exposure to the riskiest chemicals sprayed on crops would be substantially reduced over the next 10 years, the time frame that the bill would establish for reviewing pesticide uses.
At the same time, safer pesticides should be more readily approved, theoretically improving the quality, availability and price of food.
Pesticides are regulated chemical by chemical and crop by crop after complicated and time-consuming reviews, and it is too early to predict whether general pesticide use would go down under the legislation. Certainly some chemicals that are currently permitted would be banned, officials said.
It is a political deal that took more than a decade to reach, but that Democrats and Republicans alike hope will now sail through a busy Congress before adjournment. Although there remain some unresolved details, President Clinton is expected to sign the legislation.
After House proposals to roll back environmental regulations ignited an intense backlash last year, the sudden breakthrough is the latest signal of a widespread feeling among members that it is politically crucial to enact strong environmental legislation before the November election.
The compromise was reached after weeks of negotiations led by Representatives Thomas J. Bliley Jr., Republican of Virginia, and Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California. In a joint interview, they expressed confidence that the deal would hold.
Carol M. Browner, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said their bill "clearly strengthens the current law in ways that the Clinton Administration has been seeking for over three years now."
Given how long the pesticide issue has languished, the bill is now moving with unusual speed. A subcommittee passed it this morning by a voice vote. This afternoon, the full committee rubber-stamped it. The House leadership hopes to bring it to a vote, perhaps suspending the usual time-consuming rules of debate, early next week. A Senate committee will take up the issue next Wednesday.
Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the leading Republican on agricultural issues in the Senate, and Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, his Democrat counterpart, both said they wanted to enact similar legislation.
The House bill won endorsements from many industry and environmental groups.
"It is not perfect, but it should be acceptable," said Timothy Willard, a spokesman for the National Food Processors Association, an industry group.
The Environmental Working Group, which has sought strict controls on pesticides and was involved in the negotiations, said the bill "will dramatically improve the way that pesticides are regulated in food."
It is the second time in a month that Mr. Bliley and Mr. Waxman, who have been bitter opponents over issues like tobacco, have come to terms over major environmental legislation. The other bill, involving drinking water purity, is still being debated in a conference committee.
In the pesticides bill, as in the water bill, Mr. Bliley gave in to Mr. Waxman on several major points.
The most critical was the quid pro quo for repealing the Delaney Clause. In exchange, Mr. Waxman won a new standard for protecting the public: that pesticides and additives may be approved on food only if there is a "reasonable certainty of no harm" from exposure to the chemicals.
Among the other changes that many environmentalists supported was one to protect children explicitly from exposure to pesticides, as recommended by the National Academy of Sciences. They also endorsed a provision to make more information about pesticides in food available to supermarket shoppers, including disclosures when pesticides have been permitted because banning them would cause too much economic harm to growers.
But some environmental groups objected to certain provisions of the legislation, and said they would seek changes in the Senate.
As an example, Mary Raftery, the legislative director for the California Public Interest Research Group, cited a provision that would prohibit states from setting standards that are stricter than those established by Federal law. California, with its big fruit and vegetable industries and a history of ballot initiatives to go beyond Federal health and safety standards, is the state most likely to be affected by the restriction in the House bill.

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
On the Rise: Instant Selling Success

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
The New York City real estate market is full of tales of sellers who put their houses or apartments on the market, clean them every morning just in case an agent comes by with some eager buyers, only to wait and wait for an offer that seems to never come.
Although the last few years have been grim for many sellers -- average selling times have dragged out to over a year in some parts of the region -- there are now an increasing number of tales of instant selling success that give heart to the anxious seller. 
 These tales of split-second success -- referred to by one real estate company executive as "here today, gone tomorrow" -- seem to give weight to what sales agents have been saying lately: if a property has what it takes -- a fair price, a desirable location and, often, move-in condition -- one morning's wait may be all that is required.
The William B. May Company, a real estate broker in Manhattan and Brooklyn, issued a lengthy list this week of deals that took place in record time, including one for a four-story, one-family house at 295 Sterling Place in the Prospect Heights section of Brooklyn that sold for the full price of $449,000 in 20 minutes.
Another house, at 167 East 94th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues in the Carnegie Hill section had multiple offers the first day and sold for the full price of $1.25 million.
What happened with the Carnegie Hill house was not uncommon in this summer's market, brokers say. The buyers had been looking for exactly this type of five-story house, in exactly this neighborhood, for months.
When it came on the market, both broker and buyer jumped.
Echoing the remarks of other real estate company executives, Peter Marra, William B. May's president, cited what he termed "the current fear of losing out."
"People now may have missed a few things," he said. "There was a big surge of accepted offers in the fourth quarter of 1995 and the first part of 1996, and there's not a lot of good stuff around."
Marc Broxmeyer, a partner in Bellmarc Realty, agreed. "There's very little product available," he said, adding that Bellmarc sold more apartments this year than in any similar period in its 17-year history.
"People are just waiting, waiting for a specific apartment or a specific building or a specific neighborhood. They know exactly what they want; they're educated because they've lost out. They're ready to do it."
Mr. Broxmeyer listed two of his company's sales: a two-bedroom apartment on East 8th Street near University Place that sold for $430,000 -- the asking price was $460,000 -- in only one day, with several people bidding. A convertible two bedroom -- one bedroom and a dining area -- on East 40th Street near Third Avenue sold in a day for $257,000, only a few thousand dollars less than the asking price of $259,000.
Despite the euphoria, brokers are quick to caution that not every apartment put on the market sells.
Clark Halstead, who runs the Halstead Property Company, said that a property had to be priced right at the beginning or it would not sell for a long time. Sellers who try to test the water with higher prices and plan to come down later may find themselves with a property perceived as shopworn to the brokerage community, Mr. Halstead said.
Besides price, an apartment or town house must be in the right location and preferably have an unusual feature that is in demand, said Alan Rogers, managing director of the Douglas Elliman real estate brokerage firm. "Right now, there's a whole group looking for double-height living rooms," he said, "and when a double-height living room comes up, there's a stampede."
Brokers say they have waiting lists for huge prewar apartments in posh Park or Fifth Avenue co-op buildings, and for any size apartments with exquisite outdoor terraces suitable for entertaining.
Barbara Corcoran, president of the Corcoran Group, a real estate firm, related several examples of one-day sales, including one on East 9th Street in Greenwich Village: a 600-square-foot one bedroom with a 1,000-square-foot terrace.
"It was bought by a famous European designer," she said, "who was the first one in the door. He paid the full asking price of $410,000 -- and nobody else even got to see it."
Many brokers report that prices are, on average, higher than they were a few years ago, at the depth of the real estate recession.
"There are no steals," Mr. Rogers said, "but where there is pent-up demand and so many people waiting for new product, especially if it is a particular type of apartment they want or in the building they want, they will run to go see it." Then, if it is fairly priced, they will take it, he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed on Trade Data, Greenspan and German Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed against leading currencies yesterday, after being buffetted by trade data, speculation about German interest rates and testimony from Alan Greenspan.
A rally in the United States bond market failed to lift the dollar. 
 "The dollar made a couple of attempts to go higher with bonds, but on each occasion fell" to profit taking, said John Rothfield, an international economist with Nationsbanc-CRT in Chicago.
In late trading in New York, the dollar stood at 1.4920 German marks, up from 1.4857 marks on Wednesday. The dollar also traded at 108.46 yen, just down from 108.68. The British pound was unchanged at $1.5455.
The dollar tumbled in early trading in New York after a report of a lower United States trade deficit with Japan raised speculation about an increase in Japanese interest rates, which typically would make the yen more attractive.
But the dollar then gained on expectations for lower German interest rates after a widely watched German confidence survey from the Ifo economic research institute showed that business managers lost confidence in June after two months of brightening prospects.
The survey helped revive speculation that the Bundesbank would need to cut interest rates to stimulate the German economy. Such a view had subsided in recent days, particularly after the Dutch central bank decided on Friday to raise an important interest rate, which suggested that rate-cutting in Europe had ended for the moment.
But the report and recent comments from Bundesbank officials have led some traders to expect that the central bank would lower its 14-day repurchase rate as soon as next Thursday.
Mr. Rothfield of Nationsbanc-CRT said the mark fell as investors turned to the Spanish peseta, the Swedish krona and the Italian lira, moves helpful to the dollar along with the rally in the stocks and bonds.
The dollar fell in the afternoon after investors decided that Mr. Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, had hinted that a rise in short-term interest rates was not imminent.
The markets had assumed the Fed would tighten rates at its Aug. 20 policy-making committee meeting, if not sooner, to offset inflation amid growing signs of a stronger economy.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday: 1.2198 Swiss francs, up from 1.2121; 5.0335 French francs, up from 5.0325 and 1,518 Italian lire, down from 1,520.

HEADLINE: U.N. Chief Approves a New Plan To Allow Iraq to Start Selling Oil

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 18

 BODY:
Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali approved an amended Iraqi plan today for distributing food and other relief supplies bought with proceeds from oil to be sold under an exemption to international sanctions.
The Secretary General's approval of the reworked plan, which the United States had criticized in its original form as being full of loopholes and evasions, removes a major hurdle to the signing of Iraqi oil contracts. 
 Diplomats and United Nations officials said today that the original Iraqi distribution proposals had been rewritten here to meet American objections, then sent back to Baghdad.
Iraq agreed in May to accept a 1995 offer contained in a Security Council resolution allowing up to $2 billion in oil to be sold for relief supplies over a six-month period. The exemption is renewable.
If a Security Council committee also approves the distribution plan and other proposals governing technical details of sales, all that remains to be done is to hire professional monitors to oversee the oil contracts and relief officials to verify that all supplies are reaching the needy.
Edward W. Gnehm Jr., the deputy United States representative at the United Nations, who was Ambassador to Kuwait during the Persian Gulf war, said he was confident that the original intent of the exemption could be preserved under this plan.
But he cautioned that experience with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq had taught diplomats to be guarded.
"We don't think for a moment that there aren't going to be problems," Mr. Gnehm said. "We intend to remain as vigilant and as careful and as hard-nosed in the future as we have been in the past."
Events today seemed to underline his point. The approval came on the same day that international weapons monitors in Baghdad had to suspend operations because the Iraqis were blocking a site accessible only through what the Iraqis called a "presidential area."
Rolf Ekeus, the Swedish diplomat who is chairman of the commission disposing of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, said today that this was a new rationale for noncooperation from the Iraqis. On June 24, Iraq signed an agreement with Mr. Ekeus pledging to give United Nations investigators "immediate, unconditional and unrestricted access."
Until Mr. Ekeus's commission has finished its work, Iraq cannot hope for a lifting of the economic sanctions imposed after its 1990 invasion of Kuwait. The commission believes that the Iraqis may still be concealing weapons and that searches must continue.
To plug any loopholes in the plan, a letter today to the Iraqi negotiator, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, from a senior adviser to Mr. Boutros-Ghali made clear that the approval was granted on condition that the plan adhered to Security Council resolutions.
The letter also noted that the Council sanctions committee -- on which all Council members sit -- would have the last word on goods Iraq wanted to import with money from the oil sales.
The United States had charged that Iraq wanted to import high-technology equipment that did not qualify as aid for the Iraqi people, who have suffered from the lack of medicines, food and other daily necessities as a result of the United Nations sanctions.
Diplomats and officials say they are reluctant to estimate when all the pieces of the oil-for-food plan will be in place and oil can be pumped, but Mr. Anbari said today that the Iraqis were "ready to go tomorrow."

HEADLINE: Looking Both Ways on Cuba

 BODY:
Faced with reprisals by the European Union, Canada and Mexico, President Clinton chose to retreat from enforcing the most obnoxious section of the Helms-Burton Act, which imposes new sanctions against Cuba. He could have waived the section, known as Title III, for six months. Title III says that any foreigner who "trafficks" in American property seized by Cuba will be judged as causing damage to former owners, including Cubans who have since become American citizens.
He did not waive Title III. What he did do was suspend the right to sue foreigners for damages in American courts for six months -- until Feb. 1, well after American elections. Under this compromise, confected by the Administration's legal wizards, the President has embraced a principle dear to Cuban-American hard-liners in Florida while blunting its enforcement. 
 Still, judging by the initial reaction, Mr. Clinton's face-both-ways maneuver is merely feeding the controversy it was supposed to quell. Europeans, Canadians and Mexicans view Helms-Burton as an attempt to impose United States domestic law on their countries in order to enforce an American trade embargo against Cuba that enjoys virtually no international support.
They note, correctly, that Washington has historically opposed such secondary boycotts and worry that the Senate has approved an amendment that would employ the same weapon against Iran and Libya. They are especially affronted by a provision barring foreigners and their families from entering America if an adult member has "trafficked" in property confiscated by Cuba. In reprisal, the European Union approved a range of countermeasures this week, including requiring visas for American business travelers.
Mr. Clinton insists that isolating and bludgeoning Cuba will hasten democratization, a view shared by hard-line Cuban-Americans. But Europeans, Canadians and Mexicans ask why America's Cuban strategy differs so radically from its approach to other Communist states. Trade and political engagement hastened the collapse of the Soviet empire, and Washington now advocates a similar approach to China. Why sow ill will and risk reprisals over a bill that even the Administration only half-heartedly defends?

HEADLINE: Marco Rivetti, 52, Marketer Of Italian Designer Labels

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Marco Rivetti, the Italian entrepreneur who helped turn European designer labels into household names worldwide, died last Saturday at his home in Turin. He was 52.
The cause was lung cancer, said Group G.F.T. in Turin, the family business he headed as chairman and chief executive officer through its heyday in the 1980's. 
 Mr. Rivetti provided the vision that made the distinctive creations of Armani or Valentino, to name but two, popular in the United States. His skill as a merchandiser of fashions introduced Italian-made fashions to many upscale department stores and boutiques.
G.F.T. -- the Gruppo Finanziario Tessile -- started decades earlier as a supplier of uniforms. It was largely to his credit that it grew into a dynamo of haute couture humming in New York and Tokyo and other fashion-conscious capitals.
Mr. Rivetti joined his father, Franco, in the business in 1970. His knack for marketing first became evident when he approached Emanuel Ungaro.
Other arbiters of style soon joined the fold, like Giorgio Armani and Valentino Garavani, Claude Montana, Joseph Abboud and Calvin Klein menswear. Mr. Rivetti offered attractive licensing agreements, reportedly with double-digit royalties and cushions to protect the designers from the often painful ups and downs at the sales counter.
In the 1980's, the apparel industry became a pillar of Italy's export business, thanks largely to houses like the fashion conglomerate G.F.T. The top designer labels sold at almost any price in the affluent countries of western Europe and North America, and big buyers jostled at ready-to-wear shows in Italy.
By the late 1980's, G.F.T. was the world's largest maker of designer labels. It struck out into manufacturing in the United States, China and Czechoslovakia and rang up record sales of just over $1 billion in 1989.
But the economic climate eventually soured. Mr. Rivetti's fashion strategy was tripped up by overextension and royalty arrangements, rising labor costs and a bewildering sprawl of the market in Asia. The company that almost single-handedly wakened the taste for Italian designs in the United States went into debt. In 1991, for the first time in 61 years, it lost money.
Mr. Rivetti gave up the helm that year, saying: "I'm not capable of managing difficult moments." He engaged an outsider, Vittorio Levi, to take his place as chief executive officer. That, too, was a first for the family, which later put the company up for sale.
In 1994, the next year, after several false starts, the banks that had been trying to rescue the company found a solution. An investment arm of the Fiat group, Gemina, bought G.F.T. and managed to turn a net profit of $11 million in 1995, the first black ink on the bottom at G.F.T. in four years.
Marco Rivetti was born in Turin. He studied economics in Italy and the United States. He served as president until last year of Pitti Immagine, an organization that holds several Italian trade shows.
He is survived by a sister, Giovanna Rivetti.

HEADLINE: Former Scott Paper Chief Named To Top Position at Sunbeam

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 18

 BODY:
The Sunbeam Corporation said today that it had hired Albert Dunlap, the former chief executive of the Scott Paper Company, who is known as an aggressive cost-cutter, to try to turn the appliance maker around.
The 58-year-old executive succeeded Roger Schipke, as chairman and chief executive, who quit in May after failing to increase profits. Hurt by higher material costs, shipping difficulties and a slowdown in consumer spending, Sunbeam's earnings fell 42 percent in the first quarter. 
 Analysts had criticized Mr. Schipke for failing to increase sales by introducing new products or making acquisitions. Separate departments were often at odds and failed to work toward one goal, they said.
"The company's No. 1 problem has been lack of a strategic plan, and its No. 2 problem is accountability," said William Steele, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds. "There is no question that Al is a taskmaster with those issues," he said of Mr. Dunlap.
In his 18 months as Scott Paper's chief executive, Mr. Dunlap dismissed about 11,000 workers -- one-third of the employees -- and sold $2 billion of assets before selling the company to the Kimberly-Clark Corporation for $9 billion. The same treatment is expected at Sunbeam, whose earnings have fallen below expectations in five of the last six quarters.
"He's going to get to work his magic on Sunbeam by holding managers accountable for their budgets and projections," Mr. Steele said. "A restructuring is imminent within the next three months."
Mr. Dunlap said he would buy $3 million of Sunbeam stock, and Sunbeam said the company's shares would be a major part of his pay package.
Trading of Sunbeam stock was halted on the New York Stock Exchange this afternoon before the announcement of Mr. Dunlap's appointment. The stock last traded at $12.50, well below its 52-week high of $20.125, reached in March. Sunbeam's shares have risen only 4.9 percent a year since 1992, far less than the 16 percent annual increase in the Standard & Poor's 500 Index.

HEADLINE: Burmese Dissident Urges Western Sanctions to Oust Military

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, July 18

 BODY:
In a videotape smuggled out of Myanmar and made public today, the campaigner for democracy and winner of the Nobel prize, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, issued a call for international sanctions to be imposed on her country to force political change on the military rulers.
"What we want are the kind of sanctions that will make it quite clear that economic change in Burma is not possible without political change," Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi said in the videotape, which was shown by members of the European Parliament. 
 Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi dismissed fears that sanctions would hurt ordinary Burmese. "I think that the only people whom sanctions will affect are the privileged ones," she said.
Her appeal coincides with mounting pressure in the West for action against the rulers of Myanmar, who cracked down on the democracy movement in May.
In Strasbourg, France, members of the European Parliament passed a non-binding resolution today urging the European Union to end all trade, tourism and investment ties with Myanmar.
So far the European Union has resisted sanctions, with many countries arguing that without similar moves from China and other Asian nations, sanctions would be meaningless.
But Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi differentiated between Asian investment and potential investment by the European Union and the United States.
Asians, she said, invested mainly in hotels, department stores and tourist-related businesses. "These, of course, are only related to the very privileged groups," she said, while Western investment would be in the basic projects that Myanmar needs if it is to grow economically.
She said sanctions would help the democracy movement by discouraging investors. "Good business anywhere is very much dependent on confidence," she said. "We think this is the time for concerted international efforts with regard to the democratic process in Burma."
The videotape, which European Parliament officials said was filmed within the last two weeks, also showed Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi addressing supporters.
Pressure has been growing on governments and companies to shun Myanmar. The Carlsberg and Heineken breweries both announced earlier this month they were ending business dealings there after pro-democracy groups called for a boycott of the companies' products.
Within the European Union, Denmark has been the driving force for sanctions, after the June 22 death in prison of James Leander Nichols, its honorary consul in Yangon, the capital.
Mr. Nichols, who also represented Finland, Norway and Switzerland, was Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi's godfather. She did not mention the incident in the video.
The United States has also expressed concern. Secretary of State Warren Christopher plans to consult his counterparts from the Association of South-East Asian Nations on the issue when he meets them this weekend in Jakarta, Indonesia.
But the secretary general of Asean, Ajit Singh, said today that Myanmar would not be an issue.
"The West and the media are going on a witch hunt," he said, because Myanmar "is not an issue at all as far as Asean is concerned."
Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi also announced through a spokesman today that she would attend a government-run ceremony on Friday to mark the anniversary of her father's assassination.
The ceremony marks the date, July 19, 1947, when her father, Gen. Aung San, and eight other leaders of the pro-independence movement were killed as they prepared for the end of British rule.
If Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi had shunned the ceremony, it might have been seen as an affront to the military at a time when relations between the opposition and the Government are already strained.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Lower Costs, Better Sales Bolster Sears

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 18

 BODY:
Sears, Roebuck & Company reported today that its performance was strong in the second quarter, a result of lower costs and robust sales at its Sears stores and furniture, hardware and other specialty stores.
Although net earnings were down 51 percent compared with the similar period a year earlier -- $274 million, or 67 cents a share, versus $559 million, or $1.41 a share -- the 1995 quarter included gains from the spinoff of Allstate Insurance Group and the sale of the Homart Development Company. Without those one-time gains, Sears's profit in last year's quarter was $218 million, or 54 cents a share. 
 The most recent results exceeded Wall Street expectations. Analysts had been expecting profits of about 64 cents a share, according to a survey by First Call.
Sears operates more than 800 department stores and 1,500 specialty stores. Its stock rose 25 cents yesterday, closing at $46.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.
"This was a nice clean quarter, typical of Sears, with strong sales throughout the company and margin improvement beyond what I expected," said Peter Schaeffer, an analyst with Dillon, Read & Company.
Sears continued to outperform its competitors because of its apparel business, which was revamped in recent years, and strong sales of hard goods like appliances and hardware.
The company, based in Hoffman Estates, Ill., a Chicago suburb, said sales rose 11 percent, to $9.13 billion. Sales at stores open more than a year rose 9.4 percent. Such sales are considered a more reliable gauge of a retailer's performance.
At Sears stores, sales were especially strong in appliances, and all apparel segments had significant increases.
The retailer's specialty chains like Homelife furniture, Sears hardware and Sears dealer stores had same-store sales growth of more than 11 percent.
Gross margin rose to 26.4 percent of sales from 25.8 percent. Selling, general and administrative costs narrowed to 21.3 percent of sales from 21.8 percent in the quarter a year earlier.
Sears said its operating loss at its international operations -- Canada and Mexico -- widened to $14 million from $2 million. The company attributed the loss to weak economic conditions and competitive pressures in those countries.

HEADLINE: Detroit Mayor Leads Democrats In Attack on Dole Urban Policy

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 18

 BODY:
Hours before Bob Dole arrived here this afternoon, the city's Mayor attacked the Republican Presidential candidate's urban policies, part of a new and organized effort by Democratic mayors to criticize Mr. Dole as he campaigns across the country.
Mayor Dennis W. Archer, who is president of the National Conference of Democratic Mayors and co-chairman of the Democratic National Convention's platform committee, issued an open letter to Mr. Dole, calling attention to policies that he supported and that are unpopular here. 
 Mr. Archer criticized plans by the Republican-controlled Congress to cut summer job programs and college student subsidies. He asked Mr. Dole whether he would pledge to put 100,000 police officers on the nation's streets, as President Clinton promised in his 1994 anti-crime bill. And after noting that 80 percent of Detroit's residents are members of minorities, the Mayor pressed Mr. Dole for his views on affirmative action.
"Would you end it as promised in earlier speeches, or would you mend it?" Mr. Archer asked.
Nelson Warfield, the Dole campaign spokesman, dismissed the Mayor's attacks, saying, "We never expected to win 100 percent of the vote, and I think Mayor Archer was lost to us a long time ago."
Since Mr. Dole began campaigning full time after resigning from the Senate in June, the Clinton campaign has been urging Democratic officials to attack his record as he travels nationwide, said Ann F. Lewis, the Clinton campaign's deputy manager.
"We do encourage state and local elected officials to speak out on the issues," she said. "They have the credibility; they have the stature."
While Mr. Archer is the most prominent Mayor so far to attack Mr. Dole, he is not the first. Last month Mayor Jerry E. Abramson of Louisville, Ky., issued a similar open letter to Mr. Dole as the candidate began his campaign in the Midwest.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Sees Robust Growth Slowing Down

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the robust economic growth of recent months should moderate later this year, but he warned that the central bank might have to raise interest rates anyway to insure that the slowdown happened promptly enough to avert a surge in inflation.
Investors interpreted Mr. Greenspan's remarks as a reprieve from the threat of an immediate rate increase, but many economists drew the opposite conclusion and said Mr. Greenspan was providing the markets with an unusually clear warning that the Fed was close to a decision to tighten monetary policy. 
 "Mr. Greenspan was putting the markets clearly on notice that the Fed is on track for a policy tightening, most likely sooner rather than later," said John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers.
In testimony before the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan, as is usual in his public statements, gave no explicit statements about the Federal Reserve's plans for interest rates.
But while he painted a picture of an economy in which there has been no rise in inflation despite the unexpectedly strong growth rate of the first half of the year, he cited a number of warning signs. He suggested that economic indicators due in coming weeks, including assessments of job growth and wage increases, could lead the Fed to a pre-emptive strike against inflation by raising rates this summer.
"The economy is already producing at a high level, and some early signs of pressures on resources are emerging, especially in the labor market," Mr. Greenspan said.
Despite a lack of upward pressure so far on either consumer or industrial commodity prices, Mr. Greenspan added, "there are early indications that this episode of favorable inflation developments, especially with regard to labor markets, may be drawing to a close."
Mr. Greenspan said the Fed considered itself to be in a state of "heightened surveillance" and that signs the economy was slowing would have to "become evident within the period immediately ahead" to allay concerns about building inflationary pressures.
"We don't see any acceleration, but it's still too early to basically argue that the relative exuberance that we saw in the spring and early summer has simmered down as yet, so that there is a very legitimate concern at this particular point about where the economy is heading," Mr. Greenspan said. "And I don't think anybody knows for sure."
Mr. Greenspan also characterized the recent volatility on Wall Street as a normal process in which investors, after a long run-up in stock prices, were adjusting their expectations to fit an evolving and somewhat confusing economic situation.
"I think the reason why the most recent volatility has caught our attention is that we haven't had much of that in recent years, and it is that which is unusual, not the most recent period," Mr. Greenspan said.
The Federal Reserve's policy-making committee is scheduled to meet next on Aug. 20. But some analysts believe it may raise interest rates even earlier if new data indicate that the economy is continuing to expand at a relatively rapid pace. But any such increase is expected to be modest, perhaps only a quarter point.
The Fed last raised the Federal funds rate on overnight bank loans, by a half-point, on Feb. 1, 1995. Since then, all of its moves have been to lower rates, ending with a quarter-point cut on Jan. 31, when many analysts were predicting the economy was heading into a recession. Currently, the Fed's target rate for Fed funds is 5.25 percent.
Any public analysis of the economy by Mr. Greenspan is seized on by investors and analysts for clues to the direction of monetary policy. But his testimony today, part of his semiannual report to Congress, was scrutinized especially closely because of the jittery state of the financial markets and because the economy appears balanced between overheating and throttling back to a sustainable growth pace.
Under those circumstances, Mr. Greenspan was uncharacteristically direct in addressing the economy's strengths and weaknesses and in providing analysts with a road map to the Fed's decision-making process over coming weeks.
On the plus side, Mr. Greenspan said, inflation is "quiescent" and "there are a number of reasons to expect demand to moderate and economic activity to settle back toward a more sustainable pace in the months ahead."
Among the factors that would cool off the economy, he said, were the increase over the last four months in long-term interest rates, the surging strength of the dollar and a petering out of spending by consumers and businesses.
So far, though, no evidence of a slowdown has materialized, Mr. Greenspan said, even in the housing sector, the part of the economy most sensitive to rising long-term interest rates.
On the minus side, Mr. Greenspan flagged several specific warning signals of incipient inflation. He said businesses had reduced their inventories to very low levels, and that companies might rebuild their stocks if they encountered delays in getting parts and supplies they need to keep their production lines running.
"Indeed, indications of some mounting delivery delays in June do raise warning flags in this regard," Mr. Greenspan said.
Moreover, Mr. Greenspan said, the combination of low unemployment with strong growth is beginning to put pressure on wages, a development that often sets off an inflationary cycle by encouraging companies to raise prices to maintain their profit margins.
"The surprising strength in the employment cost index for wages and salaries in the first quarter raises the possibility that workers' willingness to surrender wage gains for job security may be lessening," he said.
"Clearly, in this environment, the Federal Reserve has had to become especially vigilant to incipient inflation pressures that could ultimately threaten the health of the expansion," the Fed chairman said. "The relatively good inflation performance of the past few years, as best we can judge, owes in part to transitional forces that are only temporarily dampening the wage-price inflation process."
By specifying the potential bottlenecks he is monitoring, Mr. Greenspan was telling the markets what economic indicators the Fed would study most closely in coming to a decision on whether to tighten policy at or before its next scheduled meeting on Aug. 20.
First is the employment cost index for the second quarter, which is to be issued on July 30. On Aug. 1 comes the National Association of Purchasing Managers report, which contains data on lead times for deliveries of parts and supplies. And on Aug. 2 come data on how many jobs the economy added in July.
"I read Greenspan as saying the Fed does not yet have quite enough evidence in terms of inflationary pressures to move, but that it will not have much patience if the economy continues to grow at a rate close to its rate in the first half," said Paul L. Kasriel, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Jumps Again, Particularly With China

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit surged in May for the third consecutive month, to $10.88 billion, the Commerce Department reported today. It said that China nearly supplanted Japan for the first time as the country with the biggest surplus in trade with the United States.
The overall deficit rose by 13.2 percent, from a revised total of $9.61 billion in April, as a resurgent American economy produced a buying spree of imported cars, toys and clothing. 
 The May tally marked the highest monthly gap between imports and exports since the agency made changes in January 1992 in how it reports the figures. It also might have been the largest monthly imbalance since the last quarter of 1987, but department officials said it was impossible to say for sure, given the record-keeping changes.
Most analysts were surprised at how much the trade deficit had shot up since bottoming out in the $6 billion to $7 billion range last fall and early this year. Some said the increase could give Republicans a new lever to challenge President Clinton's trade policies, especially the handling of disputes with China.
The deficit with China jumped by 31 percent in May, to $3.06 billion, as American consumers bought more than four times as much from China, ranging from toys to footwear, as that country took in from American suppliers.
By contrast, the gap in trade with Japan, which has typically been America's largest with a single country, fell by 23.7 percent in May, to $3.13 billion, as Americans bought substantially less and sold more there.
But the latest figures also carried a measure of good news for the Administration, as Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor was quick to note.
While the overall value of imports jumped 2.6 percent in May to a record $80.64 billion, exports of goods and services also hit a record, rising 1.1 percent, to $69.76 billion.
Mr. Kantor said both numbers reflected the effects of the recent strength in the economy. He said the growth in exports of American goods had created thousands of high-paying jobs, while a bigger surge in imports was inevitable "when you have an economy that's stronger than your major trading partners."
Still, several private economists said the increase in the deficit could be a sign that American factories might not be producing quite as much as they had projected. And some said that as a result they would cut their estimates of the growth in the nation's gross domestic product in the second quarter.
"The one-word summary is 'surprising,' from the standpoint of the deterioration in the deficit," said Michael P. Niemira, an economist at the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi in New York. He said he was cutting his estimate of second-quarter growth to about 3 1/2 percent from 4 percent.
Mr. Niemira said that if economic growth slowed, as is widely expected later this year, the growth in imports would also slow. But while many economists had predicted that the overall trade deficit would fall this year, Mr. Niemira said he now thought that it could increase by $15 billion to $20 billion, from $105.1 billion last year.
Other economists said the increase in the trade deficit could also help push down the value of the dollar.
Still, other analysts cautioned against reading too much into the month-to-month changes. And some said that what happened with the big picture would also reflect the outcome of the increasingly intriguing subplot involving China and Japan.
 Dr. Sherry Cooper, the chief economist at Nesbitt Burns, a Canadian investment firm, said it appeared that "a momentous shift in regional trade patterns is under way -- China is poised to replace Japan as the U.S.'s biggest bilateral deficit partner."
Mr. Kantor said America's trade deficit with Japan had seen "steady improvement" since June 1995 for a variety of reasons, ranging from currency exchange rates to new agreements to open Japan's markets.
Japanese auto makers have also moved more production to the United States, and exports of American autos to Japan surged in the first five months of this year, while imports from Japan dropped.
Indeed, the overall May trade figures show that most of a $966 million increase in the value of imported autos and auto parts was a result of purchases from manufacturers in Canada, Mexico and Germany rather than in Japan.
By contrast, America's trade deficit with China has been growing in recent months. The Administration has been battling to stop Chinese piracy of American music, movies and computer software and to increase American exports to China.
The figures released today also showed a sharp increase in America's trade deficit with Canada, which jumped 53 percent in May, to $2.55 billion, and a 1.7 percent increase in the deficit with Mexico, to $1.59 billion.
Purchases of crude oil from overseas added to the increase in imports in May, as they rose 6.5 percent, to $4.6 billion, the highest level since November 1990.
Commerce Department officials said that while they had long recorded imports and exports of goods like autos and oil on a monthly basis, before 1992 they tallied the trade in services only on a quarterly basis. That is why it was impossible to determine with certainty when the overall monthly deficit last hit the current level.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	Japan's Surplus Shrinks
TOKYO, July 18 (Reuters) -- Japan's trade surplus fell in June for the 19th consecutive month, shrinking 26 percent, the Finance Ministry said today.
But the decrease was smaller than expected, and analysts said they expected the rate of decline to continue to slow, partly because of the dollar's relative strength.
The surplus fell to 737.110 billion yen, or $6.8 billion, from 989.57 billion yen in June 1995. Exports rose 7.4 percent, to 3.665 trillion yen from 3.413 trillion yen, while imports grew by 21 percent, to 2.928 trillion yen from 2.424 trillion.
The trade surplus with the United States fell 18 percent -- the 16th consecutive monthly decline -- to 296.11 billion yen, or $2.7 billion, from 360.76 billion yen. Japan's exports to the United States totaled 988.10 billion yen, up 7.3 percent from 920.95 billion yen, and its imports from the United States were 691.99 billion yen, up 24 percent from 560.19 billion yen.

HEADLINE: Blood Ties

BYLINE: By Linda Hodges; Linda Hodges is a food and travel writer.

DATELINE: AMES, Iowa

 BODY:
If the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 had been law when my husband and I were ready to start our family, we could not have raised our son.
In 1969, we read an article in The New York Times about the need for permanent homes for American Indian children. We had a strong interest in Indian culture, so we specifically requested an Indian baby. 
 When we learned that the Arizona Department of Public Welfare had approved us for a 4-month-old Apache boy, we checked the circumstances. His mother was 22, unmarried, an alcoholic and had two older children. We didn't think to ask whether she had an extended family that could raise him.
The Indian Child Welfare Act all but ended adoptions like ours. Under the law, when an Indian mother relinquishes her child, "in the absence of good cause to the contrary," her extended family receives special preference for adoption, followed by other members of her tribe, then by other Indian groups. If her tribe opposed it, she couldn't relinquish her child to a white family.
State courts, however, have differed in their interpretation of "good cause to the contrary." There have been instances where placing a child in a Caucasian home has been in itself considered "good cause."
Congress is debating whether to weaken or to strengthen the Indian Child Welfare Act. In May, the House passed the Adoption Promotion and Stability Act, intended to make adoption more affordable and to ease all interracial adoptions. Indian rights groups opposed a provision of the bill that would have weakened the Indian Child Welfare Act: the amendment would have limited tribal jurisdiction to those Indian children whose biological parents had significant social, cultural or political ties to the tribe.
In the Senate, the Committee on Indian Affairs scrapped the provision. On Tuesday, Senator John McCain of Arizona introduced a substitute bill, supported by Indian tribes and adoption lawyers, that insures that tribes will be informed when any Indian child is placed for adoption though it limits the time they have to respond.
It may sound odd, but I'm happy that the Senate version is the one likely to prevail, because my son's recent reunion with his birth family convinces me that its approach is better.
Like many adopted children, Andrew wanted to learn about his origins. Last May, at age 26, he met his birth family for the first time. The photos he brought back from the reservation show a world far different from the quiet Midwestern university town where he was raised: brush-covered hills dotted with ancient saguaro cactus, modest homes whose front yards are filled with worn-out cars, women wearing traditional dresses preparing traditional foods.
Andrew learned that both his parents died years ago in alcohol-related incidents, but he found a brother, grandmother, great-grandmother and dozens of aunts, uncles and cousins. They gave him a welcome-home party and showered him with gifts. He felt comfortable with them. Only the language they usually spoke set him apart. He enrolled in the tribe, is thinking of moving to the reservation and wants to be buried in the cemetery where his birth parents rest.
He learned that his family never wanted his mother to sign him away. He was told that her decision to relinquish two of her three children for placement in non-Indian homes caused such a rift with her family that, while under the influence of alcohol, she took an overdose of sleeping pills and died. The family never stopped searching for the missing children.
Although Andrew grew up happy in our home, the positive change in my son once he touched his roots, and the ease into which he entered the lives of his large family, makes me think that the pull of the ingrained cultural memory is stronger than even the most loving adoptive bonds.
Before lawmakers encourage adoptions of Indian children by non-Indian families, before they remove tribal jurisdiction over child custody proceedings, before state courts interpret "good cause" as economic superiority, they need to acknowledge the strength of the biological and cultural ties that Indian tribes can offer their own children.

HEADLINE: Stocks Surge on Comments by Greenspan

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks racked up their biggest gains in four months yesterday as investors interpreted comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, to mean that an increase in interest rates was not imminent.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended up 87.30 points, or 1.62 percent, at 5,464.18 -- its largest one-day gain since March 18, when it shot up 99 points. In the broader market, advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by 1,872 to 651 on active volume of 474 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 "The perception now is that the Fed won't do anything immediately," said Eugene Peroni, chief technical analyst at Janney, Montgomery Scott. "The bond market got a nice shot in the arm and stocks rallied nicely."
The Nasdaq composite index rose by 23.17 points, or 2.13 percent, to 1,109.82 after closing up 33.18 points on Wednesday -- its biggest one-day rise ever.
While bond prices gained on Mr. Greenspan's comments that the Fed remained vigilant on inflation, stocks benefited from the perception that no rate increase was immediately around the corner.
Recent speculation had held that the central bank would raise interest rates as soon as August after a report early this month showed that unemployment had fallen in June to a six-year low and that hourly earnings had posted their biggest rise since record-keeping began 31 years ago.
Wall Street had expected Mr. Greenspan to tip his hand during his testimony before the Senate, believing that he would have to explain any move to Congress so soon before the national election in November.
In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan said that "even though the U.S. economy is using its productive resources intensively, inflation has remained quiescent."
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond jumped more than a full point, and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction to the price, fell to 6.92 percent from 7.02 percent on Wednesday.
Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany, said Wall Street was relieved that the Fed had "re-established itself as an inflation-fighter."
"I would expect July employment and price data will be important" to the Fed for a decision on rates, Mr. Johnson said, at the Aug. 20 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy.
He said that if no rise came in August, a tightening was unlikely before the election.
Technology stocks, and the overall market, had been rocked in recent sessions by dismal earnings reports or warnings of poor results from companies like Motorola, Hewlett-Packard and Texas Instruments.
But earnings from Intel on Tuesday and from Apple Computer late on Wednesday somewhat restored the shaken faith of technology investors.
Stocks of companies that are sensitive to interest rates jumped yesterday. Citicorp rose 3 1/8, to 81 7/8; Fannie Mae was up 2 1/2, to 33 1/4, and Chase Manhattan added 1 3/4, to 69 1/2.
AT&T, the most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange, fell 2 1/4, to 54 1/8, after it reported its earnings and made bearish comments about competitive pressures in the residential long-distance telephone business.
T.W.A. fell 1, to 10 1/4, after a Paris-bound jetliner exploded off Long Island, with all the passengers aboard presumed dead.
Thermedics rose 3, to 25 1/4. Gruntal & Company repeated a buy recommendation, saying the T.W.A. crash might pressure the Government to install at American airports a bomb detection system that Thermedics makes.
McDonald's rose 1 1/8, to 45 3/8, after reporting quarterly results that topped analysts' expectations.
Xybernaut, a maker of mobile computing systems, rose 12, to 17 1/2, in its first day of trading.
Merck & Company rose 1 5/8, to 64 3/8, on strong quarterly profits.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 9.49, to 643.56. The American Stock Exchange index was up 11.64, to 551.63.

HEADLINE: U.S. Presses Effort to Remove Indicted Bosnian Serb Leader

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Friday, July 19

 BODY:
Negotiations here that the Clinton Administration hopes will succeed in ousting Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb political leader, and thus pave the way for smooth elections in Bosnia and Herzegovina dragged on inconclusively into the early hours of thise morning.
At midnight Richard C. Holbrooke, the special United States envoy to the Balkans, who has shuttled to Belgrade, Sarajevo and Zagreb in the last few days, was uncharacteristically silent, saying through a spokesman that he would have no statement overnight. 
 About an hour later, an American official said that the talks were at a critical stage but that Mr. Holbrooke had nothing to report at the moment and hoped for a breakthrough by morning.
The outcome of the talks is regarded by the Administration as vital to the credibility of approaching national elections in Bosnia and to the continuation of the Dayton peace accords.
Mr. Holbrooke is threatening the President of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic, with another round of economic sanctions if he does not arrange for Dr. Karadzic's departure, Western diplomats said.
After an initial round on Wednesday, Mr. Holbrooke returned to Belgrade late Thursday to press Mr. Milosevic for, at the very least, the removal of Dr. Karadzic as chairman of the most powerful political party in Bosnia. He was also demanding, diplomats said, that Dr. Karadzic be forced to leave Bosnia.
Dr. Karadzic, along with the military leader of the Bosnian Serbs, Gen. Ratko Mladic, has been indicted by the international tribunal in The Hague on war crimes charges and is subject to arrest.
Under the Dayton peace agreement, which Mr. Holbrooke orchestrated last year, indicted war criminal are banned from holding public office.
Before coming to Belgrade from Sarajevo, Mr. Holbrooke said that if Dr. Karadzic retained his party post, the Serb Democratic Party, known as the S.D.S., would be banned from taking part.
"If Karadzic is not out of the leadership of the S.D.S., the S.D.S. is decertified," he said.
"If it is decertified, the election will go forward. It will be on the one hand a little more difficult to implement but on the other hand a cleaner election because an organization headed by an indicted war criminal is not running."
The start of campaigning was delayed by Western officials to allow time for Dr. Karadzic to be maneuvered out of the way.
But if Dr. Karadzic's party is kept out of the election, the legitimacy of the result will also be diminished in the eyes of the Serbs because the party is the most popular Bosnian Serb political group.
In the last two months, according to Slobodan Reljic, an editor of Nin magazine in Belgrade, support for Dr. Karadzic's nationalist party has increased from about 50 percent to more than 80 percent.
Mr. Reljic said that if Dr. Karadzic's party were prevented from taking part in the elections, the vote would be considered a farce by most Bosnian Serbs.
The talks today with Mr. Milosevic, held in his suburban residence, appeared to take a serious turn with the arrival of two of the Serbian President's key associates: the head of state security, Jovica Stanisic, and the vice president of the Serbian Socialist Party, Nikola Sainovic.
Mr. Stanisic, who is believed to control the Bosnian Serb elite special forces, has been a mediator in the past when Mr. Milosevic has been under pressure from the West regarding the Bosnian Serbs.
The Serbian security chief talked to Dr. Karadzic in Pale, the Bosnian Serbs' headquarters, on Wednesday, and according to Belgrade press reports, returned to Pale alone on Thursday evening. The reported return of Mr. Stanisic to talk to Dr. Karadzic again left the impression that he had the task of persuading Dr. Karadzic to step aside.
Also present at Mr. Milosevic's villa during the talks was a close colleague of Dr. Karadzic, Momcilo Krajisnik, the president of the Bosnian Serbs' parliament.
It appeared unlikely that Mr. Holbrooke would achieve his ultimate objective: removing Dr. Karadzic from Bosnia. By leaving Bosnia, Dr. Karadzic would become vulnerable to arrest under the international warrant issued this month by the Hague tribunal.
Western diplomats said this was an ideal solution for the West, but it was definitely not in Mr. Milosevic's best interests.
"He would sing like a bird," said a Western diplomat, referring to the likelihood of Dr. Karadzic building a defense by arguing that Mr. Milosevic was ultimately responsible for the war crimes.
As part of his talks, Mr. Holbrooke met with the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, in Zagreb on Wednesday night and, according to a Western diplomat, won from him a pledge that he would support reimposing sanctions against Serbia.
Dislodging Dr. Karadzic carries some potential risks for the NATO-led forces and United Nations police based in the Serbian part of Bosnia. In the third threat of its kind in the last week, the mayor of Uglijevik warned on Thursday that foreign soldiers and police would be captured, held hostage and killed if Dr. Karadzic were removed.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

AT&T Earnings Rise 10%, But Rivals Perform Better
AT&T, whose dominance in long-distance phone service is being chipped away, said its second-quarter earnings rose 10 percent, failing to perform as strongly as either of its two chief rivals or as well as several regional Bells. AT&T also said it expected to complete the spinoff of Lucent Technologies, its phone-equipment unit, in September.
Other telephone companies reported strong profits, with MCI Communications, SBC Communications and Bell Atlantic posting records. [Page D2.]
 
NCR reported a small operating profit in the quarter ended in June, its first since 1994. AT&T plans to spin off NCR, its troubled computer division. [D2.]
 
Georgia-Pacific Settles With U.S.
Georgia-Pacific agreed to spend at least $26 million on environmental improvements and pay a $6 million fine to settle a Federal enforcement case. The company will install advanced air pollution controls at 11 plywood and wood-composite plants in eight Southeastern states. Georgia-Pacific had tried to derail the case in Congress last year through a provision in a Senate bill sponsored by Bob Dole. [D4.]
 
T.W.A.'s Shaky Prospects
Even as Trans World Airlines faces a barrage of unsought publicity and an F.A.A. investigation following the crash of Flight 800, analysts say the company can survive a short-term downturn. But if the crash turns out to have been caused by lapses on T.W.A.'s part, all bets on recovery are off. [B8.]
 
A.D.M. Executive Will Not Testify
A top Archer Daniels Midland executive has asserted his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination rather than testify about his knowledge of an alleged price-fixing scheme involving the company. [D4.]
 
Sears Posts a Strong Quarter
Sears, Roebuck reported a strong second quarter performance, citing lower costs and robust sales. But earnings were down 51 percent from the 1995 period, which included gains from the spinoff of Allstate Insurance and the sale of Homart Development. [D4.]
 
Acquisition by Johnson Controls
Johnson Controls agreed to buy Prince Automotive for $1.35 billion in a deal to bolster its position as one of the world's largest suppliers of car and truck interiors. [D5.]
 
McDonnell Douglas Profit Up 11%
McDonnell Douglas earnings rose 11 percent, as profits from military aircraft operations more than offset losses from a strike. [D5.]
 
Sunbeam Names Turnaround Expert
Sunbeam hired Albert Dunlap, the former chief executive of Scott Paper who is known as an aggressive cost-cutter, to try to turn the appliance maker around. [D5.]
 
Stocks Rally Again; Dow Up 87
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 87.30 points, to 5,464.18, as recently battered stocks continued to rebound. Traders were heartened by remarks by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman. The Nasdaq composite index rose 23.17 points, to 1,109.82. [D8.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities also rallied, pushing the yield on the 30-year bond below 7 percent to 6.92 percent. [D15.]
 
A Joint Campaign by 3 Museums
Three New York museums are pooling resources to advertise their shows in Philadelphia, Boston and Baltimore. Newspaper advertisements will herald the Winslow Homer exhibition at the Metropolitan, the "Picasso and Portraiture" show at the Modern and the redesigned dinosaur halls at the Museum of Natural History. Advertising. [D7.]

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Mets in Shuffle for Wild-Card Spot

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
To use Joe McIlvaine's term, the Montreal Expos arrived at Shea Stadium last night in their second "bad and ugly" period of the season. The earlier period, in the latter half of May, sent the Expos plummeting out of the National League East lead; the current period has brought them back to the rest of the field in the N.L.'s fourth division.
The fourth division, which forms unofficially whenever anyone wants to start following the playoff prospects of teams distant from first place, is the wild-card division. Each league has one. 
 It is too early, of course, to start determining which teams are going to be the wild cards in this year's playoffs. On this date last season, the Houston Astros and the Texas Rangers had the best won-lost records among teams not in first place. Results of the 1995 playoffs do not mention those teams.
The Yankees, on the other hand, were playing so poorly that they were worse off in the wild-card standings (eighth, eight games behind the Rangers) than they were in the division standings (fourth, seven and a half games behind Boston). Yet the Yankees wound up as the American League's first wild-card team. The N.L. honor went to Colorado, which on this date held a five-game lead in the N.L. West, meaning it followed the reverse route of the Yankees to wild-card status.
Did anyone suspect, after the stumbling start they had, that the Mets could even think of the words "wild card" this season? Yet as they began a four-game series with Montreal, they were four and a half games behind the wild-card-leading Expos, and only three other teams -- Colorado, Los Angeles and Houston -- stood ahead of them.
The Chicago White Sox lead the A.L. wild-card division, followed by Seattle and Baltimore. Milwaukee and Oakland, both playing unexpectedly well, are next, half a game closer than the Yankees were a year ago.
The Mets stumbled in the series opener with Montreal, losing, 7-3, and slipping five and a half games behind the Expos. But that margin would not be impossible to surmount if they are as scrappy as their recent play indicates.
"We've felt all along we were a candidate to be involved in it," McIlvaine, the Mets' general manager, said. "People can say what they want, but I do think we're going to have a good second half. Whether that translates into it depends on how the rest of the teams do, whether anyone catches fire. I think we'll contend for it."
The Mets began the series only two games under .500 (46-48), the first time they were that close to the break-even level since May 4, when they had a 13-15 record.
"I think people lose perspective," McIlvaine said. "One-hundred-sixty-two games is a lot of games. You're going to have good, bad and ugly periods. You can't isolate yourself to one period. It's the totality of it. In the first half, we had a lot of bads and uglies. We had some goods, but we got rid of a lot of our bads and uglies."
Whither the Mets now in their Clint Eastwood season?
In the first half, McIlvaine said, the Mets were "a young club figuring out whether they're good enough to play in this league; now they're going ahead confidently."
The Expos are a young club, too. They spent the first seven weeks in first place, but 11 losses in a 13-game span plunged them from two and a half games ahead to five games behind the Braves. Now another skid, 9 losses in the 11 games before last night's victory, has tripled their deficit, from 3 games to 9.
This more recent "bad and ugly" period should prompt the Expos to check their rear-view mirror even more closely than the road ahead. And all of a sudden, the Mets loom potentially large in that mirror ("Objects in mirror are closer than they appear.")
"What are they, four, four and a half behind us?" Jim Beattie, the Expos' general manager, asked. "We have a four-game series with them so in their minds and for us too, it's a big series."
Big decisions are coming, too. With July 31 the deadline for trades without waivers, teams must decide if they are in the wild-card race or not. If they are, they will hold onto players they otherwise might consider trading to contenders, players with high salaries or pending free agency. If teams decide they realistically don't have a chance even for the wild-card spots, they will pursue trade possibilities.
When the owners shattered tradition and adopted the wild-card concept, they did it for economic reasons. Keep more teams in contention for post-season play, keep fans' interest in the waning weeks of the season and attract more people to the parks.
Although attendance was down consistently last season compared with 1993 -- the last previous season with no labor-dispute curtailment -- it was down less in September than in any other month. After decreases in the 20 percent range in each of the previous three months, attendance was off 15 percent in September. For the owners and players, then, it's never too early to start watching the wild cards.

HEADLINE: HOUSE APPROVES SHIFT ON WELFARE

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
The House today approved a bill that would reverse decades of social welfare policy, ending the Federal guarantee of cash assistance for poor children and instead giving states vast new authority to run their own welfare and work programs with lumps sums of Federal money.
The bill, which is very similar to one taken up today in the Senate, would make the biggest changes in welfare policy since the New Deal. 
 The Republican bill was approved 256 to 170, with members largely divided along party lines. A bipartisan alternative, championed today by Democrats and supported by President Clinton, was rejected, 258 to 168.
But even the bipartisan measure would have eliminated the welfare guarantee, or "entitlement," a sign of how far the welfare debate has shifted to the right since Republicans won control of Congress in 1994.
Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said that the bill passed today by the House was better than welfare legislation vetoed by Mr. Clinton in December and January.
"This bill is some improvement," Mr. McCurry said tonight. "It still is way short of what we need in order to be satisfied."
Mr. McCurry said he hoped the Senate would further improve the bill so Mr. Clinton could sign it. "The President remains optimistic that when it comes to welfare reform we're talking signature, not veto," he said.
House Republicans had revised their bill to address some of the President's concerns, but at the same time, they toughened the bill in other ways that make it less palatable to the President.
The bill would set a five-year limit on payment of welfare benefits to any family, and states could set shorter time limits. Adults on welfare would be required to work within two years, or else they would lose their benefits, a policy the President has endorsed.
The Democratic proposal rejected today would have allowed states to use Federal money for vouchers to provide goods and services to children after welfare was cut off. The alternative version would have saved somewhat less money than the Republican bill.
The Republican bill would save $60 billion over the next six years, while the bipartisan alternative would have saved $53 billion.
How to overhaul welfare has been a central issue in the Presidential campaign, and today's debate was full of election-year politics.
Republicans echoed Bob Dole's criticism of President Clinton as a duplicitous politician who vetoed two earlier welfare bills after promising in 1992 to "end welfare as we know it." For their part, Democrats denounced the Republican bill as an assault on poor people, legal immigrants and others with few resources to fight back. But overall the tone of the debate was softer today than last year, when one House Republican compared welfare recipients to alligators and another likened them to wolves.
The Senate is expected to pass its version of the welfare bill in the next few days. The White House has made no veto threats.
Mr. McCurry, said: "In recent days, we're not talking about veto, we're talking about signing. We're talking about finding ways to find things we can sign." But Mr. McCurry left plenty of wiggle room, saying, "The President cannot accept the unacceptable."
Republicans said they would win either way.
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House Republican leader, said: "In the end, the President is going to have to make a determination whether or not he's going to sign this bill and satisfy the American people while he alienates his left-wing political base, or if he's going to veto the bill in order to satisfy the left wing of the Democrat Party, and thereby alienate the American people. That's the choice."
Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, said, "It may be good politics, but it's bad for the children of our nation."
Campaigning today in Milwaukee, Mr. Dole said: "With today's action, it appears that President Clinton will have one last chance to keep his promise on welfare reform. I urge him to heed the counsel of leaders of both parties in Congress who have helped pass the legislation and sign it when it reaches his desk."
Nearly nine million children subsist on the monthly cash benefits they receive from the program known as Aid to Families With Dependent Children. Representative Robert T. Matsui, Democrat of California, said the Republicans were endangering these children so they could put the President in a political box.
"That's what this bill is all about: politics to hurt America's children," Mr. Matsui said.
In the final House vote on the welfare bill today, 226 Republicans and only 30 Democrats supported the legislation. Four Republicans joined 165 Democrats and 1 independent in voting against the bill.
The measure approved today was more moderate than the welfare bill passed in March 1995, when House Republicans were at the height of their power. The vote then was 234 to 199. Only nine Democrats voted for that bill.
Today, only nine Republicans voted for the bipartisan alternative, devised by Representatives John Tanner, Democrat of Tennessee, and Michael N. Castle, Republican of Delaware.
Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the Budget Committee, predicted that President Clinton would sign the bill, despite protests by liberal Democrats and many charitable and religious groups.
"The third time is always a charm," Mr. Kasich said. "The President has vetoed the bill twice. This is the third opportunity he'll have to sign it. I have a suspicion that he will sign it."
Mr. Kasich said the day's most significant development was that Democrats had themselves proposed ending welfare's status as an open-ended entitlement program, which automatically expands when the number of eligible families increases.
Republicans, he said, have caused a profound change in the nation's political landscape, even though they have not achieved all their legislative goals.
"You don't think for a second, do you, that if the Republicans had not taken control of the House of Representatives, we would have this kind of activity today?" Mr. Kasich asked. "Do you really think we would be ending welfare as an entitlement, establishing work requirements and sending power, money and influence back to the states?"
After the bill reached the House floor today, lawmakers toughened it by establishing strict new work requirements for people seeking food stamps. Able-bodied adults with no dependents could receive food stamps for no more than three months unless they were working at least 20 hours a week.
Democrats said that, under this provision, a person laid off after 10 continuous years of work would be ineligible for food stamps if he had received such benefits for three months in a prior recession.
Representative W. G. (Bill) Hefner, a North Carolina Democrat who has been in Congress for 22 years, said: "This is the most mean-spirited amendment I have ever seen on any bill. It's degrading."
But Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, spoke for most of his party when he said: "We have lost the war on poverty. With today's vote, we recognize that the Great Society's welfare programs have not helped people. They have destroyed people."
Representative Xavier Becerra, Democrat of California, said that legal immigrants were an easy target because "they can't vote and they can't hurt the people who attack them."
Representative Martin Frost, Democrat of Texas, said "the Republican welfare bill will push over one million children into poverty."
But Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, complained that the White House had ignored requests for an official estimate of the number of children who would be impoverished. Administration officials said the White House was reluctant to produce such estimates because the President might eventually want to sign the bill and the poverty data would provide ammunition to liberal Democrats arguing that he should veto it.
Mr. McCurry, the White House press secretary, said "the overall intangible values associated with welfare reform," including its emphasis on work, might partly offset the loss of income for people removed from the welfare rolls. But Mr. Moynihan said this was a fallacious argument because many people who would be impoverished by the loss of welfare were already working at low-wage jobs.
Representative Marge Roukema of New Jersey, one of the four Republicans who voted against the bill, said, "No children will go hungry and homeless on my watch if I can help it."
Solid Democratic opposition to the bill presumably makes a veto more likely. Representative Major R. Owens, Democrat of Brooklyn, spoke for most Democrats when he said: "Welfare reform is very much in order. But reform should not be driven by manufactured hysteria and scapegoating. It should not become the oppression and persecution of the poor."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "POINT BY POINT: Welfare Changes"
Following are the major provisions of the House Republican welfare bill. The Senate bill is similar.
 
* The Federal guarantee of cash assistance for poor children would end. Each state would get a lump sum of Federal money to run its own welfare and work programs.
 * The head of every family on welfare would be required to work within two years or the family would lose benefits.
 * Lifetime welfare benefits would be limited to five years. (States may set stricter time limits.) Twenty percent of families may be exempted because of hardship.
 * States could stop payments to unmarried teen-age parents. Payments may be made only if a mother under 18 stays in school and lives with an adult.
 * Federal policy would bar an increase in benefits to cover children born to women already on welfare. States could override this restriction.
 * States that reduce births to unmarried women would be rewarded with additional cash grants.
 * More than 700,000 of the 25.6 million people who now receive food stamps would be cut from the rolls because of new work requirements that apply to able-bodied adults 18 to 50 years old with no dependents.
 * Some states could receive their food stamp money as a block grant. They could then set their own eligibility and benefit levels.
 * About 300,000 disabled children from low-income families would lose cash benefits because of stricter eligibility standards in the Supplemental Security Income program.
 * Future legal immigrants would be ineligible for most Federal welfare benefits and social services during their first five years in the United States. Supplemental Security Income and food stamps would end for noncitizens now receiving benefits, and states could also cut off cash welfare for them.
 * About 500,000 legal immigrants who are not citizens would be cut from the Supplemental Security Income program. At least one million legal immigrants would lose eligibility for food stamps.
(Sources: House Ways and Means Committee, Congressional Budget Office)

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Bond Rating Remains High

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: NEW YORK

 BODY:
For the sixth year in a row, New Jersey's bonds have received an AA+ rating, the second-highest, from the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The state is a good risk because of its "demonstrated ability to balance its financial operations and maintain adequate balances in an environment of slowed economic growth," Standard & Poor's said Wednesday. Moody's Investors Service also gives New Jersey's bonds its second-highest rating, Aa1.
