HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Greenspan's Testimony Spurs a Rally

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rallied yesterday after the market interpreted comments from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, to mean that an increase in interest rates was not imminent.
Mr. Greenspan, in testimony before the Senate Banking Committee, warned that the central bank might have to raise rates to insure that the economy slows down to prevent inflation from accelerating. Yet he also said he expected that the economy would indeed moderate, and it was that view that market participants chose to focus on in trading yesterday. 
 "Greenspan can't be unhappy with the way the market reacted," said James Glassman, a senior economist at Chase Securities in New York. "The bond market's saying, 'We have a lot of confidence in you.' "
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 16/32 , to 8816/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell below the psychologically important level of 7 percent, to 6.92 percent, from 7.02 percent on Wednesday. The gains came as the Treasury auctioned $48.6 billion of new one-year bills. Rates on the bills fell to their lowest level in nearly two months.
Mr. Greenspan's remarks fostered optimism that inflation would stay low, and that if it did not, the Fed was prepared to take firm action to squelch it.
"He certainly tried to make the point that there's been no resurgence of inflation," said Steven Vielhaber, who oversees more than $20 billion of bonds at Bank of America in Los Angeles. "And though he said he's not seeing a problem there, he's also keeping an eye on the numbers."
Bond yields may not rise much as long as investors believe there's little need for the Fed to raise rates to combat inflation.
The inflation rate has remained below 3 percent for the last four years even as the economy expanded. Consumer prices rose 2.8 percent in the year ended in June, compared with last year's 2.5 percent rate, the lowest since 1986.
Faster growth this year had led some traders to conclude the Fed would have to raise rates to head off inflation.
Yesterday Mr. Greenspan suggested that "maybe he can tolerate above-the-speed-limit growth for some period of time, provided inflation is quiescent," said Ian MacKinnon, who oversees $78 billion at Vanguard Group, the nation's second-biggest mutual fund company, which is based in Valley Forge, Pa. "That's a change," he added.
Even so, many investors say bond yields can fall further so long as traders are convinced the Fed is prepared to raise rates if the need arises.
"The bond market likes it when the Fed is very concerned about inflation and going to be on top of it," Harvey Hirschhorn, a money manager at Stein, Roe & Farnham, a Chicago-based firm with $17 billion in bonds, said.
In the corporate bond market, Associates Corporation of North America, one of the most frequent borrowers in the corporate bond market, took advantage of yesterday's rally to sell $350 million of new bonds.
Associates, a unit of the Ford Motor Company, sold five-year notes that pay interest of 6.75 percent at a discount to yield 6.855 percent, or 35 basis points more than the Treasuries with comparable maturities. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
In the municipal market, state and local issuers sold about $1.25 billion in new securities, led by large offerings by New York City's water agency and Nevada's Clark County school district.
New York's water agency had to raise yields on the $580 million in revenue to help attract buyers. About half of the $335 million of the competitively sold Clark County bonds remained in underwriters' hands at the end of the day.
Lehman Brothers Inc. priced the securities as term bonds maturing in 2020 and 2026 to yield as much as 6.33 percent. For an investor in the 36 percent Federal tax bracket, the bonds offer equivalent yields of 9.89 percent. Yields on the securities were raised 2 basis points from their original offering levels.
The District of Columbia returned to the municipal market with a $220 million sale of 75-day notes.
"There is still a little supply out there holding the market back," said Paul Hylle, who manages about $1.6 billion in bonds for the American Express Financial Corporation in Minneapolis.

HEADLINE: THE PASSENGERS;
Disaster in Air Unites Widely Varied Lives

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:

Judith Connelly Delouvrier
Philanthropist
Judith Connelly Delouvrier, a philanthropist who was a trustee of her family's Philadelphia-based Connelly Foundation, died on Wednesday in the crash of a Trans World Airlines jetliner off Long Island. She was in her 40's and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. 
 A sister, Josephine Mandeville, said that Mrs. Delouvrier had taken the Paris-bound flight to rejoin her two children, Henry, 9, and Isabelle, 7, who were visiting French relatives near Fontainebleau, which is outside Paris.
Mrs. Delouvrier had flown back to New York for four days to monitor renovation work being done on her Manhattan house.
As a trustee of the Connelly Foundation, which was founded in 1955, Mrs. Delouvrier played a substantial role in decision-making about its grants, which are in the fields of education, human services, social services and the arts, mostly in the Philadelphia area.
For some years until 1980, Mrs. DeLouvrier, who had a master's degree in fine arts, was employed at Sotheby's in New York as an assistant to David Nash, who was the head of the Impressionist art department. She was also employed for a time at Revlon, in public relations, especially for the Marcella Borghese line of beauty products.
Her volunteer work over the years included serving on the board of directors of Common Sense, a program to encourage philanthropical leanings in children; serving on the advisory committee of an exchange program for French and American students; assisting with fund raising for the Union Settlement Association, an East Harlem social-service organization, and founding a program called Art Tours for Children. She also was a docent at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Mrs. Delouvrier was born in Jenkintown, Pa. Her father was John F. Connelly, who founded Connelly Container Corporation and became chairman of Crown Cork and Seal Company. He died in 1990.
After attending Melrose Academy in Elkins Park, Pa., Mrs. Delouvrier graduated from Rosemont College in Rosemont, Pa. She did graduate work at the Sorbonne in Paris and received her master's degree from George Washington University.
In 1984, she married Philippe Delouvrier, the son of Paul Delouvrier, a French economist who held administrative posts in Algeria and Paris under President Charles de Gaulle.
In addition to her husband, who is president of Eastern Industrial Minerals in Brunswick, Ga., her children and sister, Mrs. Mandeville of Villanova, Pa., Mrs. Delouvrier is survived by her mother, Josephine O'Neill Connelly of Bryn Mawr, Pa.; two other sisters, Emily Riley, also of Villanova, and Christine Connelly of Columbus, N.J., and two brothers, John and Thomas Connelly, both of Philadelphia.
 ERIC PACE

CORRECTION-DATE: July 20, 1996, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary yesterday about Judith Connelly Delouvrier, who died in the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800, misidentified a group on whose board she served. The group, which encourages philanthropic leanings in children, is Common Cents, not Common Sense.

HEADLINE: From Italy, a Model T for the 90's;
Fiat Joins Race to Build a Car With Worldwide Appeal

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: TURIN, Italy

 BODY:
When Fiat, with Latin frenzy, brought out its "world car" in Brazil in April, the big Italian auto maker called it the Palio, after the breakneck horse race that the Tuscan city of Siena has staged in its cobbled lanes since the Middle Ages.
It is an aptly named effort because the goal of designing a car that can be built and sold in pretty much the same form worldwide is fast becoming something of a steeplechase on wheels. And for Fiat, which has had trouble reaching out beyond Europe, the Palio represents its most ambitious marketing attempt to compete with its Japanese and American rivals. 
 It is also expensive and risky for Fiat, which has been driven to globalization by lackluster European markets. "The industry has gone planetary," said Roberto Testore, the 43-year-old engineer who recently became chief executive of Fiat's auto operations.
The reasons for this global push are clear. While the market for cars is growing slowly in industrialized regions like the United States and Western Europe, strong economic expansion in Latin America and East Asia is spawning armies of car buyers. By the year 2000, car sales outside the United States, Europe and Japan are expected to reach 20 million, about a third of the world total, against 16 percent today.
"There'll be 2 to 3 percent growth in the developed countries, but 7 to 10 percent growth rates in emerging markets," said Philippe Schwarz, director of research at DRI/McGraw Hill in London.
But the danger in trying for a one-size-fits-all car -- as some car makers have discovered -- is that different markets demand different cars. When incomes are low, cars must be cheap; when roads are bad, car design must adapt. And a trendy design in one culture might look either silly or clunky somewhere else.
There is also a danger that cars like the Palio, designed as world cars, will be shunned by prospective buyers who see them as third world cars.
"The world car is a mirage," said Daniel T. Jones, a professor of auto industry management at the Cardiff University business school in Wales.
Still, Fiat is making the leap, spending $2.65 billion to introduce the Palio. And it is far from alone. For decades Europe's auto makers have scrambled for bigger chunks of their congested market. But with the high cost of developing attractive new models translating into only modest gains, they are setting their sights abroad.
France's Peugeot, which sells only 12 percent of its cars outside Europe, wants to lift that to 25 percent by the end of the decade. In Germany, Volkswagen's new Golf, due out in 1998, will be designed around a platform adaptable for markets around the world. And Daimler-Benz, after building in Alabama its first full-scale car plant outside Germany, recently announced plans for a $460 million plant in Brazil to make a new small Mercedes.
America's car makers, meanwhile, are increasingly using Europe as a global launching pad. The Ford Motor Company, which in 1993 rolled out its latest attempt at a world car -- in Europe it's the Mondeo; in the United States it's the Ford Contour or Mercury Mystique -- has begun a program called Ford 2000 to develop similar models into global vehicles.
General Motors entrusted its European unit, grouped around its German Opel subsidiary, with leading its global production strategy. The little Corsa, introduced by Opel in the 1980's, has already asserted itself as a global car, selling in 70 countries. In some places it is called simply the Corsa, in Brazil it is the Chevrolet Corsa, and in Mexico it is sold simply under the name Chevy. Within 10 years, G.M. wants to sell half its cars outside the United States, up from about a third today, said Louis R. Hughes, president of G.M.'s international operations.
Europeans have been no slouches in going global in the past. The fabled Volkswagen Beetle, for example, was a world car of sorts a generation ago. Fiat has been making and selling cars in Brazil for more than 20 years, and for decades has taken cars like the boxy Fiat 124 and assembled them in underdeveloped areas like the old Soviet Union, where the 124 was called the Zhiguli. (Fiat sold cars in the United States with mixed success until it quit the market in 1984.)
A lot has changed since then. For one, the Japanese are successfully building cars in the United States and exporting them in growing numbers to other markets. Thus, European car makers like Fiat are increasingly being forced to respond first to defend their home turf and second to design cars with an eye to the needs of distant markets. And while they may once have thought only in terms of export strategies, they now see themselves being transformed into global production networks as a way to avoid costly duplication.
Indeed, Mr. Testore likes to compare the global operation Fiat is creating to a "virtual factory, with its seat in Turin," Fiat's headquarters.
Detroit has taken two basic approaches. When Ford introduced the Mondeo in 1993, the idea was to produce a car for all its markets worldwide. Though consumer surveys showed that its lines had to be made sleeker for American tastes, the car was essentially the same whether it came off Ford assembly lines in Genk, Belgium, or in Kansas City, Mo.
Still, the effort turned out to be extraordinarily expensive -- $6 billion -- and it has not been uniformly popular. While Genk has turned out 1.3 million cars, Kansas City has built only 500,000.
G.M., on the other hand,has made Opel its base camp for Europe, Latin America and the Asia-Pacific region, as a way to to separate the American market from the rest of the world. And rather than try for a true world car, G.M. reduced the number of basic platforms, then varied the versions it builds on them.
Under the Ford 2000 program, basically an organizational revamping, Ford is establishing centers dedicated solely to developing certain kinds of vehicles that Ford will sell worldwide. Its new center in Europe, for example, will develop Ford's small front-wheel-drive cars for sale not just in Europe and Asia but in America, too.
As for Chrysler, it lacks the global clout and strong overseas subsidiaries of its Detroit rivals, and its approach so far has been to take models that have sold well at home, like its mini-vans, and rejigger them for foreign markets.
Fiat chose a different path.
Instead of varying existing models for emerging markets, Fiat earmarked $2.65 billion to develop a fresh line of cars. The result is a basic model that can be varied as hatchback or sedan, pickup, station wagon or mini-van. The basic, no-frills Palio has a one-liter engine that Fiat hopes to be able to sell virtually anywhere for $8,000 to $9,000, but the car can be dressed up to meet more sophisticated tastes. Though it is clearly designed for markets outside Europe and the United States, Mr. Testore does not rule out selling some versions, like the pickup, in Europe in two to three years.
To cope with bad roads, the Palio was built higher and with a tougher suspension than European Fiats, and this in turn meant interiors had to be designed differently.
But Fiat also set out to design an entire production system in which components and vehicles could go back and forth among various markets. This, it hopes, will help overcome customs barriers and create revenue flows to ease exchange-rate worries.
Building on an already strong Latin American base, Fiat sank $1.6 billion into assembly plants in Brazil and Argentina. In the next few years, Palio production will be added in Turkey, Poland, Morocco, India and South Africa. In China and Vietnam, Fiat is negotiating manufacturing rights. By the year 2000, Mr. Testore estimates, Fiat will be adding roughly a million Palios a year to the 2.5 million other cars it now produces.
To assure high local content, Fiat has lured suppliers to the Latin American production sites. By exchanging components between the factories in Brazil and Argentina, Fiat hopes to gain exemptions from high tariffs.
What Fiat is saying, said Karl E. Ludvigsen, a former Ford executive who is now a consultant in London, is, "We have enough volume out there that we can afford to design and engineer for those markets."
"This might mean the Palio has a longer life cycle," he said. "In my view, it's a quite ingenious approach."
But other European car makers, including units of Ford and G.M., are not convinced.
G.M. executives in Europe have made clear their preference for a variable system of platforms. Peter H. Hanenberger, executive vice president of international operations, says that by mixing and matching components, "we can develop 10 or more vehicle variations, which are completely different in design, purpose and character."
Whichever approach prevails, experts say further risks lurk as virtually all car makers rush into the same markets.
Still, no one dares not join the race.
Alexander J. Trotman, Ford's chairman, recently told a gathering of European auto executives that some experts were calling the "intense, fast-paced, high-stakes battle that will result from these new market conditions hypercompetition."
"I call it a real dogfight," he said.

The company sold 4.9 million vehicles in the United States, 1.67 million in Western Europe and 1.76 million in the rest of the world.
